reviewText:
I'm 17 years old. I'm sitting in front of my Pentium II PC and I've just finished installing Baldur's Gate. I've crafted my perfect character, and I'm now adventuring through a gorgeous world. I've fallen headfirst into the game reading novels worth of text and not noticing as hours melt away.

It's 17 years later. I'm 34 years old. I'm doing it all over again and it's like I'm travelling through time.

Every aspect of this game is perfect. I wouldn't change it even if I could. I find myself wondering how in-game mechanics work and I'm tempted to alt+tab and google what spell is best. Instead I just keep playing and figure it out myself. I can't even *remember* the last time I didn't look up this sort of info in a game. Who cares if this sword does a little more damage than that spear? My character likes that spear and he looks awesome wielding it.

This is the first Kickstarter decision I've made that I am completely happy with. Thanks Obsidian for taking me back in time and reminding me that you don't need gamefaqs to enjoy a game.

reviewText:
I noticed that most people reviewing this game have previously played similar games. I don't have much experience with CRPG'S at all, thats why I thought my view of the game can give another perspective on things. That means I have not played games like Dungeons & Dragons, Baldurs Gate, Icewind Dale or Neverwinter Nights before playing this game.

Pillars of Eternity starts of with a character creation. The amount of options that you have here is absolutely crazy. You can probably spend hours here, changing every little detail. You pick your sex, race, class, attributes, culture, appearance and finally voice.

This game have many difficult settings and are obviously made for replayability. Pillars recommend that you start on easy difficulty, so I did. I most say that easy in this game isn't that simple!

Loadscreens while you rest are pretty and some other environments in the game, like dungeons and forests. I like the details on the characters, it's very sharp, even when you zoom in. The only complaint I have is that some backgrounds are a little blurry and low res, which looks a little bit silly when it's next to a very detailed character. I get that they went for an old-school look" but I still think that doesnt really match. But when you zoom out that won't really bother you.

I recommend that you crank the volume up for this title

reviewText:
Pillars of Eternity is an isometric party-based computer RPG using real-time-with-pause combat.

What is Great about this game:

- Complex and deep story that moves the game along incredibly well
- Deep character creation and multiple classes each with multiple viable playstyles bringing significant variety to your own playthrough
- Rich and appropriate back story, lore, and flavor text added throughout the game that is worth reading
- Enjoyable tactical combat with numerous options for pausing and other options to make the game more enjoyable
- Unique and sometimes fascinating quest lines with multiple alternative methods for success (e.g. talk yourself out of a combat encounter)
- An ending storyline that was possibly the most thought-provoking and intelligently written as any I have experienced

What is Good about this game:

- The game looks quite nice but could have used more art/animantions to improve it further
- The voice acting is quite good where it exists
- Good use of Steam features (cloud saves, trading cards, achievements, etc)

What is Bad about this game:

- The combat could have been significantly improved (although still very good) by including methods to automate companions similar to the systems in FFXII or Dragon Age: Origins
- Given how story heavy this game is, it would have been much improved by including more voice-over work.  The voice acting is very good, but is only available sparsely.  The writing is more than worth reading, but having it spoken would have been that much more engrossing.

Conclusion:

Pillars of Eternity is the current pinnacle of story-telling in RPGs with a great combat system and a classic style.

9.5 / 10.0

reviewText:
Pillars of EternityDeveloper: Obsidian Entertainment
Publisher: Paradox Interactive

Note: I will try to be as spoiler-free as possible.
Note #2: I don't think I can do this game justice, but I'll try anyway.

Introduction
==========
Quite possibly the best isometric CRPG to be released in recent years, Pillars of Eternity is an entirely new world expertly crafted and filled with lore created in the style of the classic Baldur's Gate and Icewind Dale games. Any fan of these games will instantly fall in love with Pillars of Eternity and it's similar design.

Gameplay
==========
Played from an isometric top-down view, Pillars is packed with things to do. You play the game entirely by mouse, pointing and clicking to navigate each area, converse with NPCs, battle enemies, and more. One of the best things about this game is that it is extremely detailed and immersive with it's superb storytelling. Pretty much exactly like the titles mentioned above. There is a literal TON of reading, as everything is presented to you in much the same way a dungeonmaster or storyteller in a tabletop game would. Every detail is spelled out for you, and you get to make you own choices in each dialogue. Most of these choices have a profound impact on the outcome of whatever quest you are on (people can and will die!), and even the main storyline.

You start out by creating a character from a huge list of options. There are a small handful of races, several classes, and you can even choose some regional differences for each race. You could easily spend and hour or more creating your first character. Along with your main" character

reviewText:
After over 100 hours I finally finished Pillars of Eternity and I think I'm ready to write this review.
Is this game good? It's more than good, it's great. It's not only one of the best RPGs of all times, it's also one of the best games I've ever played. It has great story, beautiful graphics, sound and music, deep mechanics and everything what good RPG game needs. But don't expect revolution, this is just step ahead in comparison to best classics like Baldur's Gate.
So what you may expect? Pillars of Eternity is pure old-school RPG in modern times. Engine is very classic, but modern in the same time. So you have 2D view, but with zoom. Combat is in real time with active pause. There is a lot of reading and dialogues. You will spend a lot of time to manage your party stats, skills and inventory. I played in hard difficulty and it was necessary to survive.
What about world and mechanics? There is new world and RPG mechanics made by Obsidian, but it has a lot in common with Dungeons and Dragons. It's heroic fantasy with many races (there are elves and dwarves too) and classes (like paladins, warriors and clerics), which combines elements we all know and love, with some new ideas, which is great. One word about spellcasters. I love the way how each magic class is different to each other, they use totally different spells and strategy, there are many fresh ideas here.
Also other thing is great. Best dialog system I've ever seen. Here you may feel your how your reputation and stats affects your dialog options.
But not everything is perfect. There are some things in that game, that would be improved, like your castle for example. This is clear that potential of this idea isn't fully exploited. Sometimes I felt like this part of the game was done in a rush.

VERDICT:
If you're an old-school RPG fan, this is must have for you. With this game you will feel the same magic as you felt playing Baldur's Gate.
If you're younger player, I'm not sure you will be so delighted as I am. I can recommend this game to everybody but I know there are many people which expect more intense RPGs in modern style. So if you like to read a lot and think what to do, try this game and find the ancient magic.

Like this review? Consider to join Good Games Giveaways & Reviews group and maybe press big sexy Follow this curator" button on our curation page to read more reviews and win free games."

reviewText:
Pillars of EternityNote: Each field is weighted differently, and thus affects the overall score differently.
Field  Rating  Review    Graphics  8.5  While the isometric envrionments are absolutely gorgeous, the character models leave something to be desired. Overall though, the world that has been crafted in Pillars of Eternity is absolutely beautiful, and calls you to explore every damp dungeon, and every overgrown ruin. Combat animations, especially spells, are extremely satisfying to watch, as each spell has very unique and detailed animations.    Gameplay  9  A revival of the classic Infinity Engine style of gameplay, Pillars of Eternity is true to its roots. With pausable real-time combat, a maximum of 6 characters to control (12, if you choose all rangers with pets...if that's your thing), and plenty of spells and playstyles to choose from, you are bound to find a playstyle that fits you and that you enjoy. Choose between 11 different classes, 6 different races, and several more sub-races, and customize your characters look to start crafting the story you want to experience. With wonderful voice acting, fanstastic story-telling, a vast world with tons of content, and even your own Stronghold to upgrade and maintain, Pillars of Eternity welcomes both old and new players to the genre with open arms.    Story  10  The world in which Pillars of Eternity takes place has been lovingly crafted, with hours upon hours of lore to sift through and explore. Usually in games, I quickly open and close the books you pick up, and skip through dialogue rather quickly, simply wanting to get to the point (looking at you Skyrim, Dragon Age, etc). However, in Pillars of Eternity, I have found myself spending hours reading all the books available that explain the world of Eora, and talking to every NPC I can find, following every branch of dialogue. I have come to actually care about my companions that tag along with me, and want to know more about them and their background. The wonderful voice acting (though sometimes strangely absent) only helps to further create depth in this incredibly imagined world.    Multiplayer  N/A  This game is all about the single-player. Enjoy it.    Replayability  3  The drawback of such story heavy games, is there isn't often a reason to go back and play them, other than to experience the game through a different class. However, since you are able to have 6 companions at a time in Pillars of Eternity, you can experience each character class through a single play-through. Really the only reason I find to go back for another round at the game is to make some different choices, try a harder difficulty, or achievement hunt.     Overall  9.1/10  I was, personally, not a fan of the Baldur's Gate series, much less any games like it. But Pillars of Eternity has enthralled me enough with its story that I have come to love it dearly, and it has opened the door to similar games for me. If you enjoy story-rich games, Pillars of Eternity is easily near the top of the list and is the game for you. If you want to lose yourself in another world for hours on end, Pillars of Eternity is the game for you. If you want to experience an epic journey in a living, thriving world that is beautifully crafted, Pillars of Eternity is the game for you. All in all, Pillars of Eternity is a game that every gamer should take the time to experience, even if only to remember how incredible a game with a good story is.
If you liked this review, feel free to check out my curator page:
The Tipster

You are also welcome to join our group and play/discuss games together, here:

The Tipster

reviewText:
Hi, just completed this on the hardest difficulty and going to write a few things.

Pillars of Eternity is a great spiritual successor to Baldur's Gate II.

Pillars of Eternity takes place in Eora, which quickly establishes its own identity as you discover that you can see and interact with souls. The game has a deep universe in which you must use cunning, diplomacy and brute force to stand a chance. With various different political factions you must muscle with, to views on religion this game covers quite a lot. The story offers a lot of options open to your own interpretation with many choices / choose your own adventure cut scenes forcing sometimes difficult choices on you; these choices factor into a disposition system with 10 different personality types which change based on your choices throughout the game, the personality your character has allow for additional role playing through out the game by affecting how npc's respond to you. There's a lot of well written dialogue and every situation and character I've encountered has been described in detail. Dialogue options are plentiful, with frequent skill and stat checks that do a great job of tying the RPG system into the conversations.

Both the classes of which there are 11 and mechanics are basically modernisations of the D&D archetypes and rules. With spells only being able to cast a certain amount of times in encounters and without resting to the abiltiy to conquer quests and scenes in a variety of different ways. Although the game does have several additions; you have an infinite inventory for junk, craftable food, potions, enchantments and scrolls giving various benefits. You also have Endurance which is basically your combat health, alongside your actual health which when reaches zero you die, and can only be regained by resting. You also get a stronghold fairly early in the game which with some investment offers various buildings which provide bonuses on resting there alongside NPCs and a recurring supply of gold (if well defended).

Pillars like various D&D rulesets has a lot of variety in character design which strays away from the MMO trinity, whilst you will have your frontline, damage dealer, support classes there is no weapon or armor type limits, which allows your characters to be more customisable. If you want a Wizard in heavy armour and a pistol go for it, everything will still have its advantages and disadvantages however with armour types still playing a huge role in your defence and recovery and weapon types having their various different niches, some causing different types of damage such as crushing and slicing. Levelling up allows your character to spend skills point alongside ability and perk points which ultimately improve your character, I felt like the characters progressed very well alongside the game and my characters never felt too powerful at any point whilst the improvement was still noticeable although I can't comment on how lower difficulties will be affected.

Playing this game on the hardest difficulty, I found the combat was extremely difficult right from the get-go. Combat in this game has a lot of tactics involved, the rules of engagement in this game are very important as a glass cannon character can not simply run and kite enemies as then enemies will get a free disengagement attack which usually results in that characters untimely demise, frontline tanky characters will always want to engage first as to grab enemy mobs attention as this game does not use a threat system people may be familiar with in MMOs such as WoW. These rules make positioning and entry into combat extremely important and have a lot of tactical value, if you run into a fight unprepared enemy mobs will destroy your squishy damage dealing classes and ultimately wreck your remaining party members. The game does have several tools to help you with this such as the ability to create custom formations in which your party will walk around in alongside a scouting ability for your more stealthy classes to scout ahead and into rooms. Due to how this works this means that the general pace of the game can be very slow with your more stealthy classes constantly scouting ahead so you can prepare for upcoming battles especially in higher difficulties, as if your not careful battles can be quickly decided against you.

The large variety of classes, races, backstories and cultures should offer plenty of replayability when combined with the vast amount of different choices you can cause every conversation to go.

The graphics are gorgeous with great painterly backgrounds and several improvements to the Infinite Engine of years ago such as dynamic water and great particle effects. The 3D character models mold into the backgrounds and scenes incredibly well and also have great animation quality. I was equally impressed by the audio quality, everything sounds fitting from simple footsteps to arrows striking their mark, I personally loved hearing casters chant they're various incantations. The soundtrack is something you would expect out of a fantasy game with nothing standing out but nothing dissapointing either and there are plenty of breaks from the music for ambience meaning that the music never became repetitive. The games interface is great, it's easy to use and pretty modern, visually being of a fantasy RPG style it avoids being clunky and hard to manage with the font being very easy to read and also adjustable in size in the options.


Overall, I think the game is great and I do recommend it but this doesn't mean that the game is faultless. The game has various bugs which stopped me from progressing in some quests by having certain npcs and objects key to advancing the quests be uninteractable although I did not encounter this in the main questline hence not stopping me from completing the main game it did affect a few side quests making me miss out on story, stunting character exp and rewards making the game slightly harder on my difficulty and reducing my overall experience. I had an issue where Steam Overlay would not work if I ran the game as Administrator. I also found some parts of the game to be lacking in variety towards the end of the game, I realised that there honestly isn't that many different types of enemies visually and your armour doesn't change your character much visually which is something I have come expect naturally from modern RPGs.


I feel I've potentially missed quite a lot out and this is the first proper review I have done so feel free to ask anything in the comments your unsure about if you are considering buying this game. :)

reviewText:
Obsidian set the mandate from Day 1 of the Kickstarter that the game would be a spiritual successor to the Infinity engine games (Baldur's Gate, Icewind Dale, Planescape: Torment).

In all ways, Pillars of Eternity is a successful evolution of exactly that.  Where Infinity games were all based on Dungeons & Dragons, a system designed for turn-based combat, Pillars of Eternity maintains that same depth and feel, however built from the ground up for real time with pause combat.

Pillars allows the player a choice of 11 character classes, each are a very unique experience much like the Dungeons & Dragons classes they're inspired by.  Unlike a lot of modern games that follow the MMO-inspired holy trinity design (tank, support and healer classes), Pillars, like early Dungeons & Dragons ruleset have a lot more variety in their class design.  Sure, when you go into combat, you will still have your frontline, damage, support and healing characters, but it is not quite as cut and dry.  Additionally, there is no weapon or armor type limits on your character because of your character class, so a character could be a wizard in heavy armor and a blunderbuss, whether that is a good idea or not is up for debate but it is possible.

One of the biggest improvements to me over Infinity series as well as most RPG designs is the engagement system.  In most games, if a glass cannon character gets engaged by an enemy, their initial thought is to run and kite the enemy until a frontline character can reestablish engagement with the enemy.  However, if you attempt to run and kite in Pillars, you will suffer an automatic disengagement attack.  This system forces the combat to have more tactical value than what you see in most games with enemies just being kited around.

Of course, that is a lot of talk about combat, Pillars also has very deep and reactive story telling through conversations and choose your own adventure style cut scenes.  In both, you will have a variety of choices based on your characters attributes and skills.  Additionally, in conversations, there is a disposition system which tracks your character in 10 different personality types such as cleverness, cruelty, honesty, and more.  These will allow for some additional role-playing through the game as you develop your character.

With an unnamed expansion already announced, Pillars should have a lot of run time and with the variety of character classes and choices in the story, a lot of replayability as well.

reviewText:
Pillars of Eternity is a RPG game developed by Obsidian Entertainment, releasing on Steam in March 2015. This game is a spiritual successor to the game series Baldur’s Gate and Icewind Dale. The game was kick-started in September 2012, with the highest ever funding at the time of over $4 million.

Game play in POE is very much like the other games in the series, the tactical combat with your party of adventures, and an overwhelming amount of choices in terms of stats, equipment, skill points and attacks.  The game play does get easier the further into the game you get, as you characters grow in strength and you just become more tactically aware of your surroundings and you will work out how to get the most out of all of your characters. The game is has a heavy amount of dialog, if you don’t like reading then this game is definitely not for you. The game starts off very slowly and for the first three or four hours, you will spend the majority of that time reading text and getting started with the story. Throughout all of the dialog choices, you also get plenty of important decision that can change the outcome of certain events as you progressively get further in the game, such as siding with different factions etc. Whilst the outcome of your choice is not always very clear, the game does a very good job of masking those decisions without you realising how important they actually are.

Right from the character creation screen, you will see how in-depth this game goes, there is an abundance of choice and options for you to make whilst creating your character. I was a little disappointed to see that I actually reached a level cap towards the end of act three, so almost half way through the game, I couldn’t progress my character any more. This in turn made the rest of the game seem somewhat imbalanced as I was able to just waltz through the enemies without batting an eyelid.

POE whilst it doesn’t have super amazing graphics, the environment and locations that you find yourself in still look gorgeous. The way the world is presented makes you want to explore it inch by inch. The UI is the most important part of this game graphically; it is smooth and functions perfectly. You are able to find all the information you need within a click or two – believe me, there is a lot of information in this game you are going to need!

This game is basically a novel inside of a game. The story is often criticized by some people, but I for one was completely intrigued and loved following it right from the start. The story is deep and moving, with plenty of cliff hangers, twists and turns as you progress.  On top of the main story line, you can follow plenty of optional side quests which add so much more immersion to the world you are in, it allows for extra character development and more choices. I actually really cared so much about my characters at the end due to what they have gone through, I spent more time than I would like to admit pondering over dialog choices. Like I said above, there is a lot of text in this game, whilst a good portion is voice acted, another good portion is not. So you better be prepared for some reading. Normally I much prefer my games to be completely voice acted; it helps me get more immersed in the story and I am probably a bit lazy, but I was completely happy to read everything this game had to offer. I honestly thought I was reading a book at times.

When you begin the game, the difficulty level is fairly challenging. You have to really think about your adventures’ next actions and movement, but as with most games, as you become more familiar with how the mechanics actually work, you become more and more Intune with it, allowing you to breeze through the game at points. The end boss is somewhat of a challenge, which required me to retry a couple of times. Once you get a few bits of high quality equipment, and your characters become over levelled due to the amount of experience awards in the game, you won’t find any point to be impossible to conquer though.

I finished my play through of POE in just under 60 hours (not sure why Steam says I only have 45?); this was doing the majority of side quests and exploring the world quit sufficiently whilst also taking the time to enjoy the dialog in the game too. I have seen some people put well over 100 hours into this game, and I suspect that is because of the game’s high replay ability factor.  One of the main elements which makes the game replay able, would have to be the in-depth character creation, you can create a brand new character that plays completely different to your last one, making your gameplay experience different too. Personally I don’t think I would do a second play through of the game because I feel I have got all I can out of the game right now, but those that really want to drill down this game for every inch, there is definitely a high amount of replay ability on offer.

The game runs like a dream too; I was able to play on 4k resolutions with the graphics turned right up. At times I did attempt to use the Steam controller, but the mouse and keyboard is the much prefer method for this type of game. The game did release with a few bugs and glitches, but after the first patch, these have all been cleaned up so I was able to play without any problems.

Pillars of Eternity is any classic RPG fan’s dream. If enjoyed Baldur’s gate, or want a completely immersive in depth role playing experience, then you need to be picking this game up. Steam’s price of £34, 99 to me seems a bit excessive, but you can pick this game up for almost half that on external websites if you shop around.  For me this is a stunningly good game, that I would consider a must play.

Tom's Score Card
1) Stay away
2) Not Recommended
3) Only recommended when on sale
4) Recommended
5) Highly recommended
6) This is a must play

If you found this review helpful, please consider giving it a thumbs up. You can also find more reviews over at http://www.completingthebackloggroup.com/

Please also check out Completing the Backlog's Curator page here - follow for regular updates on reviews for other games!

reviewText:
Pillars of Eternity is incredibly in-depth and one of the closest experiences to Dungeons & Dragons I've had in a video game. The storyline is definitely one of the more interesting ones, with an incredible amount of lore to explore and each character you meet has a background just waiting to be heard. The environments are gorgeous. And the combat is deep & challenging and a real plus for fans of Balder's Gate and Dragon Age.

I would highly recommend checking it out. Especially for fans of the old Infinity Engine games and cRPGs. It's fun!

reviewText:
Pillars of Eternity is maybe a hard approach for people who never played Baldurs Gate, Icewind Dale (or any other Infinity-Engine Game), as Diablo 3, Dragon Age and other Action-Roleplaying-Games are out these days. But if you have played e.g. Baldurs Gate (and so on...) it's like a warm welcome home.

All characteristics of good and old fashioned roleplaying are fully included in Pillars of Eternity. On top of that comes a wonderfully detailed painted world, a great and lovely written Story along with very fine dialogues and character interaction.

I highly recommend it to every fan of Infinity Engine Games, as well as to everybody who is looking for a challenge along roleplaying and to those who are not thrown back by slightly outdated graphical styles and the absence of a Coop- or Multiplayermode.

To be honest, there are not that many overly outstanding features - I like the Keep Building and the way of character development very much, the fights are nice and tactical challenging sometimes (!). There are also some nice hints and referers to other games and stories. All I expected from PE was a solid RPG in the Style of Baldurs Gate - and yes, that's what I got.

With that I want to adress the pricing, which seems to be a problem for many people out there at the moment. Judging about the worth of a game is pretty subjective, of course. But I'll try to approach it from an almost neutral point of view; in Germany it's at 41,99€ at the moment what makes it a fullpriced title. Does it contain playtime and replayabilty worth that price? Yes! But does it contain a mindblowing new experience to RPGamers? No! If you're looking for new and innovative games, better search elsewhere. This is an all-classic experience, polished to glow these days, but not to brightly shine.
So the price may be a bit to high at the moment. People who either don't really care or are into the genre anyways should buy it. Those who just want to test and give it a quick look better shouldn't at the moment, instead they better wait for a steam sale or online-distributor deal.

The point and the grounding of this choice is; Are you aware of what you get? Get informed - The Internet offers so many ways these days.

Personally I have a great load of fun with it. And when I play I find myself spending almost 4+ hours a session afterwards, which is a mark for a good game to me.

Thanks for reading!

reviewText:
Full disclosure: review copy provided by developer/publisher!

Gorglax the Destroyer, an orlan aristocratic ranger, was far from home. Hell, she was far from civilization. The nearest town was a day's walk, and she needed medical attention. Ever since that storm she hadn't felt herself. She stared for a while at the clearing ahead, a quiet meadow painted purple by wildflowers in bloom. Birds chirped, flitted and fluttered. Bugs droned, bumbled and buzzed. A symphony orchestra was blasting all around her, which was more than a little jarring. Finally she was jerked from her daze by her antelope companion, Gary. “We have to get to Gilded Vale,” she said, breaking the silence. “MRRABLURGHHBLURGH,” agreed Gary the antelope (that is an approximate onomatopoeia of antelope noises).

They set off to find the road when two young wolves, truants probably, attacked. Gorglax raised her arbalest, wound it, and loosed a bolt into one wolf. It whined and bled out on the soft blanket of wildflowers as the other closed in, bearing its canines. Gorglax was done for, she couldn't wind her arbalest fast enough. She shut her eyes and had all but accepted her fate when Gary the ♥♥♥♥ing antelope butted the beast, causing it to explode in a gory geyser. After acknowledging how metal that just was, the pair continued on their adventure.

I liken video games to baking. Yes, the recipes are frequently rigid and mostly unforgiving of experimental deviation (one such deviation I made while baking resulted in what I've coined as “bread soup”); but even the most structured recipe allots for the 'dash,' the mysterious magic that often defines the finished product.

“Oh, this is simply DELICIOUS. What did you put in this?”

“Oh, this old thing? It's pretty standard: egg, milk, flour... and just a dash of magic.”

“MAGIC ISN'T AN INGREDIENT, TED.”

And yet that douchey non-response best describes what makes Pillars of Eternity so excellent:  it's an original CRPG with the combined minds, bodies, and souls of its classic predecessors. It is, perhaps, greater than the sum of its parts.

So for the mildly spoiler sensitive crowd, let's revisit at the last paragraph. Everyone else keep your hands and feet inside the review at all times.

Pillars of Eternity has you, the hero, traveling the land of Dyrwood, a mystical realm filled with beings, creatures, ruins, and adra – a sort of organic rock jutting from the earth like jade claws from the depths. You are (shockingly!) the chosen one of sorts, a Watcher – beings capable of seeing the previous lives of the inhabitants of Dyrwood, speaking to the dead. Most that claim to be Watchers are hucksters, charlatans, and the rest are often driven positively batty by all of the intrusive soul fragmented former lives (theirs included).

There's mystery, intrigue, ancient civilizations and arcane magics, unique party members to drag along... pretty standard RPG fare. There are troubled hamlets, a large city, a ruined fortress, and natural wonders to gawk at, all lovingly prerendered. The world and those settled there feel alive, and for the first time in a while I felt compelled to listen to every bit of dialogue, read every bit of codex, flavor text, all just to familiarize myself with this fascinating new world.

Of course you'll have to do some killing, it is an RPG after all. And you'll kill 'em all: wolves, giant spiders, lizard men, ghosts, bandits, trolls, wizards, spooky skeletons, mushroom men and dragons... Pillars of Eternity doesn't exactly break the mold when it comes to mythical beasties and foes, but the combat does. When an enemy is spotted your party will pause and you'll be able to select a general attack or take the time to individually select special actions for each party member.

When you do engage you'll see their various defenses, strengths, and weaknesses of your foe – dependent on factors like weapon type, flanking, status effects, etc. It's thoroughly tactical and engaging, and even on lower difficulty settings I watched my entire party succumb to one or two enemies because I just tossed them into the fray all willy nilly. After dispatching enemies your bestiary will be updated with pertinent information. There's also often sweet, sweet corpse loot; loot can be equipped, used for crafting, or sold to vendors.

I'll also touch briefly on the travel/sleepy time mechanics. See, the Eastern Reach is pretty expansive, and you'll be hoofing it from the get go. Day and night cycles, and characters will become fatigued from travel (not to mention bogged down by negative status effects after lots of fights). You have one of two options: camping out “in it” while adventuring, or shacking up at a number of permanent locations. Camping should only be used as is necessary, since you only have so many supplies to set up camp with, and some of the longer adventures will require your party to get that much needed refreshing between combat.

The minor-est of complaints! Here they come, ready yourselves. Because the world is prerendered and mostly static, fights will sometimes break out behind solid objects, which is a little frustrating (if you zoom in on a solid object obscuring a character it will become semi-translucent, but it's still a pain). And when you have a full party attacking enemies the notifications fly by in a flurry of text, which can make optimizing attacks difficult on the fly. Other than these quibbles the game is great. I've encountered no bugs, no glitches, and it's just overall a delight to play. Anyone familiar with classic BioWare fare and CRPGs will find themselves very much at home.

Pillars of Eternity is, simply put, really really good. The scope of it is dizzying, your first hour ingame may very well be in the character creation menu (but in a good way!), the combat is deeply satisfying, the score is GoT/LotR/Souls Series/Elder Scrolls Series all wrapped up in one, and  the story is thoroughly captivating. I haven't completed this game (it looks like the first of many playthroughs may well take 60+ hours), but short of it ending with an about-face “it was all a dream” or an elaborate song and dance number my sentiment will remain unmoved: Pillars of Eternity is a spectacular game, proof that old-school done right is timeless... it certainly helps that I'm playing as a dwarf/elf with a wisecracking antelope sidekick that explodes wolves.

That's always a plus.

reviewText:
Pillars of Eternity is an isometric CRPG from the studio that brought us Fallout: New Vegas and South Park: The Stick of Truth. One night you are travelling with a caravan through an area north of the Gilded Vale. The caravan stops for everyone to rest and you go out to get water for the group, you return to find a group of mercenaries who have killed all but one member of the caravan, a strange phenomenon occurs and you are forced to flee through a cave. When you reach the other side you find a strange ritual taking place and when it is complete, something about you is different. In Pillars of Eternity you must venture through Eora to find out what this change is and how you can reverse it.

PoE is set in the fictional realm of Eora. Eora is full of different factions and races and as you play the game you will discover how they link to each other and why as well as discovering the rest of Eora's deep and incredibly well thought out lore.

A couple of things to note before you carry on reading my review. Firstly I have not finished this game at the time of writing my review, I'd say I'm about a fifth of the way in but I feel like I've experienced enough of it to write a detailed review. Secondly this is the first time I have properly played a CRPG and so I'm inexperienced with this type of game so some of my opinions may differ from CRPG veterans.

The Game Itself
+Great graphics and well designed emvironments though the character models aren't the best
+A reasonably detailed character creator with a number of different races, classes and backgrounds to choose from
+An interesting main plot as well as some interesting side quests
+There's a hell of a lot to do, as mentioned previously at 16 hours playtime I'm only around a fifth of the way through all of the content on offer
+Due to the game's reputation system and side quests with different possible endings you can create your own story when playing PoE even though the outcome is the same
+Fantastic writing, in particular the interaction of different characters who feel real due to how good the writing is, e.g. how they respond to what is being said
+Some great voice acting
+As mentioned before Eora has very deep lore and finding out about it over the course of the game and through the Digital Collector's book is fascinating
+The combat is simple yet rewarding and you really have to think about who should attack who and with what so that you are successful, especially when fighting large groups
+Eight different companions to find and team up with over the course of the game, each of a different class with unique abilities to help you in a fight
+All eight companions have interesting backstories and all have a reason for being where you found them which is good to see
+Relatively early in the game you get possesion of a rundown stronghold and you can restore it to its former glory, I absolutely love that kind of thing in games so I thoroughly enjoyed building it back up
+The different locations in the game are rather large and each one either has or is linked to a fair few sidequest though the map looks a bit empty as there aren't too many different locations
+Outstanding soundtrack and great sound effects throughout
+The game's difficulty can be changed throughout
+Big heads mode, thanks Josh!

-Voice acting is used sporadically, the main characters all have their own voice actors yet most of their dialogue is unvoiced and you have to read it, I felt that it often broke the flow of dialogue as one section would be voiced and the next wouldn't be with seemingly no method behind it
-As mentioned previously the character models don't look great
-Frequent loading screens which take a long time
-There's a Kickstarter backer only achievement so unless you backed it you can't get 100%

Special Edition Content
This covers the Royal Edition of the game, the first five are also available in the Champion edition. I will cover them in the order that they appear on the store page.

+The OST is, as mentioned, fantastic
+/-The Campaign Almanac is interesting but the font is difficult to read
+The Digital Game Map is very nice and has a good amount of detail though it has a bit of a strange resolution
+/-The Making Of Documentary isn't available yet
-The Wallpapers are all very nice but they all have strange resolutions and aren't available in 1920x1080
-The ringtones are nice little sound clips but I don't think you'd want them set as your phone's ringtone, most of them are soundclips of a character speaking
+/-The Digital Novella isn't available yet
+The Digital Collector's Book is very good and goes into great detail when explaining the game's lore
+The Concept art is absolutely fantastic and very high quality, I thoroughly enjoyed looking through it
+The Digital Strategy guide is very helpful and well written

Verdict:
9.5

A truly outstanding isometric CRPG with great graphics, an extremely well-written story, good combat and rich lore to back it all up. If you're a fan of CRPGs you've done yourself a disservice by not picking this game up sooner.

***This review was written using a key provided by the Publisher for review purposes***

El K.

reviewText: Yes it's early.  But whoa...    This game should be up for literary awards.  Only the written word can so easily, and completely, convey meaningful emotion and nuance.  Perfected along with the vibrant backgrounds, subtle yet solid soundtrack, and actually legible at high resolution text (adjustable font size in menu), this game will hold to be the test amongst all story based rpgs.  What little I have played of the combat engine has been intuitive.  Infinity engine perfected.  This game plays like a MUCH better written Baldur's Gate, except buttery as well, ...butter!   The extremely competent game mechanics hide away nicely, so that the immersion in environment and story stands unbroken for hours.  There have already been some large mood shifts and some mouth open gasps within the first 2 hours of gameplay.  I admit that I am already a huge fan of Obsidian, but it is with great reason.  I do not game for victory.  I do not game for competition.  I game to be entertained.  A 50-100 hour interactive book or movie is an immesurably better option than scrolling endlessly thru Facebook, or watching reality" advervision.\n\nMr Sawyer

reviewText:
What a fantastic game, I have been completely blown away so far. After playing Divinity Original Sin last year, I didn't think it could get any better but this gem has proven me wrong. The story and writing is absolutely incredible, the lore is very rich, and best of all the game is HARD. In just my 7 hours of playing so far, I have had to redo many fights, planning out new strategies, trying out new spells and weapons, all in the goal of bashing those pesky monsters to bits. Did I mention the bits, or rather giblets? Yeah, many times when an enemy is crittically injured by a blow and dies, he will explode in a shower of blood and fleshly bits, and it's always a fun sight.

In the graphics department, this is a very debatable topic, but I think these lovely hand drawn backgrounds surpass many modern games in their simplistic beauty. Music and sound is also very well done, and I've taken a special interest in the great way ranged weapons sound and feel in this game.

The two companions that I have come across my travels so far have been very well written, and their backstories very diverse. My only complaint on their regard is that at the moment the game has no rogue, barbarian or monk companions, so you will most likely end up filling those roles with custom adventurers or your own player character, but that is a minor gripe.

In regards to equipment, scrolls, potions and a plethora of other goodies, this game has them in spades. Hundreds of common and magical weapons and armor are just waiting to be discovered, many of them very unique in both name and appearance. Thankfully, the game has a stash mechanic to store your massive hoard of items, so you can gather to your heart's content.

All in all, I couldn't be happier with my purchase. The one very minor bug I've ran across so far was restricted to the tutorial popups and a very odd sound loop, but disabling those easily rectified the issue so in no way does it hamper the game for me. If you are one of the many avid baldurs gate, icewind dale, or neverwinter nights fans that yearn to revist the glory days of old, look no farther because Pillars of Eternity is the perfect choice for you.

So I just finished the game... [Review]

Well, at 46 hours, that was one, long and fun ride.  I haven't felt so involved in a roleplaying game since Planescape : Tormet and it speaks volumes of the writing here.  There were a couple bugs and I'll get to them in an instant but the major ones were swiftly corrected, leaving some minor ones with very little impact in game.

First, let's start with the obvious.  This game was obviously developped by gamers who know what they like in a game.  Everything about the interface screams convenience.  At first I was surprised to only find sixteen equipment slots in the inventory, until I noticed a well organised, infinite stash" box. reviewText: Baldur's Gate was the ultimate videogame for me when I was a kid, but I've always had trouble convincing my friends to like it. The same is true now for Pillars of Eternity. The quality of the game is superlative, it's just an inaccessable format to some people.  I think this is probably the game for you if you can enjoy a fantasy novel or have ever read up on the lore of a videogame outside of the game.\n\nThe thing this type of game does best is world building. The characters you meet have weight, everything matters, and the universe feels unique. It's not a cheap knockoff fantasy world where they just switch around the names of familiar tropes. There's a holistic personality to the world you're in and you just want to get to know it. And the best part is that getting to know the world doesn't mean reading through the codexes in a menu somewhere. The game teases bits of lore and it's up to you to find out more. You learn about a war and you have to meet a veteran to find out what happened. You find the name of a god and you seek out a priest to learn their beliefs. You'll hear someone tell a myth and you'll actually seek out the book in game so you can get the full story. And even then, no one source is definitive, so you're delighted if you ever stumble upon a new tidbit.

reviewText:
It's finally out. Jesus, just when I was getting my life on track...

Pillars of Eternity is, hands-down, the best game in its genre since Baldur's Gate II.

So, yeah. Anyone who ever played any Infinity RPGs for fifty hours straight knows what I'm talking about. Huge, isometric, story-driven games which emphasized immersion in worlds where your choices mattered, your mistakes were painful and the story was engaging. Sure, you had to read giant blocks of text and fight uphill battles that you could lose at the roll of a die, but both of these activities were immensely rewarding in themselves, because the writing was top-notch and the tactics you had to employ against your enemies had to be both creative and abide by Gygax's Tome of Neverending Rules to succeed. This was obviously before they slapped the RPG label to streamlined generic space operas or sandbox Bethesda countryside crawlers with bad writing and worse design.

Pillars of Eternity takes place in Eora, which might seem as a garden variety fantasy world at first, but quickly establishes its own identity as you discover that souls can be seen and interacted with and are considerably more palpable than the metaphysical malarkey you normally use to pick up drunk hippy chicks at pretentious parties. Add the political intrigue of separatist colonies and the invention of gunpowder into the mix and you get a uniquely deep universe in which you will have to use cunning, diplomacy and brute force in equal measure to stand a chance.

While both the classes and mechanics are basically modernisations of the D&D archetypes and rulesets, enough has been built on top of them to improve the overall experience: you have an infinite inventory for junk, craftable food, potions and enchantments provide secondary activities that enrich your arsenal and there's a really clever compromise between streamlined gameplay and the typical Dungeons and Dragons downtime which separates your encounter health pool (called Endurance) from the general health pool (which you can only regenerate by resting). The cherry on top is the stronghold you get to conquer and own fairly early in the game, and investing into its various buildings not only beautifies the initially decrepit keep, but also provides bonuses, NPCs and a recurring supply of gold.

The graphics are gorgeous, giving a painterly feel to the backgrounds and overcoming the technical limitations the Infinity engine had 17 years ago (dynamic water, convincing particle effects and modern resolutions being just the obligatory minimums), while retaining the general feeling gamers had exploring Faerûn. Even the classes and spells are pretty much the same, with occasional renames (presumably to avoid copyright infringement), though their efficiency has been tampered with and itemization is much less restrictive than it used to be.

If what you read appeals to you, then, by all means, buy this game. It's worth every penny and you'll get your money's worth in gametime, guaranteed. If you're like me, which is to say an absolute loser with no future and zero qualifications, you'll probably have the time to run through it within a week, but if you spread your doses responsably enough you'll probably be playing this a few months from now. Regardless of how immersive and brilliant this game will seem three hours in, don't forget to walk your dog, hang out with your friends and bang your girlfriend 'til she smiles.

I cannot reccomend this game enough for anyone who even moderately enjoys roleplaying games, tactical combat, or anything with a good story.\n\n10/10. We can all hope that we get a steady dose of expansions and sequels.

reviewText:
A game that old school RPG players waited for a long time. A true isometric RPG in Baldur's Gate style. Fantastic gameplay where tactical combat is more important than fast clicking. For example, the old/new stats system really make you question and forces you to think seriously when it comes to choosing your weapon or armour that grants specific attribute bonuses, or, for that matter, when you are creating you character.

The endurance - health system is also one of the factors you must consider when you enter a battle, because, when you lose all the endurance in the battle you get knocked out. When the battle is over you regain your senses, but you lose health. The only way to regain your health is by sleeping in the Inn, using the camping supplies, and, of course, keeping an eye out on the endurance levels all together, because, when your character health is depleted, he/she will die.

There are so many things you can do in the game and you can easily be side-tracked, but, as it happens, the main story doesn't get lost in the mix. It only expands, whether it is by adding the content and backstory to your companions, or by upgrading your stronghold and solving quests inside it.

All in all, it is a great kickstarted game for the die hard and greenhorn RPGers alike.

reviewText:
Alright, this is going to be a bit more in depth. So if you're interested in the mechanics featured in Pillars of Eternity, this might be for you.

Character Attributes and StatsAttributes as you might know them, have been repurposed, and some of their effects put into their own sub categories. Every main Attribute has it's base purpose now. Like Intelligence for example affects the size of the AoE and how long spells/buffs/skills last, and Might affects the strength of physical attacks, spells and also healing.

The reason for this change is to throw away the old min/maxing of stats in favor of viability and sandbox character creation. Other effects that are usually tied to these attributes or classes have their own categories now, which can be adjusted through equipment or during a lvl up. One example of this is Lore. Where Intelligence is used in other games to determine what scrolls you can read, Lore takes it's place in PoE.

Even though this might sound intimidating or confusing at first, it honestly isn't. Not only is it easier to understand than the old" way
date: where the same attributes affect different classes in different ways
recommended: but it also prevents hitting a wall in late game because you chose the wrong attributes for your class in the beginning. In PoE this problem is (almost) nonexistant because the system is made so your character will still be viable. Maybe not the way you planned it originally
hoursPlayed: but still viable. Even messing up deliberately is very hard to do. The basic idea is: create your character the way you want it. And the tooltips explain very clearly what each stat does and how it affects your character
voteText: making it very easy to build the one you want to play.\n\nCombat systemCombat in PoE is real time with the option to pause it anytime you want. And you definitely want to pause
helpfulPercent: because the combat is generally pretty fast in this game. Most fights against regular mobs are over after the first couple of seconds if you have a strong opening(The Cipher's 'Mind Blades' followed up by crippling melee skills for example.) I've played two characters on normal and hard so far
votesHelpful: and most basic encounters are relatively easy when using the right strategy. But a strong opening
votesTotal: combined with tactical positioning is the key to handle most encounters quickly. This game rewards the thinking person
votesFunny: and the combat is no exception.\n\nThe combat system is quite deep and has a lot of room for tactical adjustments. I'll just cover the basics here. As you might suspect
commentsCount: dice play a large role in combat. If you hit your enemy or not
column16: is determined by a D100. 1-50 is a grazed hit and 50-100 a regular hit. -0 is a miss
column17: and +100 a critical hit. Grazed hits do -50% DMG
column18: crits do +50%
column19:
and a miss makes you look like an idiot. Here's an example of an attack as you'll see it in the combat log:

Acc:40 - Def:26 = 14. Roll:70 + 14 = 84(Hit). 13.5 - (DR:6.0 - 3.0) = 10.5 Pierce

So
column20: what's happening here? First you have your Accuracy which is compared to the Defense of the defender. In this case the difference is 14 in my favor(40-26=14.) Next is my dice roll to which the previous result is added(or subtracted if your Acc is lower than the defender's Def.) I rolled a 70 plus the 14 from my Acc bonus
column21: meaning 84 = a Hit!\nThen
column22: there's the DMG my weapon does(13.5) and after that the ]Damage Reduction from the defender
column23: which is subtracted from my attack's DMG. Normally this would reduce my damage to 7.5(13.5-6.0)
column24: but since my Dagger has the effect to bypass 3.0 Damage Reduction
column25: I only get a 3.0 penalty and do 10.5 Pierce type damage.\n\nWhew! Not so complicated after all is it? However
column26: there are 4 different types of Defense for each character and multiple types of Damage Reduction
column27: which give this system quite a lot of depth to work with.\n\nAnother basic mechanic is Engagement. Once two characters are engaged in combat
column28: they are "locked" to each other. Breaking this lock(to escape or attack a different character) gives the other combatant a free attack. This is a fundamental system
column29: that some people have trouble working with. It also means that the character making the most DMG or aggro doesn't necessarily pull all your enemies. This is where clever positioning and the usage of skills comes into play. (You're going to hate enemies that tunnel or warp their way around your carefully aligned defense. Stop them with spells and skills before they get a chance to do so. See: strong opening.)\n\nVitality & EndurancePillars of Eternity has basically two versions of Health: Vitality and Endurance. Endurance is your resistance to short-term injury
column30: or how much damage a character can withstand before they are knocked unconscious in battle. Vitality represents long-term injury or how much damage a character can sustain before they are maimed or die permanently. A character's Vitality is based on his Endurance and multiplied according to his class. A Druid with an End. of 50 will have Vit. of 200
column31: since his class multiplicator is 4.\n\nEvery hit you take in battle reduces End. & Vit. If your character takes 10DMG
column32: you'll lose 10 End. & 10 Vit. End. is de facto your combat health
column33: and if it's totally depleted
column34: you're knocked out for the rest of the battle. Therefore the healing spells/skills in the game affect the End. The only way to replenish your Vitality however is by resting. Either by camping or sleeping in taverns. Also
column35: your End. will sink with your Vit. once it reaches it's value. Meaning that with a Vit. of 36
column36: you'll also have an End. of 36.\n\nIf your Vitality reaches 0
column37: you'll be maimed. Maimed is a serious condition that inflicts grave combat penalties. Once a character has been maimed
column38: further reduction of Vit. will always result in death
column39: and it can only be healed through resting.\n\nSpell castingAs in old Infinity Engine games
column40: spells have limited use and need resting to replenish said uses. But Pillars of Eternity also features skills that replenish after each battle. The key is to balance these two
column41: so you'll not find yourself without spells in the middle of a dungeon. The amount of camping supplies you have also varies with each difficulty. On hard

column52: that the cursor stops working etc. All these are already confirmed to be fixed by next week though.\n\nPillars of Eternity is not simply Baldur's Gate 3

column57: and you won't have any trouble with frustration :^)"

reviewText:
Summary:

Beautiful visuals, brilliant art direction, great sound, fun combat, excellent characters and NPC's, lots of choices and consequences, elaborate dialogue, comparable to that of Planescape, fairly challenging, great writing, great atmosphere.

Some frustrating bugs in combat, especially during chaotic battles, hard to keep track of your party among large enemies and amongst tons of visual effects, some god awful pathfinding in some battles.

___________________________________________________________

Pillars of Eternity has not only taken the task of bringing back life into a genre that has laid dormant for years, it did it damn well, and by damn well I mean ♥♥♥♥ing amazingly! It brings me joy beyond expression to finally play a game in this era, an RPG in particular, that offers a fully rounded experience. A game that breaks the mold of what gaming has become, Pillars of Eternity has laid the myth of there being no talent left in the gaming industry to a relieving rest. I have yet to complete the game so this review should be considered a place holder and is subject to change.

In Pillars of Eternity, you play as what is known in this world as a 'Watcher', this grants you the powers to tap into peoples souls and relive important events in their lives, whether this is a blessing or a curse is unclear but what you find out soon enough is that some people don't take too kindly to their presence and it is best to keep it under the ropes. The world in this game is brutal and shows little room for mercy. Madmen as leaders and false prophets, power, greed and deceit paint the picture this game portays and how you deal with it is up to you.

Pillars of Eternity takes place on a sprawling, absolutely beautiful world for you to explore at your own peril. It is setout with similarities relating to the map seen in Baldur's Gate where you traverse through individual points of interest plotted out on the map. The areas for you to explore are varied and a pleasure to explore thanks to the extreme amount of attention to detail poured into this game. They weren't pulling our scarf when saying that this game was crafted with love and care as this game oozes those from every pore.

As with traditional RPGs, you're given a main quest along with smaller side quests on the side. This game has no single point of attraction, the whole game itself is the attraction. The quests are diverse making seeking them out a pleasure rather than a chore. Each with often with very entertaining outcomes, gone is that feeling of go there fetch/kill that this era of RPGs sunk into, there is a true feeling of responsibility behind the actions you partake in and many questioning you on an ethical level as there are often choices to make and consequences which follow.

It is with content that I can say that Pillars of Eternity has brilliant writing that helps you delve into and understand the lore, characters, circumstances and events around you. The writing is non-pretentious and explains in extreme detail, painting a vivid picture of your surroundings, going as deep as you're likely to handle, many of the characters you interact with have an insane amount of dialogue pinned to them, you can have elaborate discussions that have a mind numbingly amount of content to them. This adds an incredible amount of life to this already buzzing world. The writing in dialogue is consistent, it never feels as though their hands got tired of typing so lazied off with the sloppy, uninspired writing that plagues gaming these days.

The audio/visual style of game is breathtaking, a work of art. From the sounds of your sword slicing an enemy to the ground, to the trance inducing, stunning sountrack to the beautifully created backdrops. Everything here is meticulously designed and put together extremely well which is a massive challenge by itself. The atmosphere this game oozes, gives off one of the best fantasy vibes I've ever felt in gaming and this is coming from someone who is a massive fan of the original IE games.

Pillars of Eternity features a handful of companions that will aid you through your quest, each masterfully well written, they all have their quirks, background, likes and dislikes and you're able to engage in deep and meaningful conversation with them, learning of their past, giving them advice or agreeing and disagreeing with them. This breathes a lot of life into the game as you feel as though you know the people you're adventuring with rather well as opposed to having that generic, soulless band of companions that offer nothing more than snide comments, empty, worthless dialogue and so on.

The combat featured in this game is incredibly fun, if you're familiar with games such as Baldur's Gate and IWD, you're likely to hop in and have an understanding off the bat of how things operate. The combat in this game is in real-time, allowing you to pause to issue out commands to your character as well as those in your party, this is of importance, especially when playing on higher difficulties where your tactics need to be as sharp as your blade and one small error could lose you the battle. Each character has their strengths in the form of endurance, accuracy, spell casting and so on from what you'd expect from a traditional Western RPG and utilizing them strategically is key to your success. I am currently playing on hard and while it isn't as brutal and merciless as the games it takes it's inspiration from, there are still quite a few challenging encounters that are bound to warrant a reload.

Browsing discussions on the Steam thread, I came across numerous posts saying that this game is dumbed down and streamlined when compared to Baldur's Gate, people need to stop the comparisons and play this as it's own game. Sure it takes a lot of influence from the likes of Baldur's Gate, IWD and Planescape (in terms of elaborate writing and story telling), but it strives off it's own merits and mends together it's influences in a unique way.

A few problems I currently have in this game is the AI in combat, while these don't happen very often thankfully but when they do they're bound to make your blood pressure rise, such as your units not always reacting to orders, pathfinding issues, attacking when you want them to retreat and a few other small annoyances.

It is with a pleasure that I can say Pillars of Eternity is trully worth your money and time, I haven't been this impressed with an RPG since 2000, this takes the genre right back to the standard which it should be today. Offering a deep experience, good role playing, great mechanics and so forth. Thank you Obsidian and the people who made this game possible by backing it. Trully a modern classic.

A serious review now that i sunk a fair few hours into it and completed the game on the harder settings.

Pillars is a great in its own right, there is no reason a Baldur's Gate fan or an owner of Wasteland 2 should not buy this game. Its mechanics are familiar and simple enough to pick up.
The combat is forgiving on the lower difficulty settings but when you crank it up you really need to know you're stats, abilities and enemies.

There's a good reason 80,000 people backed this game, raising over $4 million just so they could then buy the game and play it. Although im not a backer i would like to thank everone who is.

Good Job Obsidian.
Good Job gaming community.

reviewText:
Genre - Fantasy RPG with paused tactical combat

I had played through both Baldur's Gate games extensively back in the day and I have played this game a lot before making an opinion.

It began as a kick starter and stays true to the gameplay of the Baldur's Gate and Icewind Dale games. You have an isometric view and guide your hero through story driven quests whilst recruiting up to 5 NPCs with their own dialogue options and personalitys. The story is interesting and manages to be fairly original, immersing you in a new universe to explore. You have a world map to navigate and the White March expansion adds an increased level cap, weapons that level up and a new area with quests.

I haven't completed the game yet as I have hit my level cap near the end of White March 1 (14), and suspect that White March 2 will increase it further (16?) so don't want to lose out on exp. Some of the fights are still difficult on normal and I have found myself going back to them once I powered up a bit more. The weapons/spells are varied enough for a fantasy universe and the side quests interesting.

You also get to look after a stronghold near the start of the game. This to me was more of a minor distraction and something that could be built on in the sequel, although it still performs many useful functions and the basis for the endless paths quests.

As a fan of Baldur's Gate I think the developers have done a great job, and I hope they continue to build on this franchise. I am now looking forward to White March 2 so I can beat the end boss or rage quit trying...

reviewText:
Impressions after 11 hours of gameplay. Will keep updating as I play more.

Pillars is Obsidian's best game to date, and a genuine masterpiece.

Visually stunning: incredibly detailed backgrounds, with plenty of environmental particle effects that add a lot of life to the scenery. The 3D character models fit perfectly into the scenes, and have smooth, weighty animations (far improved from the backer beta, from what I remember).

The audio is equally impressive. Everything sounds 'right', from footsteps to arrows hitting their mark. Music seems to be fairly standard fantasy stuff, with lots of flutes and such (Not a music expert, sorry.) Being 'fairly standard' is by no means bad. All the pieces I've heard have been very nice, and fit the scene and situation perfectly. The music is also not on a continuous loop: there are moments where all you'll hear are the ambient noises. Makes me appreciate the music even more, and has (thus far) prevented it from being overly repetitive.

The game's interface is great. It's modern and easy to use, but not minimalist. Wood and paper textures ties it to the world, but it avoids being old school clunky brilliantly. Fonts are clear, and the size can be adjusted in the settings. There's also a colourblind setting, for those who  need that.

Often in games like this, the story starts off very, very slow. Not the case in Pillars. In the 11 hours I played, the world has me absolutely hooked. The main storyline seems very interesting and highly personal. Side quests are mostly tied to the main story, and all offer a variety of choices along the way. I especially enjoyed a quest where the party is tasked with killing a lord. I figured out three distinct ways of disposing him:

1. Enter through the sewers and sneak into his throne room.
2. Scale the castle ramparts, enter through the top floor, disguise the party as priests and just walk to the throne room.
3. Storm the gates and murder everyone.

This specific quest also had an added layer of complexity, but I won't go into detail here; too many spoilers as it is.

As you would expect from Obsidian, there's a lot of well-written dialogue and every situation and character I've encountered has been described in great detail (made even better by the fact that the descriptions match the visuals, unlike in, say, Shadowrun Returns or Wasteland 2) Dialogue options are plentiful, with frequent skill / stat checks that do a great job of tying the RPG system into the conversations. Most characters also have at least one line of voiced dialogue, to give the player a better feel of the person. A nice touch.

The combat is solid, and reasonably challenging even on Normal difficulty. 11 hours in, my party consists of two fighters, two spellcasters and an archer. Even at low levels (2-4) my party composition offers great tactical depth. The casters both have ~12 extremely varied spells available, and the rest have 2 or 3 abilities each. Battles are quick and very dangerous; I find myself pausing after most actions.

Armour seems to play a huge role: my fighters wearing brigandine take significantly less damage than my archer, clad in padded cloth. The differences between weapon types are fairly noticeable as well (especially short vs. long weapons). As a whole, the combat is very fun and the interface for it is highly intuitive.

Character progression feels a tad slow, but every level up offers plenty of skill points to distribute, one or two abilities to pick and sometimes a perk as well. Leveling up feels meaningful, and it's immediately noticeable in the characters' performance.

The large variety of classes, races, backstories and cultures should offer plenty of replayability, when combined with the absolutely vast amount of different directions every conversation can go.

I don't care to ever write reviews and quite frankly my PC Gaming has taken a major halt in the last few years because like a lot of you interested in this game I've been playing PC games since the start and been through all the classics. Quite frankly I don't get impressed easily anymore.

Finally a game comes by (single player non the less) that has totally encapsulated me in it's world and I want to play, I think about playing, and I enjoy every minute playing. I did download this game cause I'm broke right now but after the first day I immediately bought it. I never thought a single player game would be worth 45$ again. It has some minor bug of course but it's refreshing playing a game that feels complete and not another terrible early access mess that I play, get bored, and never ended up playing the completed" game.

Thanks Obsidian for bring us back to how PC gaming use to be and you have my full support in the future. Don't be eaten up by big brother and continue doing what you're good at."

reviewText:
Pillars of Eternity. Widely acclaimed as a spiritual successor to Baldur's Gate and Icewind Dale. While I do not doubt the truth of such claims, I would like to offer my perspective as someone who's never played Baldur's Gate or Icewind Dale, and thus approach PoE with fresh eyes.

For a start games in the fantasy genre which PoE sits in are plenty on Steam. Indeed I have an earlier review of Spellforce, a game which was somewhat forgettable for me despite brave attempts to capture the spirit of fantasy RPG. As I hadn't played Baldur's Gate nor Icewind Dale, PoE's first job as to sell itself to me on the steam store page. I approached it with some skepticism initially and wasn't entirely sold on the top down isometric view. The game's content, gameplay, mechanics, lore etc however, reminded me of my evenings of pen and paper RPG games I've had with friends, and that convinced me to give it a try.

It was a decision I would not regret. Character creation is one of the biggest parts of any good P&P fantasy RPG game, be it Dungeons and Dragons or Warhammer. The character creation of PoE made me feel exactly like I was starting a P&P RPG game. It wasn't so much as customising my character's look as it was fleshing out my backstory, allocating stats etc. I spent almost 3 hours alone in character creation.

The story is well written, well paced. The lore is rich, you feel like you are in a wonderful fantasy world to be explored. While having individual maps instead of a massive world like any of the Elder Scrolls games makes exploration less of a focus, nonetheless it's still good fun discovering new places. The combat system takes a while to learn and master, and having a game manual would really help, but by and large the mechanics of the game aren't too difficult to pick up. When playing it I had a sense I was playing a game with Elder Scroll's rich lore and setting with Diablo's graphics and interface, both franchises I absolutely adore. As a setting for individual role playing in, it's right up there with Elder Scroll games.

There aren't many games which have made me think I really love the fantasy genre". Fable was the first that got me started. Warcraft
recommended: got me deep into it. Elder Scrolls cemented my love for the genre
hoursPlayed: and I didn't think it was possible to take my love for fantasy to a new level
voteText: but Pillars of Eternity has somehow managed to do that. Playing it brings back the sort of emotions I experienced the first time I played Fable
helpfulPercent: WoW
votesHelpful: Elder Scrolls. All the more amazing given the isometric top down projection and fixed maps PoE utilises instead of first person or over the shoulder views in an open world those other games share.\n\nWith the rich amazing lore as its foundations
votesTotal: I can see PoE being the beginning of something great. A grand new fantasy franchise to go alongside giants such as Warcraft
votesFunny: Elder Scrolls

reviewText:
Pillars of Eternity is the crowd funded spiritual successor to Baldur’s Gate 1-2. It’s an overall very good game but suffers from a few issues. I will be looking at the strengths and weaknesses of the game.

The Good:
-Very well written
-Some very interesting NPC’s and companions
-An interesting setting with some great ideas
-Highly entertaining
-Good choice/effect
-Nice atmosphere
-Solid and well developed lore

The Bad:
-You have some really good quests but also a lot of throw away quests
-Fairly weak main story line with a forgettable villain and there is in fact no true, believable motivation      for your player character to do things he/she does for most of the time
-too many loading screens
-boring spells

The Ugly:
-The combat and the encounter design is just flat out bad
-Too much combat in the game and it gets incredibly tedious after a while
-visually the combat is a cluster♥♥♥♥

Overall a solid title 8/10

reviewText:
“If there were no gods, it would have been necessary to create them.”

Pillars of Eternity is an isometric role-playing game (rpg) developed by the company Obsidian Entertainment with emphasis on tactical combat.

Atmosphere & presentation:

+ Vast and mature fantasy world with great love for detail.
+ Excellent background music enriches the atmosphere.
+ Additional game mechanics, like the bounty hunter missions and castle construction, create a welcome diversion to the mundane tasks of an adventurer.
+ The extension White March increases level cap and delivers additional characters, equipment and side story elements.
+ Clean user interface and good inventory management.
+ Great replay value.

o The different factions are interesting in the beginning, but their general involvement with the player is rather small.
o Satisfying execution of almost every aspect of the game, due to several patches.

Combat & gameplay:

+ The ability to approach a potential combat situation in multiple ways is well balanced in the game.
+ Transparent combat mechanics allow the player to understand each encounter.
+ Implementation of a dynamic difficulty system provides rpg newcomers, veterans and masochists with a satisfying challenge.
+ Impressive customization system allows for extensive weapon and armor modifications.
+ Broad spectrum of skills offers good character development.
+ Lower spells remain efficient on higher levels.

o Party size is limited to a maximum of six characters.
o The player can decide to travel alongside a companion party or custom party.

Characters & story:

+ The main plot is complex and multi-layered.
+ Well written dialogues and narrative.
+ Very good voice acting of all characters.
+ Certain quests offer several ways to complete them.
+ Dialogues and events can be solved by an attribute or skill check.
+ Major decisions of the player are reflected in the end sequence of the game.

o While some characters are interesting and provide an authentic development, others remain immature lacking depth.
o Not all dialogues with non-player characters are synchronized.
o The protagonist cannot start a romance.

- Any character class can learn to pick locks and disarm traps, which diminishes the attractiveness of the rogue class.
- The creation of a multi-class character is not possible.

Summary:

Overall, Pillars of Eternity offers high-quality content and sophisticated gameplay. The world is fantastically immersive, and represents a wonderful role-playing experience.

Amusing quotes:

“Let’s try this again: Step aside or die chocking on your own innards.”

“What kind of coward asks for his own man to be killed? The kind who will be so enraged by it, that no amount of pain will stop him from beating you so savagely, that you will carry the disfigurement into your next life.”

Trivia:

NPCs with gold name plates were designed by the backers. Interacting with them will allow you to experience each one’s unique history.

Achievements:

Estimated time for 100 % completion: +300 hours

Singleplayer achievements: 48
Multiplayer achievements: none

Chronology:

Pillars of Eternity (PC)
Turn-based role-playing game
(Dark Fantasy) – 2015
