reviewText:
Up until now, I had never played an isometric RPG like this and I figured I'd add in my two cents for others like myself.  My previous experience has been with games like Skyrim, the Mass Effect series,  various shooters and an assortments of strategy games.  With that in mind, I was a little concerned that the pacing of this game would be an issue (having to pause repeatedly in combat, reading through a lot of text, the lack of flashy special effects and cutscenes, etc...).  Not only is it not an issue, I found that it was quite relaxing!  This game makes me want to play it while drinking a cup of hot tea while sitting in front of a crackling fire.  It's an experience to be taken slowly and savored.  I spent about 30 minutes in the character creation alone and loved all the various options that went into crafting the perfect hero.

I read some copmplaints here about the graphics quality, but it was a non-issue to me.  In fact, I have found that to be one of the things working in its favor.  In a weird way, not being bombarded with flashy special effects and cutscenes is one of the things that has helped make the game more immersive and relaxing to me.

I highly recommend this game.  It's deep, immersive and the story and world is charming and interesting.  It requires time and thought and is not a game that is designed to be rushed through, but I feel that it does a great job at rewarding the player's time investment.

reviewText:
Not Recommended at full price, wait for $10 or lower at least. Loads of tedious combat encounters and binary quest solutions. Unable to get all achievements since one is exclusive to Kickstarter backers.

UPDATE: Finally made it to the end boss on Ironman Path of the Damned and the game has glitched rendering me unable to complete it and invalidating ALL of my progress. I have spent nearly 150 hours trying to find something other than the main story to redeem this game but I have nothing.

I have played Baldurs Gate, Icewind Dale, Fallout, Torment, as well as Neverwinter Nights 1&2. I have played just about every obsidian game that has come out as well, with my favorites by and far being NWN2 Storm of Zheir, and Fallout: New Vegas.

However when I play this game, it is (to my surprise) boring. The problem is a vast majority of the game is combat, tedious number rolling save-scumming low damage limited spells combat. There are no instant-kill abilities or vibrant graphic spells to break up the monotony such as Torment, it is largely just putting a tank or two at a bottleneck and picking apart packs of monsters. It almost feels that most enemies exist of the sake of existing. There are other things I dislike about the combat (especially the engagement system) but I will save my figurative breath.

As with any Obsidian game the dialogue is well-written, although I find that a majority of  dialogue choices loop to the same outcome. Most quests end up with you fighting the person regardless if you want to or not, a vast majority of people are more than willing to just charge in and die to a group of random strangers for no discernible reason instead of going to jail or opting to run away. It seems most persuasive" options involve threatening people until they tell you what you probably already know.

That being said I don't really enjoy this game
date: it holds a lot of potential that just isn't realized and ends up executing ideas poorly. Obsidian has an undeniable talent for writing
recommended: but they are just not up to balancing a game. The leveling system is a mess of must-have or don't-touch abilities
hoursPlayed: and even with a 6 person party it just feels completely underwhelming."

reviewText:
I have to say the game has surpassed my expectations thus far. I fell in love with Baldur's Gate in 1998, and this is the game I was waiting all those years for as a lifelong RPG fan.

It has all the important pieces firmly in place

- Great story
- Deep gameplay mechanics (even if I would like it to be D&D 5th edition)
- The dialogues are well written and utilize the attributes in a clever and interesting way
- The party banter is here (yay)
- The world is nicely crafted (I would prefer Forgotten Realms though, but beggars can't be choosers)
- Added great additional mechanics (Choose your adventure style encounters)
- Doesn't treat the player like an idiot, gives a solid amount of challenge
- The graphics, music and the atmosphere are ideal, and unbeatable, especially for the heroic fantasy fans
- Interesting quests, and amazing writing (i have mentioned that before, but can't stress in enough)

I do hope this gem will sell millions and will herald a true RPG revival, not only from Obsidian (love you guys), but from other talented developers as well. I am sick and tired of the cancer modern Bioware-EA and other soulless developers were publishing after the demise of infinity engine era games, trying to pass dumb, console oriented, 'streamlined' uninspired turds as 'rpgs'.

Like other reviewer wrote Dear Baldur's Gate fans
recommended: I do not regret backing this gem

reviewText: Wow, this game is amazing. If you are a fan of the Baldur's Gate series, or just looking for a good, challenging rpg, do yourself a favor and buy this game. I'm only playing on normal difficulty and I still find the game frustrating (in a good way) at times. The music in the game is amazing, though I wish there was more of it, and the controls and ui are all on point. I'm a huge fan of the Stronghold system, you gain a castle of sorts early on in the game and can make an array of upgrades for it to improve defense and commerce. Whether you're new to this sort of game or a returning veteran, this is definitely a fun time.

reviewText:
Pillars of Eternity is Obsidian's first try to make a game without any publisher pushing (which is what fans believed was always the problem with the bugs in their games for example) thansk to their kickstarter campaign.

As it turns out yes they can release a well polished game (even with a huge complicated world like poe).

Managed to finish the game after 75 hours more or less so you can see this is a huge game.

there is tons of quests both main and sidequests and most of them are actually decent (not the go there and get me 5 furs kind). Even in the few fetch" quests there is a story there and twists that made them fresh and enjoyable.

The game looks very pretty if you like the old school isometric style
date:
has a great soundtrack which managed not to bore me after playing the game for 70+ hours.

Everyone who likes the genre this is perhaps the top crpg that has come out in the last 10+ years and certainly the best kickstarted project i have backed so far (although shadowrun is a close second).

There is a ton of options in the dialogues and choices that can and will affect the world in quite a big way (unlike other "rpgs" which will not be named).

The combat was interesting and engaging and quite hard even on normal especially on the start of the game.

There is also a huge totally optional dungeon in game (14-15 floors).

Definitely recommend this game and i hope obsidian can go back to ks and would gladly back them for more."

reviewText:
THE SONIC 06 OF ISO GAMES.

This game is a shell of what I expected it to be. I let the hype train, and the 3.9 million budget (on kickstarter) isometric rpg game, make me think it was going to be an epic that would allow me to relive Baldur's Gate. And I was wrong.

I'll start off with a few things I liked. Inventory management is much easier. You can place the majority of loot in a huge container. The Prologue I found to be extraordinarily fun, and I felt everything about that part of the game was well fleshed out. The fast forward that allows you to quickly walk around is a dream come true. The stronghold mechanics were extremely fun and well done.

EDIT: I'd like to update the news on this review, the devs caved into SJWs to remove a limerick that was pathetically not offensive. In addition to that, the devs have stated modding on the Baldur's Gate scale is unlikely. So yeah, enjoy this objectively worse game. Funnily enough, they largely stated they would support" mods. By support

I'd also like to mention the absolute shameless moneygrab the upgrade packs are. It makes EA look generous.

reviewText:
So....this game was everything I hoped for and more. Obsidian really set the bar for CRPG's. Beyond that, I think Avellone and company really elevated their game further as far as their story writing goes as well. Just flat out superb, seamless, and fairly well flawless IMO.

There has been a lot written about this game already, obviously, but I will say that with all the hype and all the funding that went into this, the potential for a let down was great, so to have the game not only deliver, but deliver in such grand fashion was amazing.

The character development was deep and fulfilling and the quests actually made sense....rather than just simple fetch and escort quests with no rhyme or reason, everything had an actual reason in this game, and even where they didnt serve to advance the main story, they still had a very real role in filling out the depth of the world itself.

The actual story line itself was pretty gripping. The end of Act 1 gave you the sense of a journey really just beginning, the end of Act 2 was a holy ♥♥♥♥!" moment
date: and the end of Act 3 let you know there was no turning back and that everything was about to get all too real as you approached the end of the game. That doesnt even factor in some of the other
recommended: non main quests story lines that develop throughout the game
hoursPlayed:
which are also stellar.

The journey itself was filled with pretty much any emotion you can imagine. The moral choices were often difficult due to the realistic consequences that come with every decision.
Speaking of decisions
voteText: quite a few of them factor into the ending...and speaking of endings
helpfulPercent: I cant remember another game that had such a well thought out one. There also seems to be potential for a lot of variations to the ending depending on what choices you made at pivotal moments throughout. My ending was a fair mix of incredibly good and depressingly bad consequences to what I had done during my extensive playthrough. I loved that fact.\n\nI am thoroughly impressed with this game

reviewText:
After 40 odd hours of play time and extensive experience with the old Iso Infinity Engine games; There was a real hype surrounding this title. Thankfully the wait has not been a dissapointment for me. Since Launch I took the weekend to play through the campaign and currently 40 hours in I have not even scratched the surface yet, so a short experience in gametime is not an issue.
The story is 100% worth experiencing and is pretty close to Planescapes Experience if you enjoyed that classic. The sidequests can be engrossing and feel as detailed as the main campaign at times. Tasks are your fetch/kill/item quests for extra xp, so the three tiers of quest types cover all the usual ground.
I am loving the companions, Obsidian have always made well written characters. Durance is probably my favourite so far. ♥♥♥♥♥S!!!
Combat is fairly clunky but provides a challenge and a lot of patience late in the game on normal to hard difficulty. I played for a good 10 hours or so on hard but switched down to normal to experience the game over the engine issues that need fixing. No doubt various balance patches will come out for this. Obsidian are hardly known for their clean bugless games on launch..historically their QA department are a bunch of clowns, which is a shame considering how good their game design can be.
I would say the only flaw (albeit a subjective one) is that Obsidian did make some progressive choices with NWN2 with regards to game performance (faster loading or no loading when moving upstairs in a building etc. For some reason they have regressed to having a loading screen for every map change similar to Baldurs and Icewind Dale engines. While I realise this is a nostalgia trip for some, to completley dismiss advances of modern tech to cater to some purists is an oversight in the long term now you're marketing to people beyond the backers.
Eitherway, I am loving my experience of this game and purposefully have said nothing about the plot.
Reccomended if you enjoy detailed, lore rich, micromanagement, tabletop inspired, story driven CRPG's

reviewText:
I'm going to keep this very short. For the fans of the genre, this is a must-have. The old school feel, dialogue boxes, the hud and the isometric landscape will bring tears to your eyes if you were around for the first BGs like me.

BUT, as you progress you'll start seeing through the nostalgia and noticing the flaws. And there are a few;

1- Spell menu designs; horrible! Spells only appear when you hover your mouse over the spell level slot, which is frustrating because you keep missing it by an inch and it goes to the next slot, or worse cast the wrong one just to realize turns later. Sounds like a small thing, but considering the hours you spend casting them I would have expected something better.

2- auto leveled companions; yeah, you start your game, hang around for a couple of levels then meet this great guy, priest or something; you should be happy, but you can't. Because their level always matches yours and as usual they are complete idiots when it comes to picking talents. Don't be surprised to find your exact build (happened to me with a paladin) and stupid worthless crap like extra level 1 spell slot?!.

3- very inconsistent difficulty curve; won't be a problem for a some of you but I have friends giving up on the game just because the first few levels were near impossible to beat. this game starts really tough but once you reach level 8, you'll start butchering people like crazy. The problem is the dungeon below your castle which you can use as a grinding area and get a few levels without advancing in the story. So from that point on you'll breeze through the dungeons, stopping only for a few occasions like a few bosses (the master below!).

4- And finally, subplots. I have to say the story is great here, but all of us oldschoolers expected funny sidequests, really wacky npcs with stupid motives, the occasional wondering idiot and so on. Also everything kinda ties into the main arc, which is great in a way, but what about stuff like the knights of solamnia in BG2, vampires and such? I miss those.

Apart from all that, this is a very good game, and I was hooked. The game has a very good story, great voice acting, beautiful sceneries and intense battles.

my rating: 8/10

reviewText:
Pros:
+ Extremely well-written
+ Customization options for many features (when to auto-pause, how the stash can be used, dialogue displays, UI, etc)
+ Modernized Baldur's Gate experience
+ Deep, three-dimensional characters
+ Expansive lore
+ Character stronghold
+ Mega-dungeon
+ Choices and consequences matter and are rarely black and white decisions
+ Custom system that's easy to learn but hard to master
+ Dialogue and character interaction is extremely complex, and relies on varying attributes, abilities, reputations and previous character choices to determine available options and how those options are received
+ The ending actually reflects your choices in game and gives a sense of closure

Cons:
- Loading screens.  So.  Many.  Loading screens.
- Spotty voice acting
- Combat pathfinding can be kinda stupid
- Immersion-breaking backer content
- Extremely text-reliant

Overall: Pillars is a great game that's extremely immersive and fun.  If you are a fan of isometric games like Baldur's Gate or Icewind Dale, but can't get into them due to their age, this is a perfect game to try.  Obsidian did everything right.  The game is streamlined and their original system works wonderfully.  The text is beautifully written, and if you can ignore the backer content (any tombstones or yellow-name characters) the game is one of the most immersive you'll find.  Voice acting gets choppy (one frame is narrated, the next is not, then another narrated, etc), and there are a lot of loading screens.  These are minor issues in an otherwise perfect game.  Every choice matters in this game, and if Bioware pays attention, maybe they can take a few notes on how to properly end a Mass Effect game.

Bottom Line: You probably already know if you want this game or not.  But if you're on the fence, wait for a solid sale and buy it.  It's a blast to play, and whatever problems the game may have fade away in the face of the final package.  I will never not recommend this game.

reviewText:
I've quite a history when it comes to playing infinity engine games and D&D oriented games in general and I can not in good faith recommend this game for the price it's being offered. I've played Baldur's Gate 1 and 2, including the expansion throne of Bhaal. Yes I've played Icewind Dale 1 and 2 and even Neverwinter nights 1 and 2.

Pillars of Eternity just doesn't measure up, in large part due to the laziness of the developers and an overall lack of innovation. This is the first time I've played through a Bioware/Obsidian rooted game and skipped through the text conversations out of the shear dreariness/tediousness of the story in PoE. The combat is dull and a step backwards from the scripted companion AI in the infinity engine games. If the idea of micromanaging every action of your party members sounds appetizing, then you might very well enjoy this game, that is if the bugged AI and invisible walls don't ruin your experience, as quite regularly you will find that your party members will twitch or stand around aimlessly while you attempt to slog through the game's ever boring world. I should also mention the fact that your party stops getting xp from battles after getting enough kills of certain mobs and completing that mob's beastiary, making battles an annoyance and borefest later in the game).

I paid $38 for this and regret doing so, for those infinity engine fans wishing to purchase this game, I would suggest waiting for a price drop and paying no more than $8. Don't believe the hype, this is not the lovingly made Baldur's gate successor you had hoped for.

reviewText:
Pillars of Eternity a throwback back to the days of proper Role Playing games. Where character sheets and making actual dialogue decisions (coinciding with some stat checks, I don't believe there are dice rolls) were par for the course.

An only slightly more modern take on Balders Gate or Icewind Dale.

The game pretty quickly drops you into the action and tells you you're very important. Its up to you what to do with that or how to react. Combat takes place in real time. With each action using a cooldown to activate in order to avoid an interrupt, aside from movement. A sort of active turn based variety of combat.

Character creation is extremely in depth perhaps lacking in physical customization but the character traits, stats, class and narrative background are all available for customization.

There are many many many classes to choose from to fill out your 6 person party.
- Barbarian – pretty self explanatory
- Fighter – Most well rounded class
- Chanter – magic user (units – 'lines chanted' during battle)
- Druid – Shapeshifter (DPS)
- Cipher – magic user (units – 'Focus' earned from doing damage with regular weapon)
- Monk – Special abilities earned from 'Wounds' or damage taken
- Paladin – Can be tankish, healer
- Priest – magic user, healer, pos+ neg- buff, debuff dealer
- Ranger – has pet, (slightly useless rogue in my opinion)
- Rogue – charismatic, DPS, scouts, disarms and detects traps
- Wizard – magic user (most effective use of Grimoire)

Perma Death is a real thing on higher difficulties. The green bar on the character portrait is Heath, the overall status of that character. The portrait itself, when taking damage fills in red, this is endurance and when depleted is what will knock someone out of battle. If someones Health is depleted entirely. Bad News Bears I'm afraid. You'll run into characters that have quests associated with them and require you to take them on your journey. These characters are also voice acted as well as some important NPC's. Though not every line has a voice over as this was a kickstarter game (as the loading screen is very apt to point out) That's simply not a realistic goal for something with as much text and dialogue. I should mention that though another character can interact with NPC's you are making the dialogue choices based on your base character for any stat checks that may occur in conversation.

You can re-spec any character at any inn for a relatively inexpensive price if you've made a terrible judgment in choosing traits or some other facet that would otherwise make your current quest more difficult. You can 'hire' a new recruit at any inn, by which I mean you can just make the exact type of character you are missing from your party. More money equals higher starting level.

Fairly early on, you arrive at a place called Caed Nua, which becomes your own stronghold and fairly integral part of the game. You can upgrade it, repair it and use it as a place to rest and receive bonuses from. Depending on how much prestige you and your party have as well as the overall status of your stronghold it can be attacked by bandits (or by other groups) in which you are given the option between hiring some mercenaries and auto-resolving from afar (they can help in a manual resolve as well) if your travels have taken you too far away to make it back in time before they strike or you can travel back yourself and manual resolve to defend your keep. There is also a rather extensive side mission available here among other things.

THE GIST
A true delight for the days of old when RPG's were more than 'press button for sarcastic response'. One can only hope that games of this depth and caliber remain popular enough to be feasible for proper development in the future.

reviewText:
OK, I have to get this out.

I loved BGII (not BGI) and consider planescape:torment an ideal game. Everyone loves this game, and if you buy the game, you probably will too. But I feel like I am the only one who sees all the problems with this game.

We need to move forward. The old crpg's were great, but they were not to be idolized. We need to understand why we loved them, and let the genre grow with us and become better.

This game feels like it was made by a team of writers who felt that combat was an interruption. Far too much emphasis is placed on words words words. Dear god the reading. I'm even a huge reader myself, but I do not turn on the computer to read a novel.

The addition of write-your-own-story style vignettes was a great idea, but honestly they were never that shocking or a real decision. If you took a risk you gained an item and usually just lost some hit points (overall not a huge detriment).

I want to go off-track and rant for a bit. Can we please not make any more ultra-generic fantasy games? Nothing about this world was remotely interesting until the 3rd act. It was the same, the mayors daughter's is lost" stories that I have seen so many times I'm over it. But everyone gobbles it up and I don't know why.

The game demanded I do their textbook reading. They had people speak

reviewText:
Having finished my first and more or less thorough walkthrough I think I'm ready to write a little something about this game. Short version: this game is beautiful and I enjoyed playing it immensely. And now for details.
I didn't back this game on Kickstarter. I must say I had my doubts, even when the beta was out I wasn't sure I liked what I saw.  Gladly, I was wrong, but nonetheless let me start with negative criticism:
- Bugs. Yes, there are bugs. Back when the game was released there were quite a lot of them, some of them rather nasty. However, bugs are only a temporary issue as long as developers work hard at fixing them and right now Obsidian is doing fine. You can see a lot of communication between gamers and developers going on at the forums, most issues are already reported and will be addressed at some time. Which is why I don't think that bugs are that much of a problem.
- Bad/weird design decisions. Those are much worse than bugs because those are a part of the game. The interface, for one, is far from being perfect. Pathfinding is terrible, especially in battle. Battles themselves are separated from the peaceful exploration which means that pre-buffing or pre-summoning or other things like that are not possible. So there are things like that, but not that many of them. Not enough to spoil the pleasure of playing but for some players probably enough to wince once in a while.
- Backer content. I have deepest respect for Kickstarter backers, but all that backer content is better off somewhere... well, not in the game itself. The tombstones can be ignored, but I would trade all those 'special' NPCs for just one real NPC of Obsidian's design, or, better still, for a little quest.
- Role-playing system. The game utilizes an original role-playing system that was designed to kind of remind you of D&D while not being D&D, which benefited the game and harmed it at the same time. Some things work nicely: combat mechanics work, original classes like Chanters and Ciphers are awesome, ability and skill checks function properly. However, such classes as priests, wizards or druids seem (to me) like they were just copied from D&D without much thought. Also I have a real problem with attributes, skills and abilities. Why don't they influence each other? And why are the skills so odd? Outside of dialogue interaction, each skill has exactly one use. Then there are attributes. For example, in this game Might represents both physical and spiritual power, which means that virtually every class needs Might to be able to do damage. At the same time, Intellect only affects the duration of effects and such, so a Wizard might fare better with high Might and low Intelligence. Interesting, but doesn't make much sense if you compare it to how attributes are treated in dialogue options. In textual interactions Might is just plain physical Strength and Intelligence is, well, how smart you are. This means that attributes fail to describe your character. So do I make a mighty wizard to be effective in battle or do I make an intelligent wizard to actually roleplay in dialogues? Anyway, chances are you won't even pay attention to all this while you're playing. However, in the long run, in case there are sequels, not having a coherent and thought-through role-playing system might do some harm.
- White text on dark background. Had to note that specifically. My eyesight is not perfect, I know, but this bright white  font against dark background is killing meeeee. And there's a lot of reading to be done in this game...

But enough with the negative. The good things! There are actually a lot of them so I'll only mention what comes to mind immediately.
- The game is very rich in content. It isn't some linear sham that gets shorter and plainer the longer you play. The game is very consistent with lots of quests, NPCs, fractions and locations to explore.
- Exploration is pure joy in this game. Actually, I believe that PoE has the best dungeon-crawl gameplay ever. Dungeons are so beautiful, so lovingly crafted, so interesting to explore that I wouldn't probably mind if the whole game was one big mega-dungeon. And I have never been a big fan of dungeon-delving before!
- Options. There are a lot of options in the game. A lot of different ways to finish quests, but also a lot of plain game options. Fast mode, slow mode, bigger fonts, smaller fonts, color-blind mode, auto-pause, languages, subtitles - everything is adjustable and this is awesome.
- Most importantly, this game has that elusive charm that BG2 or IWD had. The feeling that makes you explore map after map until it's morning and your eyes can't read the dialogues anymore. It is immersive, it is thrilling, it is intriguing. Obsidian put their hearts and souls into this game, they genuinely care about it and it really shows. Which is the main reason I have to call this game a major success. Everything that is wrong with this game can be corrected, it isn't such a big deal.
The only thing that you cannot patch is the absense of the soul. This game deals with the problem of human souls and of so called Hollowborn - children born soulless. Today, there are a lot of games that seem to be Hollowborn too, but not this one. I hope Obsidian makes many more games like this and next time I'll try my best to support them early on!
P.S. Something I forgot to mention. Doing a complete playthrough took me 70+ hours, but for some time I had to play offline due to a very odd bug that several other people encountered too. So don't mind the 'hours on record' thing too much.

reviewText:
I come from The Frontier. From war swept wastes. I've been fighting there for my entire life. I've seen strong men perish in a blink of an eye. Young men brutally murdered and their corpses desecrated.
I've cheated death many times but the last time was too close. I could feel the Grim Reapers ice cold hands on me. No more!

I hear stories that a town, Gilded Vale, is accepting settlers. All are welcome! A nice, quiet and a friendly town. Sounds too good to be true ? Sure. But it's something.
So i joined a caravan that's heading towards the Gilded Vale. I'm mostly accompanied by small families: Women and children. Refugees looking for a better life.
I feel as if i was accepted just because they needed someone to guard the people.. For the road ahead is long and dangerous.

We've been on a road for a week now. I've been feeling strange for a couple of days. A sickness...unlike i've never experienced before. The Grim Reaper doesn't want me to leave. I can feel his presence. He's following me and something is about to happen.
We stop for the night and i decide to go look for some berries for a curing tea. I wonder into the woods. Not too far from the camp but far enough to lose visual of the people. I finally find some berries and i'm about to head back when i hear a scream...It's coming from the campsite!
I rush back! Running as fast as i can in my condition. I slip a couple of times but manage to keep balance.
I reach the campsite...Everyone has been murdered! Bandits?!
I see a man standing in middle of corpses. He's about 10 meters away from me. He's pulling his sword out of his last victim: A single mother who was looking for a better life for herself and her son.
I notice two more men sneaking out behind tents. Swords drawn. They think i don't see them.

The man in the middle says something about desecrating old ruins and tells me to drop my weapons. I can tell they've never fought a warrior. These bandits, cultists...whoever they are, they've never seen a real fight. A real challenge.
I quickly draw my bow and put an arrow right between his two eyes.
The men from the sides are running towards me. I grab another arrow, shoot one of them in the knee. He screams and falls.
The third guy is now reaching me. About a meter away from me. I drop my bow, quickly draw my sword, take a step back and slash his right arm off right before i behead him.
The second guy is trying to stand up and reach for his sword. I calmly walk up to him. Kick his sword away and push him on his back.
He screams out of pain as i slowly push my sword through his chest.
I take a deep breath and look up to the sky but just when i think it's all over...A Bîaŵac!!!
Noone has escaped a Bîaŵac alive. NEVER! I see a small crack in a mountain about 20 meters from me. I run towards it!
I'm about to reach the cap when i feel a kick and fly through the crack, fall flat on the ground and feel a trumble. I look back and see that the mountain crack has collapsed behind me.
WHEW! I escaped!...But how ? Actually nevermind that right now. Important things first! I scout the cavern and it seems to be empty. I make a fireplace and tend to my wounds. I didn't notice in my adrenaline packed haze that i've dislocated my left foot. The last fall also hurt my right shoulder and elbow quite badly.
I lay down on the hard rocky ground and fall asleep.

It's morning. I wake and struggle to stand up. Still ill. Now wounded and my entire body is aching from sleeping on this rocky ground.
I spend the next hour looking for a way out. Finally i see sunlight. *Sigh* Freedom"
I walk out but i hear yelling. I quickly hide in the bushes at an edge of a cliff and look down. Seems like somekind of cult. A cloaked man is turning people into ash by using somekind of a machinery!
I have no time to figure this out tho. I'm ill and badly wounded. I'm lucky to be alive. I can't risk to be seen so i decide to sneak around and look for a path that leads to the Gilded Vale.

8 hours pass. I'm hungry. Starving even! I'm ill and sweating all over the place but i see the city gates. I keep groaning as i limp towards it.
I finally reach the gates. "Ahhh finally a safe haven!...Wait
date:
what the hell..." I see a gigantic tree full of hanged people. At least 20 corpses hang there. Men and women of all ages. Some corpses are mighty fresh. Feels like the most recent one was hanged no more than couple of hours ago.
I hear loud laughing and footsteps of at least 4 men coming towards me...

I am Metsakurat. A ranger. A Watcher.
This is my story..."

reviewText:
This review is based on a 99% done playthrough on Hard difficulty.

Let's start with the story and the eight NPC recruits first.  While it's hard to top 'You are immune to death, but your memories are gone. Have fun out there.' and 'Remember when you almost died to that wolf? Ok now go kill a god', Pillars of Eternity's main plot is very engaging and weaves itself well into the set pieces and characters you meet throughout your journey.  You are a random person in a caravan that approaches some weird cult and it's leader fiddling with an ancient machine. You're knocked out and wake up with the ability to peer into other people's souls.  Meanwhile sometime before the events of the game started Everyone's Favorite Benevolent God starts punishing heretics before finally being destroyed by a big F-off weapon and has not been seen since.  The main plot involves chasing down this cult leader while either dodging or supporting the influence of the many more gods present in the world. Many of the NPCs you can recruit have their own struggles with their own gods, and if you stick with them long enough, you can help them resolve their issues as well.  The game's reputation system, where you get 'points' towards the different attitudes you present while speaking with others (benevolent, cruel, rational, honest, etc.) is very well done and is sure to result in repeat playthroughs. Conversations can also depend on what class and backstory you picked during character creation. During one particular quest in Act 2, I found myself wishing I was a Priest of Skaen (evil jerks) just to see how it would have played out differently.

The recruitable NPCs are written very well, have good party banter, and help you understand the quite wordy backstory of the world, however many of their pre-selected combat talents are either very poor or don't make any sense at all.  This has been known to cause players to rush to them before gaining too many levels so that they can build them how they see fit.  Min-maxers are going to do what they do in this regard, but I believe this to be justified until they are tweaked a bit to more accurately reflect what the game expects from you while in combat.

The combat is what you can expect from the 'real-time with pause' games that it emulates such as Baldur's Gate and Icewind Dale but with a few major changes.  The first major change deals with stealth.  When you go into stealth mode, your whole party goes into stealth mode. When one person is caught, everyone is caught.  This makes absolutely no sense whatsoever, and renders a rogue's major class talent, backstab, completely and utterly useless.  It's such a terrible, incomprehensible combat mechanic that I have to wonder if we, the players, are doing something wrong, and the developers intended it for some other use that we haven't thought of yet.

Another quite jarring combat mechanic is 'engagement.'  Once you engage with an enemy, you are basically rooted to that spot. Any attempt to even move an inch will open you up to a huge free hit to your character.  While there are both items and talents that help with your defense while breaking engagement, it is still not enough for me to consider it a fun, worthwile addition to combat.  The AI pathing isn't good enough, especially when fighting in hallways and doors. I find myself tolerating engagement rather than enjoying it as a challenge to overcome.

With all that said I am greatly enjoying my time with the game and can't wait to start another character.  It truly is a successor to the great Baldur's Gate games and it is one I will be playing for a long, long time.

reviewText:
Better than any modern Jrpg or Western rpg. This is a shining example of  a backed indie done right.

Closing thoughts:
Best. RPG. Ever. Non commercialized, not tainted by the publishers. Shaped for the fans. Best RPG in 15 years. No hand-holding. Gameplay is not overshadowed by action-oriented gameplay or romances. There's no romance, it's just good old fashioned role-playing game. If you are a real rpg fan, this is a must buy. Thanks for reading! :)

p.s There was alotta hate and troll posts on this game before it came out, all of those people actually ended up buying the game before release though, kinda interesting.

tl;dr:

Pro:
Great writing (plot, character dialog, scene description, lore), awesome artwork and music, long playtime. Weirdly gratifying combat, challenging gameplay*. Lots of classes, specs, and gear to choose from, huge number of viable playstyles.

Con:
Micromanagement can be hard if you aren't used to it, and combat overwhelming* (controlling six characters at once is hard until you master the pause" function). Player may have to choose between more immersive roleplay (voice-acted
date: scripted NPC companions) and a better chance in combat (character-made
recommended: optional companions).\n\n*Higher difficulties are only for veterans of squad-combat games. Don't be a hero

reviewText:
Guys, this game ♥♥♥♥♥♥ me off so many times. It really did. I absolutely hated the fact that it's... where do I start from?!

1. Clunkily isometric - no camera rotation - what you see is what you have to work with.
2. Objects would intersect with one another so many times, that I barely knew what was going on.
3. My guys would wiggle left and right behind one another in a futile attempt to find a way towards the enemy. And even when there is actually space for them to occupy, they would not. Unless I click. Seriously?!
4. My guys will absolutely leave the positions i have carefully put them in to expose my weak rear line. There goes Aloth... Again!
5. My guy(s) would sit and wait like they are braindead while their comrades are getting slaughtered, waiting for a command on my part while I am way too busy making sure my Priest is on top of the whole endurance/conditions/buffs situation.
6. Breaking my space key cause, honestly, that is where your left or right hand should be all the time, based on your orientation.

To continue, although I was a teenager during the dawn of the crpgs, I never ever played one - I was way too busy with games like Might and Magic 6-9, Heroes of MIght and Magic 1-4, Starcraft, Caesar 3-4, Pharaoh & Cleopatra, Zeus - Master of Olympus & Poseidon, etc. I never got into that genre. And now, since Divinity: OS launched, I was slowly drawn to it. And I embraced PoE for all it is:

1. The rich lore.
2. The interesting companions with their own rich story and personality.
3. The companion interactions that made me sit, listen, smile and laugh.
4. The little side stories which were making me connect even to the npcs that I had nothing to do with.
5. The gorgeous handdrawn maps.
6. The approach to combat. I have never ever prepared so painstakingly for my battles. Feels really good.
7. The exploration, looking under every nook and cranny. Spending half a minute carefully moving your mouse over the screen in search for hidden stuff has never been more satisfying.

AND FINALLY, that damn crpg's tons-of-math-and-formulae combat system. At one point I found myself looking into every equation and every calculation and trying to improve my odds.

Holy hell, what has become of me... From a guy flagging PoE as Not Interested" to a person who delves into its mechanics
date: busying himself making plans for future playthroughs and builds and whatnot.\n\nTo conclude - buy this game
recommended: even if you hate the stuff I hated before it appeared. It has this weird way of drawing you in as the game progresses. I played a good part of it with clenched teeth
hoursPlayed: sometimes even shouted at my monitor - while waiting for the next time my guys will ♥♥♥♥ me off in combat by doing the very exact thing I dont expect of them. And I still went on and enjoyed everything it threw at me
voteText: and boy was it worth it. I can't wait for the expansion!"

reviewText:
Pillars of Eternity is riddled with irksome flaws from dodgy AI pathing that should have stayed in the '90s to a story which sometimes offers only an illusion of choice.

Not one of these flaws undermine what is the deepest, most personal adventure to grace the genre in many years. Obsidian's writing is on form; the combat's vast array of strategic options deeply satisfying. Whether you're a life-long Infinity fan or you've never so much as seen a cRPG, Pillars is a quest which everyone should attempt. Here's to many more.

Full nostalgia-free review (link contains mild non-story spoilers): https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yU4xWNucKxY

reviewText:
I wanted to like POE and I played it through to the end but there are just too many issues. First of all there is WAY too much dialogue and lore to sift through. Instead of adding to the immersion it really becomes a chore. I can't imagine doing another play through primarily for this reason.

With the exception of the Roderic's Hold quest the game is relatively linear and there are few choices you can make that materially effect the world. The castle upgrades seem tacked on and pointless. The skill system is very basic and doesn't allow for much specialization. Characters will often end up with similar stats and the only ones that seem to really matter are lore, lockpick and traps.

They've updated some basic party AI for this game but it is woefully insufficient. Programmable AI was a feature in IE games 15 years ago. So there really is no excuse for the lack of its inclusion originally.

As it is the system they have doesn't work effectively on the higher dificulty levels. Be prepared to click hundreds of times in a tough battle rather than have your party follow a simple script. There is SO much combat in this game it really does become a grind and I don't understand why people defend the massive amount of micromangement it requires.

The load times in POE simply take way too long. I have an average system but I've heard that even players with good rigs still suffer from bad load times. This shouldn't be an issue for a 2D game running an old engine.

The plot is meh and the characters aren't particularly memorable. This game is a dungeon crawler first and foremost and more like Icewind Dale than BG1 or 2.

The party AI and dialogue just kill it for me but if you're a fan of this genre it might be worth a play through if it's on sale.

RPG masterpiece it certainly is not.

reviewText:
A true homage to the infinity engine games. Probably my favorite game of the CRPG kickstarter revival so far.

A good story, although sometimes too wrapped up in its own lore for its own good. There are times when the NPCs will be using words that aren't defined, and you sort of have to use context clues to figure it out. There's also a lot of talk of different gods, regions, etc, and with no prior knowledge of the setting it can be a bit overwhelming. Still, the story was good and the world created was interesting.

Mechanically, the game is basically a modernization of the old infinity engine games. The interface looks the same, the combat works the same, and it's all pretty great. My only complaint might be that the underlying game system is basically just a rip of D&D (which is to be expected), but to the point where you might wonder why they bothered to differenciate in terms between the systems. Might vs strength, deflection vs armor, etc.

I encounted a couple of bugs, but nothing too serious. I had to use a third party program to fix a characters run speed at some point, but i'm sure that will be fixed in a patch.

The kickstarter stuff is, thankfully, easily avoided. If you want to dive into it you're welcome to, but it's easy to know what to avoid if you don't care.

Overall, a great game. I highly recommend it.
voteText: 22 of 28 people (79%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
5/10  - That's being generous.

Baldur's Gate this certainly isn't

Pros -

1 - Graphically it's adequate. A step up from the games it claims to be emulating but certainly nothing to get all hot and bothered about. After 15 years, this type of game should look better than BG and BG2. Why people are going mad about this is as if its a new innovation, is beyond me.

2 - I'm struggling to think of a 2.

Cons -

1 - Character generation. Too many crap classes so that you either go for the old faithful fighter (dull, very dull) or a cipher (gets dull real quick). It all comes down to random dice rolls anyway, so it doesn't really matter what points you put where.

2 - As a game, either you're going to be new or old. If you're going to have new races, don't have elves or dwarves. Either forge your own identity, or don't. This just feels like a lazy attempt to pretend POE is somehow a new experience wrapped in a nostalgic bubble. By either description, it falls way short.

3 - Wow the items are dull. Looting your local grocery store would result in more interesting items than you'll generally find at the end of a dungeon in this game. You'll grind your way through generic mob after generic mob, just to find a chest full of crap. So then, you're left with crafting, which while available, feels half hearted and ill thought out. They added crafting as a tick box exercise, rather than make the effort to make it rewarding.

4 - Combat. Okay.....open You Tube and find the Benny Hill theme. Then start a combat. Play the theme as your enemies target your spell caster. Watch the spell caster flee around the screen, followed by the enemy, followed by your tank hopelessly trying to reacquire the enemy.

5- Combat. It's so bad it deserves more mentions. Combat will go like this. Fire off the spell you always fire off. Switch to your standard attack. Go downstairs. Make some dinner. Ring a friend. Come back to find the party still trading boring blows with boring enemies. This is if you're lucky.

6 - Combat - If you're unlucky, you'll fire off a spell and set your tank(s) fighting, only to find that your ranged attackers have bizarrely ceased to attack and are now stood around doing nothing. That or they've been killed by the super teleporting shadow monsters that appear on top of them. In this case, you have the choice to either try and run, dying immediately due to the absurd game mechanics, or stand and die anyway. Your spells are mostly useless, so you'll be presented with a big list of crap to choose from each time you level, rather than spells that feel useful. In 30 hours, I have never found an item with any kind of wow factor. Nothing that I equipped gave me any sense that the effort of slogging my way through the generic, uninspiring dungeon was actually worth it.

7 - The NPCs. Talking to strangers at the bus stop is more rewarding than engaging these generic, dull characters in conversation. They have as much life when they've been killed as they do alive. They have no reason to follow you and nothing much to say when they do. Baldur's Gate etc are old games now, but they managed to produce real characters. Fifteen years later and POE has undone this. I didn't care if they lived. I didn't care if they died. In an RPG of this price in 2015, that's just not good enough. I didn't expect Mass Effect character development, but I certainly hoped for more than walking cliches, that largely dissolved into taciturn automatons after their initial, uninvolving dialogue.

8 - The Lore/World - Lots of lore can be a good thing. It's been done well in other games. It's not done well here. It's like a commitee pulled together a load of standard fantasy fiction and slung it together to create a world notable only by it's staggering blandness. Blah, blah, elves, dwarves, blah, blah, ancient ruins, blah, blah dungeons. It's all so lazy and predictable.

9 - Having to rest to somehow regain your ability to use magic is a mechanic that was crap fifteen years ago. It belongs in table top roleplaying gaming, and that is the type of player attracted to POE. They want to play D&D again, but no one does anymore, so they wax lyrical about POE instead. That kind of limiting, tedious mechanic doesn't appear in computer RPGs anymore for a reason. Unless you're an old school roleplaying gamer, with the accompanying problems with OCD, this kind of mechanic has no place in computer RPGs.

10 - Price - If you loved BG and BG2, then maybe you'll like this. I didn't, but you might. Wait for a sale though. To price this in a similar band to Witcher 3 or DAI is ridiculous. What you're getting is a  facsimile of games that are 15 years old. There's nothing new here and certainly not one iota of innovation. I would argue that POE is in fact a huge step back from the old games it seeks to emulate. Don't pay full price for this. It's not worth it when you can pay a fraction of the price and pick up the original and vastly superior genre games from the early 2000s, like Baldur's Gate or Neverwinter Nights.

Conclusion- For the price, this just isn't good enough. POE is bogged down by a bland world, uninvolving characters and a dull, bugged combat system. I spent hour after hour hoping it would get better. That somehow the world would come to life. It never did. For 5.99 this game would be okay. For 34.99, it's a been one huge and, frankly unacceptable disappointment. It piggy backs on the reputation of much older and far superior games, without ever matching their achievements. Baldur's Gate will be remembered in another fifteen years. Barring bargain basement sales, POE will have been forgotten in fifteen months.

reviewText:
Yes this game is enjoyable - no I still wouldn't recommend it.

This game is mostly a shallow attempt at recreating the succes of Baldurs Gate and similar infinity engine games but fails coming close to them.

Better play Baldurs Gate 2 or Dragon Age: Origins again or just wait for 75% sale.

Positive: + The graphics are beautiful yet stay true to it's sucsessors art style.


Negative:
- Loading times and perfomance
There are pretier games out there. But there are few that take so long to load. And it get's far worse the longer you play. And for a game with such a nostalgic look the perfomance is horrible(low framrate and freezing). This game just is badly optimised in many ways.


- The game just gives the illusion of choices. Nothing what you do and say matters.
E.g. Godlikes are decribed as beeing hated on - you will never see any reaction on beeing a godlike.

Or you can be a mass murder and people still react friendly to you. There are almost no quests where any of your choices change something. There are a few where a person dies or not accourding to your actions - but thats the most you get. Normally you can kill everyone involved or try to solve everyting peaceful - the outcome is the same. Your party members wont leave no matter what ♥♥♥♥ you do, even if you sacrifice one person from your party.

- The game is full of Kickstarter comercials"
1/4 of all Characters you see in the game are from kickstarter funders - that do nothing
date:
say nothing and often have totally unfitting names. They are just there so you can read the little stories the funders wrote.
Even worse are the Kickstarter-tombstones. In every dungeon you see tombstones that are filled with funder texts - often nonsense ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t. The loading screen advise is even to not read them because they break the 4th wall.

- Content was cut and put into the Expansion - it feels like an unfinished game without.
Without the addon you don't even have a character for every class. Yet those Expansion characters where put on the cover of PoE. The items in the base game are very bland - all interesting weapons
recommended:
especially the souldbound ones are expansion only. It feels like this content has been cut out and put in the expansion to sell these. Which wouln't even be that much  of a problem if we wouldn't be talking about more than 40€ for the base version amd 24€ for the DLC.

- The game feels low-budgeted or rushed at many parts.
* I have seen few crpgs with so few spoken text lines. There are many NPCs which don't even have one sentence which features voice acting. Yet for many NPCs it's exactly one spoken line and nothing more.  Oh other languages don't even get that 1 sentence spoken - voices stay english.
* You are the only character contributing to the story. You followers don't matter. In conversations only your skills matter - even if one of your followers boosts a much higher skill than you. You are the only person involved in talking - the best you get is some meaningless comments from followers but these are quite rare.
* Most uniques are not unique
hoursPlayed: they are just crafted with the same stats that you can craft by yourself. There are like 5 helmets with stats
voteText: and normal headwear doesn't gives any stats(why is so much of it even there?). Even full helmets don't give armor(=deflection).\n* You will come accros bugs that make you feel you play a beta game. Items that don't work and show code-blocks
helpfulPercent: quests that you can't finish because you took a path that the devs didn't saw
votesHelpful: save games going corrupt
votesTotal:
very odd balance choices.

- The game is at an awkward spot regarding story vs. gameplay
The story followers are built to bad that you feel punished for playing with them. Custom Characters are FAR stronger.
Custom Characters don't talk.
Even if they don't talk that much the story followers add much to the gameplay. Without them PoE feels more like reading trough a "choose your own adventure" book. Especially on the higher difficulties you are forced to play with custom Characters which reduces the amount of fluff and story you experience.

So what do you want: A party with talking characters or a good party?

- There are LOTS of informations missing.
It begins with the lacking informations on weapon speed and other stats. You need to look up how everything works like you want to write a min maxing guide on some MMORPG to understand basic combat math - and you better look that up.

- Minor nitpickings
* You can't pickpocket.
* Looting/stealing stuff reduces your reputations - unless you kill all bystanders. But the slaughter doens't affects your reputation most of the time. You can even play a "rightous" Paladin and don't suffer for killing & looting unimportant NPCs.
* Combat is best solved in the cheesiest way possible 90% of the time - putting a tank in a chokepoint and the damage dealers behind him.
* Often you can't loot the items that charaters obviously got.
* Balance patches can make your party obsolete. I can understand that you can't play a character in the beta and expect that he will be as good as when you started. But PoE got a few heavy balance patches that made good characters nigh unplayable. One of these is coming soon
votesFunny:
heavily nerfing one class (cipher).
* The guide from the Royal Edition is wrong in many points because of changes after the release.


In the end this game is not horrible. But there are so many odd design choices
commentsCount: lacking parts and bugs that this game is not that enjoyable. I would only advice to buy on 75% sale or in a bundle with the 2 DLCs."

reviewText:
My fiance bought me this game based on the hype from streamers. He also knew that I loved the Baldur's Gate games and Pillars of Eternity was being hailed as a spiritual successor. I bought in the hype myself, and was very excited to play it.

I'll overlook the glaring bugs that I encountered initially (having to do with Unity's network management [including Hamachi and wired ethernet adapters], which isn't even used for the game) because those don't have anything to do with the story, writing, shoddy combat system, or massive class imbalances.

I started with a rogue, which I quickly learned was a mistake. Any character can use rogue skills like stealth and lockpicking, and the backstab bonuses are negligible. The game's monsters ranged from easy one-shot skills to groups of Shadows that will ignore your warrior and pick off your party by swarming the weakest character first.

I don't have any problem with this type of mob, but when they occur within the first hour or so of the game without any learning curve, it's a bit imbalanced. I really wonder if people who aren't used to CPRGs even enjoy it.

The writing is cumbersome and extremely difficult to suffer through. There's just too much of it. Which wouldn't be a problem if it wasn't mediocre to start with. That's nothing new in games, but the writing borders on shakespearean levels of twisted, confusing wording without any of the art or cleverness. I find myself either re-reading passages to figure out exactly why they're over-describing some scene or I just read a few words and skim through.

This game is not unplayably difficult but the combat is extremely imbalanced and random. It just saps out the fun.

This is just not a good game. And it's frustrating that since this is a Kickstarter-backed game, there is nothing but insane hype and blind support. People who gave money to the development of this game will support it unconditionally. Even when I seek help for some difficult parts, forums are filled with maybe you shouldn't suck so much" instead of acknowledgements that *MAYBE* Oblivion's custom combat mechanics are s***.

If you're thinking about buying this game
date: read the negative reviews first. Be prepared for what's wrong with it so there aren't any nasty surprises."

reviewText: Still a bit early but I'm making a review regardless. I backed this game for $160, that was not a poor decision, because so far PoE is really fun.\n\nI'm not a big fan of the old D&D WRPGs, personally I think they're convoluted messes and I only really played through Planescape because the writing, atmosphere, and roleplaying made up for the ♥♥♥♥♥♥ combat, and they really, really did, Planescape is one of my favorite games. I backed PoE because Obsidian are pretty much head and shoulders above almost every other dev team when it comes to writing, atmosphere, and actual roleplaying and I always want to see more games from them. (I’m also happy to have saved Obsidian from bankruptcy too) PoE being a spiritual successor to Baldur's Gate, still feels a tad bit grognardy to me compared to something like Shadownrun’s more streamlined and accessible combat but I'm getting the hang of it and having fun with it and the game does a good game explaning itself for the most part such as telling you exactly what stats you should be dumping into for each class you roll. It still does has a few dumb grognardy mechanics that it doesn't explain very well though, they're not dealbreakers but they can be annoying at times, such as seprate equipment not being able to buff  the same stats and no way to aggro enemies. Playing on Easy helps, but I still can’t play too stupidly so it’s not braindead easy. If you want a challenge though this game is very happy to oblige. The three reasons I backed this game for are all definitely here. The game can get pretty expostiony with its world building but its interesting worldbuilding so it’s cool. As said still too early to make a true final verdict but if this game keeps it up it will be a really good game and a must play for all the old D&D RPG and normal RPG fans alike.

reviewText:
This is what I craved for since Baldur's Gate and Icewind Dale series.
I expected more than 38 hours of gameplay and more locations but even I consider it too short it was beautiful.
Nice story with some original elements, lots of side quests, but characters personal quests seems underdeveloped. I wanted more story for some of them, like Pallegina or Grieving Mother.
Some backgrounds are impressive but not all of them. Voice acting is good, music is enjoyable.
Anyway, if you really want to get the story you will have to read and imagine for yourself a lot.
Entire scenes are only in text, so if you lack imagination or you really hate reading don't try it, as there is no animations and no sounds for lots of scenes (like souls memories). Also not all dialogues are spoken.
Crafting is so-so but Enchanting is really nice - why waiting to loot a good weapon or armor when you can make one yourself?

I am an old gamer and I know to appreciate a good game, so I give it 9,5/10.
Might seem outdated for some people but for me is a returning to CRPG roots and Obsidian knew how to made this enjoyable. Sorry for my poor English.

reviewText:
A very strong game that boasts a lot of player choice with different outcome to most quests, a wide selection of customization for your party, and a lot of different and cool weapons to use.

Unfortunatley it's not perfect, the amount of particles makes large fights with many spellcasters very cluttered, but the foundation is there to kickstart this fantastic style of games back into action for a long time coming.

Get it if you like a challenge, enjoy epic fantasy adventures, and have gotten tired of the pathetic character design of recent BioWare games where the whole focus seems to be for the main character to find someone to stick his ♥♥♥♥ in.

reviewText:
Pillars of Eternity is a well-written and strongly executed spiritual successor to Baldur's Gate II. No RPG in the last decade can hold a candle to its immersive role-playing experience or engrossing, highly believable world. This modernized take on the classic CRPG is a must-buy for any fan of the genre.

But how does it measure up to it's predecessor?

Below I will list a few points from the perspective of a veteran gamer who values immersion in his RPGs above all else, and will attempt to measure it against one of the greatest RPGs of all time.

You must gather your party before venturing forth…Pillars is much easier to play than the Baldur's Gate trilogy, doing away with several annoyances Infinity Engine veterans won’t miss:

++ Flawless path-finding
++ Sexy as ♥♥♥♥
++ Excellent UI design
++ Level design plus “fast mode” saves a ton of time
++ Tutorial, though heavy, is very informative
+ Tooltips!
+ New stash system for painless inventory management
+ Flags for stat-qualifying conversation options
+ Quest notifiers
+ …and much more!

++ Options to turn off most of the above if you feel it interferes with your role-playing
++ Does all of this while retaining the feel of classic CRPGs (major nostalgia bonus)

Character BuildingAt the systems level, Pillars biggest departure from classic CRPGs lies in its new attribute and skills system. To me this has been a mixed bag:

+++ Every attribute and skill has a place in conversations and scripted sequences
++ A ton of options for each class, much more customization than classic CRPGs
++ Updated reputation system is excellent and works as intended
++ Very challenging early game– hallmark of the classic RPG
++ Every attribute influences combat, no dead-weight attributes
+ Skill system allows more freedom for customization
+ Mastering new attributes is a fresh challenge for RPG vets
+ Can build custom NPC adventurers whenever you want

- - - Classes are not nearly as unique as in classic CRPGs
- - No multi-class / dual-class, classes all have same XP chart for leveling
- - Leveling up doesn’t have the occasional power spike that was so satisfying in BG
- - No alignments! This affects companions most, more on that below

So to sum up there is a big tradeoff here: much deeper customization at the cost of much weaker character identity / personality on each character sheet. Is this modernization worth it? Depends on the player.

Modernized CombatIn general, combat in Pillars is much more enjoyable, though Baldur’s Gate still does some things better:

+++ More combat, challenging combat –closer to Icewind Dale than Baldur’s Gate
+++ Limited resting plus “per rest” and “per encounter”  system rounds out encounters!
++ Melee engagement completes the positional party-based combat feature-set
++ New damage-type and defense-type systems are excellently executed
+ New friend/foe AoE mechanics add a bit more depth
+ Modernized combat UI with AoE overlays decrease yolo-ness of spell-casting
+ Item enchanting adds customization to combat style

+/- In general, more abilities and options, less impact of each individual ability

- - - Spells and abilities feel nerfed compared to classic CRPGs
- - Not as many crazy encounters as in BG.
- - Challenge is more in mastering the system than in new encounters.
- AoEs everywhere, not enough single-target spells

Characters, Story & WritingFirst off: good effort by the new narrator, but not even close to the narrator of Baldur’s Gate!

Obsidian’s writing may be its greatest strength as a studio, and I would say that several of their sequel projects exceeded the writing quality of the original (Fallout: New Vegas, KOTOR2, Mask of the Betrayer).

In my opinion:
+++ Better high-level concept, deals with religion, philosophy and identity better
++ Original world, characters, etc. are extremely fleshed out
+ Main player arc is basically same story as BG, but written better

- - - BG still tells the small stories better, with more detail and broader range of outcome
- - Writing feels rushed sometimes

The companions, though, are where Pillars loses clearly to Baldur’s Gate:

- - - - - - - - - - Nothing close to a Minsc :(
- - - Less personality range of companions. Companions are not differentiated strongly
- - - Weaker classes and no alignments means companion identity and opinions are not as convincing
- - Companions rarely interact directly with other NPCs and events. When they do, feels forced.
- Less companions

Aside from my extreme Minsc bias (shared by many), Pillars has significant weaknesses in its systems-level representation of characters, and therefore clearly falls short of Baldur’s Gate in storytelling.

Content Design & Parameter DesignThe obvious complaint here is that Baldurs Gate is bigger, takes the player to more places, and exposes the player to a wider variety of characters and factions. No comparison can be made until Obsidian is done with the Pillars franchise– which hopefully will not be anytime soon.

However, in many cases, Pillars is too balanced and too accessible, leading to some significant drawbacks:

- - - In BG, you can walk into a random house and start a huge quest, not the case here
- - - Very few chances to permanently gain (or lose) stats
- - - Related to above: less consequences for decisions and therefore less interesting choices
- - - Conversation and NPC interaction in general is not as varied as in Baldur’s Gate
- - Only one stronghold type, less replayability with different classes / characters
- - In general, items feel less unique– especially when compared to Baldur’s Gate
- Curve of item acquisition is more linear, so no dramatic item-based power spikes
- Effect suppression system is healthy for game systems but disappointing for player

Pillars is not Torment, and was not designed to be, but its choices above make it modern at the expense of the “anything can happen” feel of Baldur’s Gate. As a role-playing game, the balance feels more like a smooth and guided experience– cleverly giving you the trappings of choice and freedom, while remaining very accessible.

The result is a game with strengths that most players will experience, but lacking in the varied details and unbalance that made Baldur’s Gate so special. I would submit that those small details: silly side-quests, ridiculously unfair interactions, huge amounts of content almost completely hidden, etc. They are the quintessence of the open-world RPG experience.

And still…There have been many advances to systems design since BG2, and Pillars exploits them to its full advantage. However, in many cases it does so at the expense of immersion. In the end, Obsidian has made conscious choices to make an experience that carries the torch of classic CRPGs in a new, accessible package. As they have said, Pillars does not replace the Infinity Engine games.

Pillars of Eternity is a great RPG, and the best RPG of the last decade. With updates, expansions and sequels it may become the greatest of all time.

But for now, and in my humble opinion, Baldur’s Gate retains its seat as the king of CRPGs.

reviewText:
Obsidian delivered again.

All their known qualities (world building, deep lore, profound story and characters) are present in this game. Combat system and exploration are also great. There are some cons here and there such as little unique loot, short companion quests and medium combat difficulty (at least on normal) but the potential is there for future installments to tap into it.

Most of rpgs in recent years are just a footnote to its magnificence. Pillars of Eternity is a classic of our times, prepare to be enthralled by it.

reviewText:
Best 120 hours of gaming I have spent. Quality from start till finish, and throughout every single side-step in between.

Pillars of Eternity is extremely well written. The stories are told in very rich language that is way above average even in fantasy literature. The game is one grand adventure and feels like reading/watching an epic and long story where it's up to you when and where the main characters will go and what course of action they will take. To fully appreciate this game you need to read  a lot of in-game texts, like books, dialogues with other characters, descriptions and all the information that shows up in your journal. And this is a very welcome gameplay element for me. Not only is it a pleasure to read due to how well written it is, it also fosters your own imagination.

I love everything about this game: the combat, the stories, the main story, the lore. But most of all I love it because it's a properly executed awesome and epic long adventure that I never wanted to end.

reviewText:
As a huge fan of the old Infinite Engine games like Baldur's Gate I had hoped for so much *more* from this game. Whilst it did much to modernise the genre, in many areas it failed to live up to the nostalgia.

Graphics - The game kept true to the art style whilst bringing it forwards into the modern era of gaming, the backdrops were breathtakingly beautiful and it played smoothly without any issues.

Sound/Voice Acting - The sound/voice acting wasn't particularly noteworthy, it wasn't terrible yet it wasnt great either, it didn't really stand out much.

Story-telling/narrative - The story was a bit vague and didn't really have much direction during the first act but it quickly picked up during the second act before slowly tapering off towards the end. There weren't any really exciting revelations or twists that made it wow me. The villain, their motivations and relationship to the protagonist were somewhat interesting but it wasn't anything that stood out. Often at times to convey just how filled out the world and backstory was you're presented with a wall of text which probably wasn't necessary and felt like it detracted from the story at times.

Gameplay Mechanics/Combat - This is probably the most disappointing aspect of the game. The game feels like it's more of a stealth crpg because they limited the experience gained from combat to just the first few initial run ins with each foe type and kept the overall experience gained from combat to a very minimal amount, along with the plethora of items that dropped from enemies being utterly useless, it often felt like the better choice was to sneak/avoid enemy encounters which just slows down the pace of the game. Avoiding combat entirely was also made more desirable by the fact that you were heavily penalised for trying to escape combat or run around or disengage with an enemy during combat which often resulted in the character dying quicker than had you just stayed in place and tried to (but likely fail to do so anyway) tank it.

Spell casting also felt more burdensome and tiring than in the older IE titles because of the resting mechanics of the game whereby you had to carry supplies to rest and were limited to only carry a certain amount of supplies with you, so if you ran out of supplies you were forced to return to a store to purchase more or not rest and not be able to heal, or restore spells for combat.

Itemisation - The difference between a normal, un-enchanted item and a unique item felt lacking. The difference in damage was minimal, I played as a barbarian and would do 80s with normal items and as high as 96 using a unique item of the same type. Another problem with the itemisation is that so many items gave boosts to player stats, but conflicting stat boosts (ie. gloves that give +1 might and boots that give +2 might) would be nullified meant that gearing most slots felt like a waste of time and forced players down the route of jack of all trades, master of none.

Overall I would rate this game as a 6/10, or in terms of similarities to the old IE games it has the combat of Planescape Torment with the story of Icewind Dale, it tries to relive the nostalgia but focuses on the wrong aspects of what made them great games.
