reviewText:
I'll keep this short for you: If you know what TSR, Black Isle, or Interplay are, you'll either nod knowingly or have things to flame me about, by the end of this. If not, you might have some poorly informed opinion-hate for me by the end, anyway. For safety's sake, if you still defend -- say, the D&D alignment system, assume you will hate this review, and me. Oh well.

BUCKLE UP AND BRANDISH YOUR D20'S!

This will come as a strange response, from a player of older cRPGs, such as the Baldur's Gate series, Icewind Dale, Neverwinter Nights, and Planescape Torment, but, after playing Pillars of Eternity through to its resolution, I suddenly come to realize that the Infinity engine has not aged well.

The entire game is plagued by cliches of Tabletop gaming, and does little, either to adapt them for PC gaming beyond what Baldur's Gate and its successors already did, or to turn the conventions harshly on their head, the way Planescape: Torment's story was able. Even most of the enemies are ripped remorselessly from your Saturday night campaign, and given mildly gaelic redubs; Ghouls are Guls, Vampires are Fampyrs, Banshees are Cean Gwla, but it's blatantly transparent. The variety of enemies is even drastically down, from say, Baldur's Gate II. (You've got your typical 'horrible' living dead, bad-mouthed bandits and fanatical ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ zealots, some slimes, some beasties, trolls, dryads, and dragons. Yay. I probably missed something and will be narked at about it. Bring me back killing my own mortality.)

Worse yet, I never felt the story came to any decent level of 'resolution', for my character--one needling plague of open-ended gameplay that eternally haunts.

For perspective for current gamers who are some five paragraphs in, and have never heard of Gary Gygax--if you felt like, say--the ending to Fallout 3 was stupid (having an anticlimactic final battle, being guilted to martyr yourself needlessly to someone else's morality, or suffering a lousy ending because you weren't a completionist when it came to sidequests), you'll feel cheated by the end of PoE, even when you think you're heading toward the ending you want--simply by the system of flags and scripts that determines what disappointing exposition scene you get. (No, Fawkes. You're not denying me my destiny, now get in the '♥♥♥♥ing' GECK chamber. I have a dog to walk away with while the narrator smugly talks about War. No, I am not buying the expansion DLC!)

While the end boss to PoE is wholeheartedly on the opposite end of the difficulty spectrum to Fallout 3's ending, you can bet that the outcome doesn't justify the effort.

Again for perspective, Torment's boss can be killed in dialogue, but provides a massively more satisfying resolution, that resonates with the overall 'message' of the game. The big bad of this game, by contrast, utterly refutes every line you throw, regardless of stats or what you've accomplished, to the point that you may as well fast-forward to immediate combat (--and past that, just turn on cheats, mouse over him and hit the key to shut him up.) Afterward, the game gives you the ending it has mathed out that you maybe could want, if Obsidian didn't have to spread itself thin covering all the bases (and you'd best bet they had to, the title was nearly their swan song.)

Even these things weren't dealbreakers, alone. What truly threw me out of the experience was simply reaching the end stretch of the game, and realizing just how little has changed from older cRPGs in the engine--in fact, in terms of gameplay, things have taken a backslide, in the sense that the descriptions for the function of many of PoE's items are vague at best, and the merits of many of the different stat tweaks and perks pale in comparison to just exploiting the shoddy AI of the Infinity engine. Many encounters I won simply by targetting a single difficult enemy and having a character run around in circles to distract it, or spamming summons and pinning the enemies in corners, while my expendable characters took their time shooting. And if I feel like I'm coming up with tricks to outsmart bits and bytes, and doing complex math before battles, rather than winning out of a sense of skill... welp... Screw math, I'll save that for making stock investments. Back to games that make me care, rather than teabagging my corpse over algebra.

MY BURNING QUESTION: IS +10 WILL more valuable than HITTING THINGS FOR 1.2x more DAMAGE?! I HAVE NO IDEA.

What made sense as a general guideline for pen-and-paper get togethers over chips and Mountain Dew has never worked particularly well as filler for functional gameplay, on Infinity's part. Hearing the same statistical song and dance try to dress up as something new and improved over twenty years later just makes me groan.

Point in Case: Borderlands 2 has a jumbled mess of statistics handed to me to sort out, for its guns--but I can tell what 'fire rate' or 'pellet count' or 'reload speed' are, without a glossary. If I get an amazing weapon, I can tell it's amazing at a glance, and it feels like an event. I know what elements on weapons are effective against what kinds of threats, at a glance, without a monster encylopedia. More to the point, the struggles of Roland and the Crimson Raiders, and the humour of characters like Hammerlock and Claptrap, keep me going in spite of needless number crunches that the devs may as well have handled. Pillars of Eternity gets as far as 'telling' me to care, and then 'literally' sets all my efforts on fire to advance its shallow tale, within the second act.

One particularly egregious example: I kill a raving mad local lord who is driving his village into extinction, and appoint his idealistic cousin as successor. By the end of my overly arduous final boss-fight, hidden numbers assigned with dealing out the game's ending montage have determined that my old foe gets up from being dead, goes even crazier, and wipes out everyone in said village before the end credits can even roll. And I have no say in it--how was I supposed to forecast that?  ♥♥♥♥ move, game. Imagine if Handsome Jack got away with nuking Sanctuary despite your best efforts defeating the Warrior, in Borderlands 2. How lame would that be?

But since I'm not twinking out six me's with optimum gear and stats, maybe I'm not doing something right. I'll never know--I'll be playing other things. Tip for you geniuses of metagaming preparing to flame me: none of the enemies provide combat exp, and the level of encounters scales with your level. Fighting trash mobs produces equivalent results to running to the far end of the room. Have fun with your grind.

In summary: Pillars of Eternity neither renews the Infinity engine's myriad wrinkles, nor does it tell a particularly fresh or engaging tale. It's not particularly horrible either--just woefully over-promising, mediocrity on all counts. It was a lukewarm reminder that old things can get a second chance to show how well they've festered, and that's all a good little twink can ask for: spoilt milk and stale cookies with a great big fat +10 to some stat I'll have to look up the applications for, on the end.

There's always Torment: Tides of Numenara, coming Q4, right?

reviewText:
This is the game I was waiting for. Controlling a huge party and micro managing all their abilities. No more online mmorpgs for me for a long time. I can make my own party and go into dungeons and battle Epic bosses to satisfy my ego, and I do not have to repeat fights because of other people's mistakes. I only have myself to blame if i make mistakes.
I thought Skyrim did it for me, I thought Diablo did it for me, I thought Dragonage did it for me and it was the closest, but finally this game nailed it.
If you complain about the game's graphics please leave now. It has enough graphics to keep fans of this genre interested. I do not have problems with bugs, I have no idea why people cry about them so much, I just step on them if I ever see any.

Warning: This game will deprive you from sleep. Play with caution.

reviewText:
The time has come for me to review my first game, and so it shall be Pillars of Eternity.

So far the game has enthralled me with musical cues, surprisingly intricate graphics, and a gripping storyline. The text-driven story has me acting out the scenes to myself, physically, and mentally.

I was unsure of how this kind of game would play out in this day in age, being a veteran of this style of game, but Pillars of Eternity proved that it can still hold up to today's gaming needs. After over a decade of watered down, run of the mill games that I have played, this is a breath of fresh air.

I can finally enjoy role-playing again.

Thank you Obsidian Entertainment.

reviewText: I really wish I didn't buy this game. There are so many awful design choices (or oversights) that ruin the experience. The gameplay basically boils down to having your tank in the front and having as little melee as possible. It's so immersion breaking that, in order to make your crew more effective, you don't use armor to make sure they refresh faster. There are tons of cheap fights where enemies spawn on top of you (spectres) or you enter a room and you engage in a fight right off the bat and your guys are in a terrible formation and just get slaughtered.\n\nI was doing fine for awhile until I couldn't beat certain fights and then I learned that simply having all your characters use ranged weapons (preferably guns) without wearing armor is the best way to go. It totally killed the game knowing that's how you roll through this game.

reviewText: This is one damn fine game. It takes a classic formula and breathes new life to it in the form of a modern game with modern production values but all the atmosphere of the original Infinity Engine games. In addition, it takes a careful look at the mechanics, not tied to the AD&D rules, and sets about determining what works and should be kept essentially as is, what doesn't and should be either jettisoned or improved, and what new things could be brought in to further improve the formula. The result is a game that, while not without flaws, is not just a worthy follower to classics like Baldur's Gate but an improvement in most ways that count. The main thing the game could be improved with would be a slightly larger selection of companions.\n\nStill, if you're fan of cerebral, atmospheric CRPGs with lots of reading, good world-building and slick but not simplified mechanics, this game is for you.

reviewText:
129 Hours Later, Finished! (Thoughts On The Game)

First off a big thank you to Obsidian for such a wonderful game and second, thanks to all the kickstarter backers. I was only able to back the amount for the game (25 or 35) and I also added on the addition for the beta backer later on, so a huge thank you to the backers who put in the big money! Now onto my thoughts on the game!

The things I loved:

- Writing was fantastic, from the dialogue to the story to the characters, wonderful writing once again Obsidian

- Art Design is so beautiful, seriously... so seriously, love it

- Combat is fun, at first I wasn't to sure about it but I have grown to love it. While not 100% perfect, it is a well done combat system.

- Soundtrack is fantastic, really sets the atmosphere for me as I am exploring or going along my adventures

- The Stronghold is a cool idea and i like it, but it was def not perfect, alot could be added to this aspect in an expansion pack

- Had zero crashes, no fps issues, no gamebreaking bugs and no broken quests.

- Some of the decisions I had to make had me really thinking about it

- Atmosphere is very well done

- Enjoyable final fight!

- The character creation and classes I feel are all well done


Things I didn't like or that I think can be improved:

- The Pathfinding was honestly my biggest issue. There was times when I would tell guys to go attack this game and they would either try and go the long way or try and go through another player. Some other times moving around cities one would get stuck on something. Nothing gamebreaking but this was the biggest thing that annoyed me during my time with the game.

- The Stronghold could be alot better, while I enjoyed it and think its improved over Inquisition and Dragon Age Awakening, it could still use some improvements. Maybe more things to build? A type of trial aspect where you decide on issues people have? Give us more options as to what we can do with prisoners and allow more random people to come and live in your stronghold.



Things That could be added for expansion pack:

- A coop mode like Divinity Original Sin for an expansion pack? As much as I loved this game, I think it would be even more fun if I could play the campaign with ONE friend (as long as it didn't effect the singleplayer)

- More character Portraits next time. I love that we can import our own, but in future expansion packs maybe get the artists to do a handful more with more variety for difference races,etc..

Love the game! I enjoyed Divinity Original Sin, Wasteland 2 and Shadowrun Dragonfall last year but this is even better imo. So wonderful to see this revival of a genre that was my favorite for so many years. Here is to more Pillars Of Eternity, more CRPG's in general in gaming and more Obsidian magic.

Someone asked me for a score, I don't usually give out scores, I prefer just writing thoughts on the game. But, I can appreciate any review score from 8 to 10. If you had a gun to my head and asked for a score though? I would say its a 9.5/10 for me personally. Not perfect but a hell of a wonderful experience! I have liked so many Black Isle and Obsidian games over the years, but you really didn't fool around with this game did you!

I know there is a tank game coming from Obsidian and another unannounced game and two expansion packs for Pillars in the future, hope to see many more rpg's from Obsidian in the future, keep up the wonderful work! I have to deal with chronic pain every day so when a nice rpg like this comes around (or a good foreign movie or book/tv show,etc..) and has the ability to pull me into its world so well with and take my mind off of things it is a wonderful thing. Thank you Obsidian, I can tell this game was crafted with love!

reviewText:
Note: I recommend installing on an SSD in order to reduce load times, especially if you’re a meticulous explorer type. You can also use a mod to disable auto-saving, but remember to quick save/manual save occasionally.

Pillars of Eternity, a beautifully crafted crpg filled to the brim with content, will hold your attention for a long time. A single playthrough can easily take over 70+ hours depending on how much of the world and quests you to decide to explore. I spent hours reading as many in-game books as I could and even spent some time reading the bestiary. There's even a character journal that'll summarize the things you've done in the game. You can also expect your choices to affect outcomes and your reputation with people and factions. This game is extremely dense and I suggest not rushing through it. Take your time and enjoy yourself. At this point in time, the game is also much more stable than when it first released. They supported the game with patches that solved many issues and squashed interfering bugs. They’ll continue to support with version 2.0 in the future which will add more functionality.

Freedom of Choice

This game’s degree of freedom and consequences lends itself well to roleplaying and being the character you want to be whether that’s a vengeful barbarian, a monk that’s just trying to set things right, or even a gigantic jerkface. Most of quests have multiple outcomes depending on your actions. Dialogue choices are abundant too and your character stats/background can also affect what you might be able to say. Sometimes the extra responses are for flavor or can result in a fight being completely avoided. Keep that in mind should you decide to have a smooth-talking intelligent character or a mighty sort of person who intimidates. All of the main stats can influence conversations, but some do so much more often than others such as Intelligence and Resolve. If you really wanted to, you could just fly through the game solo, though I’d expect more talking and sneaking around if you chose that kind of path.

Graphics

The game's art assets look fantastic for the most part. I only noticed a building or two and maybe some walls that appeared to be in a low resolution compared to the rest of the game. Just don't zoom in all the way and keep the camera at an appropriate distance, things become blurry if you go in all the way. Every place in the game is a work of art. I especially like the leaves on trees. The trees are gorgeous as are the big, scary spells in the game. It’s quite the sight when a druid calls down a thunderstorm. It’s a beautiful game. Hmm, I suppose I should mention the character models are a bit funny looking since they’re usually seen from an isometric view until you’re in the inventory screen. Also, please try big head mode at least once.

Story

I thought the story was fine for the most part, but my efforts and interests focused on everything else since I wanted to do as much as possible. I’ll be unspecific to avoid spoilers. The world is a dark place filled with murder, vengeance, and betrayal. The side-quests benefit from the settings by doing interesting things with it. It felt good to vanquish foes that I thought were deserving since my monk didn’t like liars or murderers in general. I thought the main villain’s motivations were interesting and how far he went to accomplish his goals went beyond insanity. The companion storylines/quests might be a mixed bag for some people, but I did end up liking most of them all except for Kana and Pallegina. Pallegina was definitely underutilized and should have had a more fleshed out companion quest. Kana was an interesting person, but his quest seemed underwhelming. On the other hand, Durance and Grieving Mother had some fantastic storylines. I highly recommend seeing the quests of those two to the end. There’s plenty of story to find and read. Even the unique items have different legends associated with them. Some of them function like tragic short stories and are told well.

Combat

The combat is a mixture of real-time and turn-based in the sense that you can pause the game mid-combat and issue orders to your party. You can also change the settings to have the game auto-pause when certain conditions are met like low Endurance or when someone is knocked out. I found normal to be somewhat easy for the most part after I had a full party of six members. The game’s difficult encounters still had me pausing and considering my movement and orders very carefully. “Okay, I need a damage reduction buff here. You’ll make it rain thunderbolts, you two try and knock the big guy down, and I’ll have you summon some shades.” The combat has a nice amount of complexity to it when you come across a worthy challenge. If you decide to not have such a large party, then you can expect the game to become harder if combat is your primary way of handling situations. Pause often and succeed, this is not meant to be a 100% real-time experience.

Hopefully Pillars entertains you for a long time if it’s your type of game. It has much to offer unless you hate reading, but if you play, you’ll have the added benefit of an increased reading stat. Hooray.

reviewText:
As a long-time lover of isometric RPGs such as PS:T and BG, this game looked remarkably promising. Being a part of the kickstarter since its infancy, I followed this game for years and was very eager to play by the time it was released.

The game was an overwhelming disapointment.

The mechanics were not transparent, most of the spells were unoriginal and unused, magic items had absolutely no personality, NPCs were mediocre, and the plot was ham-fisted.

On the plus side, it's pretty. That's about it. This is not the revival of iso fantasy RPGs many were hoping for; it's a botched attempt to pander to a dying group.

reviewText:
Inspired by the games I grew up playing like Baldur's Gate, Icewind Dale and Planescape Torment, to name a few, Pillars of Eternity is by far the best isometric RPG to come out in years. A new and exciting world to explore, a deep and intruiging story, oodles of customization and everything else that no doubt already has you feeling nostalgic about the good old days and how RPG's used to be. You should be playing this game, or at the very least be watching someone else play it. I've spent a good 15 hours in Pillars of Eternity and just can't get enough, loving every moment of it.

Go now, gather your party, and venture forth into this adventure that should last you the better part of 70 hours!

reviewText:
It took me 50 hours to play it through in a rather slow and calm kind of way. While it obviously cannot nearly keep up to the amount of content of a Baldur's Gate II, (lenght of the campaign, amount of optional quests, interesting storylines), it yet does some things better than its predecessors.

It is in every sense indeed a game for adults. Dialogues are very well-conceived and sophisticated, and so is the whole background of the story and this new world. Prepare yourself for a LOT of careful reading, if you want to really understand what's going on and take some insights from this game. If you don't, there is still a very good tactical fighting system to explore, but that's obviously not the major purpose here.

You find yourself confronted with truly hard moral decisions, where you really have to think about what's right and what's wrong. That is so because the game gives you absolutely no hints where things might lead you or what is now the good character"-choice. Sometimes I found myself staring for five minutes on some dialogue options before i chose one
date: thinking really hard what to answer. The game
hoursPlayed: rewards you for the effort
voteText: building plausible consequences even on the nuances of how your character behaves and what he says.\n\nThere is no black and white and grey like we are used to from the fantasy genre. Every situation is unique
helpfulPercent: and sometimes several or even all options lead to consequences that you can't morally justify
votesHelpful:
but yet you have to come to a decision!

It's just like in the real world.

That's why i liked this game."

reviewText:
So let me start by saying that this is A Very Good Game (tm).

I was a bit pessimistic about it -- after all, how many times has Obsidian come so close to releasing a truly great game, yet failed to completely deliver (granted, often through no fault of their own). I got to play a bit of Pillars at Gamescom last summer and was left feeling pretty meh about it. In hindsight this was probably more because the limited time I had to play it wasn't enough to really properly get" the game from the very beginning.

The writing is very Obsidian
date: and the worldbuilding is deep and complex. After a few hours in
recommended: I can already see Obsidian's trademark moral choices everywhere
hoursPlayed: and they definitely appreciate the shades of grey that they always have. Some of the choices you're forced to make leave you seriously wondering if you're -actually- supporting the good/bad guys

reviewText:
Do you enjoy spending hours at a time working on a branching questline only for all of your actions to be rendered completely pointless? Do you like micromanaging obtuse and obsolete game mechanics? Do you want a game that throws all its potential out a window in favour of being 'safe'? Then boy do I have a game for you!

Pillars of Eternity presents itself as a throwback to the classic CRPGs, like Baldur's Gate and Planescape: Torment. However, it actually comes across as a game made by people who liked those games but did not understand why they were good. Pillars throws at you the trappings of choice, of an interactive world, of interactive design, but does not actually include these in any meaningful way.
As an example, let's look at character creation. You're presented with a half-dozen options for races, all with different stats and backstory, then a handful of different class options based on the traditional DnD classes (fighter, wizard, rogue, bard, etc.) and then finish up with options for personalising the character's backstory, appearance, etc. Sounds great, right? Just what you'd expect. But when you come to actually play the game, you'll find that none of it really matters. The classes really just resolve into ranged" and "not ranged"
date: and everything else is just fluff. Your actual playstyle will be exactly the same whether you play a big
hoursPlayed: sneaky rogue. The character options present different possibilities for interacting with the world
voteText: but these almost never actually come up in the story. If you play as a goblin (I don't care what you actually call them
helpfulPercent: they're still goblins)
votesHelpful: the game will tell you that your race is hated and discriminated against. This came up ONCE
votesTotal: in the 20-odd hours I wasted on this game. In a single option
votesFunny: hidden behind another conversation option
commentsCount: while talking with a single minor character.\n\nQuests and storylines may have multiple ways of approaching them
column16: and multiple ways of progressing
column17: but almost all that I played ultimately had only one single outcome
column18: which had nothing at all to do with what I did. You can spend hours at a time working carefully on choosing which faction you're going to support
column19: choosing which quests to do for that faction
column20: deciding how you're going to accomplish your quests from the several options presented to you
column21: weighing the pros and cons of each possible outcome
column22: only for all of this to be rendered pointless when the storyline progresses with absolutely no impact from you or your actions. The writers are determined to tell you their story
column23: despite what you do
column24: without you being involved in that story. There is no real choice
column25: no actual 'multiple paths' as advertised
column26: there is just "well
column27: that's nice
column28: now here's what is ACTUALLY going to happen."\n\nUltimately my problem with this game is that there is no real choice in anything. It is a crude imitation of what came before
column29: with nothing new to add or innovations to include. 20 years ago
column30: this game would have been a brilliant new addition to the CRPG library. It would have stood up against the best of its genre. Unfortunately
column31: it's not 20 years ago. But I don't think the developers know that."

reviewText:
Heard about this game from a freind of mine who got me to play Baldurs Gate I + II. Seeing a huge improvement in graphics which is something that catches my eyes I'm so satisfied with this purchase.  The ability to go around fight, quest, explore, strategize is incredibly enjoyable. Even if it did take me five tries to kill the first Drake I encountered.

If you're not sure about picking up this high quality, well done peice of art check out youtube videos and some streams. I'm sure your interested will be piqued and I'll garentee you would pick up the game if you can afford it. (Worth every cent).

Adding on since I was rushing for this review.

It has enough modes to challenege all levels of intensity you may want in a RPG. I have seen little or no limits as to what you're able to do in game. Many hours of exploration, questing even improving your own Fortress, Keep, Man/Woman Cave whatever you want to call it.

Overall this game is  a 10/10 Must buy for me.

reviewText:
Here is my impression.

This is pure excellence. Pillars of Excellence should be it's freaking title.

This is THE successor we've been waiting for from BG1/2. I just love this game so much so far after encountering disapointment after disapointment from the AAA RPGs.

I'll even make a bold claim and say it's better than the first baldur's gate (so far). Here I said it.

The story is good (so far), the world/lore is interesting even though it has some classism to it, the writing is impressive for a game, the game is challenging (on hard for me), the combat are fun little puzzles...

It's everything you could have hoped for from a successor but with:
- FAR far better UI (some strealining for inventory management etc...).
- Cute Living story" elements when interacting with the world. Kickstarter project so no cinematics and instead you'll get drawings and texts.
- Interesting combats right outside of the tutorial area. BG1 was really lacking with your level 1 characters and many classes having no special skills. Here I played a Cipher and quickly teamed up with a Wizard and a Fighter. I have a good amount of skills to play right at the beginning and on hard difficulty it's 100% needed.
-The stat system is a lot more intuitive and explained through tooltips.

Some may dislike the disengagement system (attacks of opportunity) but there are 0 reason for a fan of the old cRpg to skip that one. None."

reviewText:
“She’s a goddess, as fickle as they come… and with all the failings you’d expect of an empress and a ♥♥♥♥♥”, Durance says to me in his growly voice. He is a priest talking about his own goddess Magran in whose name he helped kill Waidwen (who claimed to be the living vessel of the god Eothas) during the Saint’s War. Such is the relationship between gods and people in Pillars of Eternity. Gods are not abstract terms used only in blind faith, they are among us every step of the way providing blessing and punishment as they see fit. They are deeply woven within the very fabric of society, with everyone opting for a god to serve and follow. As you start your journey, you learn of Waidwen’s Legacy, a horrible plague beset upon the people of Dyrwood which sees their newborn come into the world soulless. It is definitely true that faith and religion are overarching themes in Pillars of Eternity, but it’s the liberty to create a personal touch provided by Obsidian that makes it so compelling.

You witness a strange ritual at the beginning of the game and something strange happens to you. From there, your motivations are up to you. Nobody designates you as the would-be savior of the world, nobody even tasks you to look into Waidwen’s Legacy. You are simply a person making his way through the world designing your own motivations and choosing your own actions. It was this aspect of the game that I found most liberating and compelling. Too often in games you are simply tasked and/or commanded what to do with clear goals set before you. Pillars of Eternity removes all that which makes the whole journey very organic and natural. It’s devoid of that silly feeling of clearly knowing you have something grand to do, but you simply opt to do a lot of things on the side despite everyone constantly reminding you how the world’s fate rests in your hands. This may be a subtle effect, but I found it extremely refreshing and compelling.

Obsidian was clear on what it set out to do with Pillars of Eternity, it is definitely a throwback to classic Infinity engine games most notably Baldur’s Gate and Icewind Dale. It even looks the part with its rather simplistic 2D graphics that will instantly remind anyone of those glory days of computer RPGs. However, even though Obsidian didn’t really push any big new ideas, Pillars of Eternity is still very much imbued with many modern takes on what we’ve seen and played a long time ago. The visuals aren’t going to blow anyone away, but the 3D character models, some very nice effects and a strong art style go a long way to make it visually appealing, even gorgeous at times.

The combat is real-time with pause, very reminiscent of the first Dragon Age. It is highly tactical with plenty of abilities, spells and traps to choose from. The only problem regarding the combat is the atrociously bad pathfinding. Outside of combat, it works perfectly fine, but during combat, characters will very often get stuck on walls, obstacles and each other requiring you to very closely monitor everything that is going on and manually select each character to get them out of a bind, particularly in confined areas. This can be alleviated to a degree by smart group formation and a bit of micromanagement, but that shouldn’t be necessary. What’s different about the combat is its emphasis on endurance over health. Monitoring health is a long-term affair in each battle, but a far more pressing matter is each character’s endurance level. As they receive damage, their endurance decreases, if it reaches zero, they get knocked out. There are ways to get fallen members back up again and certain classes specialize in such abilities. However, if any character’s health should reach zero, it’s game over for that particular character. So it is possible to lose designed party members for good. However, you can create your own party members at taverns for a fee. There is a large number of character classes and races to choose from, some of which are rather unique such as the cipher class or the godlike race. The downside is the extremely low level cap (12).

The game world is very big, there are quite a lot of different and interesting locations to visit from your map view whereas each location is spacious yet not overwhelming. You will also get your own stronghold ruin at one point which you will be able to build up again and receive various benefits. The best thing about the stronghold is that it hides a massive dungeon consisting of 15 levels and a nasty boss fight at the end. What is overwhelming at times is the lore and dialogue which sometimes goes on for too long. Also, the writing, while generally very good, can get a bit opaque. The main story is interesting, it raises many questions, but leaves the conclusions up to the player. There is a great number of choices to be made throughout the game and a lot of them will be addressed at the very end.

There’s a lot to love about Pillars of Eternity. The way it liberates players by letting them play their own way at their own pace through the story, by letting them decide on both their motivations and actions, the interesting game world and lore, memorable characters and a very tactical combat system. By liberating themselves from existing worlds and publisher demands, Obsidian had complete control to create their best game to date and one of the best RPGs in recent years.

9 OUT OF 10 (SUPERB)

reviewText:
I'm a huge fans of Chris Avellone and Obsidian Entertainment.
However, I will comment this game very honestly. This game I rated for (6/10) because it does not hit my expectation.
It is a good/OK game. I do not recommend to buy this game based on the current price.

<Pro>
Great Graphics
Improved UI of the baldur's gate version. Awesome weather effects, detailed surroundings.

Endurance System
Great introduction of the endurance system that affects the Health Point system.

Event Sandbox mode:
User action based that on the stats is good concept.

Warden System:
It is a better game grinding version of Caed Nua Levels.

<Less Impressive>
Storyline:
There is no breakthrough in the storyline. The reincarnation that retain the previous life memory is just too lame to be rewritten again and again in so many games and novels. If you are expecting Torment or Fallout 2 level of storyline, you might be disappointed. It's still an overall OK storyline.

Stronghold:
The concept is awesome but the system not impressive. It allows you idle NPC to join the adventure and get items/exp. The shops inside your stronghold sell normal stuffs that can be bought from any NPC sellers you find in the game. To travel all the way (very long hours/days) to get the a free rest bonus is redundant, you could get a better rest bonus at very cheap rate in any Inn.

Dungeons:
Basically you just hold  5-6 prisoners of the game. That's it. You mihght get rare items in exchange the prisoners but is entirely unnecesary in this game.

Caed Nua Levels:
Basically is designated for the player who likes to grind the game to prolong the game play hours.

Godlike Race:
The only race that is stood-out in this game. The rest are just the replica of the typical elves, dwarfs, halflings race with different names.

<Cons>
Bad combat system:
There is no tactical position neceasary for your NPC. The easiest way to win the combat is group your teamates all togather and wait for the enemy to come to attack you. All you need to do is slow mode or pause the game to spam your spells and skills.

Buggy combat system: The characters always got stucked or take the longer/danger route to reach enemy.

Boring Side Quests: The side quests are easy, boring and insignificant. It does not really impact too much on the storyline but only the epilodges. The only side quest that capture my attention is the Undying Heritage.

Unmotivated Main Quest:
Basically you are just chasing an old man who did 'something' on you. There is no 'A MUST' reason to motivate you to continue the main quest. You could just live at your stronghold for the rest of your life.

reviewText: Pillars of Eternity was expressly created as an homage to the Infinity Engine games; the interface and beautiful painted backgrounds definitely make it look the part.  But what made games like Baldur’s Gate, Icewind Dale, and Planescape so special was more than just an aesthetic: they were vast, sprawling settings with epic stories that delivered engaging tactical encounters.  And when judged by those criteria, I feel that Pillars of Eternity is a worthy successor to carry on the legacy of the Infinity Engine.  Though the loss of the AD&D engine and settings does take some getting used to, the mechanics are solid and the world is compelling and fun to discover.  It’s an easy recommendation for fans of of the Infinity Engine and I’d also recommend it for anyone interested in an engrossing quest through a fantastic land.

reviewText: Pillars of Eternity is the much anticipated spiritual successor to the Bioware Infinity Engine RPGs many of us loved (and some still do). If you enjoyed those games, Pillars is a must buy. If you didn't, Pillars probably won't change your find and it stays pretty true to that formula. Pillars is a party based RPG with a strong sense of story. It's personalized to your character by incorporating your character's traits into conversations with NPCs - for example, your knowledge of the wilderness or a reputation of being kind may open new options. The sheer number of ways Obsidian  accomplished this was one of the highlights of the game. Of course playing out the tactical battles is another large aspect to the game. While they are well done, too many of them were easy on hard difficulty while a smaller number were challenging. The game would have benefited from a better balancing of battles to provide a more uniform challenge. Quibbles aside, I recommend Pillars for fans of this type of game. You can find my full review here.[www.oneguytoomanygames.com]

reviewText:
A nostalgic romp in an original and engaging world. Obsidian has made good on it's promise to bring you a fantastic and unforgiving isometric RPG.

If you've played games like Baldurs Gate, or Planescape: Torment, then you know what you're getting into, but for the uninitiated, this is a text heavy roleplaying game. Instead of the constant grinding of enemies to level up associated with most similar games currently on the market, your experience will largely be rewarded from exploring new areas and completing quests, of which you'll find plenty.

This is not to say that the combat system was neglected, it is both engaging and relentless. You'll need to take control of your entire party (unless you choose to go solo) and plan your attacks and formations accordingly. A host of spells, abilities and talents help you maintain control of the battlefield in real time as you dispatch your foes and progress through an compelling and well written story. Definitely a contender for Game of the Year.

reviewText:
Pros:
+ Obsidian
+ Going on 80 hours and just got to the 2nd act (I prefer to chew on something great rather than swallow it whole)
+ Great story
+ Dialogue
+ Art direction
+ Depth of customization (including combat options such as slowing down time for better control, auto-pausing when encountering an enemy or not auto-pausing, etc.)
+ Nearly endless amounts of spells, upgrade options when levelling, and loot
+ Branching story and consequential decision making
+ Managing a stronghold provides some interesting options
+ Interesting factions
+ Great replability
+ Awesome enemy variability
+ Enchantments are actually worth a damn
+ PLENTY of stuff (quests, tasks, bounties, dungeon crawling) to do
+ A sprawling mega dungeon that will make fans of good old fashioned dungeon crawling do cartwheels

Neutral:
+- You don't gain experience points from regular battles with enemies (as with most RPGs) but from completing quests, at first this really irked me because I'm used to gaining XP from encounters but as you play you understand why they did it. This is more a positive than negative for me, but I placed it here because I can see some people not liking this aspect of the game.

Cons:
- Durance's ♥♥♥♥
- The game has to end

I honestly can't recommend this game enough, it can be daunting at first but stick with it and figure out what builds work for your playstyle and what strategies synergize and which don't. I promise you it's an incredibly rewarding experience.

reviewText:
Pillars of Eternity is an oldschool themed RPG which delivers on all aspects while staying true to the classic template of RPGs of 90ies. The story is captivating and intriguing, music is perfectly tuned to world setting, mechanics are solid and transparent, animators have done a great job as well and level design is plainly fantastic, it's an enormous pleasure to go through each one of them.

This is the game where you can go on an adventure and lose yourself in it. Only downside is that price tag could have been little lower. Otherwise it still is worth the original amount.

If you loved games like Baldur's Gate and Neverwinter Nights then you'll be right at home with this one!

9/10

reviewText:
This is an example of a game made to 'please the fans' rather that to have something actually enjoyable.
Because of the kickstarter they felt obliged to stick to an uninspired backbone that killed any possibility to create a great game by adding features organically. They rather had a list of thing they wanted to show that they had, for the fans, and rushed them into the game.

You can't make a game good because on paper its features look good. A good game is something that is crafted and tested iterativelly. Here the different ideas don't hold together properly.

On paper you have for example :

Good graphics
Lots of lore
'Innovative' class and combat system
'Innovative' xp system (combats give no xp)

In pratice:

Loading times between tiny maps are embarrassingly long. Unacceptable for a 2015 game that pretends to emulates a 2000 one.
I couldn't care less about the story, the characters. As it was said everywhere else, it looks like a collection of fan fictions.
Class system is dull, characters feel all the same.
Combats are a joke. You can't prepare for the combat before you engage the enemy (can't use spells and so on). Enemies are overpowered and even though there are lots of different lloking enemies in the game they don't feel very different. Abilities are boring and their effects interchangeable.

The xp system is an absolute joke. This game as 10 monsters per square meter and combats give absolutely no xp ??!!
Basically the entire game feels like a ripoff (I have barelly played it but I can imagine it is consistent trough the entire game).
Is it supposed to be more realistic? So gaining levels and improving your combat skill by doing stupid quests is more realistic than doing so by winning fights?
I will rephrase it : The entire purpose of experience points in this game is to improve combat related skills, but then combats give no experience?
This game drifts too far away from what normally makes a good game.  That idea of having to go back to town almost every fights because you need to sleep to regain your spells... In baldur's gate it was ok because you could outsmart/outpower your enemies with well thought tactics and items, but this game suffers from the tall poppy syndrome and there isn't much you can do to feel clever/good. You feel like you're playing the same way everyone is playing, like on a rail.
Apparently helmets in this game are purely decorative, give no stats. You can have an iron helm or a simple hat on your magician, it makes no difference. Is it for more realism, like the xp system?

In this game everything feels so generic, watered down. What a waste of crowdfunding money! They could have just copied baldur's gates mechanics with better graphics and made an awesome game but no, they had to 'dust it off'.

What worries me the most about this game is all the positive critiques it managed to get. It is neither an old school game nor a modern one, so what is it? What do people find in it ?

reviewerDisplayName: Bad Dad and the Sad Lads
reviewText:
Really liked the tactical combat in this game. Primarily emphasizes preparation, using narrow doorways to your advantage, and generally positioning your folks properly. This leads to delightfully varied and challenging encounters. Do note, however, that micromanagement is also an important part of combat (they even tell you that when you're choosing a difficulty level), so if you don't like that sorta stuff, this game might not be your cup of tea.

When it comes to story and such, I almost don't know where to begin. The world in this game is really creative and unique (just the fact that it's more of a fantasy version of the Age of Discovery rather than medieval Europe is refreshing), your companions are all interesting characters (really felt like I was friends with most of them, rather than being their leader), and since it's an Obsidian game, there are some really delicious philosophical ponderings here and there.

Special mention goes to all the different dialogue choices you can make, though. Instead of just being different solutions to quests and such, there are also plenty of options that exist solely for the sake of roleplaying, to further flesh out your character's motivations and so on. That's really neat.

If there's one major gripe I have with this game, though, it's that pathfinding can be really rubbish sometimes. Seeing folks politely waiting behind their allies because they don't realise they could go around that guy in order to bludgeon someone is something that happens too often.

Oh yeah, and you can get at least three cats and a piglet in this game (but you can't give them little hats or armors, which I hope will be remedied in a future expansion).

reviewText:
A great retro-style, isometric view RPG, probably the best of its kind since Dragon Age: Origins. Though the writing quality is uneven, with some names feeling as though they came out of a fantasy name generator and some plotlines being disappointingly anticlimactic, the narrative as a whole and most of the major side quests are extraordinarily well designed. This, paired with the game's beuatiful, painterly art style and the amount of freedom granted to the player in terms of narrative choices are what makes the game worth playing.

The game is not without its faults: the level of cap of 12 is too low for a game with so much to do, and if you're the sort of player who likes to complete all side quests, you'll find yourself reaching it long before the final dungeon. The megadungeon which forms a major side quest in the game is irritatingly grindy, with interesting points popping up so rarely in between frequently redundant battles as to make the trek through the entirety of it rather infuriating. Finally, and perhaps most problematically, the game's mechanics are a mess: skills, attributes, the array of 8 different damages, and a confused jumble of traits intertwined together just feel incongruous and make no intuitive sense.

Despite all of that, however, the excellent storytelling and fascinating lore of the world are what make this game shine. All in all: a fantastic throwback.

reviewText:
Pros:
-Good visual style, nice graphics.
-Story is decent, except for the 4th wall breaking kickstarter content.
-Some of the weapons are amusing.

Cons:
-The stats of your character don't really matter except for combat, and even there, they matter surprisingly little.
-The classes are very similar to one another
-Combat is extremely repetitive: There isn't much variety on how to build your characters, and once you build them, you always fight every combat in exactly the same way
-There is very little or no skill involved in the actual combat: The side which can out-tank the other wins.
-The kickstarter content ruins the immersion. You can't even wander the woods without running into some flame-haired ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ with a unique and involving" backstory.
-You can't even talk with those stupid kickstarter npcs. They just stand about everywhere like flame-haired signposts

It's not a completely worthless game

reviewText:
Baldur's Gate 9/10
PoE 7/10

Finally!
I heard about this game in 2012. Now it is finally released.
PoE is a trip down the memory lane. I am an old guy and have been waiting 15 years for something like this to happen.
I am a big rpg fan, have been playing tabletop and lots of crpg's.
So should you get this game. Did you ever play Baldur's Gate? Did you like it? Then get this!!

Obsidian pitched this game as a spiritual successor of the old IE games (Baldur's Gate) and it is. The rules are different, as this is NOT D&D. But the feel, the mood, the sound and even the graphics (though very updated, it's been 15 years) reminds me so much of the good old days.

That beeing said the game is not flawless. But I have been playing 15 hours with no major bugs.
There are many small bugs though, but compared to other releases. it is running quite smooth... Even on my old machine (but I do have problems on the big maps, and with loading screen time)

If I should warn ppl about anything, it would be the differences from the old IE games. Yes there are many.
The things that I personally find a little strange:
*The game is build with Unity, I would have preferred Obsidians own engine. Unity have ALOT of performance issues...
*No ammunition. I miss this from IE.
*Can't costumize your char in-game. Very bad. Not even change the portrait or voice!! (fixed in patch1.05)
*Stash (like your bag of holding) can't be sorted... (also fixed)
*Some npc's that join you are REALLY weak
*False options in dialogue.
*Un-necessary hand-holding
*Most chars you can build, are perhaps too similair. I have to play more, though

I am waiting for Obsidian to release their first patch, and that will hopefully take care of most of the problems. It is certainly their best release ever ...

ADDED: So, now that I've played through this, I must also warn about a mediacroe story, and this is not very replayable... There is still some issues with UNITY, that engine is really hard on your CPU, and I guess I am dissappointed in the minimum specs, that kept going up, my PC was brandnew when I bought this (pre) and I can hardly make it run smooth...

reviewText: I'd have loved to love this game. From the outside it looks just like I'd want a modern successor to the Baldur's Gate and the Planescape stlye of RPG to look. And indeed it's gorgeous. It looks and sounds just right. But I just can't seem to be able to play it right. I simply keep getting killed. On the easiest settings. Repeatedly. I can't make heads nor tails of the spells (most of them seem to buff some ability I've never read of by 0.5%) nor of the combat system in general. Which is a pity cause everything looks so great. But now, almost 10 hours into the game I don't think I've progressed further than discovering the first hints of what the plot would have been about. I mean, I can live with a low power level. But I'd far prefer my wizard to have a magic missile and my cleric to have a simple healing spell instead of just some obscure buffs or offensive debuffs. In my days the only buff we had was the Bless spell (and, seriously, who ever really used that one?)...\n\nI'll be deinstalling the game to free up HD space again, but I feel sorry that I'm missing out on what appears to be a great game for others. But it's just too complicated for me. And I *did* finish Planescape. Thrice.

reviewText:
Baldur's Gate I & II are huge shoes to fill, but the ol' timers did a great job of it.  I love this game.  I'm gonna start with the negatives, but mind you these are critiques coming from a caring family member, not a nagging spouse.  And the source for a lot of this is me being Baldur's Gate #1 fan, so... yeah.

The :(
At times it feels a little combat-heavy, but that might be because I obsessively explore every little cranny and categorically slay anything with a red circle underneath it.
Things are streamlined quite a bit compared to BG (much like Dungeons and Dragons 4th Edition was compared to previous versions).  It's also a positive, but the negative is, well, as awesome as it is to magically throw a battalion's worth of equipment into your stash throughout a long day of wholesale slaughter, and as convenient as it is to sleep off 500+ damage around what must be one magic campfire, it does tap a little bit on the fourth wall. And the 4th Edition style Per Encounter abilities are a little silly :\ (This is really about me not liking 4th Edition Dungeons & Dragons).  And the ranger's animal companion can't die (only get knocked out), so I have to roleplay him off as a crazy dog whose nickname is Lucky.
The biggest one: PoE doesn't *quite* reach the level of character inspiration that Baldur's Gate had.  I think the voice acting is almost as good, for the most part (and still far, far, far above average), but there's not much of the miniature-giant-space-hamster, Ned (forgot his name) repeatedly talking to you and thanking you for not throwing rocks at him, Jaheira's Yyess

reviewText: As you can see from my hours played I tried greatly to enjoy this game.  Whilst this game attempts to harken back to the good ole days" of Baldur's Gate and other isometric crpgs
date: Pillars of Eternity feels bland and suffers from some major game breaking bugs cropping up in each patch cycle.\n\nWith each patch cycle Obsidian makes changes to the stat
recommended: ability and buff/debuff mechanics in what is an already convoluted system
hoursPlayed: not to mention the myriad of bugs that such a cycle brings.   Having to thoroughly read through patch notes to understand what over-the-top changes have been made can be frustrating.  Obsidian also seems to make changes to mechanics and systems that work fine whilst seemingly ignoring broken classes and abilties.\n\nThe combat becomes tedious very quickly
voteText: usually involving bottling up your adversaries in a choke point and autoattacking them until dead.  When you do decide to use spells or abilities you will quickly find that a majority of them are completely useless
helpfulPercent: whilst those that cause stun or knockdowns to be king.\n\nAt those times that you are unable to keep your enemy hemmed in
votesHelpful:
you will find those carefully crafted tank characters will be next to useless in keeping the enemies of your squishy damage dealers.  The fault here is with the poorly implemented engagement system.  A tank has the ability to 'engage' an enemy and should that enemy leave the area from the tank they will take a hit.  Of course this hit does nothing to actually stop an enemy from casually walking over and making paste of your rogue or wizard.   I won't detail the number of enemy creatures in this game that can just bypass the engagement system by teleporting straight into your group's back ranks and perma-stunning or killing them in two or three hits.  This problem has only gotten worse with the new expansion.

The itemization for character equipment is dull.  After a lengthy dungeon crawl of tedious fights to find items that are mostly yawn worthy was very disappointing.

The writing in the game seems to peak and trough.  The companions and their storylines seem to vary from interesting to just mind numbling boring.  The lore itself comes at your thick and fast with exposition upon exposition though with the latter it takes too many liberties by assuming you already know some hidden but integral world lore.  This can affect your conversation choices
votesTotal:
though admittedly that is not a big deal as your choices in the end really mean nothing.  The authors are telling a story and be damned if you are going to have really influence on how that is going to be told.

On a few positive notes the graphics are very good and I absolutely adore the music.  Many times during my day I've caught myself humming the music from the game.

If you want to try the game
votesFunny: do so!  Just wait until it is on sale.  The price for non backers is astounding when you compare it other rpg styles games released in the same time that offer a whole lot more."

reviewText:
I'm new to CRPG, but I have been gaming on commodore as a child up to RTS and FPS on PC and other consoles. So I believe I've got a great idea of a good game and this is a brilliant game!

First off, the customisation of your character at the start is immense.

Second, much like fable, Mass effect and other RPGs. Your words and choices mean something. But I believe PoE takes the choices to another level!

Thirdly I am new to CRPG I have played other ones but found them rather unexcitable. I found for example Baldurs Gate Dark Allience far better then it's PC CRPG older version. Generally due to the PC CRPG version being rather confusing. But PoE is very simple! Also very difficult! It all depends on the difficulty you play the game on and if you enjoy reading the hints/explanations.

Pros

Graphics are brilliant, kind of old school with a more recent HD and flair touch

Simple, but can, is challenging and complex 'abit contradictory but you will understand once you play the game

Music and voices implimented are imersive and brilliant

Storys throughout, even in side quests are amazing 'as far as I've played they have been'

Cons

I don't know if this will change but I'm finding the areas we can free roam to be medium sized rather than big? I might just be being picky here, but wanting a little more stuff to do within the roaming areas. But remember in this review I've only been playing for so many hours. So may change later on!

Overall an amazing game! One of my best buys in such a long time! Couldn't be happier! 10/10 in my eyes!

reviewText:
There are the classics: The SSI Gold Box Adventures, Ultima, Baldur's Gate, Icewind Dale, Planescape and Fallout. Now there is Pillars of Eternity and I can offer no greater praise than to add this title to that sacred list.

Obsidian really have rolled a natural twenty on this one. It's a polished, smart and beautiful cohesive gestalt of superb art, deep systems and great writing that is simply levels beyond the doggerel peddled in almost every other game (well, any other games that isn't written by Troika / Obsidian).



I did just notice that they left me off the Kickstarter Backers in the credits though. Boo!

reviewText:
Pillars of Eternity is like a scrumptious hot fudge sundae made from the highest quality ingredients. It tastes good all the way through. Just don't expect your gustatory preferences to be expanded.

PROS

Infinity Engine graphics on steroids - Seriously, love the fog effects in the sea port.
Great soundtrack - Especially in the first town. Basically, the music there made me want to hang myself in real life. Good thing I didn't.
Magic - Interesting abilities that aren't locked to an existing ruleset like D&D. I can chant a drake into existence! Every  battle!
Party Characters - All of the characters have interesting back stories and are voice acted well

CONS

Plot - I found the overarching plot to be pretty dull, especially in Act III.
Melee Weak - Seriously, melee characters are nowhere as powerful as magic users. I kind of wish there was better parity.

8/10 - Would listen to Durance refer to everything in his life as a fiery ♥♥♥♥♥ again.

The game itself is TL;DR.

I wanted to love this game
recommended: but I simply don't have any fun playing it."

reviewText:
This may turn into a somewhat lengthy review, so if you don't wanna read all that sh#t here's the bottom line first: This game is boring. There, I said it.

First of all, let me say that I've been anticipating this game for about 2 years, having been a huge fan of the Baldur's Gate series for many years before that. This isn't a case of the concept being new to me, or that I was expecting an action game. It's not even a bad game. If you're genuinely enjoying this game I'm not here to tell you that you shouldn't. I will share with you, however, why I'm not thrilled.

I have probably spent half of my entire gaming life in the BG series. After playing it so much, and having watched it age, it has become apparent that there are many aspects of the game that could be improved upon. When I think spiritual succesor to Baldur's Gate released in 2015" I get certain expectations. Expectations I feel were not met.

Foremost of all
date: is that the game is flat out boring. The game fails to create an interesting or immersive world. Too much of the game is presented in written form (i.e. prepare to read a LOT.) I can't say I have a problem with reading
recommended: but I found myself being bored often while reading what the game was serving up. I always felt like I was playing a game; it never took me to another place in my mind. All the lore was standard and uninspired. I'd rather it were set in a classic world we know and love as opposed to this hollow one.\n\nIt doesn't help that in Dialogue
hoursPlayed: you can't tell how much longer the latest uninteresting NPC is going to babble on for.\nToo much of the written content is either wholly unnecessary or could have been presented in a more interesting and visual way. Instead of giving me a mini essay to read on the appearance of the huge sharkwoman warrior
voteText: how about making the character models more interesting and expressive? i.e. SHOW me.\n\n**MINOR SPOILER: Another example
helpfulPercent: when Raedric was offering me the chance to join him
votesHelpful:
I had lost all interest in the "story" of the quest. All I had to go on was two characters giving speeches. I just wanted him to shut up and for this boring quest to be over. **

Why did I travel all the way across to the other side of this room just to click on a magnifying glass and read "Rats scurry in between the cracks of the stairs." or something banal like that. The game is littered with these useless nothings.

The look of the in-game world is bland and uninteresting to me. It reminds me of a cross between Diablo 2 and Icewind Dale 2 in terms of atmosphere. I was never a fan of those games
votesTotal: precisely because they felt "lifeless" to me. Character appearance customization is something RPG gamers typically enjoy. Too many games fail to give us the fun we seek in this regard. The Infinity engine games failed
votesFunny: and so does Pillars.\n\nSpeaking of a lack of improvements: All my old frustrations are still there. Namely characters getting in each other's way during combat
commentsCount: small and claustrophobic areas making for messy gameplay
column16: poor selection of roleplaying options
column17: etc.\n\nIn a visually appealing sense
column18: there is very little upgrade from the old Infinity Engine games. Yes
column19: the graphics are "better." More advanced
column20: smoother. Water looks nice. But there's nothing that's done really well. In a lot of ways
column21: Pillars of Eternity feels like an old game. That's not necessarily a bad thing
column22: I just think there's actually better old games out there. Games that managed to create a visually appealing environment despite graphical limitations.\n\nOne thing games like this always seem to fail in is visual presentation of populated areas. NPCs look particularly stiff (notice there isn't a single patron in the Gilded Vale tavern that's sitting down? WTF?). Oh and the choreographed movement of your party... ugh that's gross! Baldur's Gate actually did it quite well for the time. NPC models seemed more organic. I remember how alive the actual city of Baldur's Gate felt when I was exploring it for the first time. In this
column23: and many other aspects
column24: Baldur's Gate left a lot to the imagination. But it stimulated the imagination and took it in specific directions. Pillars on the other hand
column25: is just dull. Or maybe I'm just getting old and not so easily amused any more.\n\nThere's plenty I find frustrating with the in game mechanics too. Like why can't I use stealth with just one party member? Why is my whole party stealthed? What's the purpose of making the entire party move slower when stealthed? As a seasoned BG player I thought the game mechanics would be fairly intuitive for me
column26: but I haven't been able to figure out the stealth system or some of the decisions that went into making it.\n\nI remember in an interview one of the devs was very enthused about how all the stats would actually matter and be helpful now
column27: and how it would allow for unexpected and interesting character builds. Well
column28: to be fair
column29: the first part of that is kinda true. All the stats matter in certain ways now
column30:
which is nice. But I tried to make a smart and wise barbarian the first time I loaded up. Let's just say I had to restart the game.

What's the purpose of limiting your party to 2 sets of camping supplies? All it does is make the game less fun for me.

The party NPCs are just not memorable. Granted
column31: I haven't got very far in their individual quests yet...but here's the thing: I don't really care to either. Baldur's Gate had memorable NPCs that oozed personality.\n\nI could go on but I think that's enough. I may end up finishing the game and putting a lot of hours into it. But that's only because I've waited a long time and there's nothing better. I've had some decent fun on it too

reviewText:
This game made me a nihilist.
Well, it's a great game and has great tactical diversity, especially during early levels.
Gamepressure-approved early game guide:
1. Create Character
2. Figure out basic controls
3. Die alot
4. Die some more (those ♥♥♥♥ing bears and wolves)
5. Try and error
6. Get to level 5 and be finally able to replace those abused F5 and F8 keys on your keyboard.

Bonus feature: In every instance there are at least 2 encounters you just can't win the first time you get there. I love that Obsidian also thought of the masochistic roleplayers while creating the game, they just care deeply about their community :)

Alright, I'm off to play, haven't had my share of anger today. Hussa!

reviewText:
Excellent game. If you enjoy RPGs which give you choice, you will likely enjoy this. Not only do you make choices regarding the plot, you customize your party, and the individual characters.

There are a few odd bugs. Mostly a couple of interface glitches which appeared here and there over the weeks I played. They were easily cleared away by restarting the game. Nothing game-breaking in my first playthrough. As someone who is easily angered by glitches, I did not find myself getting angry about the few glitches I saw.

This is the first great RPG I've played in a long time. I am more happy with my purchase of this game than I have been with any other game I've bought in probably close to a decade. A second playthrough awaits, with new choices, and new characters.

Oh, I forgot to mention... Played on Linux. Performance was excellent.

reviewText:
First off, I initially got into this game with some bias as I am an old infinity game player, I was already predisposed to this game in that light. After playing it however I noticed the merit of this game in particular.

If you've ever played an infinity engine game...this game is identical. Its as if they took the infinity engine and just leveled it up graphically and added a few extra moves to it. I was astounded at how it felt, it was like I was playing Baldurs Gate all over again...but then it differed. The primary difference is of course the law and the storyline. The immersion is there,its very good, I can only hope there is a continuation of this type of game. The lore is unique and intriguing, not your everyday thing but still familiar enough to not be too alien. Learning the lore of the game world was rewarding in its own right. Especially when you replay scenes and you actually understand what is going on.

Gameplay is also excellent and well balanced in my opinion, the additional difficulties are also there for the veterans or some might say geeks". There is a ton of customisation in many forms. Simply in character creation there are more options than I've seen in most any game. You select your gender
hoursPlayed: background
voteText: culture
helpfulPercent: you select detailed stats
votesHelpful: skills..many races have subraces and subcultures and most of these things may have some impact on story progression and interaction with the game world. The balance of your characters statistics affects combat and also interaction...you might end up having a strong focus on combat...only to have difficulty in social interactions. The reverse is also true. Skills also have a large impact
votesTotal: you might have a very unfit mage who falls off a cliff or gets injured because of poor footing
votesFunny: or you could move massive boulders out of your path with raw strength if you are so inclined. The combinations are plentiful and would take many replays to see all the possibilities. If there was ever to be another Baldurs Gate then this was it.  A true spiritual successor.\n\nFor all my bias and the flowery words about it...I still have some issues with it. If I had not played Baldurs Gate
commentsCount: I may not have seen this as a problem...but the interaction with companions was not as satisfying as I'd have liked. It just doesn't delve deep enough. I couldn't at the end of it all say that I'd really bonded with any of them. It was more like we start as strangers and end as comrades...but not really good friends or anything more. In that sense I might as well play it as a solo character without the need for companions. The companions do have their own draw and they are interesting but as mentioned
column16: there is nothing to keep one interested in them. Once you assist them through their own problems they cease to be interesting and you cannot deepen any bonds. Suffice to say they are very limited.\n\nAdditionally I did not enjoy the conclusion to the story
column17: this is my deduction but the story appeared to have a thoroughly atheist agenda and I did not find the conclusion satisfying. Thats all I can say without spoiling anything. The writing is however very good
column18: dialogue as well.\n\nAll in all
column19: this is one of the best games to grace the monitors of the gaming populace of this decade. I heartily recommend it."

reviewText:
Seriously an great game, 8/10

I bought this game yesterday and I fell in love with it at the very start. I never played Baldur's gate, but I am a massive RPG and medieval fantasy enthusiest. Anything with swords, castles, knights and magic makes me squeal with delight, and this game is a gods send for someone looking for a new game to get immersed into.

For starters the art is absolutely beautiful. It has a really unique and interesting feel to it that I thought I wouldn't enjoy at first, but it compliments the feel and atmosphere of the game very well. The environements are realistic and detailed as well.

Where there is voice acting in the game it is good. It doesnt feel like a low budget voice actor who is putting cliche emotion into their characters (see: Lichdom Battle mage). The character creation is quite interesting, giving lore right away about the interesting cultures and combinations of classes available to play.

The combat is the only thing I find a little bit lacking because it feels a little bit slow and can get sort of tedious after a while. But what it falls short of in combat it makes up for in content. This game has a massive amount of lore. There are backstories for practically everything, and lots of interesting reading to be done to really immerse yourself into the world of Pillars of Eternity. This is the part that I love the most because in my opinion for a fantasy world to be good, it needs to have a sense of rich lore and immersion. This game does exactly that.

If you are like me and a solid 95% of your steam games are fantasy/medieval themed and you love the fantasy genre, buy this game. It is worth every penny and I seriously hope I can find more games that are this rich in lore and history in the future.

TL;DR Great fantasy game, worth every penny.

reviewText:
As a kickstarter backer of Project Eternity, I am swooning with joy right now!

After playing the public beta for a while and seeing how responsive the Obsidian devs were to some truly fantastic backer feedback, and by fantastic I mean there were some who really delved deep into the guts of the combat system, which initially wasn't received well at all, and in a mathematician kind of way that would make my eyes cross whenever I attempted to read through it,  I had a really good feeling about the game just from that, and when the launch date was pushed out to work on it some more for extra polish, I felt even more reassured.

Then today when I launched the official game for the first time and played, as corny as it sounds, it really did feel like I was home again. It totally brought me back to the days of Baldurs Gate 1 & 2, the Icewind Dales, Planescape, etc . the games that would make hours seem to disappear in  minutes.  It's good to be home.

reviewText:
The writing is voluminous but says little, almost as if crafted by an accomplished wordsmith who lacked a story to tell.
The world is reasonably large, but I couldn't get attached to it.  Despite the verdant outdoor maps, everything in this story feels beyond dead.  There is no joy of life.  I'm sure they were going for this, but that does not make it a good thing to put in a game.
The characters talk a lot but, with the exceptions of Sagani and Eder, aren't likable.   You won't find an Imoen, Minsc, or Keldorn here.
The combat system attempts to copy the mechanics of Baldur's Gate or Icewind Dale... and for functionality it might have made a good clone.  Somehow, it lost the soul of those games in the attempt.

I don't know.  I can't really put my finger on the exact problem with this game.  It just didn't live up to its lofty goals of providing something like those great late-90s D&D games.  Skip it.  If you need a party-based RPG, I'd suggest Divinity: Original Sin instead.

reviewText:
My initial impression about this game was that it was doomed to be hated. First, it was hyped by middle-aged men wishing to reclaim their glory days of playing Baldur's Gate. Second, it was made by Obsidian. Third, it's a Kickstarter game (which annoyingly they don't let you forget). And finally, it's made on the Unity engine or some variation therof. However despite all these worries Pillars of Eternity is one of the best RPGs I have played in the last ten years. If you liked Dragon Age Origins, you'll really like this game (which is my only comparison since I've never played Baldur's Gate or Icewind Dale).

This isn't an MMO, but I still feel like Pillars of Eternity does everything correct what all MMOs do wrong, and I really wish MMOs were this complicated today. I love that it takes me 5-10 minutes to level up one character the reload a save when I realize what I picked didn't work as well as I hoped. This kind of learning curve that makes you want to learn and play is hard to pull off these days, but Pillars does it so well. The story is easily on the level of early Final Fantasy games, except unlike Final Fantasy it actually explains what's going on instead of leaving it to your 'imagination,' which I call lazy story telling. Good on Pillars!

I'm also amazed at the customizability of the difficulty. Why can't all games do this? It seems that so many games today want to take away your freedom for every little option, but Pillars allows you to blast through it so easily that it may as well be a Telltale Game or make it so difficult you can't even beat the prologue unless you're used to the D&D level of thought behind each attack.

If you're looking for a game that has many reasons to play and keep playing with (as far as I know) a brand new fantasy world that doesn't rely on old names and old characters then Pillars of Eternity is definitely the game to buy.

As a final note, I now have a list of two games I can say are successful Kickstarters: Shovel Knight and Pillars of Eternity!
voteText: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Old school, good times! Lots of choices in this game, the character development is probably my favorite part. Usually you have 4 approaches to situations instead of the usual two (good/evil).

There is a lot of reading, there's excellent voice acting, too, but most of the story unfolds through text. You'll be talking to a lot of NPCs and to your teammates along the way, much like Mass Effect, to find out their backgrounds and sometimes what they think about the situation at  hand.

The environments are pretty standard fantasy: castle towns, woods, dungeons, caves, but everything seems to have  a history and a place in the world, which gives me a Skyrim or WoW level of immersion. However it's more like a fantasy novel, your imagination does half of the work, there isn't much on-screen but the world feels deep.

It's not an easy game, this isn't Diablo, it's like WoW if you controlled a full party all by yourself. You have to manage 6 group members: tank, dps, healing & buffs. Pause to give commands, unpause to watch the action, then pause again to adjust strategy. It can feel slow and difficult, but not painful like Dark Souls. Every fight can pose a challenge, but once you get a full party of 6 you have lots of abilities (maybe too many, I think the priest has about 20-30 spells, split into levels of power, each doing something specific like increasing resist to fear, for example).

I run with 2 tanks, 1 priest, 1 wizard, and 2 buff/ranged support. You'll find what works for you and you stick with it! Personally I open with a volley of ranged fire if possible, buff the party, make sure my tanks are in position to intercept, cast AOE in front of the tanks, and then try keep the dangerous enemies knocked over for as much of the fight as possible.
