The stories are excellent, the environments are beautiful, the music is superb, the effects are gorgeous without being overpowering, the combat system feels natural, the spells and abilities are very easy to understand, and it all works together to bring to life a world of magic, mystery, danger, intrigue, and adventure.\n\nOne of the things that really struck me was the fact that this game, while definitely appropriate for kids (tweens and teenagers), is so obviously geared toward adults. There's some mature content, but it's not over the top or in your face"

reviewText:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_1HRSzU5EjE

If you want to tell people that you played Baldur's Gate growing up there's no better way to fulfill that lie by playing a game like Baldur's Gate first.  No this is not Diablo light.  That would be Torchlight 2, which some would argue has now made Diablo 3 into Torchlight Light.  This is a game that is going to be closer to Fallout/Skyrim than it is going to be to Diablo.

In it you control a party of heroes with a fully customizable adventure from what missions you choose, what results you pick, dialogue that effects how people interact with you, fully customizable 6-member party, fully customizable classes and simple and intuitive controls.

The game is not beautiful.  I'm certain this game isn't even in HD.  But that shouldn't dissuade you from giving this mentally handicapped game a try, it's a lot of fun.

ARE YOU INTO CRAFTING?  Yes, it has crafting.  And much like similar titles you gain experience through just about every single thing you do (except for walking because that would be really dumb).  Unlocked a door, awesome level up.  Better put more points in that door unlocking so I can get more experience from unlocking doors!

It is truly a choose your own adventure game that you can play many many times with differing results.  In my first playthrough I played the role of the warmonger running around sweeping down enemies.  In my second playthrough I'm peacefully moving around looking for middle ground solutions to resolve everyone's issues.

The biggest downside to the game is that you can't 100% it.  Apparently simply buying it doesn't mean you support the game.  Apparently only people who contributed to the initial kickstarter campaign are allowed to 100% the game.  Other than that (which seriously developers go ♥♥♥♥ yourself) the game is amazing.

reviewText:
TL;DR Version: A good but not great throwback role playing game.

This felt very much like Baldurs Gate 1 to me.  BG1 was good but not great whereas BG2 is truly epic. BG1 was more condensed with less imaginative locations, fewer epic tales, a main story that is not quite as well told and a villain who is not quite a well fleshed out. I felt much like that in Pillars. The locations, dungeons, monsters and so forth were well done but felt a bit generic at times. There were some good quests but very few I felt were memorable. Companions were there but the vast majority either weren't interesting or were under-developed. They could have done so much more with some of these guys. Itemization wasn't very good and I never did ooh and aah over any new piece of equipment.

Now besides this being a somewhat generic RPG, I really had difficulty in two areas that probably hindered my enjoyment of the game more than any others: combat and plot logic.

Let's take the last one first. I don't think the plot was particularly well told at times and there's a reveal by a major character at the very, very end that I can't even remember seeing before Act 3. The game kept trying to force me into caring about a plot line in a past life that I couldn't give two shakes about. It's like the game kept trying to say YOU WILL CARE" all the while giving me dialog options that said "basically
date: I don't care". Thus the plot and character motivations are very uneven. Am I undertaking this quest to save the children? For my now-dead God? For my sanity? For my past? There's not just one motivation that the game allows you to stay with and thus your choices seem contrived.\n\nCombat mechanics and itemization were also not well explained and I think I was seriously missing some tactical options because I didn't understand them. Spells and skills tended not to fire and I have no idea why. Vulnerabilities and counters to strengths I never did figure out. Given the sheer amount of combat in the game
recommended: I know this hindered my enjoyment of PoE. I never could figure out the synergies within a particular class
hoursPlayed: never mind party synergies. It's a combat system that has potential but it needs a lot more explaining and some simplification. I've been able grasp every different version of D&Ds combat but I found this just a bit too obtuse to really enjoy. Needless to say
voteText: I rezzed a lot of characters. :-)\n\nNone of this means the game was bad. These are just the points that hindered my enjoyment of it. So what worked right? Well
helpfulPercent: it's the closest thing to an Infinity Engine game that we've seen in a decade. The art style is beautiful. The writing is excellent. The plot isn't bad - just occasionally poorly explained. The world itself is kind of neat. You get a cool keep to rebuild. There are some good dungeons. There's a lot of just solid RPG gameplay and even with the above problems I was compelled to see the next area
votesHelpful: the next level and finish the next quest. There's plenty of side quests and they don't always turn out like you anticipate. There are plenty of opportunities to use different skills. It's just a very solid RPG
votesTotal: one that is good enough to overcome the issues I've had with it.\n\nIt doesn't have the same emotional pull of Planescape Torment
votesFunny: the great character arc of KOTOR
commentsCount: the world-building goodness of Skyrim
column16: the sheer epic scale of Baldur's Gate II or the setting and story of Ultima 7. It doesn't hold a candle to the Fallout series
column17: have the wonderful combat of Divinity Original Sin
column18: the story and universe of Mass Effect
column19: the grim characters of The Witcher or the wonderful emotional quest choices of Dragon's Age.\n\nBut just because it's not a classic doesn't mean it's not good. Being merely good isn't a sin
column20: either. So if you're a RPG fan
column21:
you're probably going to like this and thus I'd recommend it.

...

EDIT: I've now played through the game again with the expansions. That's more than 100 hours in PoE. I feel the exact same way about the game. Combat is still obtuse. The plot is still uneven. The game is still good. 'Nuff said."

reviewText:
I was sceptical at first to this game, despite having played (and adored) Baldur's Gate. I thought I wouldn't be able to enjoy an old school RPG like this in these times where the RPG genre looks quite different. I was so wrong.

+The story is engaging and very fulfilling. It made it close to impossible to stop playing.
+Side questing is as epic as side questing comes. No rats in the cellar, no collecting bear asses.
+Combat is fun, and difficult. Fights can be extremely tough, which makes it all the more sweeter when you manage to take an enemy down.
+Graphics are gorgeous and very reminiscent of old Baldur's Gate games.
+Atmosphere! Little notes you find can tell you an entire story if you read them.

-A few bugs here and there. Make sure to save often.
-There is an inconsistency in conversations when it comes to voice acting. Some conversations have lines that are voiced, and then the next paragraph isn't.

I actually have a hard times coming up with cons to this game. If you are at all interested in immersive RPG games and lore, this is the game for you.

reviewText:
Over the years the RPG on computers has evolved into something that is a hybrid of FPS/Third Person with an RPG element. Even FPS and Third Person games have begun this transformation taking on RPG elements.

Pillars of Eternity is a step back to the pure essence of the early forays of the RPG world into the computer. It takes some of the tech advancementsa we have seen and combines it with the classic style and game play of the early days of computer RPGs.

Gone is the twitch gamer mentality that has so invaded the RPG world and in it's place is the slow, methodical game play that drew you into a story. This is a game that will not impress you with eye candy and glitz, it is more than skin deep.

If you love RPGs and loved the classic RPGs beofre they tried to become FPS, then you will love this game.

reviewText:
Having only heard about this game on the day of it's release, my curiosity got the better of me and I couldn't hold out more than 24 hours before I bought it.

I would say the best way to go into this game is to go completely blind, knowing nothing, just the assurance that is is a fantastic game (exactly as I did, no regrets). The writing and story in this game is unparalled, in plenty of games where I am never too interested in the story and am skipping over all the text, I actually feel compelled to read every little tidbit about the lore and history of the world, as it really draws me in. I may only have 6 hours in the game so far, but that is really a testament as to how deep this game draws you in!

Made by Obsidian (Fallout NV, KoTor, among others) on kickstarter (perhaps why I had never heard of this game until now), it is a well thought out, sometimes complex (but not overwhelmingly so, everything is explained very well in tooltips) old school party RPG. However the complexity lends itself to variety, in all the classes, abilities, weapons, spells, so that no two playthroughs will be the same, even if you are using exactly the same class as last time.

The combat, is first and foremost really really fun. As complex as it is, I never felt like I didn't know what I was doing, and after getting used to it, pulling of really awesome combos of spells and attacks is really satisfying, and I never felt like the game was unfair, any mistakes were made by me, and I learnt from those, for the next fight.

I would recommend anyone who is a fan of RPGs in general and good storytelling. Is the game worth it's full price? Hell yes. Did I pay full price for it? ..... Student life.

In what other game can I shapeshift into a bear and maul my enemies when sh*t hits the fan?

reviewText:
Still wondering if this game worth your money? YES!

This is the game I waited for so many years. If you miss such CRPGs like Baldur's Gate, Planescape: Torment, you will love this game!

Updated:

After playing this game for 20+ hours I only managed to finish the first act, and not because the main quest is long and boring, I was distracted by the great number of secondary quests which are as much interesting as the main story and less cliche. In this game you don't need to go and kill 10 rabbits to get a reputation from some guy. The story here is deep and catch you till the end. As you play you feel that you have much more freedom than in some of the modern RPG. Your choices aren't so evident, most of the times you can't say if it's going to add you the certain reputation or not. You choose by your concious (or your character's). I love how much of in control you feel.

It feels like Baldur's Gate by the look of it and it's game mechanics, but it also feels modern, bringing CRPG to the new level. Any character can equip any item, but some classes will handle those items better than others. I love how instead of DnD alignment system they added their own personality system that depends on your choices in game. Like punching people? People will call you aggressive. Or maybe your character prefers diplomatic solution. All those characteristics also open more choices during dialogs.

This game is not ideal, it still have some bugs, which I hope will be fixed soon. Your stronghold feels kinda useless, at first I was quite excited and spent much money to build it up, but then it almost gave me nothing and you want more from it. Your companions are great, they are interesting and each has their own story, but they don't have much impact on your story, and maybe I spoiled by BioWare games, but you don't feel so bound to them, they are your companions, not friends. There are no fightings between them like there was between Viconia and Keldorn. You can't romance them too.


Pros:

+ Freedom of choices
+ Great secondary quests
+ Huge beautiful and interesting world
+ Roleplay
+ The gameplay you know from BG series, but now it's even better!

Cons:

- Stronghold that you don't really need
- Your companions are interesting guys but they have almost no impact on the story
- Some minor bugs

reviewText:
I've been playing the old isomorphic D&D RPG's like Baldur's Gate (EE) again recently, and compared to Pillars, they still are way superior.

It comes down to world building, basically. In the old D&D RPG's, you'd have hundreds upon hundres of NPC's you could talk to and would have funny conversations or possible side quests leading into other side quests; and so on and so forth. That made the world seem real and created an immersive experience.

In Pillars however, the number of NPC's who will actually interact with the player are so limited, you're reminded all the time you're playing a game. Same with maps. They're so repetitive and foes are so predictably scattered, it's signaling all the time: 'You're playing a computer game'.

Not immersive; boring. If you're looking for this type of game, go play Baldur's Gate I & II or Icewind Dale. They're vastly superior.

reviewText: I'm not typically one for top down RPG's nor am I a fan of squad or party managment. But I have to give it to the kickstarter community on this one. I freaking love this game. I'm playing on easy expert and I don't really know what I'm doing at this point. However the reason I love this game so much is because it's not about getting to the end, grinding, or blindly rushing into fights. It is instead an adventure at the core. I stealth around dungeons because I don't know whats waiting. I cautiously talk to npc's read through the text and lore looking for clues. I really feel like its an adventure and not just something to waste my time at. I'm driven by the unkown in this game. The mystery and the oh so amazing sketch's and text when doing actions. My imagination is being driven wild and I love every moment of it.\n\nIn summary if you enjoy challenge, and adventure than this game is for you.

I don't think "Pillars of Eternity" is as great as its predecessors

reviewText:
The full review can be found on Start 2 Continue[start2continue.com].

Excerpt:

I will admit, I was but a wee lad when Baldur’s Gate first came out back in 1998. I watched my father play it and gave it a try myself (as good as a six-year-old could, at least) and I remember being so enraptured by the story and universe. Aside from the lore of Warcraft, it was Baldur’s Gate that helped shape my understanding of high fantasy--not Lord of the Rings, as many people seem surprised by.

Since then, the original developers of Baldur’s Gate have shuffled around the past few years, some of them sticking together, others branching out on their own projects, though it seems to be common to equate Obsidian Entertainment as the most direct successor of the original Black Isle Studios. Obsidian’s known for some pretty high profile stuff in recent years: South Park: The Stick of Truth; Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic II; Fallout: New Vegas (and, in a past life, the original two Fallout games), among others.

...

I definitely recommend Pillars of Eternity to any and all gamers, especially those who have been yearning for an RPG like the good ol’ days. Though it was made with a target audience in mind, the fact that this game is easily one of the best games of 2015 thus far, but its achievements and what it represents for Kickstarter projects, crowdfunding, and honoring quality and the passion of game development, as well as the amount of power we gamers have, keeping Obsidian afloat in what seemed to be a last ditch fundraising effort… this is one for the history books.

I’d be so bold as to say that Pillars of Eternity is the cRPG equivalent to Skyrim: it exhibits mastery, charm, and a standard of excellence that ought to make Obsidian proud, and that other developers should strive for.

reviewText:
Good:
+ Engaging story. I even read some of the in-game books, unlike in Elder Scrolls games.
+ Fantastic companion voice dialog.
+ Morally ambiguous decisions and factions.
+ It's stable. I've had it crash on me once in 45+ hours of play.
+ Just an addictive and rewarding play experience.
+ Lots of game for your money. I'm 45 hours in, and estimate that I'm less than halfway done. And there are chacter classes I haven't even tried yet.

Bad:
- Terrible framerates and loading times.
- Not enough graphics settings.
- Not nearly enough variability in terms of character and gear appearence.
- NPCs don't feel real, They don't follow daily routines, just stand in the same place forever.
- Obnoxious kickstarter-related content.
- Your party members will sometimes get stuck or wander away from battles at the worst times.

Overall, it's a very good game that could be made into an excellent game if more work is put into optimization. This is 2016, I shouldn't need to sit through a 15 second loading screen just to enter a one-room hut, and then again when I exit. And a system that can run Skyrim smoothly shouldn't struggle to achieve 30fps with this game. I'm hoping for a good optimization patch. There should also be an option to disable kickstarter content, because the game world is infested with NPCs that can't talk, and tombstones with immersion-destroying text. With all it's flaws, though, I still think it's fun as hell.

reviewText:
Pros:

- Nice environments, good level design, beautiful backgrounds.
- Great music (!) and sound effects.
- Great storytelling, writing and atmosphere. The world calls out to be explored.
- The main plot is mature and engaging, the world well built, the lore rich and deep. More in line with Planescape: Torment than BG or Neverwinter Nights.
- Voice acting is a bit of a mixed bag (Grieving Mother, Kana, Aloth), but mostly good (Eder, Sagani, Durance, Lady Webb).
- OMG moments, like entering Gilded Vale for the first time, or talking to Uscgrim or the animancy hearing at the Duc's.
- Chanter's 'The Thunder Rolled like Waves on Black Seas' invoked that badass feeling no other iso game ever did for me.


Cons:
- Combat may get boring after a while, as the vast majority of encounters feel repetetive. You gain access to several classes and a crapload of abilities, but in the end it all makes little to no difference on the actual gameplay. Sometimes less is more. Original Sin it isn't.
- The engagement mechanic, coupled with terrible pathfinding, dumb collisions and your own party members blocking each other is more of an annoyance than anything else.
- Random difficulty spikes, eg. Sky Dragon or the final fight...
- ... yet paralysis/petrificacion + spell nuke will easily win every boss fight within seconds.
- Certain parts of the dialogue tree are voiced while others are not. Additionally you get a lot of written storytelling in between, which is totally ignored by the voice actors. The game can't really decide whether you should be reading or listening, and this in turn breaks immersion a lot.
- A minor gripe, which is the Kickstarter content, eg. meaningless NPCs stories and cheesy tombstone memorials. Makes you ignore most yellow NPCs after a while.
- The Keep feels like an afterthought.
- Bugs.

Played it twice, the first time on hard but got stuck in the final dungeon due to a bug. Second time on normal+expert mode. Overall an enjoyable experience, writing and atmosphere is where the game really shines, while what it lacks is some meaningful, well designed combat encounters. Never been a fan of the BG series, so I'd place it before BG1 and BG2, but certainly after PS:T.

Verdict: 8/10

reviewText:
This is without a doubt one of the greatest games I have played in a long time and I've only clocked 11 hours of playtime.

The soundtrack is just amazing and it really sets an atmosphere for the game, especially at key story moments and in combat, the wide variety of combat tracks is impressive on its own. The visuals are brilliantly crafted, in my personal opinon making it look better then most games these days simply because of the brilliant art style that obsidian have used, it  truely is nostalgic and gorgeous.

The character creation is also extremely impressive for a game which doesnt even allow you to see your character closely except in the inventory menu, allowing you to give your character a personal touch, from a variety of races, cultures,classes and backstories along with a generous amount of voices to choose from.

The lore of the universe is also extremely interesting along with the intriguing storyline which I have yet to unravle.

Overall I would recommend Pillars of Eternity for anyone who is a big RPG fan, especially of old-school RPGs. This game truely has restored my love of RPG's as It has been too long since there was one as great as this.
voteText: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Pillars of Eternity set about to be the spiritual successor to Baldur's Gate, Icewind Dale, and Planescape: Torment.

Nailed it.

Offering a wide variety of difficulty options and many ways to play, this game is both a reminder of our past for those of us who enjoyed the afforementioned games as youngsters, and a great primer for the genre (and, dare I say, a possible fresh start for the genre?) for neophytes to it.

If you enjoyed the old D&D games (or similar ones, such as Arcanum) you'll want to experience this fantastic journey.

If you haven't played any of this genre before, but like epic story telling, challenging tactical combat, some of the best voice acting *ever* in a video game, and gorgeous immersive worlds, give PoE a try. It will test your tactics and your morals in the best possible way. Expect some small stumbling blocks if you've never played a game like this before, so if you're not comfortable getting used to a new style of game you may not want to pick this up before watching some let's plays of it. By an hour or two in you'll be as comfortable with PoE mechanics as you've been with any others.

Story: 10/10

Strong, engaging, exciting.

Music: 8/10

Fantastic sound track, only complaint is that there's not more of it.

Art/World: 10/10

Mind bogglingly gorgeous in every possible way

Combat: 7/10

Can be heavy on micromanagement on harder difficulties, may take some getting used to the unique systems, otherwise great

Roleplay: 10/10

Immersive roleplaying with tons of dialogue options that help you really connect with your character. Choices make noticeable impacts on the game world and often have ramifications down the road

Overall: 9/10


One of my all time favorite games already, and I still have tons left to explore. In a word (well, two): Buy it.

reviewText:
Excellent successor to Baldurs Gate. Took me nearly 80 hours to finish (with White March) and I don't claim to have done all the sidequests.

Pros:
- Atmosphere, story, art
- Usually (in sidequests) there is no clear 'evil' or 'good' which side you can take. For example: Animancy is the study of spirits. Animancers try to find the cure to the disease that plaque Dyrwood. But it is also very close to necromancy. When do the deeds they make to further the study into the disease get 'evil'?
- Black & White text- based scenes
- Weapon enchanting, crafting from the loot/herbs
- New ruleset (non D&D). Especially differentation of endurance from health is great idea!
- Stronghold

Cons:
- Loading times between maps are quite long (2.01)
- New rule set (non D&D). Takes some time to get into. To see what attributes matter to what classes etc etc. Gladly the White March expansion lets you rebuild your character
- Stronghold. Could have had something more to make the place livelier.

Also could have some better indicator which map/dungeon is for which level characters. Got stomped a few times when venturing forth to a wrong area at a wrong time (especially in WM dlc)

Rating: 9.5

reviewText:
Well, hello...
I grew up playing BioWare's fantastic RPG titles... Baldur's Gate was my favourite game for a very long time.

--- Might contain mild spoilers ---

Now, for Pillars of Eternity... It is a nice game with quite a few problems, so I'll try to summarize my whole experience...

When I started playing it, aside from strong feeling of nostalgia I was stunned by beautiful background graphics (characters are pretty low quality for today's standards, but they do the job)... Interface design is also fantastic...
Anyway, I was immersed in game, story was interesting, depressive town of Gilded Vale was... well, depressing, and I really felt that... I started doing all the quests (as I normally do), and enjoyed it...

That changed, and after some time the whole game became a kind of chore... I wasn't as immersed as at the beginning, I stopped caring for characters... i.e. I really cared of Calisca and her sister and I generally liked stories of characters in Gilded Vale... After that, I didn't feel that vibe... I probably don't have enough time (as I had 10-15 years ago) to be immersed in the game for that long, but I played Witcher 3 for about 120 hours, and enjoyed every second of it...

Od Nua is interesting idea, but I didn't find it to be very important... Endless Paths are just to Hack-n-Slashy for this type of game (and combat), I didn't like it... And that is another problem of this game; It is full of uninteresting and unimportant combat. Some encounters are very easy, and have no point both storywise and for gameplay, but are there to build up playing hours, and then some of them are so hard that it is impossible to complete them (ie when you enter the last fight location, you won't be able to go back and build up your levels, and the last combat is really, really hard... it's ridiculous).

Talking about combat, I didn't find special abilities to be special at all... Aside from healing and summoning spells... Damage spells are ok, but you can't use them too often...

I really liked other adventurers, and their personalities... Side quests are hit and miss... The main quest starts really strong, but ends up being... well, not as good as the beginning...

Reading" souls can be frustrating from time to time... It is often written in some kind of riddles or in strange sentences
date: that I needed a lot of effort to understand them... Or I just don't have as much patience... It has it's strengths; it shows that it is not so easy to read souls
recommended: and shows the chaos that is building up in his head

reviewText:
Pillars of Eternity is an uneven, yet excellent game.

Without spoiling anything, the story follows your made character as they get exposed to, basically, dark magic and is granted the ability to read souls. From here, you pursue your Nemesis across the realm in an attempt to find meaning and answer.

At times, Pillars is completely brilliant. The first 1 1/2 acts of the game is some of the best I've played. The story is riveting, the characters are interesting, the combat is complex and there's promise of some cool upcoming features that are hinted at in these early segments.

Unfortunately, the game mostly falls apart about halfway through Act II. The game loses any semblance of challenge it had, the story and characters and insane amount of side-quests all kinda boggle among themselves and the writing drops a few notches. You'll likely find yourself starting to get bored nearing the end of Act II (also right when I hit the level cap) and rush your way through Acts III and IV.

There are some cool features that I was excited about that don't seem to go anywhere. Building your own keep was a cool idea I haven't seen implemented anywhere in a game like this, but it actually does absolutely nothing in the game. Money is pretty infinite by the time you start building your keep. At that point, it's just time-gated. You can take prisoners.. but why? They just sit there doing nothing, occasionally offering bribes to be released. The crafting and enchanting systems are useless. Consumables are a joke (often taking longer to consume than they heal or buff). Some spells are ridiculously overpowered (Level 5 mage Charm is insanely powerful).

Even with all of this, I highly recommend this game. The visuals are fun, the characters and plot are largely interesting. The dialogue paths numerous and the endings multiple. The combat in the first half of the game is near perfect until you start getting overpowered.

Tl;dr: Pillars of Eternity has a slew of great ideas, some poorly or half implemented. But the core gameplay is amazing, the story is fantastic and the characters are interesting. The game is also 65+ hours long (supposedly 80-90 if you do all the content, but I rushed Act III and didn't do much in the way of side quests) and has a ton of content. B+

reviewText:
When I first got the game, the starting intro was intriguing enough, but I started to get very frustrated a few hours in, so I will start with the negatives since thats what most people will experience and notice first.  In the end, I came back to it a year later, got the expansion season pass and enjoyed it, but to do so, I had to forget my hopes and expectations and approach it as a new game again.  It was easier to do this when I knew the things I hated about it and could make adjustments (not playing as a wizard for my main character, and focusing on the story vs the combat)

Even though the game captures the look and feel of an infinity engine game, they chose to create a new game system instead of liscensing the D&D or some other popular system, and this was the primary source of my frustration.  In particular, the new system is very limited in the spell selection of both wis and int casters compared to the baldur's gate games.

The other thing I dislike about the new system is that rogue backstabing is nearly impossible to pull off, and even when you do, the results are underwhelming for the effort.  Part of it is that even with stealth maxed for your level, it is nearly impossible to sneak close enough to anything to do a backstab, and when you do, the multiplier is only something like 1.5 or 2x, and it is never enough to outright kill anything that is not incredibly weak compared to you.

The stronghold was also a disapointment.  Obsidian did a pretty good job with the stronghold in NWN2, so I had high hopes for the implimentation in this, and they did have some interesting ideas, but they just felt rushed or unfinihsed.  Its not so much that the stronghold is bad, its just not as good as it could have been, and not as good as what they did with NWN2.

Now for the good points.
The story is different and interesting with a lot of twists I did not see coming.  The first part of the game is pretty slow going as you are getting acquinted with the world it is set in, but things really start to pick up once you get to the main city.  I don't want to spoil anything, so I'll just say that the story was good enough to me that it was worth getting past the negatives I listed to enjoy it. The story and quests in the expansion (Whitmarch) are also very well done, and the expansion is well worth getting if you decide to get the game.

I'm gonna give it a positive rating, but for anyone who has not played the Baldur's Gate or Neverwiner Nights series, I would highly recomend any of those over this, and I would also recomend Dragon Age: Origins and Awakening over this (but skip Dragon Age 2, that game is a steaming pile of rubbish).

TLDR: Great story, disapointing game mechanisms.

reviewText:
I've broken this review about Pillars of Eternity (PoE) into two parts, story and combat. An entire section could be devoted to the mechanics but I will simply say they are great in my opinion.

Story: PoE is a book wrapped as a game and the storyline is novel quality that would scare young adult fantasy readers. If you are in it for the story-line alone play PoE on the easiest difficulty with all the help you can get. You create one character and over the course of the story have up to an additional five characters join you. You can even create your own and not bother with the in-game characters. You may want to have as many in-game characters as you can in your party if you want to see the story-line mature fully.

Combat: First, I am playing the game on what is called hard" difficulty and with a special setting called "expert" mode. PoE's expert mode turns off a lot of helpful information so you must learn what enemies are weak to and much of the information is hidden. Based upon my settings my overall assessment of the combat is brutally difficult
date: imagine playing chess-master on a grandmaster setting but instead you don't know what all the pieces do but computer does and often has more pieces than you until you get a full party... and even then the enemy will often outnumber you. This is refreshingly positive experience as I am expecting to steamroll the AI as I do in most games. Even with these difficult settings the battles with the AI enemies still feels fair. I feel like I am playing more a game of chess on equal footing than what most games do to make up for bad AIs such as give special bonuses and stats to the AI to make it difficult instead of developing a tactically smart AI. The AI in PoE feels like they are fighting for their life
recommended: targeting certain members of my party and using the strengths of their pieces to the best of their ability and even minimizing losses to win the complete battle at times (which is game-over for the player).  The downside of such a difficult AI is a slight draw away from the storyline
hoursPlayed: in that I've found that I won't bring the in-game characters because they aren’t min-maxed enough for their particular role which means I may be missing out on some dialogue. PoE does have an even higher difficulty but it just increases the stats of the enemies and I'm not interested in that. PoE even has an iron-man mode for the masochist which could make for a fun easy difficulty iron man story."

reviewText: This is the first CRPG of this quality since Mask of the Betrayer. It's well written, has tons of customization options and replay value, challenging optional encounters for hardcore players, but also with enough easy options for newcomers. The game is roughly 70 - 80 hours long if you try to do all of the content, so it's definitely worth its dollar value. I highly recommend this game to any longtime CRPG fans and anyone who is interested in getting into the genre.

reviewText:
The writing is Exeptional. This is the best writing I've ever experienced in a video game. I have read a lot of books that couldn't even come close to the imagery that some of the dialogues in Pillars imprint on my mind. Just incredibly high quality dialogues.

The story is very good, and it has kept me interested for 60 hours. But it's the way that it is delivered that's amazingly gorgeous. I feel for my companions, I am attached to their dilemnas and their hardships. Their personalities are so fleshed out and enthraling.

The gameplay is almost perfect for my taste. These hard to come by levels and the boost they give your characters when they do come makes me feel like I'm playing baldur's gate again. I finaly remember why I loved BG and BG 2 so much. Although some classes are a bit imbalanced.

Graphics : Well you know already what you're getting into.

This is my GOTY. And it's pretty much my Game of the last 10 years.

reviewText:
In this review, I will discuss THE GOOD (things I liked), THE BAD (things that were mechanically wrong or off with the game), and THE UGLY (more general stuff that really just shut me down about it.)

THE GOOD:
--Plays and feels like a CRPG! Mission accomplished!
--Party creation system is cool; you're able to travel around with companions from the story or custom mook-people who were designed in exactly the same fashion as you were. Your choice!
--Combat is a bit hard to learn at first, but fun and even a bit tactical when facing enemies on par with your level or higher.
--Pretty big game world, but not overly so.
--Health system is really good. It forces your party to take breaks from adventuring for fear of permadeath and gets rid of classic we've been underground for a month!" phenomenon.

THE BAD:
--Healing is at a premium for all classes but one or maybe two. This basically forces you to have a priest on hand. Or a full party of Paladins. It detracts from any sort of party diversity and feels very min-maxy.
--As of recent patches
date: crowd control effects have been nerfed into oblivion. Maybe this is a "realistic" choice considering which monsters were buffed
recommended:
but it makes some classes very uninteresting on some levels and complete garbage on others.

reviewText:
I've played this game for about 50 hours and almost finished it. I kept on expecting it to get better, but it never did. I couldn't force myself to finish it. From reading the forums this is a common complaint. Save your money and more importantly your time.

Positives:

- The graphics are good, although they are mostly for show, you can't interact with most of it.
- The interface is well designed
- There is lots to do in the game

Negatives

- There is lots to do, but little of it is interesting, tons of boring quests. A great example of quantity over quality.
- The writting is terrible, I couldn't force myself to read any more of it after wading through endless screens of it for hours.
- The combat is a chaotic mess. Lots of mindless details but few interesting decisions.

reviewText: I really wanted to like this game, and initially, I did.  I liked the atmosphere it created, especially in the first town (ooh, dark and edgy) and creating my character was interesting and full of possibilities.  But one thing brought it all down for me:  Combat.  I look forward to combat in RPGs and in this game I did not like it at all.  Once the honeymoon of the campaign setting wore off, I kept playing, hoping the sum of its parts would overcome my distaste for the combat.  Sadly, this did not happen for me.\n\nDespite how I carefully crafted my characters and selected their spells & abilities, I was not at liberty to use them in everyday encounters... which is where I spent most of my combat time (lots of small encounters).  So I ended up basic attacking (which is boring) through every fight I could, being afraid to expend real" power.  I had a lot of trouble positioning my attacks and abilities.  It made me yearn for proper turn-based combat.  I would carefully indicate what I wanted to happen
date: but once I unpaused the game my attacks would fire in the wrong place or not as quickly as I had hoped.  The result is that many of my useful abilities "on paper" were not easy to use at all.\n\nNevertheless
hoursPlayed: the story was moderately compelling
voteText: and the NPCs were interesting enough... so I pressed on until I had liberated my stronghold

reviewText:
Really, really frustrated with this game.
Having been obsessed with the previous incarnations of the infinity engine, this the most recent, and by far the most disappointing of all of the games

The good:

A well balanced class system, and a feeling of fairness in how mechanics work here.

Owning a keep was fun.

The bad:

ENDLESS text walls

Clunky and underdeveloped story (To be very clear, adding a ♥♥♥♥ load of useless information, doesn't constitute a story)

The offensive comparisons to baldur's gate (Baldur's gate was/is so much better than this game I am rather shocked.)
Why is it offensive? Because the story-line of Baldur's gate is epic, in an incredibly uplifting way. You feel awesome, your part god, and not just part god... you're partially the god of murder, and you can ascend to godhood. In this game, you have a strong soul, and you survive an odd soul storm. Your major goal in this game is to take that event...and undo it. I repeat, your goal is to undo the only thing that make your character unique. That is not exciting, and if you backed this game with high expectations... your probably going to have to hope Tides of Numeria does a better job.

The constant feeling of the game being unfinished. Whether it's the nearly empty locations you can go to, or the party member quests being both tiny, or part of the main quest, you are left wanting. I repeat from above, comparing that to the 2-3+ hours you could spend on some of baldur's gate companions is offensive. Jaheria's quest/story-line in BG2 should be proof enough for that statement, see the rest of the BG cast for additional proof.

The fact that I have been so frustrated with this game, that I wrote my first negative review, ever.

I could continue, but 50$, and the time it's taken to hate this game, and to write this review is just making me more sad I pressed Purchase""
voteText: 15 of 27 people (56%) found this review helpful 3 people found this review funny

reviewText:
Baldur's Gate I and II and Planescape Torment are among my favorite games of all time, Icewind Dale was not great but still a lot better than this.

The world feels very lifeless, the first town is full of completely unconnected NPC background stories and nobody other than a few quest givers to talk to.

The party system is badly balanced as choosing a class that can't survive and fight on its own makes fights much harder than they would probably be otherwise (in my case I picked a priest). This is compounded by the fact that there is a limit to how often you can rest with the available supplies.

There is a lot of lore and system information to remember but the explanatory popups work only in some of the places where e.g. the names of gods or skills appear.

Most of the areas I visited so far are just your regular old wilderness spot with evenly spaced enemies and a few plants to collect, making for a very boring gameplay.

If you are thinking of buying this game because you enjoyed the old Infinity Engine games I would strongly recommend against it. It is nothing like them and does not make up for it for having either particularly strong writing or engaging combat.
voteText: 15 of 27 people (56%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
As a backer, I really believed in this game, but mayeb that's why I am so disappointed!

There are other reviews that describe the problems in detail, but here are some things that are pretty bad:
- the abilities/skills of the characters are not distinct enough; it also doesn't really matter what you equip them with
- the game is unbalanced, with fights that are way too difficult on normal popping up without warning
- the loot is not worth the effort, usually
- the reputation system is illogical
- you have to sneak ALL the time
- most spells can hurt your characters too, so your wizard has to be in the front line
- your character is generic, regardless of how you build him/her, and there is no feeling of relationships with the rest of the party

There's more. These are all problems with the design, so not fixable.
There are strange bugs during combat:
- party members forget that they are fighting and just hang around after you use one of their abilities. This happens sometimes, so you never know if you need to manage them or not.
- abilities don't work as advertised, e.g. the fighters ability that lets him engage 3 enemies sometimes just doesn't register and he is flanked even with just 2.

I am not sure if I wil continue playng - it's become quite boring.

I'd give it a 60/100 - its decent, but mostly uninspired and lackluster in everything that makes a RPG great.

- choices often dont matter at all or very little

reviewText:
Baldur's Gate and Icewind Dale lovers must play it, no questions asked.

I have spend over 80 hours to finish the game although I did most of the side quests and read 99% of the text I've seen.

The world is amazing, carefully crafted,
Background information is vast and varied so much that I would recommend players to read through Guidebook describing world, history, religion, races and all connections, rivalry and friendships between each of them. Guidebook knowledge makes a play even more interesting (without it, it's a bit overwhelming at the beginning to understand what's going on but eventually you will catch it up).

I really hope they are going to do expansions to the game adding more locations and quests (the world map shows plenty of more interesting locations that are not in the current game).

reviewText: If you loved Baldur Gate series then this will be the game you're looking for.  From it's beautiful rich environments, great story line, and intriguing companions, the game brings you into a great new world to immerse yourself in.  Some small game mechanics are still a bit wonky (pathing for your companion AI is one) but it barely bothered me.  The new system with Endurance vs. Health was strange but refreshing and by the end I actually loved the idea of it.  One of the biggest problems I had in BG series was the need to rest everytime I had my wizards use their spells, however in POE that wasn't an issue at all.  The same problem applied for health in BG but again, in POE with the Endurance vs Health system it drastically cut the need for me to be resting all the time to replenish 'health'.\n\nAnother part of the game I loved was the different routes of personality you could take in this game.  The many different options to reply ingame allowed for multiple ways situations could play out.  Also if you didn't care for any of the ingame companions AT ALL you could hire/creat your OWN PARTY.  I don't know why you'd want to do that though...Eder/Aloth/Durance for life.

reviewText: Great game with deep story and focus on dialogs and choices you make.\nThis game has quite unusual feature which lets you to select amount of in-game helpers depending on your experience in role-palying games.\nAnd if you dislike being stuck in games because of strong enemies, you will be glad to know that fighting with the mightiest enemies is totally unnecessary for completing the game.

reviewText: I personally loved the game.  It certainly captures the feel of the IE games, particularly the first Baldur's Gate.  The art style is gorgeous, particularly when water is on the screen.  Your companion characters are interesting and well written.  I feel like Eder in particular is likely to become an all timer companion.  Make sure to use a variety of them, their responses in conversation with other NPCs can be great, particularly Kana.  The game handles well, although at times the combat can get a little chaotic.  Make sure to use the auto pause options to slow things down if you need to.  The main story is also great, dealing with the Gods and a curse effecting the region's children.  Basically, if you like the IE games, or just well written party-based RPGs, be sure to give PoE a try.

reviewText: I've been waiting for a game like this for many years. Finally a great old style RPG with an amazing lore to sink into. The main story is not anything special but I believe all the side quests make up for it. I love how they usually have few different endings and how the decisions to choose from are often moral gray zones. When creating our character, we have 11 classes to pick from, as well as 6 races, from which each has few subraces. Our class, race, deity or alignment sometimes matters during conversations- some of conversation options are either locked or unlocked. Some of these depend on our statistics too. If your perception is high, you'll be somtimes able to see through NPC's hidden motives. So the immersion truly is there. But yeah, there's lots of conversations in this game, lots of reading to go through... If you only like action, this game is not for you. There are plenty of things done better compared to the old infinity engine games, although some die-hard fans may see them as downgrades- just because some stuff is done differently. There aren't many NPC companions to recruit to your team, but we are given an option to recruit" a self-made character by creating them in a tavern
date: so I believe that makes up for it. Combat is quite enjoyable

This game is exceptional for what it sets out to be. I don't have enough time with it to speak to bugs or issues within the game itself. As poilished as it is; I suspect there aren't many if any at all.

reviewText:
This is my first review I have ever done for a game. Here is a poem, I wrote, that I beleive fits the bill completely.
Here goes...

Hold the torch
Then touch the flame
Upon yourself place no blame

A spirit speaks and truth abounds
The thought was pure
I heard it's sound

Feel no ill nor evil eye
All critique is but a lie
Your beauty speaks in volumes still
when all your strength it but your will

I understand you walk the road
With heavy heart amd binding load
Angelic verse in present time
Your soul is free
Though, in your mind...

This game game is not just played but experienced. Those of us who remember Baulders Gate" or/and "Ice wind Dale" will love and enjoy this game.

9.5/10

reviewText:
After spending around 60 hours with this game, I'd have to say that I absolutely love it. Having not played any of the decades-old isometric rogue-like games, I didn't have much in terms of nostalgia for this type of game to bias my initial opinion, though I very much loved Divinity: Original Sin which came out much more recently.

Plain and simple, this game is not for everyone. The combat is hard but very deep and rewarding once you learn the ins and outs of the mechanics and statistics. I've put in almost 60 hours, with one restart after the first 5 hours or so to try a different class, and I've only gotten through 2 of the 4 acts of the game. The game world is large, yet incredibly packed with stuff to do, people to meet, and big baddies (or goodies) to kill and loot!

The only real cons in my opinion are:
1) The AI pathing is kinda totally borked. In tight spaces, you and your companions rarely take the route you expect them to take, and while this is slightly frustrating on its own, it wouldn't be so bad except when combined with...
2) Engagement" - People who haven't played yet won't understand this much

reviewText:
This game had some serious depth to it.  The whole system was new to me, and I found it was fair.  I was successful in playing this through on normal mode without much of a hassel.  I never did need to lower the difficulty through the game, which is nice as I am not a hard core RPG stats guy,

That being said, I got to the final boss and did everything I could to beat him.  It felt like a fought that battle over 100 times.  No dice.  I will never see the completed the game achievement as I do not have the patience to respec my guys or to grind out a few more quests to level up.  Hats off to all those RPGers that blew through the final fight without an issue.  Just keep in mind that the game can be challanging, which is how end game content should be.

This game deserves a recommend since it was a real enjoyable playthrough up until the final boss.  Who can go wrong with 30+ hours of interesting story lines, keep management, companion building, and a TON of other things.  Great throwback to the Baldur's Gate style games.  I hate to admit it, but I ended up using god mode (which disables all achievements, but is nice for guys like me who are unable to progress) so I could just see the ending.  Either way, good pickup to all RPG fans out there.

reviewText:
What started out as a relatively fun callback to classic isometric RPGs quickly becomes a very frustratingly dense experience. In the end, Pillars of Eternity taught me why a lot of these old RPG tropes have become extinct.

I had fun with the game, relatively speaking, but in the end I spent way too much time being stumped by the way this game seems to enjoy complexity for the sake of complexity. There is so much reading to do in the initial character creation that it nearly turned me off, but I gave it a fair chance. The game seemed to be deep and it looked like a lot of fun... and then I had to restart my entire game because somehow I had gimped my character and the first actual combat I came across post-tutorial was completely unwinnable.

By the midgame, I had grown incredibly weary of spending hours in each quest hub reading seemingly endless dialogue. It took me a few hours just to gather sidequests and orient myself. The story was convoluted, dry, and appeared to be going nowhere. The stronghold was a nuisance, rather than anything interesting. Combat had switched from a terrifying problem to a boring chore.

By the endgame, combat had become more of a chore than anything, especially coupled with the amazingly terrible combat AI your party is equipped with. They don't like to listen to your directions, and they don't like to do anything that makes sense. The story had become so amazingly cloudy that I wasn't sure of the motivations of any of the characters. The final quest hub area was a pain. Combat was totally simple.

And then, suddenly, the final boss battle was stupidly difficult and caused me to rage quit the whole thing altogether.

I don't think this game was meant for me, even though I'm a fan of classic PC RPGs. It seemed to have all the weaknesses of Obsidian games with none of the strengths. I guess I endorse it because it is clearly a labor of love on the part of Obsidian, but I wouldn't put my full support behind it.

reviewText: It is very honest and well executed successor of the Baldur's Gate series, but there are a few things that I find a bit disturbing:\n\n- the game mechanics when it comes to battle are a bit too fuzzy for my taste.You don't often get a sense of whoa
date: I want this weapon" or "nice armor" that was one of the biggest things in Baldur's Gate series. In Pillars of Eternity it's more like "meh
recommended:
I really don't know if this is an improvement or not and I don't really know what caused us to win the battle". It is a bit too fuzzy and unintuitive when it comes to battle mechanics. I enjoy more clear systems where +1 means something and you know you don't have enough points yet.

- too many npcs in comparison to party size. I hate it when you have 3-4 characters waiting in line and you want to have chat with each one of them and play the story with each one of them but you can't because they don't fit in your active party. I'd either have fewer more intricate characters that I can play with at the same time instead of excess amount of characters that I have to juggle all the time in and out of the party to get everything out of them

But still recommended as the storyline is well written and atmosphere is really close to what made BG series so good. But doesn't get to Planescape: Torment level."

reviewText: After supporting the game on Kickstarter (one of very few games I supported), after patiently waiting for two part expansion to get released, I finally played Pillars of Eternity in it's complete current 3.x version and it was an amazing adventure to have. All of my expectations were met and exceeded and not just because we sadly lacked games with truly great stories for the past decade, but because even if there were many, Pillars would be just as great. It's everything you loved about Black Isle, early Bioware, Troika and, of course, Obsidian themselves, but perfected, taken to a new level, despite the very nostalgic interface. It's simple enough to get sucked into it, but complex and deep enough not to be a very fast food-ish feeling game a lot more recent AAA RPGs have become.\n\nSo what is Pillars of Eternity with both parts of White March expansion and latest patch? It's an RPG with an active pause and Infinity Engine-inspired aesthetic. But where Infinity Engine felt restrictive in later games, both technologically and storytelling mechanics-wise, where D&D rulesets felt restrictive for the stories BioWare and especially Black Isle wanted to tell, Obsidian made something perfectly suited for their needs. The inteface is highly customisable and smart, technologically the game is much less restricted and the ruleset they created for their world is a joy to play with. You pretty much cannot create a bad character" unless you try to (and if you do something you regret you can respec easily). All mechanics and ideas complement the concept of you playing the game the way you want and shaping the story the way you want. It isn't as freeform as what Fallout tried to be
date: but wow it is trying and is much more flexible than even Planescape: Torment. As an example - combat itself doesn't give you experience now
recommended: so you never feel like you NEED to kill everything you see and doing things in other ways is perfectly viable. And the idea of very text adventure-like segments that focus even more on your deeds and abilities to do things normal gameplay wouldn't allow is an incredibly smart decision.\n\nThe adventure itself is structured close to how the original Baldur's Gate worked (a region where you open new destinations on the world map to go to)

reviewText:
PILLARS OF ETERNITY a fabulous rpg which has tons of stats and classes with layers of graphical depth to make one's character unique and their own in every way possible. Exploration and combat are excellent with graceful smooth interaction which enhances the magic and wonder of discovery with the contrasting explosive tense combat. It is a much welcomed evolutionary step up from the BALDUR'S GATE series of old.

Music is soothing and transcending touching the mind with soft kisses from another world. Graphics are thick with endless variety and detail making the world feel alive with sensual delights and death threatening terror. Lighting is a mixture of the surreal, eerie and haunting casting a shimmering glow upon dungeon walls and lighting wooded areas with torches that can also be used in combat to set enemies on fire. Ancient machines glow with futuristic energies from unimaginable dimensions where time seems to have been shattered as glass into a nullified state where it has no bearing. Nights are a spooky neon blue or romantic velvet blue for the lovers out there.

Voice acting makes me connect with my character and the npcs of the world triggering emotional moments whenever the unexpected happens. Alongside the incredibly well written grim story and theatrical effects like dramatic music while cutscenes play out or a battle is about to begin these are some of the best things about Pillars Of Eternity.

I love how pausing was implemented during combat and how it can be turned on or off in the options menu. Combat is very fluid along with movement and has a certain action packed motion to it making one thirst for more battle which in turn made me want to explore every nook and cranny of the world not only for treasure,alchemy ingredients,supplies,npc interaction etc but for lethal visually stunning death dealing encounters.

Another great thing are the options for people who suffer color blindness as well as font scaling to make text bigger which is great for.. older eyes :) You can also set up the pace of combat and many other things in the options menu to make things as comfortable as you want them to be according to your play style.

Writing is truly stunning in its excellence. Its on a level of high caliber literature bringing the story home with the sizzling steak appeal of a LORD OF THE RINGS movie. Characters come across with endless range of personality making them very likeable even if they are scoundrels. Best writing i have seen in a rpg in ages since PLANESCAPE TORMENT complimented perfectly by top notch professional voice acting.

Indeed PILLARS OF ETERNITY is a beautiful and shocking harsh world which draws one in and does not let go in its seductive hug er i mean grip yea BONE CRUSHING GRIP. Before i knew it three hours had passed and i was still hankering for more but alas real life needs a chore or two done :)

If your looking for a very intense modern day Baldur's Gate style experiance with a different combat system with its mix of pause/turned based action Pillars Of Eternity is the rpg to satisfy the dnd fever in you with mind blowing writing fleshing out a grueling story of a brutal world where every day is a dark journey to survive.

Thank you OBSIDIAN and congratulations on your magnificent creation.

reviewText:
I don't write reviews for games because I feel the need to keep my opinions to myself and let people exprience games for themselves and not be influenced by others to find themselves as a gamer. That beign said here it goes.

I remeber playing thousands of hours just playing Baldur's Gate: Tales of the Sword Coast and Baldur's Gate II: Shadows of Amn and it's expansion Throne of Baal. I remember Icewind Dale one and two. I remember playing Pool of Radiance: Ruins of Myth Drannor and other countless D&D and RPG titles like Niverwinter Nights. Very selddom does a game bring me back in a way to the feelings I had about those games. I love RPGs they, to me, embody what a game should be. It sucks you into your own world that is just yours, the decisions you make effect you, charatcers that have a special place in your heart, I'm talking about you, Minsc and Boo!

This is one of those rare games that I play and I feel the magic I felt about games when I was a kid. The trail and error, the building a character and finding what playstyle works for that class, the dungeon crawls that I play for hours and don't realize it is time to eat. Instead of my mother calling me down for dinner it's my wife, or my kids sitting next to me going Dad we are hungry can you pause it after you kill this monster?" and when I pause it they groan with annoyance that it needs to stop. Now instead of playing solo like when I was a kid I have 3 of my own to share the magic with
date: and the memories I make I now share with them. I hear their laughs as the characters banter as you walk through the cities and caves and forests.\n\nMy oldest is now trying to battle her way onto my computer to play this game bcause it is like the games I loved when I was a kid. Simple yet complicated
hoursPlayed: and it has all the makings of a classic. If you are a RPG fan or a fan of any of the Baldur's Gate games or Neverwinter Nights and you don't buy this game your are an idiot. This game will take you back to a time when games were amazing and not just good. I know I might catch some flak for that but how many games that have come out in the past 8 years have made you wanna go back and play them through 20 times? I can count the number on my hands. Yes there are fun games to play that are good for one maybe two play throughs but seldom suck me into my own world for hours and hours and hours of gameplay. I have about 50 hours on this game and I got it just a few days ago. I can't get enough and niether can my kids.\n\nWhile it has it's drawbacks like any game and they are few and far between
voteText: such as the double clicking inventory bug
helpfulPercent: but they are so few I have yet to find one that is game breaking. you can't even say that for Skyrim or any other RPGs that have come out within the past 5 years. If you don't like RPGs then this game is not for you

reviewText:
This is effectively the successor we've been waiting for BG2. Does it hit as hard as BG2? No, it's hard to do that. BG2 existed in a kind of beloved universe by nerds, cultivated with a rich goofy history from Dungeons and Dragons.

This attempts to do it's own thing, though common fantasy tropes are brought in. None the less it's interesting and takes a strong themeatic focus upon the concept of the soul, which here is a particular thing with particular qualities, capable of being approached in an almost scientific manner.

The gameplay is essentially turn based though real time, you will pause often. AI can be preset for companions to make it flow easier and I've found it to work fine. The classes are many and interesting while the stat system is a little more forgiving, as usefulness is spread out wide amid the stats. It's hard to build yourself into a character hole.

The dialogue and reading is plenty. Play this game ever night, a little bit, before you go to bed. It's like cozying up with a book. It isn't supposed to give you an adrenal rush, but be an enjoyable journey.

I would suggest playing it on the harder difficulties, I did at first and rarely had any issues save for near the end. The final boss can be a real pain in the ♥♥♥.

reviewText:
Second try of writing a review as my first one was rather unforgiving...

TLDR:
Not wholy oldschool but pretty good. As a fan of the old infinity engine games you should really try it. Younger RPG lovers should also get it.

Now I'm a seasoned Planescape and Baldur's Gate (also NWN) expert so I'll use those classics as reference in mind.

Graphics are nice but old style, Divinity looked more modern but still every equipped armor shines neatly.

Music is Conan style, no surprises but good and fits. Sounds like Baldur's Gate.

Voice acting - good but we expected this.

World and lore is a copy of forgotten realms essentially. Standard fantasy you'll feel right at home.

Rule system is somewhat on par with D&D2 and slightly inferior to D&D3, no multi-classing either.

Party, choice of the assorted fleshed out companions, those have a lot of personality, bicker as always and come with a quest. You can also create more adventurers for small coins if you rather want custom characters. Companions are on par with the averagely made Baldur's Gate companions say Corgan, Keldorn or Mazzy and better in cases. No Minsk, Imoen, Morte or Annah though.

Quests - those are very good.

The main story is high above average game standards. Souls, reincarnation, unearthing the past, all of that. After reaching act 2 the plot gains some depth.

Yeah the game tends to the casual player, quest givers are conveniently next to locations, companions can hardly be missed, game is not really punishing, skill reset possible.  I hardly got lost and there are no riddles. You can out-level hard battles. Still you can break quests like by force-attacking friendly people which is even an option. I haven't seen such for years now. Still you can win battles by the skin of your teeth - I like that a lot.

There's no good/evil but a Divinity like stoic/rational/passionate etc. rating system of character, those are heavily used in dialogues as are skill, attribute and background checks where Torment fans feel at home.

Formations are in, companion AI is in, most gamebreaking is ironed out. One hang in all my playtime. Several difficulty settings, one deep optional dungeon, ton of loot. Stonghold - check. Crafting is in but really an afterthought.

It's fair to say you won't be getting a better infinity engine-like RPG in a long time. 9/10

reviewText:
This game cemented the return of the infinity engine CRPG (for those that don't know what this is, it's a real time battle system that allows pausing to issue commands to a team of 4-6 adventurers of different classes to make a well ballanced killing machine)

I had not played an IE game before this one, but I grew up on table top wargames so it appealed to my straight away.

If you, like me missed Baldurs gates and Ice wind dales the first time around, but want to see what it's all about, Pillars of eternity is the perfect starting point as it's not hindered at all by out of date UI's and such.

I fell in love withn the game almost imediately, it's beautiful hand draw invironments, the in depth class system and well written story, detailed lore, it's all here.

Since the sucess of this game, more games are starting to appear like sword coast, using a siumilar system. PoE is the original in terms of bringing back an almost dead genre. Whether you're new to IE or a vet who played all the originals, you will feel at home here.

For a nos BS, roots RPG experience, look no further. My game of the year so far and also one of the best combat experiences I've had in any game

If you're tired of AAA, watered down nonsence, all our old favourites being made more action orientated to appeal to the masses, get on board with a real game like Pillars Of Eternity and show the devs some love..

If you want a future of gaming that isn't shaped by COD-loving teenagers, Frag-Master-Camper" get on board with the Renicance revival
recommended: smoke a fat bag and enjoy.\n\nthank me later."

reviewText:
pro
* developers put effort in this game
* nice game world
* the quest journal usually clearly states what to do where
* probably more things;)
con
* way too long loading times. big entertainment loss. seriously
* game seems too much zoomed in (this may be better with a bigger screen)
* the world seems small
* positioning, attack strength and endurance seem to decide more in a fight than other strategies or abilities
* found little replay value
* re-skilling characters should be more expensive. yes it is time consuming, nevertheless i re-skilled many times because i could
other
* lots of relatively long-winded text
* it is about gods, just so you know
* game took me 60 hours
tips
* check out the gameplay/interface settings and adjust them to what you think would be better, it probably will. i adjusted several gameplay and ui settings, for example auto-pause and disabled the health bars over the characters
* you can add custom made characters pretty early in the game through a tavern/inn shop
* all fights are manageable but sometimes you just need to be a higher level
* you do not directly get experience from kills (only from defeating a kind of enemy several times for discovering the enemy type) and enemies you kill usually wont ever reappear (world gets a bit lonely after a while)
* familiarize yourself with the effects of stealth and similar attributes to know what to skill

reviewText:
First, let me start by saying that this game is not for everyone. If you have never played an isometric CRPG before I recommend looking at videos as well as user reviews.
This game, even on normal mode, can be very intimidating considering the amount of combat mechanics. The game goes over the basics, but many things either fly over your head at first or are not explained at all. However, once you are able to understand the core mechanics the game truly becomes very addicting, or it did to me.
The story is also very good. While there is voice acting for some diaglogue be prepared to read quite a bit if you want to truly understand the setting and world youre in.
I heavily recommend this game to anyone who wants something that different than the AAA market right now despite the few faults.

reviewText:
Before I played this game, I tought I was getting too old for immersion. Boy am I glad that's not the case.

While this game is getting a lot of hate in more recent reviews, it is absolutely not deserving of it.
Not that it's a perfect game, it does have faults, but nothing major.
Not even it's detractors can agree on what they don't like about it.
The story of this game is great, And it never drags on for too long.
The combat takes some getting used to, but is more user friendly (Well, new users anyway) than it's IE predecessors.

And, something that's important to me, I walked away from this game with a feeling of accomplishement, not sadness that the game was over. so that's good.

Bonus points for a fun character creation that wasn't too overwhelming while still having tons of important or interesting lore

reviewText:
One of the retro RPG games quite similar to Dragon age Origins. You command created character (you) that travels through the world to uncover deep mystery. While doing so you do many side quest and tasks and find (or create) other companions. You can go with up to 5 another champions in your adventure party (total party size is 6) while others take care of your keep which you are repairing from by enemies infested ruin to glorious castle.

>> Pros
+ Deep characters system (stats, classes, etc.). You even develop reputations (like honest, diplomatic or aggressive) by way you interact with NPCs.
+ Way you created and developped your character is reflected in conversation choices available to you. This means if you create different type of character you can have different experience while playing again.
+ Story is strong and well told.
+ Combat feels balanced and rewarding.
+ Graphics is simple yet nice with no extreme hardware requirements so you can play it on notebook.
+ No internet connection required for play.
+ Several difficulty settings that can be combined. It is not just basically divided into easy->hard options but you can turn on or off several difficulty features as well.

>> Cons
- Sometimes too many text to read.
- Only few texts are voiced (some texts are only part voiced which feels really strange).
- Extremely stupid AI of both your companions and opponents in combat. Characters stucking when available path is just next to them, going somewhere for no reason or just staying idle while few meters away there is battle is shamefully frequnt.
- Poor auto management of characters automatic behaviour in combat. You can't tell what abilities your character can use like in Dragon Age but you can only pick template like Aggresive" or "Support" which mostly doesn't meet your expectations and you are forced to handle all champions yourself
date: which is exhausting after several time.\n\nIf you like to care mostly only your character
recommended:
2 last points above are really irritating. If you like to manage all your champions yourself they hardly matter.

>> Pros or Cons? (depends on your personal taste)
o No free world. You have system of little maps connected by their borders. In the end there is very little of true exploration because on every piece of living space there is something.
o Nothing hold your hand in terms of quests means no arrows
hoursPlayed:
question marks or explamation marks. You must find your quests by talking NPCs around and if you wish to not miss any you need to talk them all through. It's similar to Divinity Original Sin.
o I personally found crafting useless except enhancing weapons which is exact opposite and is necessary.

If you like those types of RPGs it is a good choice. If you like retro type games (no hand holding) do not hesitate a second
voteText: you will love it. It is not game for everyone though as it may seem slow and boring for modern type gamers used to Diablo 3 or Dragon Age Inquisition like games."

reviewText:
It is one of the best RPGs I have ever played. Stop… Wait. It is actually the best RPG I have played and to be honest I have never expected for any to be better than BG.

Pros:
-	True RPG
•	A lot of well written dialogue
•	Choice, choice, choice
•	Atmosphere of great, gloomy and in the same time outstanding world
•	Interesting npcs
•	Great story
•	Great items and loot
•	Levelling system up to the mark
•	Intensive dialogue (yes, again) that is more than well written – I enjoyed every word!
-       Voice acting is really great! It is something I missed off the all dialogues in BG.
-	Graphics
-	Perspective – 3rd person perspective from above to control your team – God! how I missed that!
-	Music
-	Detailed locations
-	Castle and its defences
-	Fighting system I like
-	Back to old school – nothing is lacking. It is so superior over the other tries (ex. Divinity Original Sin and its tedious-plastic dialogues) to make a true RPG game

Cons:
-	Hnmmm, the world is a bit too small for my liking.
-	Maybe a level cap is too low?
-       Building all these defences in your Stronghold feels a bit pointless.

Conclusion:
That is a really great game! I am not saying it is impeccable… No game is, but all its flaws seem unimportant to me. I was really hooked on. I need to try the dlc out and this time feel like in frozen land of Ice wind Dale back in the days 

My Rating: 10/10
I need to play again

reviewText: Great game. Much more interesting combat system than in Baldur's Gate. Though it is not polished well so sometimes battles look like you are a lumberjack in the woods. Relatively complex class and abilities system sometimes require good knowledge of those to finish the fight but those happen only occasionally. Access to almost all the map from the beginning result in good battles scattered through the world which in late game on higher lvl makes most regular encounters very easy to beat. Battle AI is very usefull and sometimes gives insights into winning battles especially on Hard. I should admit that those rare battles which finish with half of your team lying unconsious and almost all with low health are unforgettable especially if you manage to do them from first try. And that trully pays for regular grinding.\n\nThe plot raises some questions about religion so some might consider playing it for some theological interest.  Nicely polished dialogs and great sound!

reviewText:
What started out as a relatively fun callback to classic isometric RPGs quickly becomes a very frustratingly dense experience. In the end, Pillars of Eternity taught me why a lot of these old RPG tropes have become extinct.

I had fun with the game, relatively speaking, but in the end I spent way too much time being stumped by the way this game seems to enjoy complexity for the sake of complexity. There is so much reading to do in the initial character creation that it nearly turned me off, but I gave it a fair chance. The game seemed to be deep and it looked like a lot of fun... and then I had to restart my entire game because somehow I had gimped my character and the first actual combat I came across post-tutorial was completely unwinnable.

By the midgame, I had grown incredibly weary of spending hours in each quest hub reading seemingly endless dialogue. It took me a few hours just to gather sidequests and orient myself. The story was convoluted, dry, and appeared to be going nowhere. The stronghold was a nuisance, rather than anything interesting. Combat had switched from a terrifying problem to a boring chore.

By the endgame, combat had become more of a chore than anything, especially coupled with the amazingly terrible combat AI your party is equipped with. They don't like to listen to your directions, and they don't like to do anything that makes sense. The story had become so amazingly cloudy that I wasn't sure of the motivations of any of the characters. The final quest hub area was a pain. Combat was totally simple.

And then, suddenly, the final boss battle was stupidly difficult and caused me to rage quit the whole thing altogether.

I don't think this game was meant for me, even though I'm a fan of classic PC RPGs. It seemed to have all the weaknesses of Obsidian games with none of the strengths. I guess I endorse it because it is clearly a labor of love on the part of Obsidian, but I wouldn't put my full support behind it.
