reviewText:
An excellent classic style western RPG in the vein of Baldur's Gate, Icewind Dale, Planescape: Torment, and the more recent Dragon Age: Origins.

The music and artwork are top notch (as long as you don't look too closely at the character models). The voice acting ranges from AAA+ to B-Movie, although not all sections of the game are voiced (even some critical scenes are missing some voice overs).

The plot takes a while to develop, is strong in the mid game, but then falls apart a little in the end game. As it's fairly open to the player to decide their progress, this may have just been because of my specific playthrough or background" choices.

The biggest detractor were the bugs

reviewText:
I'm getting all emotional over this game now. It's like Baldur's Gate 2 but way better.
This is like Baldur's Gate 3 with enhanced visuals and game mechanics to make it smooth and fun to play on modern systems.
The game is challenging, but it gives you multiple ways to complete your objectives.

What changed from Baldur's Gate 2:
+ 3D models
+ The stat system has been reworked (It got better)
+ There are multiple ways to complete your objectives while still keeping the game challenging (more immersive, better)
+ It's slightly harder. (I've only played the game on hard difficulty) (I like it)
An ogre for example looks more dangerous and hits harder too.
+ Classes and skills have been completely reworked to make every class viable. This is a huge difference and major improvement. The bard for example used to be a silly character running around playing his harp in battles. The chanter from pillars of eternity on the other hand is totally badass.

Obsidian has succeeded in making a game that gives you that same awesome look and feel you had when you were playing Baldur's Gate 2 on release day, and made it possible to enjoy this on modern machines with modern mindsets.

The only negative point I can think of in this game is that at some point in the future I will finish it, which is sad because I want this experience to last.


I've read some negative reviews to see what people could have issues with.
I'll comment on some of them based on my experience (Check my playtime)
Here are their gripes:


-  Game is bugged.
-> I have only encountered 1 bug, The game completely crashed once.
Starting it back up I was able to replicate the issue, but it was easy to get around.
For a game that has just launched it could be a lot worse IMO

- I'm stuck and had to go hire some toon to get my mechanics up
-> The  developer had apparently anticipated this problem and
they have actually implemented multiple ways to complete objectives.
This problem does not exist in the game in my experience.
Use your head and think of other ways. The game challenges you.

- The combat is slow and it sucks
-> It's not an action RPG. If you have never played a game like Baldur's Gate, I suggest perhaps watching a tutorial video, but it really isn't that hard.



That's it for my review. This is the best game that will come out in a long time still.

reviewText:
I'm one of the old school RPG fans and a KS backer.
To be perfectly honest, just because it was a crowdfunded project, my expectations weren't very high.

But here we have THAT game of our generation. Generous story, great art, well thought classes, smooth interface - everything that next game (BG3, PS:T2 or IWD3, whatever you wanna call it) needs to be.

First off; the negative reviews, I believe they are written by people that are old time RPGers but are bored of the genre now.

As for my expectations and what I got:

* Setting: The setting is brand new, and backed up with an amazing historical background. It's rather too normal" for my taste but Obsidian has done a respectable work in just 3 years. 4/5
* Story: It never let's you go. It has tons of cliché moments in it but it manages to surprise you time to time as well. I could do with a more personal story but guess customized characters don't allow it. 4/5
* RPG mechanics: These are new too. They work quite well
date: and there are almost no trash stats at all. Perks and talents are quite interesting as well - I just wished some fun perks or traits but it can come in a later expansion. 5/5\n* Interface & gameplay: This is probably the strongest side of the game. The interface works flawlessly
recommended: especially when compared to older IE games. 5/5\n* Visuals: To put it simply; they're amazing
hoursPlayed: in terms of quality. The map designs may be a little too bland for some people's taste but the customers asked for a better version of Baldur's gate series and they got it. 5/5\n* Music: Very atmospheric. It's not everywhere but when you hear it
voteText: it makes a difference rather than making background noise. 5/5\n* Companions & NPCs: Both your companions and NPCs are very detailed and involve unreadable amounts of text. Your companions are interesting enough
helpfulPercent: so you don't really want to make a custom party. However as a PS:T fan I was expecting some extreme characters such as Morte or Nordom - with unique non-class based mechanics. But now I'm not sure this franchise is going that way. 4.5/5\n\nFinal: This is an awesome

reviewText: Excellent game.   Having been into RPGs since paper and pencil D and D   and then CRPGs from Ultima 3 onwards I'd say this is one of the best.   It's  really the only CRPG that manages to capture some of the charm of the pen and paper D and D games of my childhood.   I love the little added charatcter descriptions during dialogue and pre battles.  The interaction of player characters within the party also revives the best traditions of Baldurs' Gate.    Intelligent, flexible and intuitive character development and inventory management help  but the thing that sets Pillar above so many of it peers ( especially the recent Divinity OS) is the quality of the story telling and  crisp  intelligent dialogue.    I'm going to enjoy this sweet game and hope that it  ushers in a renaissance of similar.     9/10

reviewText: A resurgance of traditional RPG gaming on the PC. Taking the core gameplay style of the original Baldur's Gate, combining it with the storytelling of Planescape Torment and creating a whole new world with new character classes, skills, magic, and abilities. Obsidian have managed to create a new classic and benchmark for RPG games in this decade. One of the great features of the game is the way that skills, character class, race, past choice in conversations etc. all give you different options in conversation with NPCs and especially in scripted moments. Being without a particular skill is never game breaking but they can give you an edge when exploring, dealing with a villain or looking for loot. The game itself is huge with lots to do, many side quests and enormous replayability with the way that the main story unfolds. It incorporates morality, the nature of religion, good vs. evil and the player character in a closely interwoven development that has you almost wanting to skip the side quests just to findout what happens next.\nA must have for RPG fans.

reviewText:
People spend a lot of time reminiscing about their gaming past. Few sub-groups do this as vocally and with as much affection as fans of traditional RPGs like the near-legendary Infinity Engine games: Baldur's Gate, Neverwinter, etc. This might be because so many of those gamers found these games in tandem with traditional pen-and-paper RPGs, which is understandable when you see how much similarity there is between the two.

Publishers and developers of course play on this nostalgia and claim that their title will be the game that ushers in a resurrection of the classic RPG - a grand return to the days of high adventure. And of course they are consistently wrong because pitching a 50+ hour game with thousands of pages of text to read through is a hard sell.

Fear not these false prophets, though, for Obsidian has delivered unto you a second coming of traditional swordplay, wizardy, and esoteric lore. Lead us not unto Dragon Age. Deliver us from The Witcher. For Pillars of Eternity is the power and the glory. It's every D&D session in a moldy basement, every late Saturday night in the cold glow of a CRT displaying Icewind Dale, distilled into one game and freshened up just enough to make it more functional to a current audience. And that's it. It's a very *pure* experience. I can't give it better praise than that.

This shows you what a team can do when the budget isn't being poured into marketing, graphics, and bloated staffs. Exemplary work.

Silly trips around the global map to get a buff you need for a conversation but then it throws you into a dead end.\n\nWith all nagging aside, a really good game, highly suggested. Divinity: Original Sin was still better though.

reviewText:
Let's get the bad things out of the way first.

Cons:
- Terrible default controls

That's about everything I hated in this game, but after much strategizing and rebinding, which involved:
- Moving the map scroll keys from the directional pad to WASD
- inventory to C,
- map to TAB
- next char/prev char to Q and E respectively,
- reveal interactable objects to V

And a whole bunch of other QoL improvements. The general idea is to completely remove my reliance from the other half of the keyboard, particularly the right side since I am right-handed and that's reserved to my mouse. Infinity Engine games needed this option like real bad. My settings are not intuitive for the casual gamer, but Diablo 3 taught me there were better ways to access my inventory besides going all the way to I. And Diablo 3 is pretty casual.

But once all these are set, and I got used to my own controls, I am able to immerse myself in the game completely. No more glancing on the keyboard, no more groping for the right key - my eyes are on the game 100%, enjoying the sheer narrative bliss, the engaging tactical combat, and the captivating story that keeps me at the edge of my seat.

This is a true successor to the infinity engine games. I would love to see Baldur's Gate on this engine, with its stunning visuals, pleasant to the eye yet evokes the imagination. This is the enigma that Bioware left behind instead of improving upon. While Dragon Age: Inquisition is a glorious adventure in its own right, my heart belongs to Eternity!

Long live Obsidian!

reviewText:
An excellent classic style western RPG in the vein of Baldur's Gate, Icewind Dale, Planescape: Torment, and the more recent Dragon Age: Origins.

The music and artwork are top notch (as long as you don't look too closely at the character models). The voice acting ranges from AAA+ to B-Movie, although not all sections of the game are voiced (even some critical scenes are missing some voice overs).

The plot takes a while to develop, is strong in the mid game, but then falls apart a little in the end game. As it's fairly open to the player to decide their progress, this may have just been because of my specific playthrough or background" choices.

The biggest detractor were the bugs
date: most frequently in the combat stats/rolls that resulted in instant deaths of high level party members at the hands of trash monsters. The reputation system was frustrating as well
recommended: as some poor choices early in the game could lock you out of different factions and break quests with no option to rebuild rep. Don't play this game without frequent saves!\n\nMost comparable to Baldur's Gate 1/Icewind Dale
hoursPlayed: I found most of my disappointment in this game was simply because I went into it expecting Baldur's Gate 3

helpfulPercent: but not to the same level of detail as BG2
votesHelpful: where party members would interact and conflict with each other
votesTotal: and there were romance options.\n\nMy expectation now is that this game is part one of a new franchise. From that perspective
votesFunny: it's a pretty great first game and I recommend it to anyone with 60+ hours to drop into an RPG."

reviewText: Excellent game.   Having been into RPGs since paper and pencil D and D   and then CRPGs from Ultima 3 onwards I'd say this is one of the best.   It's  really the only CRPG that manages to capture some of the charm of the pen and paper D and D games of my childhood.   I love the little added charatcter descriptions during dialogue and pre battles.  The interaction of player characters within the party also revives the best traditions of Baldurs' Gate.    Intelligent, flexible and intuitive character development and inventory management help  but the thing that sets Pillar above so many of it peers ( especially the recent Divinity OS) is the quality of the story telling and  crisp  intelligent dialogue.    I'm going to enjoy this sweet game and hope that it  ushers in a renaissance of similar.     9/10

reviewText: A resurgance of traditional RPG gaming on the PC. Taking the core gameplay style of the original Baldur's Gate, combining it with the storytelling of Planescape Torment and creating a whole new world with new character classes, skills, magic, and abilities. One of the great features of the game is the way that skills, character class, race, past choice in conversations etc. all give you different options in conversation with NPCs and especially in scripted moments. Being without a particular skill is never game breaking but they can give you an edge when exploring, dealing with a villain or looking for loot. The game itself is huge with lots to do, many side quests and enormous replayability with the way that the main story unfolds. It incorporates morality, the nature of religion, good vs. evil and the player character in a closely interwoven development that has you almost wanting to skip the side quests just to findout what happens next.\nA must have for RPG fans.

reviewText: If you're an RPG fan like me who loves the classic RPG games like Baldur's Gate, Icewind Dale, and Planescape Torment, then you will love this game. The party characters are likeable and you get to have conversations with them whenever. Sadly there isn't any romances, but I was okay with pretending I was in one with Aloth. The gameplay is fun and challenging even on easy mode. You find yourself strategically playing the game and pausing a lot, which is a neat change in comparison to how I played Baldur's Gate. I love the storyline and all the lore in this game as well as the enemy. Having your own fortress that you build up and protect is pretty awesome and then the neat dungeon system underneath is even cooler. While it didn't last as long as Baldur's Gate and other Forgotten Realms games did, it was well worth playing and I will definitely be playing it again. While I was broke and only had $1 to give, I was glad I helped Kickstart this game. I definitely look forward to more games like this in the future. :)

reviewText: At 10 hours in I feel I have still barely scratched the surface of this game. Though the ruleset has changed, the look and feel of Baulder's Gate have been inherited in almost every way. The writing is amazing and your peanut gallery of a party always enjoys giving their two cents. I have yet to see what challenges are brought along with keep ownership, but I know being a money drain seems to be the first. Those of you familiar with this sort of pause-based gameplay will feel right at home. The part which grabs me the most, however, is the look and feel of the world: a Forgotten Realms aesthetic with what looks to be a splash of the first Diablo's darkness.\n\nThe spirit of Black Isle and the soul of Bioware seem to reside in Obsidian, and I can't wait to see what's on their horizon.

reviewText:
CHANGING MY REVIEW AFTER PLAYING MORE; YOU STILL CANNOT IMPREGNATE ELF BABES :-(

There are a lot of video games. A lot of them are ♥♥♥♥. A lot of them are derivitive nonsense. A lot of them are flashy, and fun for what they are, and brief and forgotten a few months--or even days--afterwards. I don't think Pillars of Eternity is one of those.

It certainly follows the form of older games, but I don't know that it's derivative. Every moving part seems to have been considered with careful deliberation, and each piece seems carefully placed in an attempt to make a game that's significant, that's fun and that you can take with you.

I haven't finished the game, and I don't have the perspective to look back on it, so I don't know how much Pillars of Eternity will stand out in memory, but for the experience of activing playing it at least, it's an excellent time.

Some nameless soul on the internet compared it to a novel, noting the differences between it and other, more so-called modern games. Such other games are like movies--action movies, in particular--with flashy visuals and sound design and ultimately superficial interaction and storytelling. They're fun for what they are, but their souls are perhaps not so grand. Pillars of Eternity aims more to be like a novel, sprawling and perhaps a little uneven, but saturated and infused with wit and care and thought. This could of course still lead to ♥♥♥♥, if said thought and wit were poor and lousy and made by ♥♥♥♥boys. Luckily Pillars of Eternity seems to have been made by reasonable folks, nerds who have an understanding of atmosphere and storytelling, and a knack for finding a place for the player in the world so that the game serves as more than a mere distraction or carnival ride.

It's tight ♥♥♥♥. Smoke a bowl and enjoy.

Actually don't smoke a bowl, you should keep your mind in a fairly straight place so you might, you know, follow the plots and character arcs more clearly.

reviewText:
A great top-shelf top-down CRPG in the mold of satisfying but slightly flawed classics like Baldur's Gate 1 and Arcanum, with lots of mechanics and a decent amount of plot and side questing. If you are a fan of classic CRPGs, or of newer CRPGs like Dragon Age, you should find this very much worth your time, even if it might not be in the top 3 CRPGs of all time. It's one of those games you don't just blow through in 8 hours but can spend a while studying, and that's exactly what was called for.

I'm looking forward to seeing the Pillars team make the next BG2 or Fallout 2. But while this is a great game and a really solid effort, I think it's worth qualifying that this game isn't all the way at the top of the heap yet.

Instead of the old D&D-based setting and systems, this game has its own completely new setting and statistics. While I found these a little silly at first, I warmed up to them over time and some surprises at the end eventually made me a fan; the setting is comparable to Dragon Age or Elder Scrolls in quality. As a true CRPG, this is the kind of thing where there are lots of pointless books sitting around containing neat things like plays written from within the universe.

Other than that new stuff, most of the format comes from Infinity Engine games, particularly the Baldur's Gate series, with a few refinements and simplifications. Overall, though, this game doesn't fix what wasn't broken, and that's a very good thing. As in Baldur's Gate, the backbone of the game is real-time combat with the ability to pause, but there's a decent variety of things to do. You play a character who has a secret to explore, you recruit up to six party members, you explore their backgrounds and do their character quests, you travel through wilderness maps, you explore several city-hubs in which you do quests where you can explore conversation trees and take sides, you go through dungeon crawls and beat big bosses, you hoard magical items and dress a paper doll to get the right bonuses.

While playing this, I kept finding things which slightly reminded me of past games. Here are just a few examples:
* The Stronghold is a pleasant expansion of the concept from Baldur's Gate 2.
* The use of guns and some of the mechanics reminded me of Arcanum.
* Hiring custom party members reminded me of Icewind Dale.
* The player's role and some of the themes from the dialogue reminded me of Planescape: Torment.
* The way the ending was done is right out of Fallout and Fallout 2.

That's just a few examples of why I believe that Pillars of Eternity incorporates a lot of conscious thinking about what worked and didn't work in CRPGs of the past. And after suffering through so many games which just didn't get what was special about the best classic CRPGs, I think this thinking contributes a lot to the solid, quality feel of the game - that it doesn't try to fix what wasn't broken.

At the same time, the game isn't a slave to the past. As an example of the ways that this game moves CRPGs forward, one of its biggest refinements of the Baldur's Gate formula is the stash
date:
a huge holdall that follows you everywhere. This is welcome, because much of my playtime in Baldur's Gate was repacking inventory to make the most of limited space so I wouldn't miss out on gear (much like I spent a lot of my time in Fallout organizing my hoard on shelves). It's much nicer just to grab stuff and not think about it until I want to sell it. On the other hand, it can be hard to find things in the stash sometimes. This isn't the only improvement, just an example; I noticed a lot of well-thought little features like this.

One important caveat about this game compared to the CRPG greats, and I don't doubt this relates to scheduling and funding, is that it has somewhat less content. Playing most of the quests, I found the game to have a decently long playtime, but I didn't feel inspired to immediately reroll and try different things (and the creative ideas I have tried haven't worked out). I don't feel like I missed enough content or possibilities that it is worth a replay anytime soon, although there are lots of difficulty features for hardcore combat addicts who love replaying. There are a decent number of recruitable characters, and two big cities - enough, but not really so many. I expect there will be more content in expansions or future games, which is only fair.

In terms of its themes and writing, I give Pillars a solid B. The writing is not the best I've seen, but it's very good.  The themes explored are interesting. You have some scope what you want to be. But a limited scope. There is no restrictive alignment system, and you don't easily lose party members due to disagreements with your choices. Unfortunately few of the self-defining questions you answer as part of your roleplay really affect anything. You can be all kinds of people, mostly, but  you can't choose to be (say) a Glenfathan. You can be a priest of an evil god, but you are still basically guaranteed to be a cruel hero at worst, and all of your companions are more or less just neutral or good. It would be simply impossible to complete a pacifist playthrough.

Artistically, the backgrounds are beautiful, the 3d art is good, the sounds are good, and the voice acting is unmemorable but not bad. The music that's present is of good quality, but it feels like they only made 3-4 songs so it rapidly gets a little repetitive. This is not a huge deal, but I hope that future games will be able to budget for a little more variety.

Technically, I am well satisfied with the game. Something crucial to me is that it supports Linux almost perfectly - just without displaying capes for some reason. There were a few launch bugs affecting all platforms, but I did not find them to be that severe, and the pace of patches has been very steady. You might want to regularly make separate saves, though.

Superficially, there are a few niggling details I think people harp on way too much. Some people don't like the backer content on the gold plate" characters or the tomb inscriptions
recommended: but you are never required to read ANY of it and it can be removed with mods
hoursPlayed: so I don't think it hurts the quality of the game. Similarly
voteText: at release a lot of people complained about having to sneak to find hidden things
helpfulPercent: but you can use 2x speed to help with that
votesHelpful: anyway this is exactly like Baldur's Gate and as you play
votesTotal: you start to learn that hidden things are in certain kinds of places rather than just everywhere. Similarly
votesFunny: some classes are harder to play than others but they are still not too bad as long as they suit your playstyle. So I think there are a lot of little complaints people have that don't matter very much.\n\nIt's a good game which makes me very hopeful for the future of CRPGs. Thank goodness that Obsidian was willing to gamble on this and that Kickstarter and the Kickstarter backers were around to catalyze it."

reviewText:
At 15 hours of gameplay I strongly recommendIf you liked games like Icewind Dale and Baldur's Gate, or are a fan of classic style RPGs you will enjoy this game.

The pricepoint may be discouraging to people who look at it as $45 for a 2D game but the RPG elements are truly well done, the world is immersive, the characters are interesting and the gameplay has that familiar tough but fun feel of older RPGs.

Rather than write paragraphs of why I'm enjoying this game I've decided that a list would be both easier to read and summarise the features that I've found enjoyable:
The 2D art is amazing and the pre-rendered backgrounds look excellent
The conversation has a depth that allows your character's background or attributes to be relevant
There are multiple paths to the scenarios I've encountered so far
Combat on higher difficulties requires thought and careful planning
The classes are interesting, and while there are still a few familiar faces amongst typical RPG classes there are a few classes may have been inspired by more recent RPGs which brings new facets to classic gameplay
The stronghold is a more recent feature to RPGs that allows players to become invested in an asset which functions in game time
SO MUCH LORE.
There are a lot of short stories tied to named characters for those who like to read

And finally the two most important features I'd like to note:
There are Elves
I can play a Ranger

I would have liked to have seen the option for LAN or Internet connection for cooperative multiplayer, a little more customization for the character models and portraits, and I have the concern that players that are new to this kind of game may get lost (I know I've felt a little lost once or twice already and needed to consult the Journal).

reviewText:
Wow

This game has almost transported me back to the days of the infinity engine crpgs like bg and bgII. I know its been said a million times already but its balances the old and new fantastically. There are so many things to mention but I want to get back to the game!

A few minor bugs that need to be ironed out too, which should be patched soon!

10/10 game.. hardcore rpgers MUST play!

reviewText:
I am an oldschool RPG fan, and I have to say that I played every big RPG back in the days and some I have finished multiple times like Planescape Torment, all Fallout games, all Black Isle games like Baldurs Gate, Icewind Dale etc. so I think that I am a person who can give a really sober and neutral review for someone who needs the kick before buying the game.

The first thing that caught my attention after starting the game were the visuals. The graphics are just amazing. I was really amazed when I saw it, especially after I re-played Icewind Dale the so called HD edition. That graphic compared to Pillars is like from B.C. Pillars look gorgeous. I really really appreciated the zoom in/zoom out featuire which these types of 2D isometric RPG's were always lacking.

The music is also very good, and some songs are epic. Remind me the good old times from Baldurs Gate. Fits very very well to this fantasy world. My only problem here was, that after a while it felt repetetive. I am not sure of the songs are just similiar or there arent many of them ( didnt heard the ost ) but I had the feeling when I entered a map that the same music is playing .... again, or atleast a very similiar one.

The story overall, is basicly what makes these games so good. The story is always huge and complicated in these games. Yes, you read a lot in this game. I am a person who not only read in games ( RPG's ) , but I also read a lot of books and not only fantasy. I must say that the story in Pillars for me was mediocre, or below avarage at its best compared to other games aswell, like Final Fantasy, Baldurs Gate, Planescape Torment ( one of the best ). Pillars just doesnt catch up here. People who never played a good story based game, or never read a very good book... they might like Pillar's story but dont expect something mind blowing or something that gives you chills everytime you think about it. It's just not there for me.

Speaking asbout the story, I think that the NPC's I had in my group or Castle ( waiting for me to pick them up ) werent interesting. Eder ? Aloth ? I really wanted to like them I really tried.... I just couldnt care less about their story. It's not Minsc and Boo from BG, it's not Morte or the Nameless One, It's not Morrigan from Dragon Age. Thats why I created 4 characters on my own and just ignored almost all the NPC sidequests. I didnt enjoyed them. But you dont have to care about this if you didnt played any of these games, it is my little little note which I wanted to share.

The biggest feature of this game is always the combat, which is amazing in Pillars. It is very dynamic, fast, colorful, bautiful... and also chaotic at the beginning. You can slow it down anytime, or even pause to assign commands. Basicly it works like this. You press spacebar to pause the game, assisng command with every party member. For example, the Paladin activates this spell, atatck with Warrior this enemy, Cast a Fireball with the Mage, Cast a AoE defensive buff with your priest etc.... once you done, you unpause the game and every command you did during the pause will trigger and happen at the same time. Then, you press pause and again.... you assign command ans so on. Easy enemies can be beaten easily without the pause button, but tougher bosses or encounters literally are unplayable without the pause. But thats ok, combat is designed around this in these games.

The lack of D&D features, names, spells is also a letdown for me. This is not the Baldurs Gate 3 I wanted. I want my Magic Missile not some other looking ( similiar ) spell which is called Minoletta Missiles, it is very confusing at the beginning. You know what was really good in all the previous games ? Once you played any of them and then you jumped on the other one, you didnt had to study all the spells because in the world of D&D every spell did always the same. You had a Magic Missile, Mirror Image, Fireball wtc. in every Black Isle fantasy game. Here I had to read, study, find out what works and what not on my own... I didnt liked it too much, but again IGNORE all this if you never played the previous games. This is my personal note. I understand that implementing the D&D rules is a matter of a lot of money and license but.... oh well.

Took me 60 hours exactly to beat the game. At 51 hours, I was at the final boss, but sadly I couldnt beat him because I was level 7-8 with my party. Had to return here at max level which is 12 btw, and it was suddenly super easy. The point is, that the game didnt told me to do all these sidequests to actually even have chance to beat the final boss. I always thought sidequests are optional, not recommended. A mistake. so dont do the same. You cannot beat the boss I think under level 10, but max is recommended.

Overall the game is really really good. A lot of gametime, possible replayability with multiple and different endings. Looks very pretty, plays very smooth. I had a great time. A comeback of a classic RPG. A reminder in the modern days, what we loved so much in the late 90's. Definitely recommended.

8/10

reviewText:
I don't usually write reviews for games, but I felt compelled to this time. I didn't find out about Pillars of Eternity in time to back it on KS, but I began supporting it as soon as I learned of its existence :)

As a kid I played the old Infinity Engine games. I think my first was Fallout 2, then Fallout, then Planescape: Torment, then everything else. Basically, I cut my teeth in gaming on some of the best (arguably the very best) Western-style CRPGs ever made. It gave me a sincere appreciation for storytelling in games that has served me really well since, though I think any fan of RPGs remembers the dry spell in the 2000s where it looked like CRPGs might irrevocably change to something much lamer, or just not get made anymore. If I had to pick a game that ended that negative outlook, probably The Witcher, by my reckoning, and it has been a great deal better since. I guess it's a real resurgance of craft and storytelling in CRPGs :)

This game is the best one out of any that I've played since Planescape: Torment, though. Bar none. It has an engrossing story, a brilliantly realized and organic (but mystical!) setting, places that feel truly alien through sincere and earnest effort on the part of the developers. Interactions with NPCs carry the dramatic flair that a VERY good dungeonmaster can bring to a P&P tabletop game, and that feeling is only further enhanced by the clever system of scripted events in the game that have multiple stat or skill checks and require some thought to navigate without peril. They don't happen often enough for you to start predicting every time you'll have one, but they do happen often enough that they are a serious gameplay element and not a gimmicky afterthought. The user interface is a brilliant combination of accessibility and feature-richness, evoking the Infinity Engine interfaces in general but without their frustratingly restrictive control schemes.

I haven't played enough to assess how the game will be in retrospect, after the story has ended. But I am absolutely enthralled by my role in the story so far, and I am not looking forward to the end of it so much as having gone on this awesome gaming journey. You don't get stuff like this often. Buy it, if you're even a little interested you ARE the type of gamer it's for. This will rekindle any person's love for old CRPGs, and I bet it'll make a lot of new fans too!

reviewText:
Pillars of Eternity is a fantastic old-school cRPG game with wonderful isometric graphics, engaging combat, and compelling story. I originally funded this game on Kickstarter (Sep 2012), and I have been eagerly waiting for the game’s release. It has been well worth the wait and the game has far exceeded my expectations.

I have always been a fan of the original Baldur's Gate and Fallout games. If you enjoy these types of games, you will definitely like Pillars of Eternity.

The writing and dialog was done very well in the game. You will need to be prepared to do a lot of reading, only a small (critical) portion of the game is voiced. If you end up skipping through most of the dialog, you might be lost, or required to read cliff notes.

Highly recommend this game, 9/10

reviewText:
An isometric RPG following in the steps of predecessors like Baldur's Gate and Icewind Dale,Pillars of Eternity might not be as good when compared to them but remains nonetheless an enjoyable experience.

Pros:

-nice story overall,some companion and side quests are very nice aswell
-decent graphics,even though they don't hold up when zoomed close
-good soundtrack
-a few interesting classes amongst the usual archetipes
-good character customization
-nice party banter
-lots of dialogues,books,things to check to flesh out the game world
-the stronghold is pretty interesting
-good amount of zones to explore and lots of quests
-the game system-not the usual DnD fare-is pretty interesting
-original setting
-you can create your own party members if you don't want to use the story ones

Neutral:

-lots of micromanagement party-wise,you're expected to pause often in combat to give orders/activate skills
-some fights can be difficult

Cons:

-while the story is interesting overall it's very slow to unfold and lacks the sense of grandiose that was found in older games
-the game system isn't fully explained,leaving one to guess certain game mechanics,this is even more troubling during character creation
-some pathfinding issues
-some areas are poorly designed for combat,leading to the party getting stuck in narrow corridors/doorways and being unable to fully engage the enemy
-lack of proper party AI leads to the aforementioned micromanagement,which can get tiring in the long run
-not all party members are equally interesting,some are a bit boring or have lacking quests
-some quests can be a bit dull,or have pooor directions,especially when you're trying to remember where the original quest giver was
-stealth is a bit hit or miss (no way to stealth single characters,must stealth to find traps/secrets)

Overall this is a good game that sadly suffers a bit when compared to its predecessors,it lacks the engaging story and characters and the depth the DnD system and setting gave to the games of old.
I got it for 25$ and am satisfied with the purchase,but considering the Enhanced Editions of Baldur's Gate are available for even less makes it a tough call overall.

Still,if you already played those and are looking for more-or just want something more modern-Pillars of Eternity does have enough going for itself to make it a worthwile purchase and an interesting experience to play through, especially considering isometric RPGs are not that common these days (even though we're enjoying a resurgence with other good titles like Shadowrun and Wasteland 2).

reviewText:
I had high hopes for this game. Added it to me wishlist back when it first showed up on Steam.  I did not pick it up however till it was on sale for 50% off. It had many good reviews, so I gambled and bought it.  It's not a bad game, the story is decent enough so far. I can't say it really grabbed me, and made me not want to stop playing like other games have in the past.

Some of the game mechanics, while novel, I just don't care for.  Healing your health is only possible by camping or spending the night at an Inn.  This is seperate from Endurance, which I believe everyone can heal at some point in the game with magic, talents, or abilities, etc. I have heard there are healing potions, but, as of yet, have not found any myself. It might just be the old school RPG player in me, but, this system seems very counter intuitive.  If I just got mauled by a bear, how is spending the night in an Inn or camping in a tent going to heal those wounds up, and yet the classes that in most RPG's online or pen and paper, that can traditionally heal with magic, can't do anything but restore endurance...which is what I consider to happen while resting in an Inn or elsewhere, to do. I have seen several comment on this in various forums, saying it creates a challenge, or finite resource, yadda yadda.  It's a deal breaker for me.  I'm not playing an RPG, for the challenge of deciding how to reduce how many times I have to go stay at an inn or buy more camping gear. But, that's just me I guess.

Visually, it's a good looking game. Some of the maps are a bit small, but, everything I have seen so far, looks good. Spell effects and lighting are well done.

Character creation is fairly in depth.  Various choices can create different play styles from the same class. Classes are not restricted to certain weapons and armor, which I did like.  The weapons and armor do have tradeoffs, such has speed of attack, recovery time after using abilities, etc. This in itself creates a new challenge of optimizing your gear to suit your abilites and combat/play style. One of the concepts that I could work with.

Combat is fast paced, and had many options to autopause on various events happening. Also several options for the AI behavior during combat. Although a few times, it seemed like the AI was doing it's own thing, regardless of the settings I had selected.

Overall, just not my cup of tea I guess. Would rather play Balders Gate again or fire up Neverwinter Nights.  I wish I had done a bit more research on it. But that is just speaking for me.

reviewText:
I played through the game but didn't find myself enjoying it. Cannot recommend.

Here are some reasons why:
Exposition is overwhelming.
Very combat oriented conflict solving. I expect more from CRPGs nowadays.
Endurance/Health: Overly complex HP system. I understand the purpose but didn't like the implementation.
World lore is kinda cool but often forced fed to the player and presented in places where it doesn't really seem to fit naturally.
Main plot line doesn't direct the player to do sidequests, gain xp or improve gear; even though high level and decent gear is required for the final battle. Following main plot only results you being in the final battle with inadequate means to solve it.
Upgrade your castle"-minigame felt unnecessary and tacked on. I felt like I should care but main plot seemed to forget it right after introduction."

reviewText:

IIf you care too much about graphics, AAA game cutscenes, fast paced 0 depth combat you are not going to like this game. To Finish, the writing is very good, The pre rendered HD visuals looks stunning no matter what people say, this is a beatutifull game, the sound and the soundtrack is really good and feels on point on what you are doing. i dont want to spoil you anything, but this game has so much depth its scary. I havent messed yet with the enchanting system, or crafting, but its all there, everything a good rpg should have is there.

This game takes the RPG'S genre to its former glory, there is nothing like it right now, if you liked Baldurs Gate, Dungeon Siege 1 and the likes YOU CANT MISS THIS ONE.

IT´S THE BEST RPG RIGHT NOW, THERE´S NOTHING LIKE IT,  IT´'S JUST THAT GOOD.  10/10

reviewText:
Hands down just a fantastic RPG game. Whether you are exploring the countryside, chatting to your fellow adventurers about the history of the region or more interestingly about their background, to crawling through dark dungeons in search of unspeakable riches, Pillars of Eternity delivers on every level. It's gorgeously designed and conceived, it's got all of the depth in both the story and the worlds lore, the interactions are meaningful and interesting, the battles exciting, tactical and rewarding.

For me personally, it's an absolute masterclass in what I would call a traditional RPG game. If you are considering buying this game I can guarantee you that if you like an immersive and exciting adventure you will not be disappointed.

Good luck out there.

reviewText:
Nearly everything you'd want going into the game as an Obsidian/Black Isle/Bioware before everyone with talent left fan, PoE's only real failing is teasing the player with hints of more than it has to offer.  Out of the gate the game has the impression of something truly staggering in scope but ultimately lets itself down, like a large painting of Mount Rushmore set up on a cliff.  It's still a nice painting, it's just not quite as impressive as the real thing and setting it up to look like it only deflates the experience.

For starters the game front-loads itself heavily, throwing a couple small towns with big problems at you that do a good job of setting up the world, the problem is they're static.  Once you solve problem du jour the area is done, the NPCs hardly react to what you've done and nothing of consequence happens in them ever again.  There is one quest that sorta comes back later, but nobody in the town reacts either way the first or second time you deal with it, that's all handled in an epilogue.

This is a game where weeks pass and country-shaking events unfold.  A little reactivity would be nice, give some life to those areas beyond Questing Zone #.  The whole point of going with the text heavy exposition model is so the developers can add content without adding a whole bunch of assets to the game and it feels like an opportunity was missed when you're wandering through the streets of a town plagued by a cult or a despot weeks ago and every single person is just saying and doing the same things they were before.

The game also gives you a stronghold.  On the surface you think it might be like Neverwinter Nights 2, where you have to build it up from a ruin and make ruling decisions about the surrounding lands, but you never get so far as deciding anything and the gameplay rewards promised by the various functions of the keep are marginal at best.  It pulls double duty as the Watcher's Keep of the game, and to its credit that part is pretty well done, though that bit has zero connection to actually ruling the Keep and surrounding lands beyond a nonspecific threat that I assume gives you a very frowny epilogue if you don't take care of it.

It really lost me at the end of Act 2, when a villain so far established as a master of clandestine schemes demonstrates that he can just do whatever he wants whenever he wants.  Adding to that Act 3 feels empty by comparison, even after opening up a 2nd big city" it lacks any really meaty content to round out the game like Ust Natha did in BG2.

Even with all that said
date: the story and the big pieces in it are still pretty strong.  Darth Sidious pulling out a lightsaber and murdering everyone he has a problem with not withstanding
recommended: all the character motivations and actions are well handled.  It's a little Baldur's Gate here and a little KotoR there and a lot of Jade Empire all over the place
hoursPlayed: but it all comes together to make something new and interesting."

reviewText:
I loved baldur's gate and star wars knights of the old republic, and I'm voting no, simply because I personally wouldn't buy it at the currently advertised steam price. If you can get a cheaper version elswhere or get it on sale for more than half off then I'd be more inclined to recommend it, because it's not a bad game per se.

Pros:
Nice graphics, music, class variation and customanization. There are plenty of quests, and classes and talents seem to have a lot of depth. Still curious to see what other classes like priest and druid can bring to the table.

Cons:
-Story was vastly inferior to other games like SWOTR and BG2; found myself skipping a lot of the dialouge.
-From gameplay, plot twists and character interaction, baldur's gate 2 and the first SWOTR did almost everything better.
-Gameplay and spell mechanics came across as clunky and repetetive; was difficult to notice improvements after gaining certain talents.
-Quests were ambigiously described (i.e. find cave described in vision).
-I don't know if it's a pro or a con because of the whole if it's not broken don't fix it" philosophy
date: but the game lacked innovation in the sense that at times it came across as an inferior knock off of baldur's gate.\n\nIn short
recommended: the game wasn't bad. I had fun playing it and all
hoursPlayed: though it was just redudant or inferior if you've played other games in the genre. Perhaps most importantly
voteText: for whatever reason it lacked that extra "spark" that really gives a game something extra."

reviewText:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TQAaViT0VoQ&feature=youtu.be

Pillars of Eternity: Pillars of Eternity, a Kickstarter (77,000!) CRPG developed by Obsidian Entertainment and published by Paradox Interactive. First a bit of a disclaimer, I have NOT completed the main story of Pillars of Eternity, I am currently in Act 2 and have put almost 30 hours into the game already. Anyways, on with the review!

---->This game takes lovers of RPGs back to some of the roots of some of the most beloved video games ever, titles like Baldur’s Gate, Icewind Dale and my personal favorites Fallout and Planescape: Torment are all great examples of CRPGs and some of the highest rated games of all time. I could go on, but, just know that Pillars of Eternity is a game that will take you back to those great experiences while delivering its own. Like all CRPGs the game takes an isometric point of view, you see everything from the sky, looking down, giving you the ability to appreciate grand landscapes and structures that are beautifully done in the game.Things like large buildings, bridges, forest, swamps, the ocean, all are beautifully crafted and the isometric point of view has always been perfect for show-casing these types of games, it looks beautiful and you don't need a top-of-the-line gaming computer to appreciate it. The music scores in CRPGs are usually on par with its excellent graphics and Pillars of Eternity is no different. Every soundtrack fits the mood perfectly and really compliments the atmosphere and setting, the only music that will get annoying is when combat starts, it’s the exact same every time and gets a bit annoying, but the rest of the tracks are amazing.

---->Gameplay is pretty straight forward, use the mouse and click on the ground to move your character, the mouse is your primary device, you have plenty of keyboard hot keys to use as well to assist with things like selecting characters, formations and dialogue options. The interface is nice and slick, not too barebones, not too cluttered and laid out in a very nice fashion, and easily customizable as well. Speaking of customization the character builder in this game rocks! You have a total of five races to choose from, many of which have sub races, then you have eleven classes to choose from, each one quite unique and different and most importantly, useful, you will definitely find favorites but, from my experience, every class can easily be useful alone and in a group and that is a welcomed addition to any RPG. You'll also get to choose color pallets for your characters, multiple voices, and very beautifully detailed portraits. You could and easily will drop many hours in the character creator and still find new characters to create, the best part is the game allowing this to be used throughout the game, as you get the ability to create new companions in addition to finding story ones early in the game, it’s a nice feature, allowing you to create one of every class and try out a multitude of playstyles and strategies for combat.

---->Combat can be hit or miss, I personally enjoy it, but, I can see it being boring or frustrating to some. First, your characters never do anything on their own, even when getting abused with mace blows or shot at with pistols they will stand there taking it all without ever attempting to retaliate. You HAVE to tell your companions exactly what to do no matter what it is, they will not do anything without an order, and when it’s a party of six, fighting multiple bad guys, that can get a bit slow, this isn't helped by the fact that you'll be pausing combat a lot to tell a character to do something after they've done their previous action. Another annoyance with combat is that characters will often run into each other, and will not attempt to move around each other instead, just running forward till whatever is blocking them is out of the way, this makes unit placement annoying and frustrating, I cannot stress enough how important it is to create custom formations to help alleviate this head ache. I'm harsh on the combat but, overall, I enjoy it a lot, the game lets you be as brute force or strategic as you wish and really rewards you for coming up with clever combos and will definitely challenge you with tough fights that will require every bit of cunning and cleverness you can muster. Magic is a lot of fun, spells are flashy and look amazing and actually feel like they pack a punch, they're exciting to use and I would strongly suggest bringing magic along for any fight.

---->Something else you also get fairly early in the game is the Stronghold, this is a player home that you get to upgrade throughout your adventure, allowing you to add multiple shops, a bounty board, a treasury and more. It’s in a ruined state and will look quite impressive as you get closer and closer to completing all of the upgrades, you'll also be able to hire guards to help defend from interlopers, you'll receive taxes to help fund your adventures, and side missions for your companions to do. It’s an awesome castle they give you early on and access to one of the biggest dungeons in the game, there are some missed opportunities with the Stronghold, one that I will share is you can actually arrest NPCs in the world and put them in your prison...and that’s it. You never get to do anything outside of that and your only option is to release them or they will escape on their own eventually. I'm not sure what the point is and haven't discovered anything you can do with it so it just seems kind of pointless, still the Stronghold is awesome and I devoted almost all of my resources early on to restoring it and exploring the dungeon beneath.

---->So the story, hmm, well I haven't finished it so I can't give you a full debrief on it, however, my impression is that it is not as strong or gripping as it could have been. You find out early in the game that you are what is called a Watcher, someone who can peer into the souls of the living, and see the past lives of that person. Unfortunately this awakened something inside yourself and as told to you by a crazy man, you too will suffer the fate of all of your past lives all living with you at the same time, driving you insane and ultimately to your doom. You set out to find a cure and get swept up into other bigger things going on. The story sounds great, the idea of the Watcher is awesome, it just isn't utilized to its fullest; the world becomes background to your concerns, that is to say that at least from the point I’ve played, the world doesn't seem to care about your success or demise. That is a very fitting setting, but it’s a tough sell to engage the player in, since there isn't a life threatening doom approaching, what was needed was strong personal reasons to motivate the player. Again, this all seems very passive and aside from the occasional staring into space, being a Watcher doesn't seem to really be as bad as the world cracks it up to be.

---->Again this is from my point of view and I admit I have not finished the story, but there are only a few acts and by now I would expect to have a full understanding of all that is going on, if they reveal something later on perhaps my opinion will change, but, it shouldn't take till Act 2 to be invested in any story...

[Video Review at: www.youtube.com/RoyialNetwork] (Review was too big for Steam and YouTube, so its been split up link to video above, sorry about that! Thank you for reading and watching!)

reviewText:
The bugs that people are citing as reasons to avoid the game simply are not that bad. Don't double click inventory. If you encounter one of the other bugs, sorry, but the game itself is imminently playable as is. The combat is hard but fun (once you get past the first town's temple which has inexplicably engagement breaking enemies). The art is beautiful. The character creation is extensive and meaningful. The story is rich. The world is rich. The quests are varied. The companions are varied (though they can't compete with nostalgia). The dungeons are deep.

It's not perfect but it's one of the best RPGs in years. It's not trying to be an MMO like some modern RPGs. It can be obtained legally without DRM! That in and of itself is amazing.

While the Dragon Age series has gotten more and more faceroll with thin plots and a built in dating sim, Pillars has focused on making intense, tactical combat and a rich game world, and they did it very well.

Does the might stat make sense? No. Are there a couple bugs? Yeah. Is it fun as heck? Yes. It's an experience I would recommend to anyone, as it doesn't jerk you off while picking your pocket as is the modern trend. It delivers a real game, with real depth, and many hours of play. It's exactly what games should be.

reviewText:
Wanted to like this game but another one of those where you will end of saving every few seconds and some ways of implementing things that just make the game the opposite of fun.

-Spell use - limited by number of casts between sleeps (meaning you better carry tons of firewood) .  Reminds me of C&C 4 and the depature from typical RTS.  Just makes the game un enjoyable. Some say they do this to make it more challenging and or casters are too powerful. I personaly would rather see less dmg on a caster with the ability for me to actually cast without having to rest.  Never knew micromanagement could be done in an RPG - these programmers found a way for that.

- Gone with the Wind type texts for everything.   Overwelming amount of texts for the most simple things.


Way overly compliacted.  You have 5 main upgrade choices on levels. Lore Scroll reading, Survival (consumable duration), Stealth,, Mechanics (lock picking), and Athletics.

Typical RPG's use INT / STR / DEX / CON etc where you apply points into these when leveling - not here.  I only found gear could upgrade those and very modestly.

Items / Gear upgrades are very anti - exciting as you realize that any low level item can be enchanted" to Exceptional / Superb which is the same as the drops you get from bosses - making the boss drops nothing special.

Endurance is now part of the equation similar to "health" - when your endurance hits zero you pass out (in a fight) but your health doesn't improve.  There is no healing or health potions - just endurance.  But you can die apprently if your health goes to zero. Not sure why not just sticking to basic Hitpoints was a bad thing.

MOBS you kill give you virtually no xp - experience gain is mainly quest driven. The items dropped are just an overabundance of useless items maybe for potions or vendor trash.

One aspect I liked was owning a "stronghold" so you can rest there and get bonus'.  Initially it was great until you realize it's nightmare always attenidng to "unwanted visitors" that you have to pay off to not stay (it brings negative prestige) or escort and are constantly getting invaded that I have to go back to the stronghold (2 days travel) to fight.  You can have it auto resolve by hiring defenders that get paid but that means you can take damage to your stronghold.  Good idea that turned into more micromanagement.

Some may like this unobvious level of micromanagement throughout the game- but I hated it.  I will almost guarantee most any person that plays this game will saving every few minutes if that gives an indicator of frustration.    The dragon fights (possible 3)  - I never got through any of them - not even close to defeating one (i was level 12 the max level).

The main battle at the end same thing.  I got to the end - but game so frustating - uninstalled the game with only 1 boss to kill at the end."

reviewText: Character Classes:\n\nThere is a massive imbalance between the powers of various classes.  If you like playing a spellcaster, then you will probably hate this game because of the bizarre and excessive limitations placed on their spell casting.  If you like playing an Archer, then you may be disappointed because you are stuck with a weak pet, and when that pet (quickly) dies, you will be stuck doing wimpy damage.  The melee classes are all pretty strong, and they added a strange new type of melee-spellcaster that trumps all of the magic users combined.   It's almost like the devs hated magic users, but begrudgingly allowed one halfway decent class that is magic but isn't magic" for marketing purposes.   In any case

reviewText:
I love games like this. I grew up on them and played them for hundreds of hours. This feels like uninspired garbage. 24 hours of play, multiple starts, tried about every class/build, and it still feels lacking. I feel like this is a ripoff of the old games with a slightly new skin, just executed in a pretty pathetic way. Yup, lets remake an old goodie. When we do it lets rip out its soul and ruin everything fun about it!

Combat is lame and unispired. Not to mention the really stupid mechanics. Itemization in the game is horrible. The magic system made me want to throw things. Mages were my fav in BG2. They are pitiful in this game. I feel like there aren't any real differences in the classes/character builds other than the animation that executes.

Also seems like you end up with 3 types of character: 1. Glass cannon that gets munched in one or two shots. 2. Tank that would lose in arm wrestling to a three year old, but can take a beating like a porn star. Oh, yeah, they don't get any effective combat management skills either....3. Middle of the road that ends up not good or bad at anything (but you miss all of the dialogue options without having at least one buff stat). Seems like you spend a lot of time building a character to not have it mean anything. It really torqued me that I coudn't build a chracter that did what I thought it would do.

Loading screens... With a modern system and SSD's this game shouldn't be such a slug. I like to read but there are ridiculous walls of meaningless text less interesting than a high school social studies book. Meh. End rant.

reviewText:
This game has no edge. Icewindale 2? The story of twin Demons kicked out of hell, who decided to go on a rampage because the human world rejected them? That's edge. Min/Max stats for godly mages/fighters, edgy. Fun.

Pillars is, the higher your level, the more overpowered you become, end of story. It gets to a point where your six-peon squad is so deep in DPS that you stop casting spells, buffs, and mostly just watch your team go to town while using a handful of abilities to kill everything, at all times.

Pre-buffing was eliminated. Tweaked? Nerfed? No, gone. Armor restrictions as well, which makes for awkward scenarios where I have a Druid in full plate swinging a giant mace in the middle of a fight with the rest of them. I got half way through the game with that character and thought, wait, that's a Druid?

In Wasteland 2, when I make a team, they have character, my sniper can't move, but kills everything and can take weapons apart to boot. My run and gun is a team leader with great charisma and great bomb disposable skills. My specialist knows the ins and outs of computers, locks, and safes, while being a smart ♥♥♥, but dose the least damage.

My fighter eh.. uh. My fighter, is in a DPS race with my rouge, and my cipher. Everyone else just kinda stands around taking up space. In pillars I can't latch onto anything I create because the system isn't integrated enough with itself, or with the world it occupies. I have 200 hours and beat the game once, because once you hit lvl 10, you know that's as much fun as you're going to get, and the rest is just talking to uninteresting people, and slogging through what's left.

I dunno, what's going on Obsidian? Where is the beef? Why didn't you just make the god-bomb plot the story of your game? That was edgy, exciting, instead it's background info. What's better, the reincarnation of a god going toe to toe with locals and ending the game with a big frickin' explosion? Or playing as some guy chasing down another guy, cause he has voices in his head? Please, get some bolas before you make Pillars 2.

reviewText:
Pillars of Eternity is a love song to the cRPGs of yesteryear, drawing inspriation from the Baldur's Gate series and Icewind Dale.

Gameplay occurs at a fixed, isometric perspective - evocative of the aforementioned games. The player explores a rich fantasy setting with up to five companions. Though dungeons and questlines are relatively linear, branching dialogue provides various ways for the player to influence the world of Eora and the lives of its inhabitants.

Combat centers around a real-time with pause system, allowing the player to strategically position party members and coordinate their actions. An expertly-balanced learning curve is partnered with four difficulty settings (easy, normal, hard and Path of the Damned), along with two optional game mods (Expert Mode and Trial of Iron) to provide extra challenge for seasoned players.

The story contains suprrising depth and nuance, provoking unexpected emotion over the course of its many hours. Thematically, Pillars of Eternity explores the immutability of the soul and the role memory plays in informing our conscious and unconscious actions.

Graphically, Pillars of Eternity is a feast for the eyes. Obsidian's artists worked diligently to make little aspects of the world spring to life through the creative use of visual effects and lighting. Using the Unity engine, the developers created environments that appear to have depth, but are actually flat images and planes. A demonstration of how the environments are created can by found here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ak52BLOFyuo

Pillars of Eternity is an instant classic, taking its place alongside other memorable RPGs.

reviewText: An unfortunate blend of pure combat, overly silly background and a very sad attempt at storytelling, especially given the pedigree this game was trying to recreate.   NPCs tend to fall flat, and it is a very recycled tale of how you, the Chosen One, will completely ignore the special abilites that mark you out as special, the complete lack of consequences that should accompany them (or your actions), and hapharzardly wander to the Overly Tedious Bossfight that has no meaning beyond being the end of your suffering (as a player).\n\nThe designers made a lot of questionable decisions regarding the utility of abilities, choosing to ape the approach of 4e D&D, where if combat music isn't playing, your class abilities mysteriously don't work, and nothing outside of combat is particularly meaningful.   Unfortunately, combat is a muddy mess of poor programming and bad AI, and the best approach to any combat is find a doorway and exploit the hell out of the repetitive handful of critters.

reviewText:
This game had a quadruple budget than the intended, and it still was way worse in almost every aspect than Baldurs gate.

To begin, this is a 9/10 of a game, but the comparison here, as in the original video before the kickstarter, is with baldurs gate 2.

What annoyed me about the game:

There was no engagement on the quests, i never felt the urgency to actually complete a quest

The total playable content felt very limited

The music was really BAD, which is ridiculous in this day and age with 3 milllion extra budget, you got games like the banner saga and endless legends with amazing music, but you just had to go on and ruin this game.

There were many flaws that kinda broke the 4th wall. When ingame cutscenes ended, the characters instead of walking out of the building (like in bg2 20 years ago) the screen went black and they suddenly disappeared. This and many other minor overlooked stuff, really brought the game down a level.

I wont get into the spells system or the weapons, i never really felt engaged to the weapons or spells, whatever had the highest damage i used, everything looked the same, and i still finished the game in hard.

A friend of mine also mad about BG2, didnt even finish this game.

What mostly annoys me, is that with another 6 months of developing time, this game could have been an 11/10, without really much efforts, just some different choices in the decision making phase....

I was overhyped when it came out, and now im writing a negative review

reviewText:
Before 2.0 I would have given this a recommendation. If they fix 2.0 I'll update it with a recommendation.
Until then, steer clear, because:
-Pathing in combat is broken. Your characters will refuse to go where you click, often going an entirely different direction if they move at all.
-Various spells and powers don't work without setting AI to Aggressive (I don't want AI on at all), which is just silly.
-Enemies randomly stop attacking and begin regenerating endurance rapidly. Sometimes combat music stops when this happens. Sometimes the re-aggro. Sometimes they don't.

This is the majority of the problems, but there are other small issues that were introduced as well.
I hope it's fixed. I really want to recommend this game because it was really good when it was playable. It's just a total mess right now. Combat is unavoidable at various points for many quests, so the whole game is borked at the moment.

I'm not removing the above, because the fact that it happened at all is a travesty, and should not be forgotten.

reviewText:
WARNING BEFORE YOU BUY THIS GAME;

TL;DR - Incredible gameplay and story, with heartbreaking loading times FOR SOME COMPUTERS. Download a third-party mod to disable auto-saving for a semi-fix.

Due to the auto-save feature requiring the saving of extremely large file sizes (gets worse as the game progresses) each time you load up a new or old area or even a house within that area there is a 1-2min load time. Sounds small, but there are a lot of areas in this game.
This is so bad that there is a fairly successful mod designed to simply enable the ability to turn off the autosave feature - this mod has been updated 73 times (upon writing this). A simple fix of allowing the option disable the auto-save feature would make this game playable without mods.
Note that mods are made redundant with each new update to the game - avoid updating the game until the mod is updated...

THIS DOES NOT APPLY TO ALL COMPUTERS - check online first to see if someone else has had this problem with your system. I experienced this on a fairly old Mac, however I've read this happens with better systems as well. A quick bit of research could save you 20-50 bucks.

The few hours I put into this game were incredible. The story, the combat, the difficulty and the progression are amazing. It's a shame that I had to cut it short because I don't feel like spending half my play-time on loading screens.
Around about 15-20 hrs into the game the load times become unbearable.

It's a shame that the publishers decided to promote expensive DLC before doing (presumably) simple playability fixes on a game they've obviously put a lot of love into.

reviewText:
UNINTERESTING STORY - NEEDS MORE NPCS/LIFE - GREAT GRAPHICS - FUN FIGHTS

I'm a fan of the Baldur's Gate series (Greatest game and story of all time) and to make this short, if you like RPGs you might enjoy this one though it's not nearly as good as the Baldur's Gate games (which is the standard I measure these games to).

It needs a better story, I first tried playing this game when it released and was confused and lost, then after trying again I've now found myself skipping dialogue (something I normally don't do with these games) because the story isn't very interesting.. I don't have the urge to push on, I just kinda play it..

Needs more life... Most of the NPCs are flavor text or just there to make cities and villages look alive...I want more side quests, or random dialouge like in the Baldur's Gate games...The soul stories are even less interesting than the story.

Combat is good, and fun though it takes some adapting to if you're used to the D&D style games and rules.

Graphics are amazing.

If you like RPGs, buy it. Obsidian needs to make a better story for the next game however and build on what they've done successfully here.

reviewText:
Ugh, i really wanted to like this game, but it's not for me. I've been a huge Baldur's Gate fan since forever ago, and i'm really happy that the genre legacy continues (since stupid Dragon Age keeps moving further and further away from it, i'm glad at least someone still tries making these types of games). But I just couldn't get into this one. I think if you're into hardcore d&d and read a ton of that kind of literature - you'll love this. For me the appeal of these games is combat and strategy and it just wasn't enticing enough here. I got so bored towards the end that i rushed through everything, skipping through every dialog.
On an unrelated note i thought it was funny that they had that combat music that's pretty much straight out of De-Arnise keep (BG2). And Twin Elms had a theme that was very Kuldahar (Icewind dale).

Pros:
Baldur's gate gameplay.
Story is not stupid and cheesy.
You can create your own party and not have to use official companions.
There is a bit of that keep management stuff (although not much).
Decent amount of content.
Some interesting combat ideas but read on for cons because those mechanics get meh further into the game.
Party members have decently unique personalities. Even the bland-♥♥♥ elven mage was spiced up with a secret.

Cons:
Wayyyy too much reading: paragraphs and paragraphs of text on every dialog. That may be a pro for some people, but i've read enough in my lifetime and i'm tired of it.
Combat mechanics too complicated (too many different defenses/resistances/stats/conditions, it may not be more complicated than modern d&d rules but d&d rules have been building up slowly for a long time, while this game just jumps straight into complicatedness.) And i either never found much explanation on how stuff works as far as damage application goes, or i found it and it was more paragraphs of text and i got bored reading it.
Party members join up too easily and will never leave you, so there wasn't that much roleplaying with them, and also no alignment thing that dramatically restricts how the world perceives you, (yeah yeah there is reputation with different factions but i didn't notice much gameplay difference with that).
Unique items: that's one of the main complaints i have. They weren't amazing enough or hard enough to get. I want stuff like Carsomyr +5 (BG2). You had to kill one of the hardest enemies in game for it, and only a specific class could use it, but once you get it - it makes a huge difference, (and then you can go after Kangaxx! :P). Here - i got so many clutter drops from enemies and every once in a while there was a small upgrade but it never really made a big enough impact.

Anyway, overall this is not a bad game, and if Steam used a number rating i'd give it a 7 out of 10 maybe. But i didn't love it, i have no desire to replay it, and i wouldn't recommend it to any of my friends. It was like going to steak and shake late at night. Nothing else is open, and the milkshakes are good, but the service was mediocre at best and if I had a choice - i would have gone somewhere else.

reviewText:
Cannot recommend it. Can not hold a candle against old school RPG's like Baldurs Gate or the Black Eye (the very very old one).

It looks okay on the first glance, but the deeper you go the more boring it gets. Sure, there's a ton of spells and recipes and skills. But all the spells are for damage or protection, the enhancements is just luck about what you will find (no foraging skills or anything like that). The levelups are to far between. The whole thing is more trying to confuse you in quantity instead of quality.

That is also true for the group. 6 guys plus 1 pet and if you have a few creature spells you are with 12 guys in a fight. It's just to much. The AI is dumb as f*** and no matter what you activate, if you don't control each one of these guys by hand and tell them to use a special attack they really won't be efficient or use it clever at all.

And so the fights become more of a bore then fun. And really, without the fights there isn't much left. The world feels stale. Characters just stand around doing nothing. Also finding quest givers is hard work, there is no indication where they could be.

I can only imagine that the high ratings for this game come from the fact that there is simply no alternative if you like remotely this kind of game. But really, I prefer to pack out Baldurs Gate again then playing this crap any further.

reviewText:
I like this game, and it has a ton going for it. It's a fun RPG setting and an interesting story. I spent a lot of time on it (which makes #2, below, so bad). You can tell a lot of passion went into it.  It's very close to a 'yes' recommendation.

But...  here's the reasons for a 'no':

1) Loading screens and load time. It's way too much too often.
2) A very bad bug that occured  late in the game. One of my main NPCs (Eder) I took out of my party for a little bit, and when I put him back in, all of his gear was gone, he was level 1, and the next time I loaded, he was missing from my character roster completely. Losing an entire character with a lot of time-earned gear was very frustrating.
3) The lore comes at you with an assumption that you already know some of it, or so it seems. It can be a bit overwhelming at first, throwing names of regions, races, gods, historical events, etc, at you. It might be a bit better paced, but that could be preference.
4) Minor, but... The kickstarter backer NPCs. They're pointless, and they're all over the place (the first town is especially bad). I wish I was warned about them before reading like 15 of them (which I did because the 'soul reading' mechanic made me think they were important.)

reviewText:
If you liked the old Infinity Engine CRPGs and want something like them, but new, then stop reading this and go buy Pillars of Eternity.

If you've never played them, but have played Dragon Age and enjoyed it, then stop reading this and go buy Pillars of Eternity. It's what Dragon Age tried to be, but fell way short of.

If you don't fall into either of those camps, but like pen and paper RPGs and want something on PC, then you should buy this. It's cut from the same cloth as D&D or Pathfinder or games like that, but with a fantastic twist in the form of fresh lore and new character class types alongside your old familiar favorites.

reviewText:
This is my first review ever, i will start by saying that this a great game, well worth the full retail price, Obsidian has done great work considering the budget that they had to develop this game on. The game may have a few bugs but i did not run into any on my time playing it and if there are any they would not detract from the fun romp this game is.

Pros
-Great Story
-Great Companions
-Choices that actually matter
-You actions shape other characters opinons of you- People will reflect to you differently depending on your disposition- one character may try to kill you while that same character could listen to reason depending on your disposition.
-Challenging Gameplay- ability to structure game for either old school gaming or for those who enjoy the story based aspects more.
-Replayability- Different dialogue choices for different classes and races provides a reason to replay
-Great art style- the storyboards look very good, the hand drawn maps look well crafted and have a certian appeal to them
-15 level dungeon

Cons
-Story takes a while to pick up you do not know a lot about what is going until the middle of the 2nd act
-AI- the game needs the ability to better micromange your characters- the fact that you can not assign standard behaviours to your characters (e.g. heal yourself if under certian edurance/ health) forces to pause and play after each move, this can get frustrating particularly in the large fights with lots of mircomanagement where one wrong move can kill your party (Characters not moving if you have not selected them- they should at least have a default attack)
-Stronghold Management- feels a bit lacking while the bounty quests are good, the stronghold just seems to be a a way to spend the large amount of money you will not need to spend, finished the game with no cash than i needed
- A few pathfinding issues
