reviewText:
If you love classic CRPGS like Baldur's Gate, Icewind Dale or Planetscape: Torment then you owe yourself to pick up this game. I've played almost 50 hours now and it's utterly brilliant. In a time where CRPGs have been reduced to AAA titles with QTEs, linear progression and being spoon feed every morsel of information Pillars comes as a blessing of both nostalgia and fresh air. The character creation is brilliant, the classes deep and interesting and the combat is strategic and tough, yet very rewarding. But it it's the lore and the graphics that really makes this game so brilliant. Your adventures in Dyrwood will immerse you into a world with a rich history, interesting races, frightful monsters, a pantheon of gods, and tons of interesting NPCs. The hand drawn graphics really brings this wonderful world to life in a way 3D graphics just can't.

For the younger players or those who never played the classics CRPGs of the late 90s, get ready for a bit of shock. Be ready to spend hours reading text, from old tomes, diaries to treaties on local history, books on culture, religion and factions. You'll also spend lot of the game time reading descriptions of characters and events. The game won't spoon feed you lore, it asks you to find out by yourself. It asks you to explore and understand, like all great RPGs should. This is a game that asks you to invest and apply yourself, but if you do it will reward you handsomely for it. The world feels more real and immersive because of it.

In short, this is wonderful game and all RPG fans need to pick it up, because we need more games like it.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText: This game is great for all the reasons everyone says it is. I especially liked the unique races and classes, as well as Obsidian's original fantasy world and storyline. This fully-realized history really makes the game stand out as more than an update or clone of previous CRPGs set in some TSR world that's been around for ages.\n\nI also liked the Stronghold maintenance sidegame. Ever since I started playing AD&D back in the 90s I have wanted to see one of my characters acquire property and attract followers. Well done.

reviewText:
Huzzah for Pillars of Eternity! This is a terrific RPG! Obsidian has rolled a Critical Success with this 3rd Person Fantasy adventure! I have thoroughly enjoyed playing this game.
-Beautiful graphics!
-Lots of conversation choices
-Many different classes and races
-Running and optimizing your own castle and soldiers
-Ability to craft and enchant items
-Funny interaction between NPCs in your party
-Stable as a rock, no technical problems at all
-New world, very unique and different from typical D&D fare
-Easy to play, no great learning curve
-I LOVE the limitless inventory and not having to worry about buying and carrying arrows
-Customizable characters, including your backstory

I have not yet finished the game, but I have played more than 40 hours as of this writing. I am very much hooked and wish to press on, exploring more and learning more about the world that I am in.

I you liked the Baulder's Gate series or Icewind Dale - this is a natural fit.

This is a great, well made game. If you like RPGs or are bummed that you  haven't been able to play one in while, your search is over!

reviewText: If you like Baldur's Gate, this is the game for you. I didn't expect much at first, despite all the positive reviews I read. But DAMN... This is one of the best RPG games I've played in years! It's litterally on par with Baldur's Gate, and that's not said lightly.

reviewText:
When i played this game. I had the same feeling as Skyrim. Playing for countless hours nonstop while having alot of fun while doing so. This is a generic 'turn-based' game, nor is it a game where you can just run in and expect to kill everything.

The game is sort of unique with its combat. It can be played as if it is a turn-based game, it can also be played as if its not. The main thing that seperates this game from others is difficulty. You might (and probably will) get stuck on a certain enemy at some point in the game. That just means you need to change your tactics or go level up or change your party. Once you do beat that...one enemy... that one group... it feels good. Much like the retro games like Contra, although not NEAR as hard. (then again depending on your difficulty...)

This game is amazing, its a topnotch game.


11/10.

reviewText:
This is my first time to dig deep into this type of RPGs. And i really like it. After around 20-25hours of gameplay I decided to start allover again with different class because I didn't think my main character fits in the story by his origin or class. And yes, you should do the same if you feel this way since the game is decently long. I'd rather play thru whole game lovin it than just rush thru it and then start a new char to play properly.

+Deep character creation without limitations like warriors use 2h swords and rogues only daggers" **
+Story so far
+Combat

-** But this might lead you to the point where you start allover like me realizing your char is weird with weird stats so study each stat if not familiar yet
-Graphical style is beautiful but there could be more interactive things/modern touch like Divinity Original Sin had.

I'm not a reaviewer so thats all I say."

reviewText:
This game is a good game, a very good game ! It captured the essence of what made infinity engine games so enjoyable to play and I see myself as a youngling in front of his computer once again.

That being said, this game is, actually, overrated. In fact nearly everything is better executed in BG2. The AI  (ennemies or friends) was better, the UI was better, the story too (event though I'm not nearly finished with it, I played for some times, 10-12 hours, and it is slow to take off...), spell variety is lacking....

And if you think it's nostalgia, I played my last BG game one year ago. In Pillars, when you are behind a tree or a house you see nothing (no option of semi-transparency), you cannot force the orientation of a non-walking character, you don't see what you gain from quest (Well
date: thank you. Here seome gold as rewards !" - wanna know how many ? Well open the inventory before talking to the PNJ
recommended: loot at your amount of gold
hoursPlayed: talk to the PNJ
voteText: substract...). The pathfinding is shamefull
helpfulPercent:
especially in combat ; the other NPC lacks depth ("Hmmm I'm bored.... I guess I will come with you. I just like defying death for no reason") ; secondary quests are somewhat superficial...
And some things in need of a serious upgrade were not done (formation is well and good but if they do not move like it it's useless).

I repeat : it's a very good game for RPG lovers such as myself. But the realization is not on par with a 15 years old game.... So even if it's a good game it does not gain his place as one of the best RPG of all times : too close to Infinity Engine games to not be compared

reviewText:
Before i say anything, i just want to point out that this game kicks butt of ALL bigger title RPG's that have been made recently. I cant believe that Obsidian was almost on the verge of shutting its doors, and then they came up with something like Pillars of eternity. In my opinion, the brightest star of RPG industry currently and the best possible tribute anyone could have done for Baldurs gate's, Icewind Dale's etc. PC D&D rpg games.

If baldurs gate's 1/2, icewind dale's 1/2 were you thing back in the days, i can tell you Pillars of eternity just brought the genre back! Beautiful hand made graphics, orchestral music, top notch plot etc. brings me back to the days when games had just the right amount of difficulty and the player wasn't lead from the hand in every turn.

And dont worry, the game isnt stuck to the early years of rpg's. The UI is very well made to the modern standards, as is many other things such as possibility of hiring" a companion wich is basically creating a filler character in your group by yourself.

The hiring system is a genius idea honestly
date: as you want to have a full group as soon as possible early on in the game. Later on you can also of course find groupable NPC's that have a personality
recommended: opinions and own agenda wich you can choose to proceed if you will.\n\nSo now you get to make a group with every other npc character in game
hoursPlayed: as you can simply fill the empty spots with the hiring system. Smart.\n\nAs you play the game a bit further
voteText: you get your own stronghold where you can build stuff
helpfulPercent: switch your companions
votesHelpful: get buffs after sleeping there etc. Its a great idea
votesTotal:
because you start to get overflowing with money at some point eventually. You need to hire guards wich take weekly payment etc.

Also you can send your overflow hirelings to do your bidding in case you get a writ. Usually a smart move too.

One thing i really loved
votesFunny:
was how the inventory was made. Can't tell you how many times i almost lost my nerve (except in bg2 with bag of holding :) when i had inventory full of stuff and no idea where to put all that junk.

And now... the part that i really REALLY love in this game:

You can carry as much stuff as you ever will want. You have an option to drop stuff to stash whenever you want
commentsCount: and your inventory will never be stuffed of hundreds of "junk" -items
column16: wich btw are worth collecting and selling to vendors as you get back to town.\n\nAlso i've found out that all the items you find (mushrooms
column17: jewels etc.) are in fact useful and worth keeping instead of selling. All books
column18: papers etc. include tips if you read them carefully and use your imagination.\n\nIf you find jewels and herbs etc. you can use them for enchanting/crafting. I even found vendors selling crowbars
column19: climbing hooks with rope
column20: torches etc. All these items that i found useful eventually. Every now and then you gotta pry some bars aside
column21: climb a wall

or possibly torch something up possibly.

AND yes! You can craft anywhere! You can select the item you want to "enchant" and just do it on the spot without finding a forge and flapping thru useless junk in your inventory for hours. This makes the game much more straightforward (in a good sense) and you dont get stuck at inventory for ages.

Also no grinding is involved for crafting. Theres no skill's or such required from what i've seen
column23: no farming etc. You simply check what enchants
column24: foods
column25: potions you want/can make and just hit craft. Sometimes you can learn a recipe or such
column26:
but overall ive found crafting ever so deliciously simple.

Obsidian clearly has realized that spending time in inventory instead of playing has been a fun killer for ages. Theres a lesson to be learned from this for all the big budget RPG -maker's.

reviewText: I've not much to add to what's already been said in praise of this game. It's a 'classic' CRPG, freed from the restrictions of using the D&D licence, and designed from the ground up to have mechanics that make sense on the PC, not a pen and paper RPG.\n\nEverything you loved about Baldur's Gate and other Infinity Engine games is here, but refined. The developers at Obsidian have not coasted this in on famous names - much as that helped the Kickstarter - this is the product of decades of experience in the writing and design of epic CRPG adventures, and it shows.

reviewText: WOW. Just wow. Beautiful, challenging, story and world depth. I haven't quite reached the end and I still have no idea if I am helping or accidentally destroying the world. There are some big ideas and big questions in this one. Everything and the kitchen sink went into this and it shows. I did back this on Kickstarter and Obsidian delivered. The gaming reviews agree that this is a classic. I have had no bugs and if there were bugs they are fixed by now. Quality and attention to detail has clearly been a key focus in this game. I think it'll suck when it ends but I am actually looking forward to trying some of the other classes because they have some very unique skills and all are useful in their own right.\n\nAmazing to see what a real RPG dev can do when they own it and this is their baby. Lots of props to Obsidian for creating something fans have been missing out on for the last 15 years. If you like linearity, boring dialog, reading, seeing things and learning things, puzzles, blowing crap up for no reason or generally using your brain for anything then this is not the game for you.

reviewText: What I really love about it is that I can play for long sessions or for a quick session, completing 1 mission and saving my progress - and either way I'm satisfied. Each mission feels like a chapter of series, making this possible and feel okay to do. Being an adult with a business and family, this is a HUGE plus for me to find a game that is deep and complex, but also respects my time. I wish all games did this. Well done Obsidian, you've created a real masterpiece here.

reviewText: Never bothered writing a review before now but this game has inspired me to. The level of detail and care put into Pillars of Eternity is staggering! The more I play, the more I'm pulled into the games' story and characters. The writing and voice acting are superb and the combat system adresses some of the biggest oversights of the old D&D rulesets that should have been obvious. This is clearly a labour of love for the developers and a true revival of the genre. TAKE MY MONEY!!!!!

voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Best game of its type since Baldur's Gate 2.  Which.... well I guess that's not saying much since there haven't been many but...

Great writing on par with Planescape Torment (though lacking the same depth, somewhat), good interface, interesting, intuitive yet simple combat system.

Little threadbare in some places.  Item diversity could have used some work, as could the crafting system.  And there were some great opportunities for player-specific interaction when backgrounds/homelands/races etc intertwined that were left unexplored.  Also no romance options, which was a bummer, since those were some of the best story sections of games like Baldur's Gate 2.  You could tell they wanted to do everything but ran out of time or money at some point.  Looking forward to expansions/sequels/new games of the same type now that Obsidian has decent proof that games like this can make a profit.

Just... if you liked BG2, buy this game.  Buy it to relive the nostalgia of playing a story-heavy well written game of this type.  Buy it to encourage game devs to keep making these.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
I Just finished the game today.  That was one of the most pleasurable RPG's I have ever played.  After searching for so many years, I have finally found a worthy successor to Baldurs Gate 1 & 2.

There was not a single aspect of the game that I did not completely enjoy.  They hit a homerun in every aspect of this game.

I cannot wait to start a new game and play a different character.

For the record, I give this game a 10 out of 10.  This was truly an outstanding game.

reviewText:
So, you want to lose track of time and adventure until your eyes bleed?  You wish that Baldur's Gate could have lasted forever?  This is the game for you!

The story line is engaging, plenty of freedom to make your own way.  An excellent RPG overall.

Pros:
- Options, lots of them.
- Plenty of quests and side quests.
- Inventory slot for adorable animal companion.
- Spend less money on food by forgetting to eat in real life.

Cons:
- What day is it?
- Some clunky or missing features.  (Combat can get hairy in large groups, no button to re-center on your party)

reviewText:
(Not an in-depth review).

Being new to the genre, I can say that I have enjoyed the game for the most part thus far. The story and plot development is somewhat interesting. The combat mechanics are pretty fun. I do enjoy the upgrade paths available to classes. It can lead to interesting character builds. Altogether, i'm not too sure about replayability at this point of the game (Act II). After all, It does seem like a niche game. I can't say that most players would enjoy the game, but it is worth a try if you're willing to part with the money.

voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bMj1dI1dBLM


Lok’tar humans!  Azbolg the Gaming Orc to review the quasi-renaissance fantasy Pillars of Eternity by Obsidian Entertainment.

A grass roots crowd funding campaign, with over 77,000 backers, raising over 4 million dollars, as it recreated, and maybe surpasses the magic of the classic 3d isometric games of the 90s, the Baldur’s Gate series.  If you are a fan of that series, this game is a definite full price buy, with over 70 hours of content, and if you’re not familiar with the classics of ye old times, and are a fan of real-time strategy, D&D party mechanics, epic storytelling with a vast an immersive world, this game is also for you.

The game begins in a detailed character creation with some new races that I haven’t seen before since my time in Azergoth.  I picked a Wind Godlike Cypher, since I’ve played almost every combo in these kind of games, and this race class combo was refreshing to see something new and creative.  After seeing what kind of companions you can get, I would have re-rolled to an evil halfing monk with the evil voice, since there isn’t any monks companions in the game.  This isn’t a big deal though, because you can hire a custom adventurers of your exact choosing similar to the character creation process at any inn in the game.  It scales off your level too so don’t get too hung up about it.

http://pillarsofeternity.gamepedia.com/Party?cookieSetup=true

The game takes place in an immersive world of Eora, inside a nation known as Dyrwood.  Your character witnesses a ritual and awakens, where you are known commonly as a “Watcher.”  You are now like the boy in the six sense, but hopefully less oblivious, you can speak with dead people, and touch objects to get visions of their past.  Your journey is more or less open-ended, guided by a quest journal.

The music is incredible.  A mix between Lord of the Rings, and also brings back memories of Conan the Barbarian running the fields with his Asian nomad companion, but after listening to it on its own, outside of the game, it reminded me of a mystic mystery, which is what this game is.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mmAiP__OB9k

The unpredictability, and freedom this game gives you, is what keeps you addictively playing like a gamer craving midnight mountain dew.  For example, a boy will tell you a secret if you get him a knife made out of special metal.  You can intimidate him and throw him to the curb like the little snot that he is, or go talk to the merchant who sold the knife to some adventures who you can buy it from or attack them and take it by force, and still decide to kick the puny human kid anyways.  Or it could be as simple as breaking up a drug dealer’s den only to find out things aren’t what they seemed.  There are so many outcomes and options, and it’s up to you as the player to be bewildered by how open all of them are too fit your character’s play style.

A feature Pillars of Eternity has superior to the Baldur’s Gate series is that it allows you to have a stronghold which you can improve upon with time and gold.  It’s too bad you can only build one feature at a time though, but the options are so dynamic and fun, you can even repair the dungeon to imprison people in across your journeys.
Another epic feature of the game is the endless paths below your stronghold.  A standalone game within its own right.  The map is remarkably creative, none like I’ve seen before.  The winding twisting paths are mysterious as you venture forth through the depths to discover who built it.  It is so massive and epic, and addicting!

A few negative criticisms about the game is that you pretty much have to read the whole story’s dialogue.  So you if you are lazy and don’t like to read detailed and captivating storytelling, then this game is not for you.  So accidently you might read and miss some over some key plot points, partly because the dialogue is so rich.  Also sometimes the NPCs will voiced randomly at times, and other times will not be voiced at all, which tells me either that the dialogue was changed or the voice actor couldn’t act it all out, which is disappointing since the voice acting is great, but overall this breaks the immersion.  I wish this game was completely voice acted, even with all the coughs, yacks, and other things, which I hope a sequel or expansion will bring.

A few tips that I can suggest to you if you are going to play it are to turn up the graphics, since they are set a the middle by default, and also you can key bind abilities by moussing over them and hitting the key you want them to be bound too.  If you find the game is too easy, you can raise the difficulty, but I haven’t even at normal difficulty as some casual fights require pause-by-pause tactics.

Pillars of eternity is a vast D&D party adventure with epically rich storytelling, and those fans of these type of strategy RPG games will find that this game not only stand among the classics, but in many ways surpasses them with its unique take on a forgotten game style.  Azbolg gives this game 9 Orc axes out of 10.

This is Azbolg wishing you well human, like,  subscribe, comment, and see you on the battlefield.

reviewText: Pillars is a great game in it's own right. If you loved Baldur's Gate, Planescape: Torment or Icewind Dale, then you will feel at home. The game is very detailed and Obsidian took great care in making every area interesting to explore. There is much dialogue and while the story not as memorable as Planescape: Torment, it still intrduces us to a new world to look to in the future. The game has replay value and Obsidian continues to patch it up. The combat is fun and you will get obliretaed if you don't plan out your strategy. Character builds are very detailed as well, so take your time with that build. Be forwarned though, the game is very buggy and crashes randomly to the Desktop. F5 frequently so that you don't loose progress. I am almost 70 hrs into the game and I am still on Act 2 since I take my time with the game. I highly recommend this game to anyone that loves this genre. It's definitely helped me with my vocabulary.

reviewText:
First review ever!

Loving this game so much, thought I would share a few thoughts.

First and foremost.....Fun.

50 hours in.  So much choice and diversity.  Regret going basic fighter as my first choice, but can choose new skeletal characters from tavern and make them your own to fill your party.  Or you come along premade characters throughout your journey that will fill out your group.  Just made a paladin and ran into a ranger to fill out my, 2 fighter, 1 wizard, 1 cleric group to 6.  Have a chanter at my home castle to do quests for me.

As a D&D fan this game really holds true and makes me feel like I made the character on paper and now am in a Dungeons Masters elaborate adventure.

Best game I have played in a while.  Feel like 50 hours in I am just scratching the surface.  Probably have 150 in before I can beat the game.

If you are in to more turn based RPG games, I recommend Wastelands 2.  Just beat it before I picked this up.  Loved it.  Graphics are behind the times, but gameplay and story were phenominal.

reviewText:
I've been PC gaming for over half of my 24 years of living. (Mixed with a little console gaming) I believe this is the first review I have ever written for a video game.

This is one of the best games I have ever played. RPGs are my go-to Genre of gaming, and Pillars of Eternity hooked me and blew me away all at once.

It took me over 3 hours to figure out the exact Player Character I wanted to play, between the histories and the lore and the backgrounds of the races... there's a lot of content just in character creation. This is a true RPG. This is the TRUE successor to Baldurs Gate, and may even have one of the best narrations in gaming (Yes, I've played Planescape).

The combat is challenging but also very rewarding and the areas you visit are generally very rich in detail and content.

I truly, truly reccomend this game - it is a masterpiece in my standards.

11/10, would buy again.

reviewText: Obsidian Entertainment are the masters of cRPGs, they've had a lifetime of experience with these classics. The game is extremely well-balanced to any play style that suits you. Streamlined 'dnd'-lite rules are much easier to understand and work with than the original Baldur's Gate. Gripping, immersive story that rewards your character creation choices. Soul-reading mechanics make the game flavourful and unique.\n\nAbsolutely worth every penny, show Obsidian your support by picking this up!
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Am really enjoying this game so fare and looking forward to continue playing it. I Have only encountered one bug so fare which was bad enough to make me cuss which was a character became stuck in place unable to move during a boss fight which meant I had to restart from a previous save (cussed because had won a difficult fight but then had to do-over).

Other slightly odd things are creatures such as slime's or shades or the like being able to be tripped over?? or animal companions/ summons being able to start dialogue (can set up party then move up animal to start a dialogue which leads to combat meaning you are not caught out of formation), supper sneak (get a good look at whats ahead with animals who seem to be able to get closer to mobs than party members without being detected), animals can climb like people (if you go up a ladder or climb a vine pets should have to wait/ especially an animal which couldn't be carried by the party .i.e. bear). But these are just miner little quirks I thought and I don't mind so much, except the tripping things which shouldn't be tripable.

As I mentioned at the start I am loving this game and looking forward to continue to play, and I am sure as time progresses and the game is patched and updated it will evolve. I do very much like how combat is calculated and the HP and resting system which makes for a more tactical play style. I also like that I am not picking up +10 item of kill everything every other battle, and that monsters more often than not are dropping the items which they are using .i.e. they are not using a basic weapon in combat but then drop some amazing magical item (which just wouldn't make any sense).

Thanks for the great game and the hours of enjoyment I have had and have left to enjoy, looking forward to any additional content/ updates.

reviewText: This game is everything I hoped for and more. Ive been a big fan of RPG's in general, but lately it seems that the newer ones are dumbed down so that they will sell to a larger demographic. Games like Mass Effect while a decent game, is more of an action game with RPG elements, you never had the freedom to do what you wanted like you had in Fallout 1 and 2, and the Balders Gate series. This game delievers an old school RPG experience with enhanced graphics and great dialogue. The writing in this game is so good that its almost like reading a book. If you have any interest in RPG's, especially old style Fallout or Baldurs Gate, do yourself a favor and buy this game.  This is my first review I have ever written on a Steam game which should go to show how much I think of it.

reviewText:
Solid game, spent 91 hours in my first playthrough and still didn't find everything.
Combats can be extremely tough, Ogre's just flatten groups if you don't take them seriously.
The intensity of the last combat is out of control, took me five tries to make a solid strategy to take it down.
Old Nua is by far the best dungeon crawl I have had in a long time, it reminds me of Pathfinder's Emerald Spire, just a drag down, soul crushing grind to make it to the last floor, and than you have a boss thats harder than anything else expierence in the game.

Three thumbs up, Im working up the courage to give this game another play through at a harder difficulty setting.
This is also important. The characters you get to recruit, make sure one of them has a stupidly high mechanics score.

reviewText: Baldur's Gate 3
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
The goal for Pillars of Eternity was to recapture the essence of old RPG games like Balder's Gate or Icewind Dale.  This game not only succeeds at this...it triumphs.  Character creation is very easy to follow with excellent descriptions and explanations to help you understand your stats, spells, etc.. In-game controls and UI are also easy to master; and with a multitude of options for customizing what you see, how you see it, and when the game will pause itself, you will feel comfortable playing in no time.

While all of that is a major plus, making the game fun to play, the best part of Pillars of Eternity is the story.  The developers could've easily just have done a simple fantasy trope and put the Baulder's Gate skin over it.  Here though, we have a very interesting and engrossing story, one that I instantly fell into and became obsessed over.  Some of the descriptions are down-right poetic.  The music is very well done as well, really captuing the fantasy spirit.

This game will not be fore everyone though.  If you do not like reading a lot of text or if you don't like a lot of point and click dialogue; Pillars of Eternity will not appeal to you.  There are no fast-paced combat maneuvers or CGI cutscenes.  Most of the cutscenes are simply displayed like a Choose-Your-Own-Adventure Novel and combat is really simply picking an attack or spell and unpausing the game to see what happens.  If such a notion doesn't appeal to you, then I would pass on this.  If you have played/enjoyed Balder's Gate or Icewind Dale back in the day or now on your mobile device...then you really will love this game.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
An instant classic, but not without its flaws.

Kickstarter as a history when it comes to nostalgia-bait titles aimed to fans of certain genres, but sadly, the majority of crowdfunded to live up to the expecations they set themselves by appealing to those fans in the first place. For every Shovel Knight, you have dozens of other offerings ranging from mediocre to just flat out bad.

Thankfully, Pillars of Eternity is to CRPG's what Shovel Knight is to Platformers - It doesn't just evoke memories of it's influences, but instead draws up a chair to sit amongst them. Pillars does too much right for me to accurately sum up its brilliance (and shortcomings) in a few paragraphs, but regardless, I'll try my best.

Gameplay is highly customizatable, with multiple tweaks available for all aspects of the game. If you want no help/tooltips while in conversation, but you don't really want the combat to be too hard, then you can do that easily enough. If the reverse is true, and you fancy your chats brief, and your combat nearly impossible, then that's just as easy to set up! It's a very elegant system that, instead of tying multiple values to the same difficulty, allows you to play the game as you wish to play it. And after that, you get to spend an hour (at least) making your perfect hero in Character Select - Woo! Character creation is top notch, with so many variables for each & every class that your character will almost certainly be unique. Each class has it's own pros and cons, and the spell diversity available is nothing short of amazing... Oh, and don't listen to anyone who says Wizards aren't that good - Wizards are awesome!

The story isn't easy - It's anything but. Expect to be VERY confused for the first few hours while every NPC around you references various places & people you've never heard of before as if you're one with the world. But, as time goes by, and it all comes together, you'll be thankful for the early rounds you suffered at the hands of Obsidian's literary boxers. The fascinating world is enhanced by a selection of very varied companions, but I can't overlook the limited number of them available. This could be one of the few cases where a somewhat limited (yet very generous KS) budget might not have allowed them the time to do so, but I really would've hoped for at least one NPC per class. As it is, there's a couple of classes that you can only experience when you make them yourself, which means you're going to endure a lot of silence unless you find yourself writing up a character backstory yourself - Try it!

The art is some of the best I've seen in any videogame. While it may look a tad dated from the compressed screenshots you've seen online, it all makes sense once you boot the game up and admire the beautifully handcrafted environment and real time lighting effects. The sound design is, for the most part, just as solid, however there's a noticeable lack of variety in music. Every combat encounter, regardless of it's importance, is accompanied by the same instrumental piece. It really would've added to the effect of the larger boss encounters if they'd had a new tune like the Curst Battle in PS:T, but hey, it's a minor complaint.

Okay, so what's wrong with the game? Other than the minor gripes listed above, the game does currently have a few bugs that, thankfully, Obsidian should be patching this week. Keybindings could also be handled a lot better. When in combat, if you hover over a spell and press a key, the game will automatically bind that ability to that key - Great, right? But you're never told which keys you can and can't use, and simple things like unbinding the M (map) key while in combat to allow it to be used as an ability should be pretty obvious, but sadly isn't catered for. And damn, aiming wall abilities with just a mouse can be a pain in the backside, but it's manageable.

Minor gripes that, for the most part, don't detract from the overall experience. It's a stunning game that's best experienced blind, so do yourself a favour and give the game a chance before jumping onto YouTube to check out a few videos.

reviewText:
When i played this game. I had the same feeling as Skyrim. Playing for countless hours nonstop while having alot of fun while doing so. This is a generic 'turn-based' game, nor is it a game where you can just run in and expect to kill everything.

The game is sort of unique with its combat. It can be played as if it is a turn-based game, it can also be played as if its not. The main thing that seperates this game from others is difficulty. You might (and probably will) get stuck on a certain enemy at some point in the game. That just means you need to change your tactics or go level up or change your party. Once you do beat that...one enemy... that one group... it feels good. Much like the retro games like Contra, although not NEAR as hard. (then again depending on your difficulty...)

This game is amazing, its a topnotch game.


11/10.

reviewText:
So, you want to lose track of time and adventure until your eyes bleed?  You wish that Baldur's Gate could have lasted forever?  This is the game for you!

The story line is engaging, plenty of freedom to make your own way.  An excellent RPG overall.

Pros:
- Options, lots of them.
- Plenty of quests and side quests.
- Inventory slot for adorable animal companion.
- Spend less money on food by forgetting to eat in real life.

Cons:
- What day is it?
- Some clunky or missing features.  (Combat can get hairy in large groups, no button to re-center on your party)

reviewText: A Hardcore RPG game, one of the greats.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
I am totally swept of my feet. I have been waiting for such a game since P:T in 1999. Many games went out during that 16 years, but none were so perfect as Pillars are. It has everything a perfect RPG might need. Deep, interesting world, great visuals, awesome music, truly living npcs with their own backgrounds.

I am really amazed by the hit system. No more binary hit/miss with flat 5% crit chance. The mechanics built for attack rolls and miss/graze/hit/crit is really awesome. And the best thing is, it works the same on every aspect. Exactly the same formulas work for swinging a sword and casting a spell.

I am playing a paladin and I am really happy that for the first time paladins aren't just uber-good warriors in shining armors. You can select from multiple ways of life, you can be a cruel/aggresive paladin, honest/diplomatic, rational/stoic and more. There is no trivial good-evil axis. There are many dispositions, many possibilities of action.

It is like taking all that is best in Baldur's Gate, Icewind Dale and Planescape: Torment and improving it 300% so that it matches the expectations of today's gamers.

I am harsh when it comes to rating games, but Pillars of Eternity is peremptorily 10/10.

reviewText: WOW. Just wow. Beautiful, challenging, story and world depth. I haven't quite reached the end and I still have no idea if I am helping or accidentally destroying the world. There are some big ideas and big questions in this one. Everything and the kitchen sink went into this and it shows. I did back this on Kickstarter and Obsidian delivered. The gaming reviews agree that this is a classic. I have had no bugs and if there were bugs they are fixed by now. Quality and attention to detail has clearly been a key focus in this game. I think it'll suck when it ends but I am actually looking forward to trying some of the other classes because they have some very unique skills and all are useful in their own right.\n\nAmazing to see what a real RPG dev can do when they own it and this is their baby. Lots of props to Obsidian for creating something fans have been missing out on for the last 15 years. If you like linearity, boring dialog, reading, seeing things and learning things, puzzles, blowing crap up for no reason or generally using your brain for anything then this is not the game for you.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
This game is a good game, a very good game ! It captured the essence of what made infinity engine games so enjoyable to play and I see myself as a youngling in front of his computer once again.

That being said, this game is, actually, overrated. In fact nearly everything is better executed in BG2. The AI  (ennemies or friends) was better, the UI was better, the story too (event though I'm not nearly finished with it, I played for some times, 10-12 hours, and it is slow to take off...), spell variety is lacking....

And if you think it's nostalgia, I played my last BG game one year ago. In Pillars, when you are behind a tree or a house you see nothing (no option of semi-transparency), you cannot force the orientation of a non-walking character, you don't see what you gain from quest (Well
date: thank you. Here seome gold as rewards !" - wanna know how many ? Well open the inventory before talking to the PNJ
recommended: loot at your amount of gold
hoursPlayed: talk to the PNJ
voteText: substract...). The pathfinding is shamefull

especially in combat ; the other NPC lacks depth ("Hmmm I'm bored.... I guess I will come with you. I just like defying death for no reason") ; secondary quests are somewhat superficial...
And some things in need of a serious upgrade were not done (formation is well and good but if they do not move like it it's useless).

I repeat : it's a very good game for RPG lovers such as myself. But the realization is not on par with a 15 years old game.... So even if it's a good game it does not gain his place as one of the best RPG of all times : too close to Infinity Engine games to not be compared

reviewText:
Before i say anything, i just want to point out that this game kicks butt of ALL bigger title RPG's that have been made recently. I cant believe that Obsidian was almost on the verge of shutting its doors, and then they came up with something like Pillars of eternity. In my opinion, the brightest star of RPG industry currently and the best possible tribute anyone could have done for Baldurs gate's, Icewind Dale's etc. PC D&D rpg games.

If baldurs gate's 1/2, icewind dale's 1/2 were you thing back in the days, i can tell you Pillars of eternity just brought the genre back! Beautiful hand made graphics, orchestral music, top notch plot etc. brings me back to the days when games had just the right amount of difficulty and the player wasn't lead from the hand in every turn.

And dont worry, the game isnt stuck to the early years of rpg's. The UI is very well made to the modern standards, as is many other things such as possibility of hiring" a companion wich is basically creating a filler character in your group by yourself.

The hiring system is a genius idea honestly
date: as you want to have a full group as soon as possible early on in the game. Later on you can also of course find groupable NPC's that have a personality
recommended: opinions and own agenda wich you can choose to proceed if you will.\n\nSo now you get to make a group with every other npc character in game
hoursPlayed: as you can simply fill the empty spots with the hiring system. Smart.\n\nAs you play the game a bit further
voteText: you get your own stronghold where you can build stuff
helpfulPercent: switch your companions
votesHelpful: get buffs after sleeping there etc. Its a great idea
votesTotal:
because you start to get overflowing with money at some point eventually. You need to hire guards wich take weekly payment etc.

Also you can send your overflow hirelings to do your bidding in case you get a writ. Usually a smart move too.

One thing i really loved
votesFunny:
was how the inventory was made. Can't tell you how many times i almost lost my nerve (except in bg2 with bag of holding :) when i had inventory full of stuff and no idea where to put all that junk.

And now... the part that i really REALLY love in this game:

You can carry as much stuff as you ever will want. You have an option to drop stuff to stash whenever you want
commentsCount: and your inventory will never be stuffed of hundreds of "junk" -items
column16: wich btw are worth collecting and selling to vendors as you get back to town.\n\nAlso i've found out that all the items you find (mushrooms
column17: jewels etc.) are in fact useful and worth keeping instead of selling. All books
column18: papers etc. include tips if you read them carefully and use your imagination.\n\nIf you find jewels and herbs etc. you can use them for enchanting/crafting. I even found vendors selling crowbars
column19: climbing hooks with rope
column20: torches etc. All these items that i found useful eventually. Every now and then you gotta pry some bars aside
column21: climb a wall
column22:
or possibly torch something up possibly.

AND yes! You can craft anywhere! You can select the item you want to "enchant" and just do it on the spot without finding a forge and flapping thru useless junk in your inventory for hours. This makes the game much more straightforward (in a good sense) and you dont get stuck at inventory for ages.

Also no grinding is involved for crafting. Theres no skill's or such required from what i've seen
column23: no farming etc. You simply check what enchants
column24: foods
column25: potions you want/can make and just hit craft. Sometimes you can learn a recipe or such
column26:
but overall ive found crafting ever so deliciously simple.

Obsidian clearly has realized that spending time in inventory instead of playing has been a fun killer for ages. Theres a lesson to be learned from this for all the big budget RPG -maker's.

reviewText:
Great game. I put about 40 hours into my first play through, which didn't cover everything. Plenty of classes and races to choose from, and if you don't like the story companions you can just make your own.

The story was enjoyable, the combat can be challenging (that's without using the harder difficulties for me) and I went through it a lot quicker than I've been going through games recently.

People not used to this sort of game might have trouble getting used to the combat. I nearly gave up near the start, but if you stick with you'll learn the basics, pick up a few tricks abd hopefully enjoy the game as much as I did.

reviewText: Amazing classic isometric RPG.  Everything great about the genre with updated graphics and a beautiful soundtrack.  Some modern updates take away some of the grief of the older games, i.e.: unlimited stash, friend / foe only AoE, but overall, still presents difficult gameplay where it counts, requiring strategy and skill/stat optimization. reviewText:
This is my first review ever, i will start by saying that this a great game, well worth the full retail price, Obsidian has done great work considering the budget that they had to develop this game on. The game may have a few bugs but i did not run into any on my time playing it and if there are any they would not detract from the fun romp this game is.

Pros
-Great Story
-Great Companions
-Choices that actually matter
-You actions shape other characters opinons of you- People will reflect to you differently depending on your disposition- one character may try to kill you while that same character could listen to reason depending on your disposition.
-Challenging Gameplay- ability to structure game for either old school gaming or for those who enjoy the story based aspects more.
-Replayability- Different dialogue choices for different classes and races provides a reason to replay
-Great art style- the storyboards look very good, the hand drawn maps look well crafted and have a certian appeal to them
-15 level dungeon

Cons
-Story takes a while to pick up you do not know a lot about what is going until the middle of the 2nd act
-AI- the game needs the ability to better micromange your characters- the fact that you can not assign standard behaviours to your characters (e.g. heal yourself if under certian edurance/ health) forces to pause and play after each move, this can get frustrating particularly in the large fights with lots of mircomanagement where one wrong move can kill your party (Characters not moving if you have not selected them- they should at least have a default attack)
-Stronghold Management- feels a bit lacking while the bounty quests are good, the stronghold just seems to be a a way to spend the large amount of money you will not need to spend, finished the game with no cash than i needed
- A few pathfinding issues

reviewText: WOW. Just wow. Beautiful, challenging, story and world depth. I haven't quite reached the end and I still have no idea if I am helping or accidentally destroying the world. There are some big ideas and big questions in this one. Everything and the kitchen sink went into this and it shows. I did back this on Kickstarter and Obsidian delivered. The gaming reviews agree that this is a classic. I have had no bugs and if there were bugs they are fixed by now. Quality and attention to detail has clearly been a key focus in this game. I think it'll suck when it ends but I am actually looking forward to trying some of the other classes because they have some very unique skills and all are useful in their own right.\n\nAmazing to see what a real RPG dev can do when they own it and this is their baby. Lots of props to Obsidian for creating something fans have been missing out on for the last 15 years. If you like linearity, boring dialog, reading, seeing things and learning things, puzzles, blowing crap up for no reason or generally using your brain for anything then this is not the game for you.

reviewText:
As an avid fan of the old Infinity Engine games, and after all the rave reviews, I was very excited to be able to finally play this game, and for the first couple of hours I was impressed at the scope, the overall quality, and the succesfull way in which an old gaming formule was brought into the 21st century. A couple more hours in, I am still impressed by the scope of Pillars of Eternity...but somehow I can't help but feel slightly let down.

That's not to say that there isn't an awful lot they DID do right. The combat, e.g., has been given a successful overhaul. It's still  fun and deep, but plays out a lot faster and seems far less dependent on fairly random crowd control effects from the old games. I also like the little touches like the per-battle (rather than per-day) abilities, the fast movement mode, and innovative classes like the Chanter.

Also, in general the story and dialogue are interesting, although I do agree with some reviews that the entire affair does tend to get a bit long-winded and a bit too serious at times.

That being said..I feel the whole thing is a bit uninspired. The quests, the level design,  and even the loot (basically you get very little good stuff, you have to enchant it) certainly get the job done, but it never strays far from the established formula and all feels a bit...bland. Compared to the freshness of e.g. Divinity: Original Sin, which did manage to bring something truly new to the table in spite of being decidedly old school as well, PoE is a letdown. It also falls quite a bit short of the game it's so obviously paying hommage to, Baldur's Gate 2..that game constantly managed to surprise you with great level designs and quests..here I've waded through 7 levels of Endless Path dungeon without anything that stood out.

Maybe this comes across as overly harsh, since it is a good game and I am enjoying it, but it does feel like quantity over quality..they basically throw everything but the kitchen sink at you and hope it will stick. Most of it does, and there are some really good idea on display here, but a lot also feels like padding (far too many samey accounters, a flimsy stronghold...ironically, exactly the things that Dragon Age origins also did wrong)

The game is alright. Hardcore sucks because the game mostly won't let you retreat from battle and puts difficult fights directly into easy storylines for comedic value I guess. All in all, I think this game is a great buy for when it goes on sale.

reviewText: This game is fantastic.\n\nThere hasn't been a game that has truly had that D&D feel in a long time. Each chapter begins with a well written and well spoken introduction that pulls you into the story and makes it come alive. Along with the truly interesting story line is a great isometric combat system and a robust character creation system. I have'nt been pulled into a story like this ever. It was all I could talk about for weeks after getting it. The voice acting though sparse is well done and well written, and the game looks amazing. The different environments all have a life of their own. The combat may be difficult at first but once you get a full party going and get the hang of how each class plays a role in combat you can tackle even the toughest foes. And with that difficulty, victory becomes that much sweeter. Each time you delve into a dungeon or go hiking through the woods it feels like an adventure. Your skills and choices actually have an impact on the direction of the story as well, unlike some modern rpgs. (looking at you fallout 4) I can't really recommend this game enough. and now that both white march expansions are out it looks even more amazing. Go buy this game right now you will not be disapointed.

reviewText:
While not exactly a masterpiece, Pillars of Eternity is a nostalgic throwback to the golden era of CRPGs, and probably the Baldur's Gate 3 that we never got. Few companies write characters like Obsidian, and even if the main plot is a little on the cliché side, the D&D inspired universe is bound to keep you involved for at least 60 hours.

There are plenty of sidequests and some novelty gameplay elements that keep the game fresh, such as maintaining your own keep and  interactive fiction minigames. While the maps are fairly small to today's standards, you'll find that the sprawling dungeons and the handful of wilderness areas that are sufficiently populated with content, all of which are beautifully detailed with pre-rendered art.

The constant loading times do get annoying, and the turn based combat can be unforgiving to a younger generation, even on Easy levels, but those who welcome a challenge and are not intimitated by walls of (masterfully written) text will find Pillars a nice change of pace from modern RPGs. Last but not least, the soundtrack is absolutely gorgeous and makes up for the lack of full voice acting. 4.5/5

reviewText:
Pillars of Eternity is an incredibly good game in the spirit of Baldur's Gate and Planescape: Torment, though fans of Spiderweb Studio game's such as Geneforge and Avernum will also feel at home.

The combat system seems to inspired by the tabletop game Dungeons and Dragons 4th edition, with your abilities being split into encounter and daily powers that reset either after the end of every fight or after each rest. While I am not a fan of D&D 4th, I have always said that their combat system would work better in a com♥♥♥♥r game, and I feel that Pillars of Eternity proves me right here. I did not play Pillars for its combat system, but I enjoyed the tactical battles none the less.

Without mentioning any spoilers, the storyline for Pillars of Eternity is fantastic. There are a myriads of options and solutions to most if not all problems in the game, with significance to your characters reputation which I felt led to natural consequences throughout the game. While there were some small handful of places where I felt like I could have done with slightly more branching paths in the storyline, I were pleasently surprised when the game often gave me choices that I did not expect.

The companions are a colourful collection of eight, and while I love them and my characters' interaction with them, they may well be my biggest critique in the game. While their quests are interesting, and while I grew attached to their bantering in the background in the course of our adventure together, I felt as if they are largely ignored by the world. They will sometimes comment upon an ungoing dialogue, yet the NPCs will often neither remark upon or indeed notice your companions contribution. This makes them feel sadly invisible and unimportant. I still love them, I simply wish that they had more of an impact on the overall game.

The music of the game is discrete and enjoyable. I am generally the kind of gamer who will turn the music off while playing to listen to my own, yet I left the music on throughout the game as I felt that it heightend the experience without being all up in my face.

To round things up, I would recommend Pillars of Eternity to any cRPG fan out there, and also to anyone who wishes to get into cRPGs as the learning curve is not too steep, certainly not as steep as Baldur's Gate and Icewind Dale. The game caters to many different kind of playstyles, so anyone who likes seeing their own character grow forth as a person in and of itself is bound to enjoy this wonderful game.

reviewText:
I finished the game with about 99% of all quest/explorations done.

It is a decent spiritual successor to Baldur's Gate 2 and an absolute piece of art in it's scenery and graphics. You can notice the art team did an amazing job down to the details.

The problem is that the game is still quite buggy, I came across a lot of them, including major ones that wouldn't allow me to continue and would make me load an older save file. So keep this in mind and save often and in different files.

The battle is often poorly balanced because of it's system. It feels as if they tried to make this revolutionary system of endurance with armors, damage reduction, graze/crits being more realistic. But it fell short in the execution and you will notice battles can be quite draggy, often going for much longer than it should despite having the most powerful weapon and a high level character. I feel they could have achieved more by sticking with a stable equipment system (+1,+2, etc) and spending more time polishing the game, removing bugs and adding more depth to quests and NPCs.

The Stronghold  was extremely positive, adding a lot to the game without disrupting your adventures around. But the Endless Paths could definitely have used more time. Some levels were quite plain and could easily be just part of other levels. And safe a few levels, most of them didn't have any characteristic or good NPCs or puzzles such as Watcher's Keep did in BG2.

Having said that, I really enjoyed the game. It doesn't have the magic that Baldur's Gate series had had (every area had so much depth and quests and interesting NPCs that is hard to compare), nor Pillars of Eternity has a very surprising storyline. But I quite enjoyed it and I think everyone will feel accomplished by the end of the game.

reviewText:
Early Review

Yes I spent the $45 on it and so far I'm very happy.  This is Baldur's Gate for 2015.

Pros:
-- Character Creation:  Excellent setup - great back stories, plenty of customization.  Talents, skills, and point distribution.
--  Difficulty Settings:  several different options here - which should give it high replay value as well.
--  Storyline:  so far so good.  Got me involved right from the beginning.  The main story-arch is developing nicely and gradually.  Good voice acting and dialog seems to flow - feels genuine
--  Combat - similar to BG of course
--  Crafting -- oh yeah!  That's a nice touch, nothing too dramatic yet - but you don't just have to sell junk - you can craft some useful combat buffs.
-- Stash - very helpful
--  Recruit mercs - early on even you can recruit some party members for reasonable amounts of copper.  Very helpful in those sticky places
--  Stronghold - just just started this part.  But seems like a nice developing touch of building your stronghold - looks like you can develop some residual income

CONS
--  Graphics are so-so but this isn't a big con for me.  In a top-down 3rd person, I can live with it.  Some like it, some don't.
--  Combat sometimes is overwhelming.  Getting into some places early on where I'm completely overwhelmed.  Could be frustrating to some.
--  Fog of war feels a bit tight, but not incredibly so.

That's all I can think of now - will update more later.

Overall I have no hesitation in saying it's worth the money.  As a BG / Icewind / RPG fan, I'll get every penny's worth out of this one.
This game will make great grounds for future divorces.

reviewText: As a Kickstarter backer, I have to say, I got my money's worth.  Pillars of Eternity really captured the feel of the old Infinity Engine games (Baldur's Gate, Icewind Dale, etc), but modernized and improved.  The story isn't as strong as the Baldur's Gate games, but the world is unique and well realized (and the central question of the game was a welcome surprise).  It starts off a bit slow, and the NPCs you gather don't seem that interesting at first, but by the end they really grew on me. To the point that I felt guilty for not finishing one's quest.\nThe game manages to feel short, even after 60 hours of play - there are still several things I didn't do (and I would have appreciated a little more warning when I got to the point of no return for the end-game), and there are a number of extra missions that can be explored, several of which I failed to complete (and may go back and do, even if I don't re-beat the game). But overall, I was very happy with the game; they achieved their goal of reviving the style and adapting it to modern gamers.  There are still some niggling things they need to do (the filter on store items actually remove items rather than graying them out, better multi-step planning and visibility in battles), but those are minor flaws on an otherwise sparkling gem.

reviewText:
This game was good, but I couldn't help feeling like it wasn't as good as it could have been.  It feels like editorial mandates got in the way of the story that some writers were trying to tell and gummed up the works.  Quests can feel disconnected and companions occasionally feel neutered by editing, especially those written by Chris Avellone.

Don't get me wrong, the story is fantastic and the companions break the Bioware mold that many RPG's find themselves stuck in.  The world is fantastically realized, being both dark and gritty while also maintaining a sense of wonder not always found in contemporary fantasy.  The lore is also well written and interesting, avoiding some of the pitfalls of other games of the genre by making the lore seem too distant from what is actually presented and giving a real sense of belonging within the game world.

The graphics are another high point, for the most part.  All the backgrounds are well detailed with particle effects that just pop, but the models aren't really consistent.  For an indie game of this magnitude, they do look very good, but if you are expecting highly detailed, AAA models, look elsewhere. Occasionally enemies will have their models go over scenery that they really shouldn't, it is most notable when they die.  Despite those flaws, the overall artistic design is stunning.

Music is okay, nothing really spectacular, but it more than does the job.  For the most part, it is rather sparse and when it does come in it is typically light and unintrusive.  While this can feel immersive, it means that I wouldn't really say any of it stands out.

Overall, it is a really good game, that seems like it could have been better with more time and money.  That said, it is probably the best singleplayer RPG in years and without a doubt the best throwback to the old infinity engine games on the market (although with Numenera looming on the horizon, that may be a better option long term).
8.5/10

reviewText:
I'm gonna compare this game to Baldur's Gate II because I feel that it tries to be this style of game. Short version of my review comes first, detailled Pros and Cons second.

Overall the game improves visually and adds a thousand new exciting things to the classics Baldurs Gate, Icewind Dale and Planescape Torment. Unfortunately the battle system and the quests and the importance of your decisions is lacking greatly. I feel that if this game gets a sequel, and that sequel will be worked out properly (I feel like this game was rushed a bit) the sequel might be one of the best games ever made and might tie or even beat Baldurs Gate 2.

+ Awesome Artwork, Soundtrack and generally everything you, hear, see and feel is awesome, generally the game feels like a mixture of BG1 and BG2
+ The story is interesting and compelling
+ You get your own ♥♥♥♥ing Castle, that you can upgrade, do quests in and collect Bounties of powerful outlaws for/in
+ The Experience gaining system is very nice (Exp for new areas, exp cap for every type of enemies you kill)
+ The NPCs you can have in your party are mostly nice, although not as interesting as in BG2
+ Nice Crafting system for Potions and Scrolls
+ Almost no quests have a black & white solutions, theres always 2 sides of a story, also the amount of quests is very nice
+ New interesting Races and Classes that bring new mechanics to the game
+ The wild areas feel like a perfect mixture of BG1 and BG2, they are beautifully designed like in the first game, but not as empty
+ You can enchant weapons, armor and shields
+ Slow down/speed up buttons to play without pause/travel through already explored areas

- ♥♥♥♥ing loading screens. They're way too long and they're everywhere.
- The battle system feels clumsy and the battles don't require much tactics (except in the beginning for some reason). In comparison the IWD and BG series felt way harder and challenged me more
- Theres no choice paths in the game, so replaying and always using other dialoge options (and fractions) the game will basically be the same
- Your Castle's Dungeon Crawl quest feels boring and repetitive with an insane amount of dungeons that lack quests
- All items feel the same, especially with the Enchantment options, which is a very big con unfortunately. After a while I just stopped caring about items. Also there's a lack of certain item types like hats/helmets and the necklace/cloak slot got fused into one. On top of that some early game items are so good that you never change them through the entire game. Itemization is my single biggest issue with this game.
- AoE Damage spells don't seem to have much impact anymore
- Ranged weapons are way better then melee weapons, if you have 1 tank, that's enough melee
- The game is too hard in the beginning, especially when you don't have many companions yet

reviewText:
I haven't yet finished this game, being the type of person who likes to complete every possible side quest and explore every area in RPG's, but I feel like I have seen enough of the game to write this review.

Pillars of Eternity is a game moulded very much in the fashion of some of my favourite games of all time; Baldur's Gate (I & II) and Icewind Dale, and it definately justifies it's position sitting side by side with these greats.

Being a top down RPG it doesn't have the flashiest or most breathtaking visuals, nor the fast paced combat of many of today's modern games, but it doesn't suffer for it in the slightest. A fascinating, dark and gritty high fantasty world, bursting with interesting and entertaining characters in which you search for answers to a mysterious event from the start of the game set the stage for the telling of a very well devised story.

Like most games of this genre, it features a reasonably well detailed character creation system which allows you to feel that important attachment and immersion during the story, and the voice acting/script writing work is very well done. Expect to be amused, baffled and enthralled in equal measure by the numerous NPC's with which you can party up and travel with (all with their own backstories, most of which I found pretty neat).

Combat-wise the game is solid, being pretty much standard fare for this type of game, but it felt nice and smooth and there is a good variety and diversity of skills amongst the classes. Loot is also varied and interesting enough to keep you constantly on the hunt for that next upgrade or nice drop.

One thing I found very pleasing about the game was the abiluty to acquire and upgrade your own Keep"
date: which was obtained through a very interesting quest and worked solidly with the main story line of the game
recommended: intermingling seamlessly as I quested back and froth between them.\n\nOverall this is a game which borrows
hoursPlayed: and to a small extent

reviewText:
I am not a fan of RPG games and i have very little experience with them, so my review is based on that. After reading all the good reviews i figured i'll try this game out, not really knowing what to expect.


First i have to say i was a little bit disappointed by the graphics after the hype that was created here about them. They are not bad at all, and the atmosphere is good, but i expected even better.

After spending nearly an hour creating my character, i jumped into the adventure (props on the options). The story is interesting and keeps you curious about what will happen next.
However as a inexperienced fantasy RPG player it was sometimes hard to keep track of all the unearthy named people and parties. Further in the story, also the number of quests who are active at the same time, often left me feeling a lack of overview or perspective of why or for what side i was doing this quest again. If i did i probably would have made a few different choices.

What i did love were the conversations with NPC's, where very often you had the option to use a skill for a shortcut or outsmarting manouvre. Also that the members of your own party jump in the conversation now and then, makes them more charming.

The combat system is pauze-command-play style, and simple enough to learn. However in certain situation i felt like some of my characters were not completing the given command for no particular reason(no magic and no obstructions on the path), and if you don't pay attention they just stand idle while the rest gets butchered. That being said i didnt have problems surviving on the normal difficulty settings except for a encounter with a dragon and Raedic 1.

The story ending is clearly explained but a bit abrupt, it would have been cool to really see your keep blossom instead of just to read it has. Also 'The master below' which seemed a interesting and difficult quest to finish. Was not needed to progress to the end of the story and did not seem to influence the outcome of your keep either (wich is something different then what your stewart tells you). So i felt a bit discouraged of completing it still since the story was allready over, and thats a shame.

All in all i still think this game is not bad, it was a nice experience to get more familiarised to this kind of genre. I got this on a 50% off sale so i recommend the game. Although i think a RPG fan will prolly appreciate it even more then i did.

reviewText:
You must gather your party before venturing forth"

PoE harkens back to the cult classic of 1998; Baldur's Gate. However it does not follow any DnD ruleset at all. Instead it invents the wheel with its own set of rules that are confusing to say the least.

While traditional DnD states that health is the primary attribute for how healthy a character is
date: PoE mixes in endurance that factors in on every encounter. You will regain endurance (up to a certain point) after each fight
recommended: but health is not. Think of it as fatigue and hp. Long battles will drain your endurance
hoursPlayed: while the number of encounters you take before camping will drain your hp. Unless there are permanent effects in play
voteText: you will regain full hp and endurance after camping - for which you'll need supplies to do so.\n\nIt's certainly an alternate take on RPG and while the game offers plenty of atmosphere
helpfulPercent: a solid soundtrack and voice work
votesHelpful: the aspects of how the game calculates damage
votesTotal: modifiers and character "wellness" is confusing to say the least. I wish they just stuck with regular tropes here as after over 10hrs in I still have troubles figuring out how all of this ties together.\n\nIf RPGs of days yore is your thing you'll get your fix here
votesFunny: but think of it as a reinvention instead of a ressurection. PoE does things its own way which
commentsCount: I guess
column16: makes it unique. However
column17: it may be too unique for those hardcore savants of Baldur lore."

reviewText: Pillars of Eternity is this genres final form.  Let's just skip the bean counter metrics like gameplay/UI/length/etc... they're all perfect. Moving on to the big stuff... storytelling, strategy, meaning, writing that provokes thought and feeling, voice acting, beauty, tone, music, art. That is where this game lives and it does so in deep ways.  The effort that has gone into this is masterful.

reviewText:
After 48 hours of gameplay, after hundreds of times of recreating new characters, after trying different difficulties and modes, I still have not completed Act II, and I think I'm going to restart again.

So these are the most important and interesting features of an RPG to me: playability and fascinatingly dark story.

I admit I've never had the chance to play Baldur's Gate but I used to be fanatical IWD player, Pillars of Eternity did even better at every aspect of old school RPG. The graphic performace is  amazing under the well-shaped engine of 2D/3D, and they did pay a lot of work in the conversations and storytelling and of course the background unfolding.

Buy it my friends, 100% you won't regret it, 100%.

reviewText:
The game is alright. Hardcore sucks because the game mostly won't let you retreat from battle and puts difficult fights directly into easy storylines for comedic value I guess. You are probably suppose to memorize the game in normal because playing hardcore, which sounds about like chopping wood to me.

The game play and story are alright. The voice acting is on point. The story is kind of childishly gritty - they try to make it seem rough by having drug abuse themes and birth defects as plot drivers might work for you. It doesn't for me.

I had to butcher a party member in my hardcore game because they glitched into a wall and couldn't move. I could have saved and restarted, hoping for the best, but I didn't try that.

All in all, I think this game is a great buy for when it goes on sale.

reviewText: Engrossing. I finally settled on a druid, strong and smart, that would be able to keep me vested.\n\nI shudder at the thought of the hours I am about to sink into this title when 36 hours in I've decided on a character and begun combing the landscape without even coming close to the second act or expansions. reviewText:
Overall, a pretty entertaining game.

The combat is alright, I can never decide if I actually like this sort of game, but it seem to work pretty well for the most part. If it isn't your thing, just turn down the difficulty of the game. I personally prefer easy difficulties for this sort of thing as I find the combat more entertaining when you don't have to worry about it so much.

For those unaware, the system is that of a top down, pausable RPG where your characters have various abilities you can use which are either per-encounter, per-rest, or use some kind of in combat resource (i.e. monks use wounds" to power their stuff). I'm not personally a fan of per-rest stuff
date: as I find it tends to be that I just avoid using certain abilities unless I really need them
recommended: which is kind of lame because it makes the combat have a lot less variety. There's also a mechanic called fatigue which makes your characters weaker if you don't rest for a long time
hoursPlayed: and I'd have preferred to see that more fleshed out in place of a hard limit of "this ability can be used twice per rest".\n\nThe story and interactions is where the game stands out though
voteText: and for me is the real reason to play it. There's quite a wide variety of things to do and people to talk to
helpfulPercent: with many response options to choose from (I'd recommend turning off the option to see why you can choose certain options though
votesHelpful: as I find it makes the interactions more interesting - often if I see I've unlocked an option by having X stat
votesTotal: it will make me want to choose that option. If I can't see that
votesFunny: then I just choose more naturally what I want to do). Overall pretty fun though
commentsCount: in particular if its on sale I'd recommend picking it up - it's worth one playthrough at least if you can get it for a good price."

reviewText: A true spiritual successor to classic Infinity Engine crpgs. The game has good story, good reputation system, interesting characters and nice feeling overall. It can also be challenging at times, probably more so on higher difficulty levels. I would recommend it to anyone who appreciates really good crpgs.\n\nOn the other hand, I think 8 companions are too few (although you can add to the party custom made characters) and the game also has the most cheap optional boss in the game. No kidding.

reviewText:
I haven't yet finished this game, being the type of person who likes to complete every possible side quest and explore every area in RPG's, but I feel like I have seen enough of the game to write this review.

Pillars of Eternity is a game moulded very much in the fashion of some of my favourite games of all time; Baldur's Gate (I & II) and Icewind Dale, and it definately justifies it's position sitting side by side with these greats.

Being a top down RPG it doesn't have the flashiest or most breathtaking visuals, nor the fast paced combat of many of today's modern games, but it doesn't suffer for it in the slightest. A fascinating, dark and gritty high fantasty world, bursting with interesting and entertaining characters in which you search for answers to a mysterious event from the start of the game set the stage for the telling of a very well devised story.

Like most games of this genre, it features a reasonably well detailed character creation system which allows you to feel that important attachment and immersion during the story, and the voice acting/script writing work is very well done. Expect to be amused, baffled and enthralled in equal measure by the numerous NPC's with which you can party up and travel with (all with their own backstories, most of which I found pretty neat).

Combat-wise the game is solid, being pretty much standard fare for this type of game, but it felt nice and smooth and there is a good variety and diversity of skills amongst the classes. Loot is also varied and interesting enough to keep you constantly on the hunt for that next upgrade or nice drop.

One thing I found very pleasing about the game was the abiluty to acquire and upgrade your own Keep"
date: which was obtained through a very interesting quest and worked solidly with the main story line of the game
recommended: intermingling seamlessly as I quested back and froth between them.\n\nOverall this is a game which borrows
hoursPlayed: and to a small extent
voteText: builds on the solid foundations of prior games in this genre and couples it with a beautiful and detailed world and engaging story. There is nothing particularly groundbreaking added in this game (or at least
helpfulPercent: what I have experienced of it this far)
votesHelpful: but there a few new features here and there which fit in very well with the overall experience
votesTotal: without parting too much from the old school feel the game conveys.\n\nHighly reccomended
votesFunny: especially if you already a fan of similar games."
