reviewText:
I am not a fan of RPG games and i have very little experience with them, so my review is based on that. After reading all the good reviews i figured i'll try this game out, not really knowing what to expect.


First i have to say i was a little bit disappointed by the graphics after the hype that was created here about them. They are not bad at all, and the atmosphere is good, but i expected even better.

After spending nearly an hour creating my character, i jumped into the adventure (props on the options). The story is interesting and keeps you curious about what will happen next.
However as a inexperienced fantasy RPG player it was sometimes hard to keep track of all the unearthy named people and parties. Further in the story, also the number of quests who are active at the same time, often left me feeling a lack of overview or perspective of why or for what side i was doing this quest again. If i did i probably would have made a few different choices.

What i did love were the conversations with NPC's, where very often you had the option to use a skill for a shortcut or outsmarting manouvre. Also that the members of your own party jump in the conversation now and then, makes them more charming.

The combat system is pauze-command-play style, and simple enough to learn. However in certain situation i felt like some of my characters were not completing the given command for no particular reason(no magic and no obstructions on the path), and if you don't pay attention they just stand idle while the rest gets butchered. That being said i didnt have problems surviving on the normal difficulty settings except for a encounter with a dragon and Raedic 1.

The story ending is clearly explained but a bit abrupt, it would have been cool to really see your keep blossom instead of just to read it has. Also 'The master below' which seemed a interesting and difficult quest to finish. Was not needed to progress to the end of the story and did not seem to influence the outcome of your keep either (wich is something different then what your stewart tells you). So i felt a bit discouraged of completing it still since the story was allready over, and thats a shame.

All in all i still think this game is not bad, it was a nice experience to get more familiarised to this kind of genre. I got this on a 50% off sale so i recommend the game. Although i think a RPG fan will prolly appreciate it even more then i did.

reviewText: Pillars of Eternity is a kickstarted love triangle. It combines best parts of Baldur's Gate, Planescape: Torment and Icewind Dale plus adds a lot more. Highly reccomended to anyone who loves grand, challenging, rich cRPGs.

reviewText:
This game is an excellent bar to set for other game companies.

The story is one of the best I've had the pleasure of experienceing. My favorite picks would be BG2, BG2TOB, NWN, BG1.

Combat is flawless and follows to a small degree(loosely) the DND ruleset which is known in IE games for being a staple mechanic.

The sheer amount of content with the Endless Dungeons and bounties adds much flair and things to do. Let's not forget that you get your own keep and can upgrade it AND pay people to guard it! There are multiple secret areas and numerous items good and bad to find.

This game from start to finish took about 32+ hours to complete with about 60% of the game explored and completed.
There are multiple facets that I havn't even discovered and I plan on replaying through the game again solo.

Giving this game anything below a 9 would be ludicrous.

My only complaint is that this game advertised that it is able to be solo'ed.

So far the balancing of the classes other than a barbarian is kind of messed up. This game would be a perfect 10/10 for me if I could actually solo it. I've obtained a platinum in the Dark Souls series and Bloodborne but, even those games are not as hard as Pillars of Eternity solo on NORMAL. Please make a selectable option for solo that scales down the enemies a bit for a solo run or, take out the level cap for solo-runners.

Story: 9.5
Combat: 9.6
Content: 10/10
Play Time: 32 hrs 9.1/10
Replayability: VERY HIGH 10/10

Solo: Currently undoable for anything but barbarians.

Overall: 9.5/10

reviewText:
50+ hrs played

I waited till I hit the 50+ hrs point to write this review so that I had a complete feel for the game before I made any desessions about the game. All in all I give the game a 85/100. And the -15 is mostly just personal perference not things that are wrong with the game itself.
Pillars is a great game with 100's of hrs of game play and a large amount of replayability. Of course you have to like playing with a team of six characters of different classes. I prefer games like Skyrim where you mostly play just a single player. Pillars has a great story line with a mostly open world and you get to chose what order to solve the quests you have. There is a large amount of treasure and items to be bought with nothing bring over powering. The game can be difficult at times. And I do wish they had put a level system in the journal so you know if the quest was to high above your level to complete. The 2 dlc's are a must. And should be bought at round lvl 7 and played before you finish the main game. You can go back to the main game after the dlc's and there is some great loot that can be used like better armour and weapons to give you a better edge also. another fun option in the game is you can have a Keep which you can upgrade and make your home. This is a great game. Read all the reviews you can and get it on sale even better. Also look at all the hrs a lot of people have spent playing this game. That was the biggest factor that told me that this was a good game.

After about hour 30 you just want the blimmin' thing to be over though. The combat mechanics are also very suspect and it just doesn't quite work. reviewText:
Pros:
+ Good writing
+ Lots of skill checks
+ Well-designed leveling system
+ Challenging and tactical combat
+ No respawning enemies
+ Stash system minimizes inventory management
+ Open-ended quests with multiple solutions

Cons:
- Problematic pathfinding
- Lots of load screens
- Can't sort inventory by value or quality
- The majority of skill checks rely on one attribute
- A lot of redundant status effects

Conclusion: A great, old-school CRPG that should appeal to fans of the IE games. Combines the combat of BG with the player agency of PST.

reviewText:
Pillars of Eternity is an incredibly good game in the spirit of Baldur's Gate and Planescape: Torment, though fans of Spiderweb Studio game's such as Geneforge and Avernum will also feel at home.

The combat system seems to inspired by the tabletop game Dungeons and Dragons 4th edition, with your abilities being split into encounter and daily powers that reset either after the end of every fight or after each rest. While I am not a fan of D&D 4th, I have always said that their combat system would work better in a com♥♥♥♥r game, and I feel that Pillars of Eternity proves me right here. I did not play Pillars for its combat system, but I enjoyed the tactical battles none the less.

Without mentioning any spoilers, the storyline for Pillars of Eternity is fantastic. There are a myriads of options and solutions to most if not all problems in the game, with significance to your characters reputation which I felt led to natural consequences throughout the game. While there were some small handful of places where I felt like I could have done with slightly more branching paths in the storyline, I were pleasently surprised when the game often gave me choices that I did not expect.

The companions are a colourful collection of eight, and while I love them and my characters' interaction with them, they may well be my biggest critique in the game. While their quests are interesting, and while I grew attached to their bantering in the background in the course of our adventure together, I felt as if they are largely ignored by the world. They will sometimes comment upon an ungoing dialogue, yet the NPCs will often neither remark upon or indeed notice your companions contribution. This makes them feel sadly invisible and unimportant. I still love them, I simply wish that they had more of an impact on the overall game.

The music of the game is discrete and enjoyable. I am generally the kind of gamer who will turn the music off while playing to listen to my own, yet I left the music on throughout the game as I felt that it heightend the experience without being all up in my face.

To round things up, I would recommend Pillars of Eternity to any cRPG fan out there, and also to anyone who wishes to get into cRPGs as the learning curve is not too steep, certainly not as steep as Baldur's Gate and Icewind Dale. The game caters to many different kind of playstyles, so anyone who likes seeing their own character grow forth as a person in and of itself is bound to enjoy this wonderful game.

reviewText: This is the modern version of all the Infinity Engine titles rolled into one. Obsidian truely outdid themselves.

reviewText: Great party-based rpg. Reminds me of first two Fallouts and Planescape. You can act in many ways, each leading to a different result. Though you can't coplete the game without killing anyone, you still can resolve many problem with just words. reviewText:
Beautiful graphics and sound. Well written and voice acted story. Well designed game mechanics. Meaningful character diversity that will lead to multiple playthroughs.

Anyone who enjoyed Baldur's Gate or Icewind Dale back in the day will love this game. All of the quality and heart of the old isoRPGs combined with all the quality of life improvements and polish of a modern game.

For anyone who has never played an isoRPG but enjoys RPGs in general, this is a great game to start with.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText: Good story, funny and entertaining. Worth it !
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText: This game is fantastic.\n\nThere hasn't been a game that has truly had that D&D feel in a long time. Each chapter begins with a well written and well spoken introduction that pulls you into the story and makes it come alive. Along with the truly interesting story line is a great isometric combat system and a robust character creation system. I have'nt been pulled into a story like this ever. It was all I could talk about for weeks after getting it. The voice acting though sparse is well done and well written, and the game looks amazing. The different environments all have a life of their own. The combat may be difficult at first but once you get a full party going and get the hang of how each class plays a role in combat you can tackle even the toughest foes. And with that difficulty, victory becomes that much sweeter. Each time you delve into a dungeon or go hiking through the woods it feels like an adventure. Your skills and choices actually have an impact on the direction of the story as well, unlike some modern rpgs. (looking at you fallout 4) I can't really recommend this game enough. and now that both white march expansions are out it looks even more amazing. Go buy this game right now you will not be disapointed.

reviewText: 20/10. The funny thing is if someone asked me what I would have payed for an RPG on par with Baldur's Gate, Icewind Dale, PTorment and NWN.... I woulda said 3 hundred dollars. Just like I do with the other old school RPG's. Well done Obsidian! Very happy to say that you have my full support.

reviewText:
The game is alright. Hardcore sucks because the game mostly won't let you retreat from battle and puts difficult fights directly into easy storylines for comedic value I guess. You are probably suppose to memorize the game in normal because playing hardcore, which sounds about like chopping wood to me.

The game play and story are alright. The voice acting is on point. The story is kind of childishly gritty - they try to make it seem rough by having drug abuse themes and birth defects as plot drivers might work for you. It doesn't for me.

I had to butcher a party member in my hardcore game because they glitched into a wall and couldn't move. I could have saved and restarted, hoping for the best, but I didn't try that.

All in all, I think this game is a great buy for when it goes on sale.

reviewText:
The game has the capacity to give me a quest or an adventure per evening; more if I avoid sleep.

It's like my own tabletop D&D session, nightly, without having to buy groceries for other people, who then refuse
to quiet down and not wake up my Wife with their noisy BS. This game saves wear & tear on furniture as well.

I highly recommend this title.

If you're the type that needs music constantly playing or you will go mad, there are more expensive versions, that include a digital soundtrack.

Personally, I wouldn't want you and your headphones anywhere near my foxhole but it's a single-player game, so go ahead, develop a stupid habit that could get you killed.

;>)

There are no words for this... EPIC i guess will have to suffice, Dragon Age 1, Mass Effect series, Baldurs Gate 2, NWN series... and now Pillar of Eternity, it ranks among the most epic games ever created and has surpassed rankings.

reviewText:
If you were a fan ofthe Baldur's gate series (I don't include dark alliance!), Planescape: Torment, or The icewind dale series then you should definitely buy Pillars of Eternity.

I thought there were quite a lot of side quests in Chapter 1 but not many in Chapters 2 and 3.

The party system is a mix between baldur's gate and icewind dale as you create your main player like in baldur's gate and can meet other characters to join your party along your travels but also you can create additional Party members like in icewind dale!

Looking forward to the expansion, hope it has a lot more content included!

reviewText:
After 48 hours of gameplay, after hundreds of times of recreating new characters, after trying different difficulties and modes, I still have not completed Act II, and I think I'm going to restart again.

So these are the most important and interesting features of an RPG to me: playability and fascinatingly dark story.

I admit I've never had the chance to play Baldur's Gate but I used to be fanatical IWD player, Pillars of Eternity did even better at every aspect of old school RPG. The graphic performace is  amazing under the well-shaped engine of 2D/3D, and they did pay a lot of work in the conversations and storytelling and of course the background unfolding.

Buy it my friends, 100% you won't regret it, 100%.

reviewText: I had a lot of fun with this game, it brought back the nostalgia of first playing Neverwinter Nights but with decent graphics and fun gameplay, it's in depth enough I can enjoy it but I can ignore a lot of the details if I so choose.  I'm only about a third of the way through the main campaign and keep getting side tracked, thoroughly exploring each map as I come to it and reading any lore I come across.  I like the way the codex fills out as you travel and fight different monsters to reflect your growing knowledge of the places you visit and the creatures you fight.  Haven't played the first expansion and I'm waiting on the second but if the quality remains close to the main game I'm sure they'll be a big hit as well.  Look forward to seeing more expansions/games like this in the future.

reviewText: I was a kick-starter backer for this game and am very happy with the end-result. Being a big fan of story-driven RPGs with nice gameplay elements this game fulfills both niches. A throwback to the 2d isometric hand drawn environments for those of us who are fans of nice illustrations.\n\nThis is not the typical RPG we may be used to where we kill ever bad guy or enemy" we come across. Albeit you can play it like that (I am heh)
date: you'll just find it very difficult if you do if you're also on the hardest difficulty setting. For those who enjoy challenges this will definitely scractch an itch. But one may equally talk their way out of many hostile situations or simply avoid them.\n\nMy only complains is that there's a bit too much side-content that draws me away from the main story for too long. Being a completionist I like to do every side-quest but occasionally I found myself rushing through them because I really wanted to get back to the main story. The fact that certain achievements are tied to these side-quests didn't improve matters
recommended: but hey I'm probably the only person who'd complain about too much content.\n\nIf you enjoyed old-school rpg series like Buldur's Gate
hoursPlayed: Icewind Dale and Torment you will definitely enjoy this game as well. Kudos to the devs developing a unique mechanic system since they couldn't very well use DnD rules :P."

reviewText:
If you're new to this genre of games, then it has a bit of learning curve, but once you get the gist of game mechanics, then the game is really immersive. The story is interesting and flexible, you can play go through the story however you want; as a good guy or a bad guy. Combat is a little dull at times, but extremely challenging on others, which keeps you keen and on your feet as you go through the game, you can choose to avoid confrtontations if you'd like through careful choice of responses. All these factors put together make the game have high replayability.

TL;DR: Strongly Recommend!

voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
A game I see myself replaying in the future; a well-crafted classic with just a few snags.

I have come into my own as a gamer playing Baldur's gate II and Planscape Torment and spent good part of growing up with 3rd edition Dungeons and dragons.
Even before this game came out, I enjoyed reading up on the dev's updates and how they were planning to tweak the game mechanics. A lot has changed since BG II and the game presents us with polished and improved battle mechanics that have less exploits and frustrating bits.
That said, the devs did not try hard enough to make the game accessible to an inexperienced audience - the easy difficulty leaves the monsters' stats and battle rules unchanged, which means you still need to understand the mechanics and be able to adjust your strategy with every battle.
On the other hand, the games offers several ways to scale up the difficulty, if that is something you desire.

One of the goals this game set for itself was mature storytelling" and I think they succeeded well enough. I mostly paid attention to the main story it and enjoyed it
date: which is rare for me. I tend to skip over text and not care that much what is happening between the banter with my party and all the monster-killing.\n\nOne unattractive blemish is the issue of hollowborn children - basically a metaphor for disabled people who are nonverbal and need help with daily activities. In the game
hoursPlayed: because they are soulless. As a cognitively and developmentally disabled person I did not enjoy reading about people resembling me and my friends being inhuman. Unfortunately this is part of the main plot and as such unavoidable.\n\nThe characters
voteText: which are one of the main draws of a game like this
helpfulPercent: were well executed. They range from cute to intriguing to deliciously hateable. Their personal stories are interesting
votesHelpful: if a bit short.\nWhat I felt was lacking
votesTotal: was the depth of interaction you have with them as the PC and the interaction they have between themselves. The banter is funny
votesFunny: sure
commentsCount:
but I am used to drama complete with hissy fits and threats of leaving the party (now I miss BG II).

All in all - a good staple for those long weekends where you don't feel like doing anything.

P.S.: At the time of writing this
column16: I am almost done with the game. A few days ago White March II has come out
column17: with a patch for the regular game. Unfortunately I can't comment on the changes right now
column18: because there is no time left for me to explore them.\n"
column19: February 25

reviewText:
Playing Pillars is kind of like being in a relationship.
You acknowledge that the other person has his/her flaws, but... you still love them :)

So... yeah, some parts of the game are better than others.
Still, it's rewarding (er, not so much in loot). Whenever combat was a grind, I reminded myself that, thankfully, this is not Icewind Dale and at least there's some plot involved. And a pretty decent one too. The main quest seems a bit cliched at first but... it starts echoing Torment eventually with the questions it raises.

Pillars will charm you if you manage to see past its flaws. Recommended :)
voteText: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Pillars of Eternity is utterly fantastic.

By far it is one of the best games of the last few years; not only have we been without a good old rpg of this sort, the classic style of Pillars of Eternity is absolutely compelling and enthralling.

The soundtrack of this game is terrific, its mellow tones charming and enchanting; while its combat music intense and exciting.

I am overjoyed to see a game made in the old style of role play, full of absolutely delicious nostalgia to those who have experienced such classics as Icewind Dale or Baldur's Gate.

A truly fantastic experience, worth every penny.

reviewText:
Warning: might contain spoilers.

There are countless people telling you how this game is great and close to flawless so i wont be focusing on that. Ill tell you what is wrong with the game.

Roleplay options, - the core stats are a joke. Intelligence recommended for a barbarian, Might not recommended for monk, intelligence on wizard is only good for debuffing and 'dialog'. There are no special changes while having stat a minimum - 3 int talking like normal, 3 dex having no problems swinging 2 swords etc. The system is extremely flawed and its a huge letdown when you make some conceptual hero, take appropriate skills and then they are almost never checked outside prologue.

In the entirety of Act 1 i havent seen a single Survival/Stealth/Mechanic/Athletics*past prologue* checked in dialog or events, no finding hidden ♥♥♥♥ doesnt count. And it stinks. The game presents itself as hardcore old school RPG which it certainly is if you think ♥♥♥♥ graphics, extremely horrible party AI, massive pathing problems equals old school. The same 'roleplay' problem is felt all over - say i killed Roedric and come back to Calisa's sister she is still panicking oh no we'lll get hanged mode. Maxed out reputation with people in the village, the dialog doesnt change with anyone outside random ♥♥♥♥ villagers say. Really? This is supposed to be a top tier rpg.

I liked how the quests adapted to what you do, like instead of doing the 'make water to brew' you instead murder everyone, that was good and it was a step in the right direction, but it ultimately didnt matter one bit how you went through prologue. The outcome is always the same, same with almost everything you do. They dont change anything on macro level. Say after the other watcher dies there are 3 options to do with his soul, giving roleplay opportunity but they are the same as an outcome... Why even have it then? To show off what it could have been? Dissapointing.

The Stronghold felt exciting, yet it feels so dead and depressing when i show up, the events are not fun, they are terrirble, instead of inviting over opressed peasants to provide them heaven or w/e im visited by some duke who i cant even go have a talk with.  It could have been a great addition, but it feels superficial and obsolete since the moment you get it and all through the game.

You guys talk about creative freedom for the game, yet the achievements are the most uninspired garbage ever. Kill these many or dont kill as many! Finish the game on highest difficulty and prove you are the TRUE TRYHARD or that you can make a fire godlike monk and play fine with it. Whoever was in charge of achievements - let someone else do this, you are ill suited for the task. They feel tackled on, a 'modern burdern' which they had to make for the check mark at the game launch. For someone not constricted by publishers or backers hurrying you up that was really ♥♥♥♥in bad. Dont want people to spoil story for themselves? Make them hidden or whatnot, make them fun!

Technical issues with this game are few...but extremely irritating and game breaking including, removal of passives on doubleclick, having your people stuck somewhere with no option to get them out including: ladders with spaces below them,  treelines post scripted dialog. Game glitching out hard in dialogs if launched for extended period of time...and these are just the ones i saw, i struggle to grasp how many total there are.

Realism: a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ village with about 100-200 people in it sustaining a huge ♥♥♥ castle fit for a king with more guards then villagers. And other incredible ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ like that all over the game.


And thats all just Act 1. Almost a week past the release there is no patch. Obsidian, you can do better then that.

Overall though its still a fantastic game and possible THE RPG of 2015, but it could have been so much more. I give it 8,5/10 Right now and 9.5 when issues are resolved *at least the gameplay wise, i dont expect anyone to figure out a way to fix flawed quest design.

reviewText:
Absolutely fantastic, great writing, great characters, beautiful artwork. Brings me back to days of old, sitting around, carefully crafting my character in Baulders Gate. Taking the introduction in again as if I were back in those days, spending 20 minutes deciding to be a Dwarf, an elf, maybe a Godlike?

This game is fantastic, well worth the price, well deserved. It's easily of Baulders Gate quality and I will be putting MANY more hours into it. With the little time I've put into it so far I've felt genuine sorrow, laughed, and felt that joy in the pit of your stomach when you've found something that REALLY clicks. If you, like me, grew up on BG, Icewind Dale, etc, this is the game for you.

Don't hesitate, just love this carefully crafted gem.

reviewText:
I absolutely love the game. Their system for character creation took me a bit to figure out but now I highly enjoy it as the way it affects the storybook like events and conversations benefits any type of character.

I have 2 cons with the game. The first is the lack of AI on your party members. They will just sit their even when combat starts until given an order and sometimes their orders get lost so they just stand there again. I'm playing on a harder difficulty so I constantly pause to micromanage but for the trash fights it can get a little tedious. The second is the seemingly random voice acting. Sometimes a response will be voice acted but the next in the same conversation wont be and then suddenly the last is. It's a small thing but takes me out of the game a bit when it happens.

Still, great game. Great Lore. Rediculously fun. Highly recommended.

reviewText:
I can't recommend this game enough! If you're a fan of old school, isometric cRPGs, welcome home! Pillars of Eternity is very much like Divinity: Original Sin, except with a more streamlined character creation system and with a more interesting story/setting.

Hands down, this is the best RPG i've played in the past couple of years. If you're into RPGs that are very story-heavy and have detailed fantasy worlds, this is the game for you. If possible, I recommend getting the Royal Edition because the world and its history are so vast that it's nice to be able to read the extra digital books to get a better understanding of the game's world and its cultures. It's not necessary to enjoy the game, but it is very fascinating and helps you get the most out of it.

Easily GOTY, 10/10!

reviewText:
This is an incredibly well written, emotionally engaging, and fun to play computer role playing game. It is arguably a bit short and easy, but that is ultimately preferable to an experience that outstays its welcome.

On its surface, the setting seems like your typical fantasy cliche. However, the more you delve into the lore and each character's backstory, the more you find yourself exploring mature and thought-provoking themes. Do not be fooled by the ogres and elves - there is plenty of creativity here in both the main plot and side-quests. The writing is rich and thick with lore references, but never to the point where the player feels lost or disconnected. On the contrary, the more time I spent reading up on the lore, the more internally consistent everything felt.

But the real attraction to the writing was the characterization - both direct, in the way the characters are described by their authors, and indirect, in the way they act and interact with the world around them.

Through its characters does this world feel real and believable, and it was the intimate detail in which these little pixelated people were described that made me feel immersed in Dyrwood. There is a certain psychological realism - for lack of a better term - that manages to bridge the gap of disbelief between the player and the setting in Pillars of Eternity. It also does not hurt that the voice acting is incredibly convincing, conveying subtle nuances with perfect timing. But more than that, it feels like acting in the true sense of the word; in the sense that is above mere line-delivery. The simple-minded good-hearted warrior with a troubled past manages to consistently sound like a simple-minded good-hearted warrior with a troubled past, while still including variations in mood. The mysterious, powerful villain conveys a permanent sense of calm and authority, and yet he sometimes seems benign, while at other times there is a subtly menacing tone.

The gameplay is essentially a streamlined, modified version of the systems in Baldur's Gate 2. This is by no means a negative, although some purists or old-timers might decry certain features as being too dumbed down or casual. In my opinion, a lot the enjoyment comes from the variety of meaningfully distinct classes and abilities, as well as the freedom to continuously make additions of both player created and canon" characters to the party. Variety and experimentation are key words here. Players are encouraged to have fun mixing and matching different party members and testing different playstyles.

The developers have really paid much attention to detail

reviewText:
As a gamer who thinks Baldur's Gate-games, and in lesser extent the others created with Infinity engine,  are pretty much the best RPG's ever created, I am jubilant they finally got the offspring we have been waiting for.

The fact that it is no longer based on the D&D system was a concern of mine, but the new system works brilliantly. The classes, leveling and talents are solid and fairly easy to understand. Giving up on certain classic D&D rules is a good idea in my opinion. Now you can have your Cleric wield a crossbow, making it a deadly sniper from the back. However, the lack of specialization classes is a flaw IMHO. Also the lack of Party AI (behavior) is a really silly. A lot of micromanagement needed at times.

Graphics are very solid, beautiful, yet paying homage to the original games. 3D characters look very good an blend seamlessly into the background. Sounds are also good and the music made me think of old Baldur's immideately. The game feels sublime and finished, and there seems to be very few bugs to encounter.

However, the story seems a bit vague compared to the original Bioware games and characters lack charisma. They are not as interesting as say Minsc or Edwin, but still are interesting enough to keep you company.

All in all, I am giving this game a strict 8/10.
If the party AI is added I would raise it to 9/10.

There is plenty of content, but I do hope there will be a substantial amount of extra content in DLC-form in the future.

reviewText:
I would like to write a review much earlier, but I thought that it would be better to finish the game first so I can give people who read this a more complete opinion about it. I am a gamer of an older generation and a backer of this game, and I believe that this definitely influences my opinion about this game. Since this game was announced I like the idea of a kickstarter project by one of the best companies in the creation of RPGs . I hate to speak like an older generation, especially in such a thing like games which is mostly destined for young people. but:
Even if I wasn't a great fun of Baldur's Gate, I miss the depth and the beautiful stories of games I was playing ten or twenty years ago. New games have graphics and use technology that we, older gamers couldn't even imagine that it would ever exist. The first game I have ever played was in my uncle's Amstrad and there I could control a hero made of less than ten pixels, let alone the limited number of colours of the computer screen (less than 16 in comparison with thousands today). Today's most games are full of great cutscenes which are technologically laudable. Does this make them better games than the older ones??? If you are a gamer of a younger generation you may be used to high technology graphics, so it may be difficult for you to play an older game. For the same reason you may not like Pillars of Eternity. The graphics are certainly of the last decade and not this one, it looks like a game created in the end of 2000's. Does this mean that the graphics do not lookl good? The answer is no. They try to compensate for not being high-tech bY BEAUTIFUL HAND DRAWN BACKGROUNDS AND BEAUTIFUL ARTWORK. the design may not be that of high technology but it EMPHASISES ON LOOKING BEAUTIFUL AND NOT BEING ONE OF THE MOST RECENT TECHNOLOGY IN GRAPHICS. IT LOOKS GOOD IN THE EYE WHERE A LOT OF HIGH TECHNOLOGY TRIPLE A's FAIL. This is is why I give an 8/10 in GRAPHICS.
Another relevant you would like to consider, and gamers-older and younger-should consider is whether DO CUTSCENES REALLY MATTER? HOW IS A CUTSCENE A PART OF THE ACTUAL GAME? In the older times I was hungry for new, high tech cutscenes too, but after playing Divinity Original Sin last year, I found out that it is now for me LESS IMPORTANT THAN I THOUGHT. RECENT TRIPLE A'S FOCUS IN CUTSCENES TOO MUCH AND THEYMOSTLY NEGLECT  THE QUALITY OF THE STORY!!! THEY TRY TO MAKE GENERIC STORIES SO THEY CAN SELL IT TO EVERYONE AND NOT GOOD ONES. MOST OF THEM HAVE STUPID STORIES COMPARED TO OLD GAMES. in the beggining I thought that the reason I was tired of playing newer games was because I got older, but then there are games like this one that which give me the excitement that older games were giving me. AND A GOOD STORY MATTERS MORE THAN CUTSCENES. PILLARS OF ETERNITY IS A TEXT HEAVY GAME BECAUSE IT IS A REAL RPG, WHERE STORY DEPTH, CONVERSATIONS AND CHOICES MATTER AND CHANGE THE WORLD AND WHAT HAPPENS IN THE QUESTS. OTHERWISE THIS WOULDN'T BE ABLE TO BE ANYTHING MORE THAN FETCH/KILL QUESTS OF RECENT RPGS. YOUNGER GAMERS COULD TRY TO GET USED TO IT. It is not easy in the Beggining but it pays off. As for me I really need to play games with a story and depth like this one. so STORY 10/10

ANOTHER WEAK POINT OF MANY TRIPLE A's IS THE OVERSIMPLIFICATION OF GAMES RULES AND MECHANICS. GAMES WHICH ARE SIMPLER CAN SELL TO A BIGGER MARKET, BUT THEY ARE SOMETIMES INSULTING AND UNCHALLENGING IN COMPARISON TO OLDER GAMES. AN UNCHALLENGING GAME OR A GAME WITH FEW CHOICES IN TACTICS IS MORE LIKE AN INTERACTIVE VIDEO THAN A GAME. PILLARS OF ETERNITY HAS DEEP MECHANICS AND MAKES THE PLAYER TO TRY TO FIND THE MOST SUITABLE TACTICS FOR THE CHARACTERS IN CONTROL. BATTLES CAN BE CHALLENGING IN THE NORMAL MODE EVEN FOR RPG TABLETOPS PLAYERS LIKE ME. I would give it a straight ten if it wasn't for some bugs in the party's AI which make the use of micromanagement inevitable and a bug which I had to tolerate in one of my fighter's abilities(into the fray ability) which made the ability unavailable during the last twenty hours of the game). For this reason. GAME MECHANICS 10/10 BUT GAME'S AI 8/10.
ANOTHER PART OF A GOOD GAME. ESPECIALLY AN RPG IS THE LORE. I THINK THAT THE LORE IS AMAZING. I personally prefer this lore to the lore of FR for example, as I find the lore of FR good for designing any kind of tabletop campaign but a bit too generic. BUT THE REAL PROBLEM IS THAT TRIPLE A's worlds are usually too kitch for my taste. I DON'T BELIEVE THAT QUALITY COMES IN BIG NUMBERS. A DRAGON IS A REVERED THING IN HIGH FANTASY. A THOUSAND DRAGONS IS A RIDICULOUS ONE. I FOUND MYSELF DEEPLY INTERESTED IN THE LORE OF PILLARS OF ETERNITY, BUT THAT IS SUBJECTIVE. SO LORE 10/10.

MUSIC/SOUND/ACTING: A Game which has not perfect graphics can invest a lot in music and sound. THE MUSIC IS GREAT BUT NOT AS GREAT AS IN THE DIVINITY SERIES. THE THEMES ARE WONDERFUL BUT THERE SHOULD BE MORE OF THEM. For this Reason: MUSIC 9/10. The SOUND IS OKAY NOT EXCEPTIONAL 7/10. The budget was limited so NOT ALL OF THE DIALOGUES OF IMPORTANT NPC'S ARE RECORDED. I THINK THAT THIS IS STRAIGHTFORWARD WEIRD!!! MOST OF THE TIMES IT IS NOT A PROBLEM THOUGH AND I WILL BE LENIENT ON THAT BECAUSE OF THE LIMITED BUDGET. THIS WOULD BE UNFAIR FOR THE ACTORS, WHO DID AN AMAZING JOB AND GIVE EXCELLENT PERFORMANCES. For this reason: ACTING:10/10

A 9/10 is a fair score for this game. But in my heart it will always be one of the 10/10 titles. I DON'T SAY THAT THIS GAME IS FOR A EVERYONE. BUT I DON'T CARE. IF YOU ARE BUYING IT YOU SHOULD JUDGE IT ACCORDING TO THE THINGS IT PROMISES TO DELIVER. AND IT DOES DELIVER!!!! HAVE FUN

reviewText:
As someone who grew up playing fallout 1/2 and diablo 1/2 I've been lost for a decade with all the terrible remakes of our old classics or dissapointing sequels (diablo). Path of exile being one of the few good games we've had, but for what PoE added in good game mechanics is lacked effort in character building and story.

Pillar has EVERYTHING, from huge ammounts of effort into each quest, great voice acting that actually adds to the whole experience, i didn't just sit there groaning the voices completely ruined any immersion.  It has a dead cat

A REAL DEAD CAT! which you can have as a pet may i add, killing feral children, stealing a gem then warning the owner his gem is under threat of being stolen, Going to kill a crazy lord then changing your mind and killing the person who sent you... this game is truely open to play HOWEVER you want.

Each class feels unique, combat is fluid and difficult enough to challenge even hardcore rpg veterans.

If  I could sacrifice my first born to get a sequel to  this game, i would go out and fertilize every willing subject.

reviewText:
Playing Pillars is kind of like being in a relationship.
You acknowledge that the other person has his/her flaws, but... you still love them :)

So... yeah, some parts of the game are better than others.
Still, it's rewarding (er, not so much in loot). Whenever combat was a grind, I reminded myself that, thankfully, this is not Icewind Dale and at least there's some plot involved. And a pretty decent one too. The main quest seems a bit cliched at first but... it starts echoing Torment eventually with the questions it raises.

Pillars will charm you if you manage to see past its flaws. Recommended :)

reviewText:
Pillars of Eternity is utterly fantastic.

By far it is one of the best games of the last few years; not only have we been without a good old rpg of this sort, the classic style of Pillars of Eternity is absolutely compelling and enthralling.

The soundtrack of this game is terrific, its mellow tones charming and enchanting; while its combat music intense and exciting.

I am overjoyed to see a game made in the old style of role play, full of absolutely delicious nostalgia to those who have experienced such classics as Icewind Dale or Baldur's Gate.

A truly fantastic experience, worth every penny.

reviewText:
I actually Kick started this back when it was first announced and I do not regret doing so. If you are familiar with Baldur's Gate 2 and enjoyed it then you will love this game. It feels very familiar and yet brings a lot of new things to the table along with improvements. Even if you are not familiar with Baldur's Gate 2 you will still enjoy this game.

The combat is almost exactly the same as Baldur's gate, it's an Action RPG where you can pause mid combat (similar to the modern Bioware games such as Mass Effect etc.). It is very challenging and it actually forces you to think which weapon type and which spells to use on each different enemy.

Another great thing about this game is that it really is open, in the sense that there are multiple ways of completing a mission. As an example there is a certain area that you need to enter but it has been sealed off and it guarded by 2 guards. You can either:
1. Kill them and enter anyway
2. Bribe them and enter
3. Go to their boss and gain his favour to allow you entrance
There might be more ways that I haven't come across, but that's just one example.

Not to mention this game has mods on steam workshop. Since it is a recent release, it won't have as many mods at the moment, but give it a bit of time and look at the mods coming in.

I personally love the endurance mechanism during combat that replaces your health so that when you endurance drops to 0" you are unconcious but once the combat is over you are back up again
date: but with some sort of injury the second time your health drops below "0" you will die however unless you rest. Unlike BG2 you can't just rest as many times as you like
recommended:
you need to have camping equipment and you can only carry a maximum of 5 at any one point.

Though it's not all great. Some people have been complaining about the speed it takes to load a game once you are quite far in to the game. Personally I don't have a problem with it as back in the day the load times generally were really slow anyway.

The other problem is that I feel that there is just too much talking about things that I feel are not really that important to me. I mean sure lore is important
hoursPlayed: but too much of reading will bore the game
voteText: especially when it is not directed to me.\n\nMy personal issue with the story is there are moments when you can actually choose an option about your past of why you did something or who someone is exactly. (i.e. relative
helpfulPercent: partner friends etc.) And I feel like that freedom shouldn't be given because the story then feels fabricated rather than customised to you. So overall the story can use some improvement
votesHelpful: but that still doesn't mean that the story is bad. It can definitely use some more voiced over lines though
votesTotal: compared to modern games this one is lacking in that area. Though again if you compare it to BG2
votesFunny: PoE feels like it has more voiced over lines despite being a smaller game.\n\nOverall I would give it a 8/10. I would have given it more had it not been for the amount of unnecassary lore that was forced fed."

reviewText:
Warning: might contain spoilers.

There are countless people telling you how this game is great and close to flawless so i wont be focusing on that. Ill tell you what is wrong with the game.

Roleplay options, - the core stats are a joke. Intelligence recommended for a barbarian, Might not recommended for monk, intelligence on wizard is only good for debuffing and 'dialog'. There are no special changes while having stat a minimum - 3 int talking like normal, 3 dex having no problems swinging 2 swords etc. The system is extremely flawed and its a huge letdown when you make some conceptual hero, take appropriate skills and then they are almost never checked outside prologue.

In the entirety of Act 1 i havent seen a single Survival/Stealth/Mechanic/Athletics*past prologue* checked in dialog or events, no finding hidden ♥♥♥♥ doesnt count. And it stinks. The game presents itself as hardcore old school RPG which it certainly is if you think ♥♥♥♥ graphics, extremely horrible party AI, massive pathing problems equals old school. The same 'roleplay' problem is felt all over - say i killed Roedric and come back to Calisa's sister she is still panicking oh no we'lll get hanged mode. Maxed out reputation with people in the village, the dialog doesnt change with anyone outside random ♥♥♥♥ villagers say. Really? This is supposed to be a top tier rpg.

I liked how the quests adapted to what you do, like instead of doing the 'make water to brew' you instead murder everyone, that was good and it was a step in the right direction, but it ultimately didnt matter one bit how you went through prologue. The outcome is always the same, same with almost everything you do. They dont change anything on macro level. Say after the other watcher dies there are 3 options to do with his soul, giving roleplay opportunity but they are the same as an outcome... Why even have it then? To show off what it could have been? Dissapointing.

The Stronghold felt exciting, yet it feels so dead and depressing when i show up, the events are not fun, they are terrirble, instead of inviting over opressed peasants to provide them heaven or w/e im visited by some duke who i cant even go have a talk with.  It could have been a great addition, but it feels superficial and obsolete since the moment you get it and all through the game.

You guys talk about creative freedom for the game, yet the achievements are the most uninspired garbage ever. Kill these many or dont kill as many! Finish the game on highest difficulty and prove you are the TRUE TRYHARD or that you can make a fire godlike monk and play fine with it. Whoever was in charge of achievements - let someone else do this, you are ill suited for the task. They feel tackled on, a 'modern burdern' which they had to make for the check mark at the game launch. For someone not constricted by publishers or backers hurrying you up that was really ♥♥♥♥in bad. Dont want people to spoil story for themselves? Make them hidden or whatnot, make them fun!

Technical issues with this game are few...but extremely irritating and game breaking including, removal of passives on doubleclick, having your people stuck somewhere with no option to get them out including: ladders with spaces below them,  treelines post scripted dialog. Game glitching out hard in dialogs if launched for extended period of time...and these are just the ones i saw, i struggle to grasp how many total there are.

Realism: a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ village with about 100-200 people in it sustaining a huge ♥♥♥ castle fit for a king with more guards then villagers. And other incredible ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ like that all over the game.


And thats all just Act 1. Almost a week past the release there is no patch. Obsidian, you can do better then that.

Overall though its still a fantastic game and possible THE RPG of 2015, but it could have been so much more. I give it 8,5/10 Right now and 9.5 when issues are resolved *at least the gameplay wise, i dont expect anyone to figure out a way to fix flawed quest design.

reviewText:
As a gamer who thinks Baldur's Gate-games, and in lesser extent the others created with Infinity engine,  are pretty much the best RPG's ever created, I am jubilant they finally got the offspring we have been waiting for.

The fact that it is no longer based on the D&D system was a concern of mine, but the new system works brilliantly. The classes, leveling and talents are solid and fairly easy to understand. Giving up on certain classic D&D rules is a good idea in my opinion. Now you can have your Cleric wield a crossbow, making it a deadly sniper from the back. However, the lack of specialization classes is a flaw IMHO. Also the lack of Party AI (behavior) is a really silly. A lot of micromanagement needed at times.

Graphics are very solid, beautiful, yet paying homage to the original games. 3D characters look very good an blend seamlessly into the background. Sounds are also good and the music made me think of old Baldur's immideately. The game feels sublime and finished, and there seems to be very few bugs to encounter.

However, the story seems a bit vague compared to the original Bioware games and characters lack charisma. They are not as interesting as say Minsc or Edwin, but still are interesting enough to keep you company.

All in all, I am giving this game a strict 8/10.
If the party AI is added I would raise it to 9/10.

There is plenty of content, but I do hope there will be a substantial amount of extra content in DLC-form in the future.

reviewText:
50 hours into this game feels like the right time to start a review. The fact that I'm 50 hours in and yet have barely scratched the surface of this excellent game, should tell you something about the size and density of this nostalgic throw back to the Infinity games of yore.
The first thing likely to strike you will take place in the character generation screens. It's easy to get so involved in this process that an hour will easily flick by. I can think of few games since the Baldurs Gates series or Icewind Dales that have had that effect, perhaps Skrim or Morrowind, but again this just proves the richness of the characters and backgrounds on offer here.
Once into the game proper I felt instantly transported to the Baldurs Gate and Torment era. A little further scratching showed that whle POE has stayed true to those great games it does not feel like a game of that generation. Indeed Obsidian have managed to create a modern and innovative RPG that feels just as right in 2015 as would have in 2000 at the height if the Infiity engine age.
To name just a few of the things on offer here, player choice, great NPC interaction, a rich and diverse world and an even richer and diverse story.
So far I can't find a lot to fault. If I had to come up with one negative it could be that I will struggle to go back and play the likes of Baldur's Gate and Icewind Dale again, as finally they will feel aged and matched, if not bettered, by a modern RPG.

reviewText:
I absolutely love the game. Their system for character creation took me a bit to figure out but now I highly enjoy it as the way it affects the storybook like events and conversations benefits any type of character.

I have 2 cons with the game. The first is the lack of AI on your party members. They will just sit their even when combat starts until given an order and sometimes their orders get lost so they just stand there again. I'm playing on a harder difficulty so I constantly pause to micromanage but for the trash fights it can get a little tedious. The second is the seemingly random voice acting. Sometimes a response will be voice acted but the next in the same conversation wont be and then suddenly the last is. It's a small thing but takes me out of the game a bit when it happens.

Still, great game. Great Lore. Rediculously fun. Highly recommended.

reviewText:
I can't recommend this game enough! If you're a fan of old school, isometric cRPGs, welcome home! Pillars of Eternity is very much like Divinity: Original Sin, except with a more streamlined character creation system and with a more interesting story/setting.

Hands down, this is the best RPG i've played in the past couple of years. If you're into RPGs that are very story-heavy and have detailed fantasy worlds, this is the game for you. If possible, I recommend getting the Royal Edition because the world and its history are so vast that it's nice to be able to read the extra digital books to get a better understanding of the game's world and its cultures. It's not necessary to enjoy the game, but it is very fascinating and helps you get the most out of it.

Easily GOTY, 10/10!

reviewText:
Pillars of Eternity, what can I even say that has not been said about this masterwork.  Being a fan of Infinity engine games of old, ie Baldurs gate 1 & 2, Planescape Torment, Arcanum.  Among other non infinity games such as Neverwinter knights, Dungeon Siege ect.  This game is the glorious return of the infinity style isometric rpgs.

True Strategic Combat,  every engagement in this game is dangerous, you can easily wipe your party against even the simplest of enemies, especially on Path of the Damned difficulty.  This game nails the pausable real time combat system from the days of old in a way Dragon Age Origins only dreamed it could.  This is the true sequel that the infinity engine games deserved back then when Bioware decided to go for the more casual approach.

A deep compelling story and companions.  Hundreds of pages worth of dialogue (some is even voiced)  deep conversation trees, meaningful responses, so far beyond a simple good and evil system a la Mass Effect or dragon age.  Each companion has real in game world beliefs, aspirations, interests ect.  I find myself dripping at the mouth for more, where in some other games I've found myself wanting to skip dialogue.  The world building is astounding and it sucks you in almost instantly.  Mature dark fantasy at its very best.  No shoe horned in sex scenes or cheesy lines can be found here.  The world is so well developed and so believable that I just cant pull myself away.

I can't say enough good about this game really.  It is the true Baldurs Gate 3 that everyone has wanted for years, all shiny with a coat of new paint and modern game play improvements without leaching out the life that makes these games so loved.  When I compare this to an attempt like Dragon Age it's almost laughable.  Dragon age is the definition of streamlining, casualization and consolitus,  and even though Origins was a good game it really did destroy the line of games and turned them into something more accessible.  Pillar's does this in the right way instead.  It makes the game more accessible but not at the expense of difficulty or charm.

It's sure to spawn a fantastic new series, and will spearhead the renaissance of CRPGs.  Obsidian, along with other companies like Larian, with their fantastic Divinity Original Sin, and inXile with their Wasteland 2 and upcoming Torment: Tides of Numeria are proving that a game doesn’t have to be all about multiplayer and graphics, and that not every gamer wants their games easier with every new iteration.

I played Dragon Age Inquisition,  the tactical camera made me want to vomit, its completely unusable, and the game has essentially devolved into a strategy-less third person hack n slash game.  Bioware, oh why have you fallen so far, Just take a few pointers from Obsidian here, they made the game you have been incapable of making for the last 20 years, and they did it right the first time.

If you are in any way a fan of RPGs or Strategy games, you woudl be doing yourself a huge favour by pickign thsi game up.  It's net even the price of a full game, and it has more content and depth than most 70 dollar games even dream of having.

If you are a fan of Dragon Age or Mass Effect, I strongly urge you to pick this game up, and see how much deeper an RPG can be when the chains of mass market and console release are removed.  I guarentee you will not be dissapointed.

It would be foolish to overlook Pillars of Eternity.

reviewText:
Pillars Of Eternity is a glorious also-ran. It is a flawed but ultimately worthy imitator of the great Baldur's Gate series, and a promising sign of things to come.
If you are the kind of person who has purchased any of the recent Black Isle remasters from Beamdog, then let me tell you in no uncertain terms that you should go buy PIllars of Eternity right now. It is the nearest thing to Baldur's Gate II since Baldur's Gate II, and if that doesn't already make you champ at the bit, then let me tell you that its a darn good facsimile.

If you aren't the kind of person who has done something like that, then the first thing you'll want to know is that Pillars of Eternity is an isometric party management RPG in the style of the old nineties and noughties games, complete with their beautiful writing, massive single player adventure, and difficulty. While you start off going through the familiar motions of building a character, Pillars of Eternity introduces a few new wrinkles that make it interesting. For starters, while all the familiar archetypes are represented, some truly weird and original character classes exist here, including the chanter who sings harmful and helpful chants, and the cipher, who wields eldritch power to corrupt and destroy the souls of your foes. All the classes feel suitably different, and at time of writing the balance seems to be fairly good across the board. Another thing that Pillars of Eternity does that will probably surprise newcomers to the genre is that every single stat has a direct and significant combat impact. There are no dump stats here and while this means min-maxers will probably be arguing amongst each other for months to come, it is now pretty tricky to gimp your character.

You can also supplement your party of six adventurers by hiring characters you create from scratch at any inn. But this would be a mistake. The game includes 8 NPC companions, and you should do everything in your power to have all of them in your party at some point in the game as their writing and acting is so well done you would be robbing yourself of the experience by building a custom party of adventurers. This quality of writing extends to virtually everything else you'll encounter during the course of the game to boot, and it is consistently excellent from start to finish (with two minor and largely irrelevant exceptions which I mention below). Without spoiling anything, the world of Eora will seem immediately familiar to anyone who has spent any time travelling around Faerun in the Forgotten Realms, but it doesn't just feel different enough to be fresh - it's positively revelatory.

Oh, and did I mention its gorgeous? The area maps are eye poppingly beautiful, and the characters actually animate splendidly, plus there are loads of cool spell and ability effects. In fact, sometimes they can even be a bit overwhelming. There were moments, especially early on when I was finding my bearings, where I couldn't tell what was going on in fights.

The game also features a brand new, proprietary combat system that you'll need to spend a little time getting your head around. And I really do mean that, because this game is hard. Even on Easy or Normal difficulty (which you should probably stick to if you're the kind of person who only plays games once) you will sometimes find yourself badly overwhelmed at strange points as though the game was poorly paced. The learning curve is hardly gentle either, and even if you know your way around this sort of game, there are variations both intentional and unintentional that you wont anticipate in your first few hours with the game. It's a recipe for frustration, and while genre veterans are likely familiar with that feeling, if you're not used to that kind of abuse, expect Pillars of Eternity to test your patience from time to time. Still, the challenge rarely feels unfair (though make no mistake - there are some moments where it feels EXTREMELY unfair in some of the optional endgame content), and it is immensely satisfying to finally triumph over a difficult encounter.

Partly this is because a job well done is its own reward, but partly this is because of the loot! And Pillars Eternity has a heck of a lot of it, and it comes in a pretty smooth progression that reminds me of the best moments of Baldur's Gate II, when you were excited to pick up the burning sword that the most recent boss left behind when he finally keeled over. And best of all, the game smartly does away with the old dumb system of playing inventory tetris, Pillars of Eternity allows you to have an unlimited number of items in your inventory in the form of a stash chest that is accessible at any time with a single mouse click whenever you bring up your inventory screen. For anyone who is used to juggling arrows and quest items, it feels downright civilized.

The game is not perfect, however. Even after a patch designed to address it, the game features a strangely low level cap that you will absolutely hit. But wait

reviewText: It took nearly 15 years to finally get a proper follow-up to Baldur's Gate 2, but here it is.\n\nHaving said that, times have-a-changed since the glory days of the infinity engine. While there are a number of quality of life changes in the game system, it still has one foot planted firmly in the past. This will probably rub some people the wrong way, (Vancian spell casting seems to invite a lot of ire for example) but POE's reverence for all things old will delight just as many people.

reviewText: ★ ★ ★ ★ ★  - I give this game 5/5. Why? I grew up playing Baldur's Gate. I used to spend hours alone in my parent's basement in the dark travelling around with Minsc and Boo, shattering sh*t and kicking kobolds a*ses in. This game is that. Amazing story and universe creation. I was able to fall right into it. But this takes it further, using D&D strategies not often used with games. Need to climb that wall? Get a grappling hook and oops it is one time use. Don't have a rogue? Break that check open with a pry bar. The NPC's are great also. And is all that enough? Your world is accompanied by beautiful and epic music that inspires every adventure.\n\nIf you want a game where you can create a character (and companions) set about the world with some real quests and either steal and pillage your way or bring the ultimate boot of justice down on evil all while listening to great music with an amazing atmosphere...look no further.

reviewText:
As I used to play a lot of Baldurs Gates and Icewind Dale 'back in the days' I can't help but compare this game to them. They feel the same, they look the same and sound the same.
Pillars of Eternity looks a bit nicer but nothing spectacular in the graphical front. The areas look nice and animations are smooth.

Story driven and there is a lot of reading to do if you want to keep up with it all along with the side quests and tasks you are given.
Combat system is as close to D&D without actually being D&D. Some of the spell names give me a sensible chuckle especially seeing all those familiar effects from BG and such.
Spell system is a bit different from what you're used to if you know how it used to work and there are few 'new' classes compared to the old D&D games along with few stats and attributes that work differently.

Runs smoothl, load times are decent and I haven't encountered any bugs yet besides the characters occasionally stopping from attacking when enemies do certain things like teleport. Minor annoyance.

Some things are slightly dumbed down if you're an old BG player. Or made more convenient, depends on how you look at it. Sneaking around automatically detects for traps too and you don't have to detect from them separately for example.

The game can and will still instakill you like it's predecessors if you're not careful. And it's a good thing innit.

reviewText:
Bought it the day it was released, and I never looked back. I wasn't a fan of Baldur Gate back in the day because I had no idea how it worked, but Pillars worked that out for me, and introduced the whole Infinity Engine (Is that what it's called) to me.

Seriously. Buy it. You will never regret.

reviewText:
As a HUGE fan of the early Infinity Engine games I was seriously looking forward to Pillars of Eternity. An old school isometric cRPG? Heck yes I'm in!  Evern if it's a fraction as good as Baldur's Gate or Shadows of Amn it will still be amazing. Like Icewind Dale back in the day.

I was a bit worried that Obsidian (formerly Black Isle) would botch this like so many other games in their back catalogue but after about 20-something hours it seems my fears were unfounded.

The writing is pretty good and at times really hit home with the imagery they presented in text. The background lore is fairly interesting and the writes did a good job of creating a world with a rich past and interesting conflicts and inhabitants. My only real qualm with the dialogue, writing, and conversations was the voice acting. Sure, hearing recognizable voices was fun but the talking ruins it for me. I want to read not listen. I can read faster than you can talk and give you accents of my own imagining! Gah!

The combat is very similar to Infinity games, closer to Icewind Dale II than Baldur's Gate though. Per encounter / Per rest abilities spice things up while you're playing a figher, ranger, or barbarian compaired to BG. The caster classes and spells are all interesting and visually pleasing. I found the difficulty level fairly tame, even on Hard and Path of the Damned (Pillars hardest), but that comes with many years of playing tactical RPG's I think. If you're new to this type of genre you might want to steer clear of anything above Normal.

Graphiclly it looks much like other Unity Engine games. Shadowrun Returns, Divinity:OS, and Wasteland 2 all share the engine with Pillars and it's easy on the eyes and I believe Pillars did a better job on scenery than the others. The towns, cities, and wilderness areas are all beautiful.

This is a great game for any cRPG / Infinity Engine enthusiests and highly reccomended. If you enjoy a good RPG in general you might want to check this one out.
voteText: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
If you are a fan of CRPG's from the 90s into early 00's, then you will likely enjoy this game.  I have not had this much fun playing a CRPG since Planescape: Torment.

The game feels like a classic Infinity Engine game (Baldurs Gate, Planescape Torment, Icewind Dale), but revised with modern graphic capabilities.   Some of the best gameplay improvements are:

* Half Speed Movement
* Double Speed Movement
* Inventory Stash to remove inventory management mini-game (easy access can be disabled for the truely hardcore)
* Removal of need to monster grind for levels by eliminating XP from monsters after a certain amount of kills of that monster type.  The XP focus is now on initial kills of a monster type and Quest experience.

Here are some other gameplay change that you may or may not like. I find that they streamline the game over D&D type rulesets:

* Trap Detection / Trap disarmement / Picklocking all covered by same skill: mechanics
* Mechanics is a skill that any class can learn, so it is no longer mandatory to have a rogue in order to cover the above thief like actions.
* Some spells/skills can be used a certain number of times per combat
* mage/priests can cast a certain number of spells of each level per 'rest'; mages can only select 4 spells per level
* AoE spells have 2 ranges, an inner range that can target both friend and foe, and an outer range that only can target foes.  In addition some AoE spells are listed as foe-only and can not harm friendly characters.  Stats can increase the radius of an AoE spell.

I highly recommend this game for anyone who was a fan of the RPG classics from the 90s and early 00's.
